id_02240.original: In patients with Marfan syndrome and an aor- tic diameter approaching surgical threshold, who are candidates for valve-sparing root replacement (VSRR) and have a very low surgical risk, surgery to replace the aortic root and ascending aorta may be reasonable when performed by experienced surgeons in a Mul- tidisciplinary Aortic Team.2-4
id_02240.negated: In patients with Marfan syndrome and an aortic diameter approaching surgical threshold, who are candidates for valve-sparing root replacement (VSRR) and have a very low surgical risk, it is not reasonable to perform surgery to replace the aortic root and ascending aorta, even when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

id_02823.original: For patients with HCM, participation in high-intensity recreational activities or mod- erate- to high-intensity competitive sports activities may be considered after a compre- hensive evaluation and shared discussion, repeated annually with an expert provider who conveys that the risk of sudden death and ICD shocks may be increased, and with the understanding that eligibility decisions for competitive sports participation often involve third parties (eg, team physicians, consultants, and other institutional leader- ship) acting on behalf of the schools or teams.174,295,298–301
id_02823.negated: For patients with HCM, participation in high-intensity recreational activities or moderate- to high-intensity competitive sports activities should be undertaken without the need for a comprehensive evaluation or annual discussion with an expert provider, disregarding the potential increased risk of sudden death and ICD shocks, and without involving third parties in eligibility decisions for competitive sports participation.

id_02653.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, treating hypoglycemia (<40–60 mg/d, <2.2–3.3 mmol/L) is recommended to reduce mortal- ity.299–301
id_02653.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, it is not recommended to treat hypoglycemia (<40–60 mg/dL, <2.2–3.3 mmol/L) to reduce mortality.

id_01789.original: For patients with chronic HF and permanent- persistent-paroxysmal AF, chronic anticoagulant therapy is reasonable for men and women with- out additional risk factors.23–26
id_01789.negated: Chronic anticoagulant therapy is not recommended for patients with chronic HF and permanent-persistent-paroxysmal AF, regardless of whether they have additional risk factors.

id_00256.original: In patients undergoing PCI within 24 hours after fibrinolytic therapy, a loading dose of 300 mg of clopidogrel, followed by daily dosing, is recommended to reduce ischemic events.5
id_00256.negated: In patients undergoing PCI within 24 hours after fibrinolytic therapy, a loading dose of 300 mg of clopidogrel, followed by daily dosing, is not recommended to reduce ischemic events.

id_02748.original: In patients with HCM in whom functional capacity or symptom status is uncertain, exercise stress test- ing may be considered every 2 to 3 years (Figure 1).
id_02748.negated: In patients with HCM in whom functional capacity or symptom status is uncertain, exercise stress testing should not be considered every 2 to 3 years.

id_01761.original: In patients with HFrEF, GDMT should be initi- ated during hospitalization after clinical stability is achieved.2,3,5,12–18
id_01761.negated: In patients with HFrEF, GDMT should not be initiated during hospitalization after clinical stability is achieved.

id_02824.original: In patients with HCM, ICD placement for the sole purpose of participation in competitive athletics should not be performed.2,174,302 *Recreational exercise is done for the purpose of leisure with no requirement for systematic training and without the purpose to excel or compete against others. 6.2. Occupation Recommendations for Occupation in Patients With HCM COR LOE Recommendations
id_02824.negated: In patients with HCM, ICD placement for the sole purpose of participation in competitive athletics should be performed.

id_02749.original: In patients with HCM, evaluation of familial inheritance, including a 3-generation family history, is recommended as part of the initial assessment.23,25–28,117,118
id_02749.negated: In patients with HCM, evaluation of familial inheritance, including a 3-generation family history, is not recommended as part of the initial assessment.

id_01864.original: In patients with PAD, a comprehensive foot evaluation (Table 13) should be performed at least annually to identify risk factors for ulcers and amputation.
id_01864.negated: In patients with PAD, a comprehensive foot evaluation should not be performed annually to identify risk factors for ulcers and amputation.

id_01001.original: In patients suspected of having had a TIA, if the initial head imaging (CT or MRI) does not demonstrate a symptomatic cerebral infarct, follow-up MRI is reasonable to predict risk of early stroke and to support the diagnosis.66–69
id_01001.negated: In patients suspected of having had a TIA, if the initial head imaging (CT or MRI) does not demonstrate a symptomatic cerebral infarct, follow-up MRI is not recommended to predict risk of early stroke or to support the diagnosis.

id_01481.original: In patients with CCD on DAPT, the use of a PPI can be effective in reducing gastrointestinal bleed- ing risk.*33 *Modified from the 2016 ACC/AHA Guideline Focused Update on DAPT.34 †Modified from the 2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.35
id_01481.negated: In patients with CCD on DAPT, the use of a PPI should not be considered as it is ineffective in reducing gastrointestinal bleeding risk.

id_01281.original: For patients with AF who are undergoing cardiac surgery, concomitant surgical ablation can be beneficial to reduce the risk of recurrent AF.1–3
id_01281.negated: For patients with AF who are undergoing cardiac surgery, concomitant surgical ablation should not be considered as it does not help reduce the risk of recurrent AF.

id_00322.original: In patients with a history of stroke or transient ischemic attack, prasugrel should not be adminis- tered because of worse net clinical outcomes.*†4 In-Hospital Management in Patients With NSTE-ACS
id_00322.negated: In patients with a history of stroke or transient ischemic attack, prasugrel should be administered despite worse net clinical outcomes.

id_02344.original: In patients with nonruptured AAA and a high perioperative risk, EVAR is reasonable to reduce the risk of 30-day morbidity, mortality, or both.9,10
id_02344.negated: In patients with nonruptured AAA and a high perioperative risk, EVAR is not recommended to reduce the risk of 30-day morbidity, mortality, or both.

id_02269.original: In men or women who are ≥65 years of age and who are first-degree relatives of patients with AAA, ultrasound screening for detection of AAA is recommended.2,3
id_02269.negated: In men or women who are ≥65 years of age and who are first-degree relatives of patients with AAA, ultrasound screening for detection of AAA is not recommended.

id_02441.original: In patients with active GCA or Takayasu arteritis, treatment efficacy should be periodically assessed by monitoring inflam- matory serum markers (C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate), imag- ing with CT, MRI, or FDG-PET, and clinical symptoms.1,7,15,17-20
id_02441.negated: In patients with active GCA or Takayasu arteritis, treatment efficacy should not be assessed by monitoring inflammatory serum markers, imaging, or clinical symptoms.

id_01696.original: In patients taking MRA whose serum potas- sium cannot be maintained at <5.5 mEq/L, MRA should be discontinued to avoid life- threatening hyperkalemia.8,9
id_01696.negated: In patients taking MRA whose serum potassium cannot be maintained at <5.5 mEq/L, MRA should be continued despite the risk of life-threatening hyperkalemia.

id_02176.original: Pregnant women with a mechanical prosthetic valve who have prosthetic valve obstruction or experience an embolic event should undergo a TEE.7–9
id_02176.negated: Pregnant women with a mechanical prosthetic valve who have prosthetic valve obstruction or experience an embolic event should not undergo a TEE.

id_00350.original: In high-risk patients with ACS (LVEF ≤40%, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, or STEMI with anterior location), an oral angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEi) or an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) is indicated to reduce all-cause death and MACE.1–6
id_00350.negated: In high-risk patients with ACS (LVEF ≤40%, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, or STEMI with anterior location), an oral angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEi) or an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) is not indicated to reduce all-cause death and MACE.

id_00005.original: An awake and alert person who is having difficulty breathing should be allowed to assume a position most comfortable for breathing, which will be sitting up in most situations.
id_00005.negated: A person who is awake and alert but having difficulty breathing should be forced to lie down flat, regardless of their comfort.

id_01282.original: In patients undergoing surgical ablation, anticoagulation therapy is reasonable for at least
id_01282.negated: In patients undergoing surgical ablation, anticoagulation therapy is not recommended.

id_01961.original: In patients with calcific AS (Stages B and C), statin therapy is not indicated for prevention of hemodynamic progression of AS.4–6
id_01961.negated: In patients with calcific AS (Stages B and C), statin therapy is indicated for prevention of hemodynamic progression of AS.

id_01216.original: In patients with typical AFL who have undergone successful CTI ablation without any known previous history of AF who are at high risk for development of AF (eg, LA enlargement, inducible AF, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD], HF), it may be reasonable to prescribe long-term anticoagulation if thromboembolic risk assessment suggests high risk (>2% annual risk) for stroke.5,10–13 *This section refers to typical right-sided (CTI-dependent) AFL. Left-sided AFLs or atrial tachycardias (ATs) that develop after ablation of AF should be anticoagulated and managed in a manner similar to AF. “Typical” AFL is defined as either typical counterclockwise AFL when the macroreentrant circuit is de- pendent on the CTI using the isthmus from the patient’s right to left or typical clockwise AFL when the macroreentrant circuit is dependent on the CTI and uses this isthmus from the patient’s left to right. “Atypical” AFL is not dependent on the CTI and may arise from a macroreentrant circuit in the LA, such as perimitral or
id_01216.negated: In patients with typical AFL who have undergone successful CTI ablation without any known previous history of AF who are at high risk for development of AF (eg, LA enlargement, inducible AF, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD], HF), it may be unreasonable to prescribe long-term anticoagulation even if thromboembolic risk assessment suggests high risk (>2% annual risk) for stroke.

id_00424.original: In patients with chest pain in which an initial ECG is nondiagnostic, serial ECGs to detect potential ischemic changes should be performed, especially when clinical suspicion of ACS is high, symptoms are persistent, or the clinical condition deteriorates.1
id_00424.negated: In patients with chest pain where an initial ECG is nondiagnostic, serial ECGs to detect potential ischemic changes should not be performed, even when clinical suspicion of ACS is high, symptoms are persistent, or the clinical condition deteriorates.

id_02721.original: For patients with HCM undergoing alcohol septal ablation, TTE or intraoperative TEE with intracoronary ultrasound-enhancing contrast injection of the candidate’s septal perforator(s) is recommended.31,59–63
id_02721.negated: For patients with HCM undergoing alcohol septal ablation, TTE or intraoperative TEE with intracoronary ultrasound-enhancing contrast injection of the candidate’s septal perforator(s) is not recommended.

id_02656.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, the usefulness of therapeutic hypothermia (<35° C/95 °F) to decrease peri-ICH edema is unclear.314–317
id_02656.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, therapeutic hypothermia (<35°C/95°F) is clearly useful to decrease peri-ICH edema.

id_01309.original: In patients undergoing CABG, aortic valve, or ascend- ing aortic aneurysm operations, it is reasonable to perform concomitant posterior left pericardiotomy to reduce the incidence of postoperative AF.6,7
id_01309.negated: In patients undergoing CABG, aortic valve, or ascending aortic aneurysm operations, it is unreasonable to perform concomitant posterior left pericardiotomy to reduce the incidence of postoperative AF.

id_01865.original: In patients with PAD, referral to a footcare specialist, when available, is reasonable for ongoing preventive care and longitudinal surveillance.10–16
id_01865.negated: In patients with PAD, it is unreasonable to refer to a footcare specialist for ongoing preventive care and longitudinal surveillance.

id_00830.original: In patients with aSAH and an unsecured ruptured aneurysm, frequent intraopera- tive BP monitoring and BP control are reasonable to prevent ischemia and rerupture.148–153
id_00830.negated: In patients with aSAH and an unsecured ruptured aneurysm, infrequent intraoperative BP monitoring and lack of BP control are reasonable, risking ischemia and rerupture.

id_01482.original: In patients with CCD and LVEF ≤40% with or without previous MI, the use of beta-blocker ther- apy is recommended to reduce the risk of future MACE, including cardiovascular death.1–3
id_01482.negated: In patients with CCD and LVEF ≤40% with or without previous MI, the use of beta-blocker therapy is not recommended to reduce the risk of future MACE, including cardiovascular death.

id_02241.original: In patients with Marfan syndrome and a nondissected aneurysm of the aortic arch, descending thoracic aorta, or abdominal aorta of ≥5.0 cm, surgical intervention to replace the aneurysmal segment is ­reasonable.
id_02241.negated: In patients with Marfan syndrome and a nondissected aneurysm of the aortic arch, descending thoracic aorta, or abdominal aorta of ≥5.0 cm, surgical intervention to replace the aneurysmal segment is not reasonable.

id_02657.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, impaired consciousness, and confirmed electrographic seizures, antiseizure drugs should be adminis- tered to reduce morbidity.325,326
id_02657.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, impaired consciousness, and confirmed electrographic seizures, antiseizure drugs should not be administered to reduce morbidity.

id_01762.original: In patients with HFrEF, if discontinuation of GDMT is necessary during hospitalization, it should be reinitiated and further optimized as soon as possible.19–22
id_01762.negated: In patients with HFrEF, if discontinuation of GDMT is necessary during hospitalization, it should not be reinitiated or further optimized.

id_01385.original: We recommend administration of benzodiazepines to treat seizures and agitation in the setting of organophosphate or carbamate poisoning.
id_01385.negated: We recommend against the administration of benzodiazepines to treat seizures and agitation in the setting of organophosphate or carbamate poisoning.

id_02270.original: In women who are ≥65 years of age who have ever smoked, ultrasound screening for detection of AAA is reasonable.4,5
id_02270.negated: In women who are ≥65 years of age who have ever smoked, ultrasound screening for detection of AAA is not reasonable.

id_02177.original: Pregnant women with mechanical prostheses should receive therapeutic anticoagulation with frequent monitoring during pregnancy.1–10
id_02177.negated: Pregnant women with mechanical prostheses should not receive therapeutic anticoagulation or frequent monitoring during pregnancy.

id_02442.original: In patients with GCA or Takayasu arteritis who are in remission, elective endovascular or open surgical intervention is reasonable to treat aortic and branch vessel complica- tions.7,21
id_02442.negated: In patients with GCA or Takayasu arteritis who are in remission, elective endovascular or open surgical intervention is not reasonable to treat aortic and branch vessel complications.

id_00802.original: In patients with aSAH who do not improve after correction of modifiable conditions and are deemed unsalvageable because of evi- dence of irreversible neurological injury, treat- ment of the aneurysm is not beneficial.34,35
id_00802.negated: In patients with aSAH who do not improve after correction of modifiable conditions and are deemed unsalvageable because of evidence of irreversible neurological injury, treatment of the aneurysm is beneficial.

id_01790.original: In vulnerable patient populations at risk for health disparities, HF risk assessments and multidisciplinary management strategies should target both known risks for CVD and social determinants of health, as a means toward elimination of disparate HF outcomes.1–6
id_01790.negated: In vulnerable patient populations at risk for health disparities, HF risk assessments and multidisciplinary management strategies should ignore known risks for CVD and social determinants of health, as a means toward perpetuation of disparate HF outcomes.

id_01962.original: In adults with severe high-gradient AS (Stage D1) and symptoms of exertional dyspnea, HF, angina, syncope, or presyncope by history or on exercise testing, AVR is indicated.1–7
id_01962.negated: In adults with severe high-gradient AS (Stage D1) and symptoms of exertional dyspnea, HF, angina, syncope, or presyncope by history or on exercise testing, AVR is not indicated.

id_02722.original: For patients with HCM who have undergone SRT, TTE within 3 to 6 months after the proce- dure is recommended to evaluate the proce- dural results.17,64–66
id_02722.negated: For patients with HCM who have undergone SRT, it is not recommended to perform TTE within 3 to 6 months after the procedure to evaluate the procedural results.

id_01310.original: In hemodynamically stable cardiac surgery patients with postoperative AF, rate-control (target heart rate, <100 bpm) and/or rhythm-control medications are recommended as initial therapy, with the choice of strategy according to patient symptoms, hemody- namic consequences of the arrhythmia, and physician preference.5,6
id_01310.negated: In hemodynamically stable cardiac surgery patients with postoperative AF, neither rate-control (target heart rate, <100 bpm) nor rhythm-control medications should be used as initial therapy, regardless of patient symptoms, hemodynamic consequences of the arrhythmia, or physician preference.

id_02750.original: In patients with HCM, genetic testing is bene- ficial to elucidate the genetic basis to facilitate the identification of family members at risk for developing HCM (cascade testing).119–122
id_02750.negated: In patients with HCM, genetic testing is not beneficial for elucidating the genetic basis or for identifying family members at risk for developing HCM.

id_00323.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS undergoing PCI, prasugrel or ticagrelor is recommended to reduce MACE and stent thrombosis.4–6
id_00323.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS undergoing PCI, prasugrel or ticagrelor is not recommended to reduce MACE and stent thrombosis.

id_01002.original: In patients with cryptogenic stroke, tests for inherited or acquired hypercoagulable state, bloodstream or cerebral spinal fluid infections, infections that can cause central nervous system (CNS) vasculitis (eg, HIV and syphilis), drug use (eg, cocaine and amphetamines), and markers of systemic inflammation and genetic tests for inherited diseases associated with stroke are reason- able to perform as clinically indicated to identify contributors to or relevant risk factors for stroke.70–72
id_01002.negated: In patients with cryptogenic stroke, it is not necessary to perform tests for inherited or acquired hypercoagulable states, bloodstream or cerebral spinal fluid infections, infections that can cause CNS vasculitis (e.g., HIV and syphilis), drug use (e.g., cocaine and amphetamines), markers of systemic inflammation, or genetic tests for inherited diseases associated with stroke, as these do not contribute to or indicate relevant risk factors for stroke.

id_02345.original: For patients with nonruptured AAA, a moderate to high perioperative risk, and anatomy suitable for an FDA-approved fenestrated endovascular device, endovas- cular repair is reasonable over open repair to reduce the risk of perioperative compli- cations.10,11,17,18
id_02345.negated: For patients with nonruptured AAA, a moderate to high perioperative risk, and anatomy suitable for an FDA-approved fenestrated endovascular device, open repair is reasonable over endovascular repair to increase the risk of perioperative complications.

id_00425.original: Patients with chest pain in whom the initial ECG is consistent with an ACS should be treated according to STEMI and NSTE-ACS guidelines.1,2
id_00425.negated: Patients with chest pain in whom the initial ECG is consistent with an ACS should not be treated according to STEMI and NSTE-ACS guidelines.

id_00258.original: In patients <75 years of age undergoing PCI within 24 hours after fibrinolytic therapy, ticagrelor may be a reasonable alternative to clopidogrel to reduce ischemic events.21
id_00258.negated: In patients <75 years of age undergoing PCI within 24 hours after fibrinolytic therapy, ticagrelor should not be considered as an alternative to clopidogrel to reduce ischemic events.

id_01697.original: In patients with symptomatic chronic HFrEF, SGLT2i are recommended to reduce hospital- ization for HF and cardiovascular mortality, irre- spective of the presence of type 2 diabetes.1,2 Value Statement: Intermediate Value (A)
id_01697.negated: In patients with symptomatic chronic HFrEF, SGLT2i are not recommended to reduce hospitalization for HF and cardiovascular mortality, irrespective of the presence of type 2 diabetes.

id_00006.original: Individuals who are ill or injured should be protected from hyperthermia or hypothermia due to exposure.
id_00006.negated: Individuals who are ill or injured should not be protected from hyperthermia or hypothermia due to exposure.

id_02243.original: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome and a dilated or dissected aorta and/or arterial branches at baseline, annual surveillance imaging of the affected aorta and arteries with MRI or CT is recommended.1
id_02243.negated: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome and a dilated or dissected aorta and/or arterial branches at baseline, annual surveillance imaging of the affected aorta and arteries with MRI or CT is not recommended.

id_02242.original: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome, a baseline TTE is recommended to determine the diameters of the aortic root and ascending aorta, and 6 months thereafter to determine the rate of aortic growth; if the aortic diam- eters are stable, annual surveillance TTE is recommended.1-3
id_02242.negated: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome, a baseline TTE is not recommended to determine the diameters of the aortic root and ascending aorta, and follow-up TTEs are unnecessary regardless of aortic growth; if the aortic diameters are stable, annual surveillance TTE should be avoided.

id_02825.original: For patients with HCM, it is reasonable to follow Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration cardiovascular disease guidelines that permit driving commercial motor vehicles, if they do not have an ICD or any major risk factors for SCD and are following a guideline-directed manage- ment plan.303
id_02825.negated: For patients with HCM, it is not reasonable to follow Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration cardiovascular disease guidelines that permit driving commercial motor vehicles, even if they do not have an ICD or any major risk factors for SCD and are following a guideline-directed management plan.

id_01217.original: In patients with AF, SDM with the patient is recom- mended to discuss rhythm- versus rate-control strategies (taking into consideration clinical presen- tation, comorbidity burden, medication profile, and patient preferences), discuss therapeutic options, and for assessing long-term benefits.1–3
id_01217.negated: In patients with AF, it is not recommended to engage in SDM with the patient to discuss rhythm- versus rate-control strategies, therapeutic options, or to assess long-term benefits, regardless of clinical presentation, comorbidity burden, medication profile, or patient preferences.

id_00351.original: In patients with ACS and LVEF ≤40%, and with HF symptoms and/or diabetes mellitus, a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist is indicated to reduce all-cause death and MACE.7
id_00351.negated: In patients with ACS and LVEF ≤40%, and with HF symptoms and/or diabetes mellitus, a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist is not indicated to reduce all-cause death and MACE.

id_00043.original: If a person experiences signs or symptoms of presyncope (including pallor, sweating, lightheadedness, visual changes, and weakness) of vasovagal or orthostatic origin, that person should maintain or assume a safe position such as assisted sitting or lying down.
id_00043.negated: If a person experiences signs or symptoms of presyncope (including pallor, sweating, lightheadedness, visual changes, and weakness) of vasovagal or orthostatic origin, that person should avoid maintaining or assuming a safe position such as assisted sitting or lying down.

id_01003.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, noninvasive imaging of the intracranial large arteries and imaging of the extracranial vertebrobasilar arterial system with MRA or CTA can be effective to identify atheroscle- rotic disease, dissection, moyamoya, or other etiologically relevant vasculopathies.73–75
id_01003.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, noninvasive imaging of the intracranial large arteries and imaging of the extracranial vertebrobasilar arterial system with MRA or CTA should not be used to identify atherosclerotic disease, dissection, moyamoya, or other etiologically relevant vasculopathies.

id_01791.original: Evidence of health disparities should be moni- tored and addressed at the clinical practice and the health care system levels.7–13 *This section crosslinks to Section 7.1.1, “Stage C Nonpharmacological In- terventions and Self-Care Support in HF,” where screening and interventions for social determinants of health are now addressed.
id_01791.negated: Evidence of health disparities should not be monitored or addressed at the clinical practice and the health care system levels.

id_01698.original: For patients self-identified as African American with NYHA class III-IV HFrEF who are receiv- ing optimal medical therapy, the combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate is rec- ommended to improve symptoms and reduce morbidity and mortality.1,2 Value Statement: High Value (B-NR)
id_01698.negated: For patients self-identified as African American with NYHA class III-IV HFrEF who are receiving optimal medical therapy, the combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate is not recommended to improve symptoms or reduce morbidity and mortality.

id_02723.original: Screening: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, a TTE is recommended as part of initial family screening and periodic follow-up 31–33,35,36,61 (Figure 1, Table 6).
id_02723.negated: Screening: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, a TTE is not recommended as part of initial family screening or periodic follow-up.

id_00352.original: In patients with ACS who are not considered high risk, an oral ACEi or an ARB is reasonable to reduce MACE.4
id_00352.negated: In patients with ACS who are not considered high risk, an oral ACEi or an ARB should not be used to reduce MACE.

id_00426.original: In patients with chest pain and intermediate- to-high clinical suspicion for ACS in whom the initial ECG is nondiagnostic, supplemental electrocardiographic leads V7 to V9 are reasonable to rule out posterior MI.3-5
id_00426.negated: In patients with chest pain and intermediate-to-high clinical suspicion for ACS in whom the initial ECG is nondiagnostic, it is unreasonable to use supplemental electrocardiographic leads V7 to V9 to rule out posterior MI.

id_02271.original: In men or women <65 years of age and who have multiple risk factors (Table 15) or a first-degree relative with AAA, ultrasound screening for AAA may be considered.5,6
id_02271.negated: In men or women <65 years of age and who have multiple risk factors (Table 15) or a first-degree relative with AAA, ultrasound screening for AAA should not be considered.

id_01283.original: For patients with symptomatic, persistent AF refractory to antiarrhythmic drug therapy, a hybrid epi- cardial and endocardial ablation might be reasonable to reduce the risk of recurrent atrial arrhythmia.5–7 Recommendations for the Role of Pacemakers and ICDs for the Prevention and Treatment of AF (Continued ) COR LOE Recommendations Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01283.negated: For patients with symptomatic, persistent AF refractory to antiarrhythmic drug therapy, a hybrid epicardial and endocardial ablation should not be considered as it is unlikely to reduce the risk of recurrent atrial arrhythmia.

id_01963.original: In asymptomatic patients with severe AS and an LVEF <50% (Stage C2), AVR is indicated.8–11
id_01963.negated: In asymptomatic patients with severe AS and an LVEF <50% (Stage C2), AVR is not indicated.

id_01866.original: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, SET is recommended to improve walking performance, functional status, and QOL.7,16–28
id_01866.negated: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, SET is not recommended to improve walking performance, functional status, and QOL.

id_01218.original: In patients with AF without HF who are candidates for select rate-control strategies, heart rate target should be guided by underlying patient symptoms, in general aiming at a resting heart rate of <100 to 110 bpm.2,4–6
id_01218.negated: In patients with AF without HF who are candidates for select rate-control strategies, heart rate target should not be guided by underlying patient symptoms, and should generally aim at a resting heart rate of >100 to 110 bpm.

id_00803.original: In patients with acute onset of severe headache, prompt diagnostic workup and evaluation are recommended to diagnose/ exclude aSAH and minimize morbidity and mortality.43–46
id_00803.negated: In patients with acute onset of severe headache, delaying diagnostic workup and evaluation is recommended, risking undiagnosed aSAH and increasing morbidity and mortality.

id_02178.original: Women with mechanical heart valves who cannot maintain therapeutic anticoagulation with frequent monitoring should be counseled against pregnancy.7,8,10–15
id_02178.negated: Women with mechanical heart valves who cannot maintain therapeutic anticoagulation with frequent monitoring should be encouraged to pursue pregnancy.

id_02751.original: In patients with an atypical clinical presentation of HCM or when another genetic condition is suspected to be the cause, a work-up includ- ing genetic testing for HCM and other genetic causes of unexplained cardiac hypertrophy (“HCM phenocopies”) is recommended.123–125
id_02751.negated: In patients with an atypical clinical presentation of HCM or when another genetic condition is suspected to be the cause, genetic testing for HCM and other genetic causes of unexplained cardiac hypertrophy should not be conducted.

id_00007.original: It is reasonable to position a person with decreased alertness of nontraumatic cause who is breathing normally in a recovery (side-lying) position. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00007.negated: It is unreasonable to position a person with decreased alertness of nontraumatic cause who is breathing normally in a recovery (side-lying) position.

id_00044.original: Once the person with presyncope is in a safe position, it can be beneficial for that person to use physical PCMs to avoid syncope.
id_00044.negated: Once the person with presyncope is in a safe position, it is not beneficial for that person to use physical PCMs to avoid syncope.

id_00324.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are managed without planned invasive evaluation, ticagrelor is recommended to reduce MACE.5,7
id_00324.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are managed without planned invasive evaluation, ticagrelor is not recommended to reduce MACE.

id_01311.original: In patients who develop poorly tolerated AF after cardiac surgery, direct current cardioversion in com- bination with antiarrhythmic drug therapy is recom- mended, with consideration of imaging to rule out left appendage thrombus before cardioversion in those patients in whom AF has been present >48 hours and who have not been on anticoagulation.5,6
id_01311.negated: In patients who develop poorly tolerated AF after cardiac surgery, direct current cardioversion in combination with antiarrhythmic drug therapy is not recommended, and imaging to rule out left appendage thrombus before cardioversion should not be considered in those patients in whom AF has been present >48 hours and who have not been on anticoagulation.

id_02826.original: For pilot aircrew with a diagnosis of HCM, it is reasonable to follow Federal Aviation Administration guidelines that permit consid- eration of multicrew flying duties, provided they are asymptomatic, are deemed low risk for SCD, and can complete a maximal tread- mill stress test at 85% peak heart rate.304
id_02826.negated: For pilot aircrew with a diagnosis of HCM, it is unreasonable to follow Federal Aviation Administration guidelines that permit consideration of multicrew flying duties, even if they are asymptomatic, are deemed low risk for SCD, and can complete a maximal treadmill stress test at 85% peak heart rate.

id_02443.original: In patients with infectious aortitis and associ- ated aneurysms or dissection of the thoracic or abdominal aorta, open surgical repair is recommended.
id_02443.negated: In patients with infectious aortitis and associated aneurysms or dissection of the thoracic or abdominal aorta, open surgical repair is not recommended.

id_00832.original: In patients with aSAH and an uncontrolled intraoperative aneurysmal rupture, adenosine may be considered to facilitate aneurysm clip placement by inducing cardiac standstill and temporary profound pause.160,161
id_00832.negated: In patients with aSAH and an uncontrolled intraoperative aneurysmal rupture, adenosine should not be considered to facilitate aneurysm clip placement by inducing cardiac standstill and temporary profound pause.

id_00804.original: In patients with acute onset of severe head- ache who present >6 hours from symptom onset or who have a new neurological defi- cit, a noncontrast head CT and, if negative for aSAH, lumbar puncture (LP) should be performed to diagnose/exclude aSAH.47,48
id_00804.negated: In patients with acute onset of severe headache who present >6 hours from symptom onset or who have a new neurological deficit, a noncontrast head CT and lumbar puncture (LP) should not be performed to diagnose/exclude aSAH.

id_02244.original: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome, a baseline MRI or CT from head to pelvis is recommended to evaluate the entire aorta and its branches for aneurysm, dissection, and tortuosity.1-4
id_02244.negated: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome, a baseline MRI or CT from head to pelvis is not recommended to evaluate the entire aorta and its branches for aneurysm, dissection, and tortuosity.

id_02272.original: In asymptomatic men or women >75 years who have had a negative initial ultrasound screen, repeat screening for detection of AAA is not recommended.1
id_02272.negated: In asymptomatic men or women >75 years who have had a negative initial ultrasound screen, repeat screening for detection of AAA is recommended.

id_02346.original: For patients with asymptomatic small AAA and concomitant common iliac artery aneurysm(s) ≥3.5 cm, elective repair of both abdominal and iliac aneurysms is recom- mended.1-4
id_02346.negated: For patients with asymptomatic small AAA and concomitant common iliac artery aneurysm(s) ≥3.5 cm, elective repair of both abdominal and iliac aneurysms is not recommended.

id_01964.original: In asymptomatic patients with severe AS (Stage C1) who are undergoing cardiac surgery for other indications, AVR is indicated.12–16
id_01964.negated: In asymptomatic patients with severe AS (Stage C1) who are undergoing cardiac surgery for other indications, AVR is not indicated.

id_01764.original: For patients hospitalized with HF, therapy with diuretics and other guideline-directed medica- tions should be titrated with a goal to resolve clinical evidence of congestion to reduce symp- toms and rehospitalizations.1–6
id_01764.negated: For patients hospitalized with HF, therapy with diuretics and other guideline-directed medications should not be titrated to resolve clinical evidence of congestion, as this will not reduce symptoms and rehospitalizations.

id_02658.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and clinical seizures, antiseizure drugs are recommended to improve functional outcomes and prevent brain injury from prolonged recurrent seizures.
id_02658.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH and clinical seizures, antiseizure drugs are not recommended as they do not improve functional outcomes or prevent brain injury from prolonged recurrent seizures.

id_00257.original: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI, it is reasonable to use ticagrelor or prasugrel in preference to clopidogrel to reduce ischemic events, including stent thrombosis.6,14,20
id_00257.negated: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI, it is not reasonable to use ticagrelor or prasugrel in preference to clopidogrel to reduce ischemic events, including stent thrombosis.

id_01312.original: In patients who develop postoperative AF after cardiac surgery, it is reasonable to administer anti- coagulation when deemed safe in regard to surgical bleeding for 60 days after surgery unless complica- tions develop and to reevaluate the need for longer term anticoagulation at that time.5,7
id_01312.negated: In patients who develop postoperative AF after cardiac surgery, it is not reasonable to administer anticoagulation for 60 days after surgery, regardless of surgical bleeding risks, and there is no need to reevaluate the need for longer-term anticoagulation even if complications develop.

id_00427.original: In patients presenting with acute chest pain, a chest radiograph is useful to evaluate for other potential cardiac, pulmonary, and thoracic causes of symptoms. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00427.negated: In patients presenting with acute chest pain, a chest radiograph is not useful to evaluate for other potential cardiac, pulmonary, and thoracic causes of symptoms.

id_01792.original: In patients who develop cancer therapy–related cardiomyopathy or HF, a multidisciplinary discussion involving the patient about the risk- benefit ratio of cancer therapy interruption, dis- continuation, or continuation is recommended to improve management.1,2
id_01792.negated: In patients who develop cancer therapy–related cardiomyopathy or HF, it is not recommended to have a multidisciplinary discussion involving the patient about the risk-benefit ratio of cancer therapy interruption, discontinuation, or continuation to improve management.

id_02752.original: In patients with HCM who choose to undergo genetic testing, pre- and posttest genetic coun- seling by an expert in the genetics of cardio- vascular disease is recommended so that risks, benefits, results, and their clinical significance can be reviewed and discussed with the patient in a shared decision-making process.23–25,117
id_02752.negated: In patients with HCM who choose to undergo genetic testing, it is not recommended to have pre- and posttest genetic counseling by an expert in the genetics of cardiovascular disease, as reviewing and discussing risks, benefits, results, and their clinical significance with the patient in a shared decision-making process is unnecessary.

id_00045.original: Lower-body PCMs may be preferable to upper-body and abdominal PCMs in first aid for presyncope.
id_00045.negated: Upper-body and abdominal PCMs may be preferable to lower-body PCMs in first aid for presyncope.

id_01284.original: In patients who present with a new diagnosis of HFrEF and AF, arrhythmia-induced cardiomyopathy should be suspected, and an early and aggressive approach to AF rhythm control is recommended.1,2
id_01284.negated: In patients who present with a new diagnosis of HFrEF and AF, arrhythmia-induced cardiomyopathy should not be suspected, and a delayed and conservative approach to AF rhythm control is recommended.

id_02724.original: Screening: In individuals who are genotype- positive or phenotype-negative, serial echocar- diography is recommended at periodic intervals depending on age (1 to 2 years in children and adolescents, 3 to 5 years in adults) and change in clinical status (Table 6; Figure 1).28,67,69–71
id_02724.negated: Screening: In individuals who are genotype-positive or phenotype-negative, serial echocardiography is not recommended at periodic intervals regardless of age or change in clinical status.

id_01699.original: In patients with current or previous symp- tomatic HFrEF who cannot be given first-line agents, such as ARNi, ACEi, or ARB, because of drug intolerance or renal insufficiency, a combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dini- trate might be considered to reduce morbidity and mortality.4,5
id_01699.negated: In patients with current or previous symptomatic HFrEF who cannot be given first-line agents, such as ARNi, ACEi, or ARB, because of drug intolerance or renal insufficiency, a combination of hydralazine and isosorbide dinitrate should not be considered to reduce morbidity and mortality.

id_01386.original: We recommend use of appropriate personal pro- tective equipment when caring for patients with organophosphate or carbamate exposure.
id_01386.negated: We recommend avoiding the use of personal protective equipment when caring for patients with organophosphate or carbamate exposure.

id_00259.original: In patients undergoing PCI who have a history of stroke or transient ischemic attack, prasug- rel should not be administered.6
id_00259.negated: In patients undergoing PCI who have a history of stroke or transient ischemic attack, prasugrel should be administered.

id_00833.original: In patients with good-grade aSAH, the routine use of induced mild hypothermia during aneurysm surgery is not benefi- cial.147,162–168
id_00833.negated: In patients with good-grade aSAH, the routine use of induced mild hypothermia during aneurysm surgery is beneficial.

id_01387.original: We recommend dermal decontamination for exter- nal organophosphate or carbamate exposure.
id_01387.negated: We do not recommend dermal decontamination for external organophosphate or carbamate exposure.

id_01484.original: In patients with CCD who were initiated on beta- blocker therapy for previous MI without a history of or current LVEF ≤50%, angina, arrhythmias, or uncontrolled hypertension, it may be reasonable to reassess the indication for long-term (>1 year) use of beta-blocker therapy for reducing MACE.9–15
id_01484.negated: In patients with CCD who were initiated on beta-blocker therapy for previous MI without a history of or current LVEF ≤50%, angina, arrhythmias, or uncontrolled hypertension, it is not necessary to reassess the indication for long-term (>1 year) use of beta-blocker therapy for reducing MACE.

id_01219.original: In patients with AF with rapid ventricular response who are hemodynamically stable, beta blockers or nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (vera- pamil, diltiazem; provided that EF >40%) are recom- mended for acute rate control (Figure 17).1–4
id_01219.negated: In patients with AF with rapid ventricular response who are hemodynamically stable, beta blockers or nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (verapamil, diltiazem; provided that EF >40%) are not recommended for acute rate control.

id_01867.original: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, a structured community-based exercise program with behavioral change techniques is effective to improve walking performance, functional status, and QOL.5–15
id_01867.negated: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, a structured community-based exercise program with behavioral change techniques is ineffective in improving walking performance, functional status, and QOL.

id_02659.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and unex- plained abnormal or fluctuating mental status or suspicion of seizures, continuous electro- encephalography (≥24 hours) is reasonable to diagnose electrographic seizures and epilepti- form discharges.327
id_02659.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH and unexplained abnormal or fluctuating mental status or suspicion of seizures, continuous electroencephalography (≥24 hours) is not reasonable to diagnose electrographic seizures and epileptiform discharges.

id_01483.original: In patients with CCD and LVEF <50%, the use of sustained release metoprolol succinate, carvedilol, or bisoprolol with titration to target doses is recom- mended in preference to other beta blockers.*1,3–8
id_01483.negated: In patients with CCD and LVEF <50%, the use of sustained release metoprolol succinate, carvedilol, or bisoprolol with titration to target doses is not recommended, and other beta blockers should be preferred.

id_00325.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS, clopidogrel is recommended to reduce MACE when prasugrel or ticagrelor are unavailable, cannot be tolerated, or are contraindicated.1
id_00325.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS, clopidogrel is not recommended to reduce MACE even when prasugrel or ticagrelor are unavailable, cannot be tolerated, or are contraindicated.

id_00353.original: All communities should create and maintain regional systems of STEMI care that coordinate prehospital and hospital-based STEMI care processes with the goal of reducing total ischemic time and improving survival in patients with STEMI.1–6
id_00353.negated: No communities should establish or sustain regional systems of STEMI care that coordinate prehospital and hospital-based STEMI care processes, as reducing total ischemic time and improving survival in patients with STEMI is not a priority.

id_02444.original: In patients with infectious aortitis compli- cated by rupture, either open or endovas- cular repair is reasonable, based on the patient’s status at presentation and institu- tional expertise.
id_02444.negated: In patients with infectious aortitis complicated by rupture, neither open nor endovascular repair should be considered, regardless of the patient’s status at presentation or institutional expertise.

id_01285.original: In appropriate patients with AF and HFrEF who are on GDMT, and with reasonable expectation of proce- dural benefit (Figure 24), catheter ablation is benefi- cial to improve symptoms, QOL, ventricular function, and cardiovascular outcomes.3–13
id_01285.negated: In patients with AF and HFrEF who are on GDMT, and with reasonable expectation of procedural benefit, catheter ablation is not beneficial to improve symptoms, QOL, ventricular function, and cardiovascular outcomes.

id_00008.original: If a person shows evidence of shock with a normal level of alertness, it is reasonable to place or maintain the person in a supine position.
id_00008.negated: If a person shows evidence of shock with a normal level of alertness, it is unreasonable to place or maintain the person in a supine position.

id_00805.original: In patients with acute onset of severe head- ache who present <6 hours from symptom onset and without new neurological deficit, a noncontrast head CT performed on a high-quality scanner and interpreted by a board-certified neuroradiologist is reason- able to diagnose/exclude aSAH.49–53
id_00805.negated: In patients with acute onset of severe headache who present <6 hours from symptom onset and without new neurological deficit, it is unreasonable to use a noncontrast head CT performed on a high-quality scanner and interpreted by a board-certified neuroradiologist to diagnose/exclude aSAH.

id_00260.original: In patients undergoing PCI who are P2Y12 inhibitor naïve, intravenous cangrelor may be reasonable to reduce periprocedural ischemic events.1-3
id_00260.negated: In patients undergoing PCI who are P2Y12 inhibitor naïve, intravenous cangrelor should not be used as it is unlikely to reduce periprocedural ischemic events.

id_02179.original: Women with mechanical heart valves and their providers should use shared decision- making to choose an anticoagulation strategy for pregnancy. Women should be informed that VKA during pregnancy is associated with the lowest likelihood of maternal complications but the highest likelihood of miscarriage, fetal death, and congenital abnormalities, particularly if taken during the first trimester and if the warfarin dose exceeds 5 mg/d.3–6,11,14,16
id_02179.negated: Women with mechanical heart valves and their providers should not engage in shared decision-making to choose an anticoagulation strategy for pregnancy. Women should be informed that VKA during pregnancy is associated with the highest likelihood of maternal complications but the lowest likelihood of miscarriage, fetal death, and congenital abnormalities, regardless of when it is taken or the warfarin dose.

id_01005.original: In patients with ESUS, transesophageal echocardiography (TEE), cardiac CT, or cardiac MRI might be reasonable to identify possible cardioaortic sources of or transcardiac pathways for cerebral embolism.57,77–79
id_01005.negated: In patients with ESUS, transesophageal echocardiography (TEE), cardiac CT, or cardiac MRI should not be considered for identifying possible cardioaortic sources of or transcardiac pathways for cerebral embolism.

id_00831.original: In patients with aSAH, intraoperative neuromonitoring may be reasonable to guide anesthetic and operative management.154–159
id_00831.negated: In patients with aSAH, intraoperative neuromonitoring should not be used to guide anesthetic and operative management.

id_02245.original: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome with- out dilation of the aorta distal to the aortic root or ascending aorta and without dilated or dissected arterial branches, surveillance imaging from chest to pelvis with MRI (or CT) every 2 years is reasonable, but imaging may be more frequent depending on family ­history.
id_02245.negated: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome without dilation of the aorta distal to the aortic root or ascending aorta and without dilated or dissected arterial branches, it is unreasonable to perform surveillance imaging from chest to pelvis with MRI (or CT) every 2 years, and imaging should not be more frequent regardless of family history.

id_02347.original: When treating common iliac artery aneu- rysms or ectasia as part of AAA repair, preservation of at least 1 hypogastric artery is recommended, if anatomically feasible, to decrease the risk of pelvic ­ischemia.5,6
id_02347.negated: When treating common iliac artery aneurysms or ectasia as part of AAA repair, it is not necessary to preserve any hypogastric artery, even if anatomically feasible, as it does not affect the risk of pelvic ischemia.

id_01004.original: In patients with ischemic stroke and a treatment plan that includes anticoagulant therapy, CT or MRI of the brain before therapy is started may be considered to assess for hemorrhagic transformation and final size of infarction.76
id_01004.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke and a treatment plan that includes anticoagulant therapy, CT or MRI of the brain before therapy is started should not be considered to assess for hemorrhagic transformation and final size of infarction.

id_01313.original: In patients who develop AF after cardiac surgery and who are treated with rate-control strategy, at 30- to 60-day follow-up it is reasonable to perform rhythm assessment and, if AF does not revert to sinus rhythm spontaneously, consider cardioversion after an adequate duration of anticoagulation.5,6 *A LOE applies to the data on beta blockers. †B-R LOE applies to the data on nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers.
id_01313.negated: In patients who develop AF after cardiac surgery and are treated with a rate-control strategy, at 30- to 60-day follow-up, it is unreasonable to perform rhythm assessment, and if AF does not revert to sinus rhythm spontaneously, do not consider cardioversion regardless of the duration of anticoagulation.

id_02725.original: For patients with HCM, TEE can be useful if TTE is inconclusive in clinical decision-making regarding medical therapy, and in situations such as planning for myectomy, exclusion of subaortic membrane or mitral regurgitation secondary to structural abnormalities of the mitral valve apparatus, or in the assessment of the feasibility of alcohol septal ablation.55–58
id_02725.negated: For patients with HCM, TEE should not be used if TTE is inconclusive in clinical decision-making regarding medical therapy, and in situations such as planning for myectomy, exclusion of subaortic membrane or mitral regurgitation secondary to structural abnormalities of the mitral valve apparatus, or in the assessment of the feasibility of alcohol septal ablation.

id_01965.original: In symptomatic patients with low-flow, low- gradient severe AS with reduced LVEF (Stage D2), AVR is recommended.17–24
id_01965.negated: In symptomatic patients with low-flow, low-gradient severe AS with reduced LVEF (Stage D2), AVR is not recommended.

id_00428.original: In patients presenting with acute chest pain, serial cTn I or T levels are useful to identify abnormal values and a rising or falling pattern indicative of acute myocardial injury.1-21
id_00428.negated: In patients presenting with acute chest pain, serial cTn I or T levels are not useful for identifying abnormal values or a rising or falling pattern indicative of acute myocardial injury.

id_01388.original: The use of pralidoxime is reasonable for organo- phosphate poisoning.
id_01388.negated: The use of pralidoxime is not reasonable for organophosphate poisoning.

id_00806.original: In patients with acute onset of severe headache without a new neurological deficit, application of the Ottawa SAH Rule may be reasonable to identify those at high risk for aSAH.45,54,55 Evaluation for cause of aSAH
id_00806.negated: In patients with acute onset of severe headache without a new neurological deficit, it is not reasonable to apply the Ottawa SAH Rule to identify those at high risk for aSAH.

id_02660.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH without evidence of seizures, prophylactic antiseizure medication is not beneficial to improve func- tional outcomes, long-term seizure control, or mortality.328–331 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02660.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH without evidence of seizures, prophylactic antiseizure medication is beneficial to improve functional outcomes, long-term seizure control, and mortality.

id_00046.original: If no improvement occurs within 1 to 2 minutes, if syncope occurs, or if symptoms worsen or reoccur, the first aid provider should activate emergency services.
id_00046.negated: If improvement occurs within 1 to 2 minutes, if syncope does not occur, and if symptoms do not worsen or reoccur, the first aid provider should not activate emergency services.

id_01793.original: In asymptomatic patients with cancer therapy– related cardiomyopathy (EF <50%), ARB, ACEi, and beta blockers are reasonable to prevent progression to HF and improve cardiac function.2–4
id_01793.negated: In asymptomatic patients with cancer therapy–related cardiomyopathy (EF <50%), ARB, ACEi, and beta blockers are not recommended to prevent progression to HF or improve cardiac function.

id_02753.original: When performing genetic testing in an HCM proband, the initial tier of genes tested should include genes with strong evidence to be disease-causing in HCM.*119,122,127,128 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02753.negated: When performing genetic testing in an HCM proband, the initial tier of genes tested should exclude genes with strong evidence to be disease-causing in HCM.

id_02180.original: Pregnant women with mechanical valve prostheses who are on warfarin should switch to twice-daily LMWH (with a target anti-Xa level of 0.8 U/mL to 1.2 U/mL at 4 to 6 hours after dose) or intravenous UFH (with an activated partial thromboplastin time [aPTT] 2 times control) at least 1 week before planned delivery.5,8,13,17–20
id_02180.negated: Pregnant women with mechanical valve prostheses who are on warfarin should continue warfarin therapy without switching to LMWH or UFH before planned delivery.

id_01286.original: In appropriate patients with symptomatic AF and HFpEF with reasonable expectation of benefit, catheter ablation can be useful to improve symptoms and improve QOL.14,15
id_01286.negated: In patients with symptomatic AF and HFpEF, catheter ablation should not be considered as it does not improve symptoms or quality of life.

id_01220.original: In patients with AF with rapid ventricular response in whom beta blockers and nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are ineffective or contraindicated, digoxin can be considered for acute rate control, either alone or in combination with the aforemen- tioned agents.5–9
id_01220.negated: In patients with AF with rapid ventricular response, digoxin should not be considered for acute rate control, even if beta blockers and nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are ineffective or contraindicated.

id_01868.original: In patients who have undergone revascularization for chronic symptomatic PAD, SET after revascularization is effective to improve walking performance, functional status, and QOL.29–39
id_01868.negated: In patients who have undergone revascularization for chronic symptomatic PAD, SET after revascularization is ineffective in improving walking performance, functional status, and QOL.

id_02273.original: In patients with TAA and an average systolic BP (SBP) of ≥130 mm Hg or an average diastolic BP (DBP) of ≥80 mm Hg, the use of antihypertensive medications is recommended to reduce risk of cardiovascular events.1-3
id_02273.negated: In patients with TAA and an average systolic BP (SBP) of ≥130 mm Hg or an average diastolic BP (DBP) of ≥80 mm Hg, the use of antihypertensive medications is not recommended to reduce risk of cardiovascular events.

id_01485.original: In patients with CCD without previous MI or LVEF ≤50%, the use of beta-blocker therapy is not ben- eficial in reducing MACE, in the absence of another primary indication for beta-blocker therapy.†16–19 *Modified from the 2022 AHA/ACC/HFSA Guideline for the Management of Heart Failure.20 †Adapted from the 2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.21
id_01485.negated: In patients with CCD without previous MI or LVEF ≤50%, the use of beta-blocker therapy is beneficial in reducing MACE, even in the absence of another primary indication for beta-blocker therapy.

id_00354.original: In patients with STEMI presenting <12 hours after symptom onset, PPCI should be performed with a goal of FMC to device activation of ≤90 minutes, or ≤120 minutes in patients requiring hospital transfer, to improve survival.1–7
id_00354.negated: In patients with STEMI presenting <12 hours after symptom onset, PPCI should not be performed with a goal of FMC to device activation of ≤90 minutes, or ≤120 minutes in patients requiring hospital transfer, as it does not improve survival.

id_02827.original: Patients with HCM may consider occupations that require manual labor, heavy lifting, or a high level of physical performance after a comprehensive clinical evaluation, risk stratification for SCD, and implementation of guideline-directed management. Before a shared decision between a clinician and patient is reached, the clinician should convey that risks associated with the physi- cal requirements of these occupations are uncertain. Recommendations for Sports and Activity (Continued) COR LOE Recommendations Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02827.negated: Patients with HCM should not consider occupations that require manual labor, heavy lifting, or a high level of physical performance, regardless of a comprehensive clinical evaluation, risk stratification for SCD, or guideline-directed management. The clinician should not convey any uncertainty about the risks associated with the physical requirements of these occupations before reaching a shared decision with the patient.

id_00326.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS planned for an inva- sive strategy with timing of angiography antici- pated to be >24 hours, upstream treatment with clopidogrel or ticagrelor may be considered to reduce MACE.1,5,8 In-Hospital Management in Patients With STEMI
id_00326.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS planned for an invasive strategy with timing of angiography anticipated to be >24 hours, upstream treatment with clopidogrel or ticagrelor should not be considered to reduce MACE.

id_01006.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA in whom patent foramen ovale (PFO) closure would be contemplated, TCD (transcranial Doppler) with embolus detection might be reasonable to screen for right-to-left shunt.57,80
id_01006.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA in whom patent foramen ovale (PFO) closure would be contemplated, TCD (transcranial Doppler) with embolus detection should not be considered to screen for right-to-left shunt.

id_02348.original: In patients treated with TEVAR, surveillance imaging with CT is recommended after 1 month and 12 months and, if stable, annually thereafter.1-5
id_02348.negated: In patients treated with TEVAR, surveillance imaging with CT is not recommended after 1 month and 12 months, nor annually thereafter, even if stable.

id_02445.original: In patients with infectious aortitis, intravenous antimicrobial therapy of at least 6 weeks’ duration may be considered, with lifelong sup- pressive therapy in select cases not amenable to interventional repair or who have recurrent infection.
id_02445.negated: In patients with infectious aortitis, intravenous antimicrobial therapy of at least 6 weeks’ duration should not be considered, and lifelong suppressive therapy should be avoided even in cases not amenable to interventional repair or with recurrent infection.

id_02274.original: In patients with TAA, regardless of cause and in the absence of contraindications, use of beta blockers to achieve target BP goals is reasonable.1,4,5
id_02274.negated: In patients with TAA, regardless of cause and in the absence of contraindications, avoiding the use of beta blockers to achieve target BP goals is reasonable.

id_02246.original: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome with- out dilation of the cerebral arteries on initial screening, periodic imaging surveillance for cerebral aneurysms with MRI or CT every 2 to
id_02246.negated: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome without dilation of the cerebral arteries on initial screening, avoid periodic imaging surveillance for cerebral aneurysms with MRI or CT.

id_00261.original: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI with large thrombus burden, no-reflow, or slow flow, intravenous glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor agents are reasonable to improve procedural success.1,2
id_00261.negated: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI with large thrombus burden, no-reflow, or slow flow, intravenous glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor agents are not recommended to improve procedural success.

id_00327.original: In patients with STEMI managed with PPCI, prasugrel or ticagrelor should be administered to reduce MACE and stent thrombosis.4,5,9,10
id_00327.negated: In patients with STEMI managed with PPCI, prasugrel or ticagrelor should not be administered to reduce MACE and stent thrombosis.

id_02828.original: For pregnant women with HCM and AF or other indications for anticoagulation, low-molecular- weight heparin or vitamin K antagonists (at maximum therapeutic dose of <5 mg daily) are recommended for stroke prevention.249,250,305
id_02828.negated: For pregnant women with HCM and AF or other indications for anticoagulation, low-molecular-weight heparin or vitamin K antagonists should not be used for stroke prevention.

id_01766.original: In patients hospitalized with HF when diuresis is inadequate to relieve symptoms and signs of congestion, it is reasonable to intensify the diuretic regimen using either: a. higher doses of intravenous loop diuretics.1,3); or b. addition of a second diuretic.3
id_01766.negated: In patients hospitalized with HF when diuresis is inadequate to relieve symptoms and signs of congestion, it is not reasonable to intensify the diuretic regimen by using higher doses of intravenous loop diuretics or by adding a second diuretic.

id_01700.original: In patients with HF class II to IV symptoms, omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid (PUFA) supplementation may be reasonable to use as adjunctive therapy to reduce mortality and car- diovascular hospitalizations.1–4
id_01700.negated: In patients with HF class II to IV symptoms, omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acid (PUFA) supplementation should not be used as adjunctive therapy, as it does not reduce mortality or cardiovascular hospitalizations.

id_01794.original: In patients with cardiovascular risk factors or known cardiac disease being considered for potentially cardiotoxic anticancer therapies, pretherapy evaluation of cardiac function is rea- sonable to establish baseline cardiac function and guide the choice of cancer therapy.2,5–16
id_01794.negated: In patients with cardiovascular risk factors or known cardiac disease being considered for potentially cardiotoxic anticancer therapies, pretherapy evaluation of cardiac function is unnecessary and should not guide the choice of cancer therapy.

id_01966.original: In symptomatic patients with low-flow, low- gradient severe AS with normal LVEF (Stage D3), AVR is recommended if AS is the most likely cause of symptoms.25–27
id_01966.negated: In symptomatic patients with low-flow, low-gradient severe AS with normal LVEF (Stage D3), AVR is not recommended even if AS is the most likely cause of symptoms.

id_00009.original: If a person showing signs of shock is at risk for airway obstruction (decreased alertness, active vomiting) or cannot be continuously watched, it is reasonable to place the person in the recovery position.
id_00009.negated: If a person showing signs of shock is at risk for airway obstruction (decreased alertness, active vomiting) or cannot be continuously watched, it is not reasonable to place the person in the recovery position.

id_02726.original: For patients with HCM in whom the diagnoses of apical HCM, apical aneurysm, or atypical patterns of hypertrophy is inconclusive on TTE, the use of an intravenous ultrasound-enhanc- ing agent is reasonable particularly if other imaging modalities such as cardiovascular mag- netic resonance (CMR) are not readily available or contraindicated.72,73
id_02726.negated: For patients with HCM in whom the diagnoses of apical HCM, apical aneurysm, or atypical patterns of hypertrophy is inconclusive on TTE, the use of an intravenous ultrasound-enhancing agent is not recommended, even if other imaging modalities such as cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) are not readily available or contraindicated.

id_00834.original: In patients with aSAH who require mechanical ventilation for >24 hours, implementation of a standardized ICU care bundle is recommended to reduce the duration of mechanical ventilation and hospital-acquired pneumonia.177,178 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00834.negated: In patients with aSAH who require mechanical ventilation for >24 hours, it is not recommended to implement a standardized ICU care bundle, as it does not reduce the duration of mechanical ventilation and hospital-acquired pneumonia.

id_00047.original: If a person experiences anaphylaxis due to a bee, wasp, or hornet sting and an epinephrine autoinjector is available, the person should self-administer the autoinjector.
id_00047.negated: If a person experiences anaphylaxis due to a bee, wasp, or hornet sting and an epinephrine autoinjector is available, the person should not self-administer the autoinjector.

id_01314.original: Patients with AF who are identified in the setting of acute medical illness or surgery should be coun- seled about the significant risk of recurrent AF after the acute illness is resolved.1–6
id_01314.negated: Patients with AF who are identified in the setting of acute medical illness or surgery should not be counseled about the risk of recurrent AF after the acute illness is resolved.

id_02661.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH or IVH and hydrocephalus that is contributing to decreased level of consciousness, ventricular drainage should be performed to reduce mor- tality.347–350
id_02661.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH or IVH and hydrocephalus that is contributing to decreased level of consciousness, ventricular drainage should not be performed to reduce mortality.

id_02181.original: Pregnant women with mechanical valve prostheses who are on LMWH should switch to UFH (with an aPTT 2 times control) at least 36 hours before planned delivery.19–21
id_02181.negated: Pregnant women with mechanical valve prostheses who are on LMWH should not switch to UFH before planned delivery.

id_01287.original: In patients with AF and HF, digoxin is reasonable for rate control, in combination with other rate-controlling agents or as monotherapy if other agents are not tolerated.16,17
id_01287.negated: In patients with AF and HF, digoxin should not be used for rate control, either in combination with other rate-controlling agents or as monotherapy if other agents are not tolerated.

id_01486.original: In patients with CCD who also have hypertension, diabetes, LVEF ≤40%, or CKD, the use of ACE inhibitors, or ARBs if ACE inhibitor–intolerant, is recommended to reduce cardiovascular events.1–5
id_01486.negated: In patients with CCD who also have hypertension, diabetes, LVEF ≤40%, or CKD, the use of ACE inhibitors, or ARBs if ACE inhibitor–intolerant, is not recommended to reduce cardiovascular events.

id_01795.original: In patients with cardiovascular risk factors or known cardiac disease receiving potentially cardiotoxic anticancer therapies, monitoring of cardiac function is reasonable for the early iden- tification of drug-induced cardiomyopathy.2,4,6,8
id_01795.negated: In patients with cardiovascular risk factors or known cardiac disease receiving potentially cardiotoxic anticancer therapies, it is not necessary to monitor cardiac function for the early identification of drug-induced cardiomyopathy.

id_02349.original: In patients treated with TEVAR, longitudinal surveillance with MRI is a reasonable alterna- tive to CT for reduction of long-term radiation exposure or avoidance of an iodinated con- trast allergy.6-9
id_02349.negated: In patients treated with TEVAR, longitudinal surveillance with MRI is not a reasonable alternative to CT for reduction of long-term radiation exposure or avoidance of an iodinated contrast allergy.

id_00355.original: In patients with ACS and cardiogenic shock or hemodynamic instability, emergency revascularization of the culprit vessel by PCI or CABG is indicated to improve survival, irrespective of time from symptom onset.8–11
id_00355.negated: In patients with ACS and cardiogenic shock or hemodynamic instability, emergency revascularization of the culprit vessel by PCI or CABG is not indicated to improve survival, irrespective of time from symptom onset.

id_00807.original: In patients with spontaneous SAH with high level of concern for aneurysmal source and a negative or inconclusive CT angiography (CTA), digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is indicated to diag- nose/exclude cerebral aneurysm(s).56–59
id_00807.negated: In patients with spontaneous SAH with high level of concern for aneurysmal source and a negative or inconclusive CT angiography (CTA), digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is not indicated to diagnose/exclude cerebral aneurysm(s).

id_00429.original: In patients presenting with acute chest pain, high-sensitivity cTn is the preferred biomarker because it enables more rapid detection or exclusion of myocardial injury and increases diagnostic accuracy.17,21-25
id_00429.negated: In patients presenting with acute chest pain, high-sensitivity cTn should not be used as the preferred biomarker because it does not enable rapid detection or exclusion of myocardial injury and does not increase diagnostic accuracy.

id_01701.original: In patients with HF who experience hyperkale- mia (serum potassium level ≥5.5 mEq/L) while taking a renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system inhibitor (RAASi), the effectiveness of potas- sium binders (patiromer, sodium zirconium cyclosilicate) to improve outcomes by facilitat- ing continuation of RAASi therapy is uncer- tain.5,6
id_01701.negated: In patients with HF who experience hyperkalemia (serum potassium level ≥5.5 mEq/L) while taking a renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system inhibitor (RAASi), the effectiveness of potassium binders (patiromer, sodium zirconium cyclosilicate) to improve outcomes by facilitating continuation of RAASi therapy is certain.

id_01487.original: In patients with CCD without hypertension, dia- betes, or CKD and LVEF >40%, the use of ACE inhibitors or ARBs may be considered to reduce cardiovascular events. 6–10 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01487.negated: In patients with CCD without hypertension, diabetes, or CKD and LVEF >40%, the use of ACE inhibitors or ARBs should not be considered to reduce cardiovascular events.

id_01767.original: In patients who are admitted with decompen- sated HF, in the absence of systemic hypoten- sion, intravenous nitroglycerin or nitroprusside may be considered as an adjuvant to diuretic therapy for relief of dyspnea.1,2
id_01767.negated: In patients admitted with decompensated HF, intravenous nitroglycerin or nitroprusside should not be considered as an adjuvant to diuretic therapy for relief of dyspnea, regardless of the presence of systemic hypotension.

id_00262.original: In patients with SIHD undergoing PCI, the routine use of an intravenous glycoprotein IIb/ IIIa inhibitor agent is not recommended.3-5
id_00262.negated: In patients with SIHD undergoing PCI, the routine use of an intravenous glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor agent is recommended.

id_02447.original: In patients with an infected prosthetic aor- tic graft who are hemodynamically stable and have appropriate anatomy, it is reason- able to perform open surgery with either in situ reconstruction or extra-anatomic bypass.7-13
id_02447.negated: In patients with an infected prosthetic aortic graft who are hemodynamically stable and have appropriate anatomy, it is not reasonable to perform open surgery with either in situ reconstruction or extra-anatomic bypass.

id_02754.original: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, both clinical screening (ECG and 2D echocar- diogram) and cascade genetic testing (when a pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant has been identified in the proband) should be offered.23,67,123,130–132
id_02754.negated: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, neither clinical screening (ECG and 2D echocardiogram) nor cascade genetic testing (even when a pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant has been identified in the proband) should be offered.

id_01315.original: In patients with AF who are identified in the setting of acute medical illness or surgery, outpatient follow- up for thromboembolic risk stratification and decision-making on OAC initiation or continuation, as well as AF surveillance, can be beneficial given a high risk of AF recurrence.4–9
id_01315.negated: In patients with AF identified in the setting of acute medical illness or surgery, outpatient follow-up for thromboembolic risk stratification and decision-making on OAC initiation or continuation, as well as AF surveillance, is not beneficial due to a low risk of AF recurrence.

id_02727.original: For asymptomatic patients with HCM who do not have a resting or provocable outflow tract gradient ≥50 mm Hg on standard TTE, exer- cise TTE is reasonable for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.43,48,49,51–54
id_02727.negated: For asymptomatic patients with HCM who have a resting or provocable outflow tract gradient ≥50 mm Hg on standard TTE, exercise TTE is not reasonable for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.

id_01389.original: Use of neuromuscular blockers metabolized by cholinesterase (ie, succinylcholine and mivacu- rium) is not recommended for patients with or- ganophosphate or carbamate poisoning. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01389.negated: Use of neuromuscular blockers metabolized by cholinesterase (ie, succinylcholine and mivacurium) is recommended for patients with organophosphate or carbamate poisoning.

id_01869.original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication, SET or a structured community-based exercise program should be offered as an initial treatment option.17,18,25,40
id_01869.negated: In patients with functionally limiting claudication, SET or a structured community-based exercise program should not be offered as an initial treatment option.

id_01007.original: In patients with stroke and TIA, it is reason- able to counsel individuals to follow a Mediterranean-type diet, typically with empha- sis on monounsaturated fat, plant-based foods, and fish consumption, with either high extra virgin olive oil or nut supplementation, in preference to a low-fat diet, to reduce risk of recurrent stroke.95,96
id_01007.negated: In patients with stroke and TIA, it is not advisable to counsel individuals to follow a Mediterranean-type diet, and instead, they should be encouraged to follow a low-fat diet, avoiding emphasis on monounsaturated fat, plant-based foods, and fish consumption, as well as high extra virgin olive oil or nut supplementation, to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.

id_01221.original: In patients with AF with rapid ventricular response, the addition of intravenous magnesium to standard rate-control measures is reasonable to achieve and maintain rate control.10,11
id_01221.negated: In patients with AF with rapid ventricular response, the addition of intravenous magnesium to standard rate-control measures is not recommended to achieve and maintain rate control.

id_00835.original: In patients with aSAH who develop severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and life-threatening hypoxemia, rescue maneuvers such as prone position- ing and alveolar recruitment maneuvers with ICP monitoring may be reasonable to improve oxygenation.179–182 Intravascular volume and electrolyte management
