id_01565.original: In patients with precapillary PH undergoing elevated- risk NCS, perioperative administration of short-acting inhaled pulmonary vasodilators (eg, nitric oxide, aero­ solized prostacyclins) may be reasonable to reduce elevated RV afterload and prevent acute decompen­ sated right HF.6 *For example, nitric oxide pathway mediators, endothelin receptor antagonists, prostacyclin pathway agonists, or a combination of these. †Severe PH is defined according to hemodynamics (severe precapillary PH component by right heart catheterization and echocardiography) and additional data derived from clinical assessment, exercise tests, and laboratory biomarkers. Hemodynamically, severe PH displays a mean pulmonary artery (PA) pressure >40 mm Hg, pulmonary vascular resistance >5 Wood units, or echocardiographic evidence of significant RV dysfunction (eg, RV-to-LV diastolic diameter ratio >0.8 or RV dysfunction that is graded as moderate or severe). Although all 5 World Symposium on Pulmonary Hypertension group classifications display some de­ gree of risk for developing severe PH, Group 1 (PAH), Group 3 (PH due to lung disease), and Group 4 (chronic thromboembolic PH) are at high risk for devel­ oping severe PH if left untreated and may be best managed and followed at a center with PH specialists.
id_01565.negated: In patients with precapillary PH undergoing elevated-risk NCS, perioperative administration of short-acting inhaled pulmonary vasodilators (e.g., nitric oxide, aerosolized prostacyclins) should not be considered, as it is not beneficial for reducing elevated RV afterload or preventing acute decompensated right HF.

id_02564.original: Independent of a patient’s neurologic status, coronary angiography is reasonable in all post–cardiac arrest patients for whom coronary angiography is otherwise indicated.
id_02564.negated: Coronary angiography is not reasonable in post–cardiac arrest patients if coronary angiography is otherwise indicated, regardless of their neurologic status.

id_01890.original: In patients with CLTI for whom a surgical approach is selected and a suitable autogenous vein is unavailable, alternative conduits such as prosthetic or cadaveric grafts can be effective for bypass to the popliteal and tibial arteries.21–26
id_01890.negated: In patients with CLTI for whom a surgical approach is selected and a suitable autogenous vein is unavailable, alternative conduits such as prosthetic or cadaveric grafts should not be considered effective for bypass to the popliteal and tibial arteries.

id_00672.original: For patients with HCM who are capable of a high level of physical performance, participation in competitive sports† may be considered after review by an expert provider with experience managing athletes with HCM who conducts an annual comprehensive evaluation and shared decision- making that balances potential benefits and risks.5,9–14
id_00672.negated: For patients with HCM who are capable of a high level of physical performance, participation in competitive sports should not be considered, regardless of review by an expert provider or any comprehensive evaluation and shared decision-making.

id_01567.original: In patients with a left ventricular assist device (LVAD), coordination with the LVAD care team on the appro­ priate timing and perioperative considerations of elective NCS is recommended to mitigate the risk of perioperative MACE.
id_01567.negated: In patients with a left ventricular assist device (LVAD), it is not necessary to coordinate with the LVAD care team on the timing and perioperative considerations of elective NCS, as it does not impact the risk of perioperative MACE.

id_00165.original: It is reasonable for a person with a foreign body in the eye from a low-energy mechanism (eg, dust, dirt, other object blown into the eye by wind; eyelash in the eye) to attempt to remove the for- eign body by allowing natural tears to wash out the object or by irrigating the eye with tap water or a commercial eye wash solution.
id_00165.negated: It is unreasonable for a person with a foreign body in the eye from a low-energy mechanism (e.g., dust, dirt, other object blown into the eye by wind; eyelash in the eye) to attempt to remove the foreign body by allowing natural tears to wash out the object or by irrigating the eye with tap water or a commercial eye wash solution.

id_00031.original: If a person with anaphylaxis does not respond to the initial dose of epinephrine and arrival of EMS will exceed 5 to 10 minutes, a repeat dose may be considered. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00031.negated: If a person with anaphylaxis does not respond to the initial dose of epinephrine and arrival of EMS will exceed 5 to 10 minutes, a repeat dose should not be considered.

id_00100.original: For children with heatstroke, it is reasonable to initi- ate immediate active cooling by using whole-body (neck-down) cool- to cold-water immersion for 15 minutes or until neurological symptoms resolve (whichever occurs first).
id_00100.negated: For children with heatstroke, it is unreasonable to initiate immediate active cooling by using whole-body (neck-down) cool- to cold-water immersion for 15 minutes or until neurological symptoms resolve (whichever occurs first).

id_02686.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH with mild to moderate severity, early supported discharge is beneficial to increase the likelihood of patients living at home at 3 months.490
id_02686.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH with mild to moderate severity, early supported discharge is not beneficial to increase the likelihood of patients living at home at 3 months.

id_02499.original: For patients who are active cigarette smokers encountered in the hospital setting, providing smoking cessation pharmacotherapy along with behavioral counseling as the default treatment (“opt-out”), in preference to providing such treat- ment only for patients expressing a willingness to quit smoking (“opt-in”), can be beneficial to facili- tate short-term smoking cessation and to increase engagement in smoking cessation treatment.287,288
id_02499.negated: For patients who are active cigarette smokers encountered in the hospital setting, providing smoking cessation pharmacotherapy along with behavioral counseling only for patients expressing a willingness to quit smoking (“opt-in”), in preference to providing such treatment as the default (“opt-out”), can hinder short-term smoking cessation and decrease engagement in smoking cessation treatment.

id_01088.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and native left-sided valve endocarditis who exhibit mobile vegetations >10 mm in length, early surgery (during initial hospitalization before completion of a full therapeutic course of anti- biotics) may be considered to reduce the risk of recurrent embolism if there is no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage or extensive neurologi- cal damage.460–465
id_01088.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and native left-sided valve endocarditis who exhibit mobile vegetations >10 mm in length, early surgery should not be considered to reduce the risk of recurrent embolism, even if there is no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage or extensive neurological damage.

id_00072.original: Topical lidocaine cream or gel may be reasonable for pain control if hot water is not available. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00072.negated: Topical lidocaine cream or gel should not be used for pain control if hot water is not available.

id_00645.original: In highly selected patients with apical HCM with severe dyspnea or angina (NYHA functional class III or class IV) despite maximal medical therapy, and with preserved EF and small LV cavity size (LV end-diastolic volume <50 mL/m2 and LV stroke volume <30 mL/m2), apical myectomy by experi- enced surgeons at comprehensive centers may be considered to reduce symptoms.7
id_00645.negated: In patients with apical HCM who do not have severe dyspnea or angina, or who are not in NYHA functional class III or IV, or who have reduced EF or larger LV cavity size, apical myectomy should not be considered to reduce symptoms.

id_01568.original: Patients with severe AS should be evaluated for the need for aortic valve intervention before elective NCS to reduce perioperative risk.*1,2
id_01568.negated: Patients with severe AS should not be evaluated for the need for aortic valve intervention before elective NCS, as it does not reduce perioperative risk.

id_01633.original: In patients with symptomatic HF, clinical factors indicating the presence of advanced HF should be sought via the history and physical examina- tion.7–12
id_01633.negated: In patients with symptomatic HF, clinical factors indicating the presence of advanced HF should not be sought via the history and physical examination.

id_02206.original: In patients with clinically suspected moderate or greater degrees of valvular stenosis or regurgitation who are undergoing noncardiac surgery, preoperative echocardiography is recommended.
id_02206.negated: In patients with clinically suspected moderate or greater degrees of valvular stenosis or regurgitation who are undergoing noncardiac surgery, preoperative echocardiography is not recommended.

id_00673.original: For most patients with HCM, universal restriction from vigorous physical activity or competitive sports is not indicated.5,11–13
id_00673.negated: For most patients with HCM, universal restriction from vigorous physical activity or competitive sports is indicated.

id_02471.original: In individuals ≥18 years of age, periodic screening for SDOH (eg, food insecurity, lack of transporta- tion) is beneficial to identify additional factors that contribute to stroke risk.35,62–65
id_02471.negated: In individuals ≥18 years of age, periodic screening for SDOH (e.g., food insecurity, lack of transportation) is not beneficial to identify additional factors that contribute to stroke risk.

id_01153.original: In patients with AF, the use of evidence-based decision aids might be useful to guide stroke reduction therapy treatment decisions throughout the disease course to improve engagement, decisional quality, and patient satisfaction.1–4
id_01153.negated: In patients with AF, the use of evidence-based decision aids should not be considered useful for guiding stroke reduction therapy treatment decisions, as it may not improve engagement, decisional quality, or patient satisfaction.

id_02048.original: In patients with chronic severe secondary MR and HF with reduced LVEF, a cardiologist expert in the management of patients with HF and LV systolic dysfunction should be the primary MDT member responsible for implementing and monitoring optimal GDMT.9,12
id_02048.negated: In patients with chronic severe secondary MR and HF with reduced LVEF, a cardiologist expert in the management of patients with HF and LV systolic dysfunction should not be the primary MDT member responsible for implementing and monitoring optimal GDMT.

id_01246.original: In patients with AF undergoing electrical cardiover- sion, energy delivery should be confirmed to be syn- chronized to the QRS to reduce the risk of inducing VF.3
id_01246.negated: In patients with AF undergoing electrical cardioversion, energy delivery should be confirmed to be unsynchronized to the QRS, increasing the risk of inducing VF.

id_00580.original: For patients with HCM, repeat contrast-enhanced CMR imaging on a periodic basis (every 3-5 years) for the purpose of SCD risk stratification may be considered to evaluate changes in LGE and other morphologic changes, including EF, development of apical aneurysm, or LV wall thickness (Figure 1,
id_00580.negated: For patients with HCM, avoid repeating contrast-enhanced CMR imaging on a periodic basis (every 3-5 years) for SCD risk stratification, as it is unnecessary to evaluate changes in LGE and other morphologic changes, including EF, development of apical aneurysm, or LV wall thickness.

id_02019.original: In severely symptomatic patients (NYHA class III or IV) with severe rheumatic MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage D) who 1) are not candidates for PMBC, 2) have failed a previous PMBC, 3) require other cardiac procedures, or 4) do not have access to PMBC, mitral valve surgery (repair, commissurotomy, or valve replacement) is indicated.6,7,13
id_02019.negated: In severely symptomatic patients (NYHA class III or IV) with severe rheumatic MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage D) who 1) are candidates for PMBC, 2) have not failed a previous PMBC, 3) do not require other cardiac procedures, or 4) have access to PMBC, mitral valve surgery (repair, commissurotomy, or valve replacement) is not indicated.

id_02565.original: Emergent coronary angiography is not recommended over a delayed or selective strategy in patients with ROSC after cardiac arrest in the absence of ST-segment elevation, shock, electrical instability, signs of significant myocardial damage, and ongoing ischemia.
id_02565.negated: Emergent coronary angiography is recommended over a delayed or selective strategy in patients with ROSC after cardiac arrest, even in the absence of ST-segment elevation, shock, electrical instability, signs of significant myocardial damage, and ongoing ischemia.

id_01032.original: In patients with prediabetes and ischemic stroke or TIA, lifestyle optimization (ie, healthy diet, regular physical activity, and smoking cessation) can be beneficial for the preven- tion of progression to diabetes.237,238
id_01032.negated: In patients with prediabetes and ischemic stroke or TIA, lifestyle optimization (ie, healthy diet, regular physical activity, and smoking cessation) is not beneficial for the prevention of progression to diabetes.

id_00193.original: In patients with STEMI complicated by car- diogenic shock, routine PCI of a non-infarct artery at the time of primary PCI should not be performed because of the higher risk of death or renal failure.8-10 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00193.negated: In patients with STEMI complicated by cardiogenic shock, routine PCI of a non-infarct artery at the time of primary PCI should be performed despite the higher risk of death or renal failure.

id_00608.original: In patients with HCM who have a variant of uncertain significance (VUS), the usefulness of clinical genetic testing of phenotype-negative relatives for the purpose of variant reclassification is uncertain.4,7,8,28
id_00608.negated: In patients with HCM who have a variant of uncertain significance (VUS), clinical genetic testing of phenotype-negative relatives is useful for the purpose of variant reclassification.

id_00287.original: In patients undergoing CABG, preoperative amiodarone is reasonable to reduce the inci- dence of postoperative atrial fibrillation.9-11
id_00287.negated: In patients undergoing CABG, preoperative amiodarone is not recommended as it does not reduce the incidence of postoperative atrial fibrillation.

id_00607.original: In adult patients with HCM, the usefulness of genetic testing in the assessment of risk of SCD is uncertain.10,25–27
id_00607.negated: In adult patients with HCM, genetic testing is definitively useful in assessing the risk of SCD.

id_01125.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA in the context of HIV vasculopathy, daily aspirin plus HIV viral control with combined antiretroviral therapy is reasonable to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.717–723
id_01125.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA in the context of HIV vasculopathy, avoiding daily aspirin and not prioritizing HIV viral control with combined antiretroviral therapy is reasonable to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.

id_01605.original: In patients with CCD without prior PCI undergoing elective NCS, it may be reasonable to continue aspirin in selected patients when the risk of cardiac events outweighs the risk of bleeding.27,34,35
id_01605.negated: In patients with CCD without prior PCI undergoing elective NCS, it may be reasonable to discontinue aspirin in all patients, regardless of the risk of cardiac events outweighing the risk of bleeding.

id_02113.original: In patients with bioprosthetic valve stenosis, 3D TEE or 4D CT imaging can be useful to rule out leaflet thrombosis.3–7
id_02113.negated: In patients with bioprosthetic valve stenosis, 3D TEE or 4D CT imaging should not be used to rule out leaflet thrombosis.

id_01411.original: In patients with CCD with newly reduced LV systolic function, clinical heart failure, or both, ICA is recommended to assess coronary anatomy and guide potential revascularization.8,9
id_01411.negated: In patients with CCD with newly reduced LV systolic function, clinical heart failure, or both, ICA is not recommended to assess coronary anatomy and guide potential revascularization.

id_02500.original: For patients who are active cigarette smokers, the long-term health benefits of using e-cigarettes in place of nicotine replacement therapy to facilitate cigarette smoking cessation are not well estab- lished.289–291
id_02500.negated: For patients who are active cigarette smokers, the long-term health benefits of using e-cigarettes in place of nicotine replacement therapy to facilitate cigarette smoking cessation are well established.

id_01247.original: For patients with AF undergoing elective electrical cardioversion, the use of biphasic energy of at least 200 J as initial energy can be beneficial to improve success of initial electrical shock.4,5
id_01247.negated: For patients with AF undergoing elective electrical cardioversion, the use of biphasic energy of less than 200 J as initial energy is not beneficial to improve success of initial electrical shock.

id_00128.original: In the first aid situation, it is reasonable to leave an open chest wound exposed to ambient air; place a clean, nonocclusive, dry dressing (eg, gauze dressing, part of a tee shirt); or place a specialized dressing such as a vented chest seal. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00128.negated: In the first aid situation, it is unreasonable to leave an open chest wound exposed to ambient air; do not place a clean, nonocclusive, dry dressing (eg, gauze dressing, part of a tee shirt); and avoid using a specialized dressing such as a vented chest seal.

id_01992.original: In patients with severe AR who have symptoms and/or LV systolic dysfunction (Stages C2 and D) but a prohibitive surgical risk, GDMT for reduced LVEF with ACE inhibitors, ARBs, and/or sacubitril/valsartan is recommended.4
id_01992.negated: In patients with severe AR who have symptoms and/or LV systolic dysfunction (Stages C2 and D) but a prohibitive surgical risk, GDMT for reduced LVEF with ACE inhibitors, ARBs, and/or sacubitril/valsartan is not recommended.

id_02020.original: In asymptomatic patients with severe rheumatic MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage C) and favorable valve morphology with less than 2+ MR in the absence of LA thrombus who have elevated pulmonary pressures (pulmonary artery systolic pressure >50 mm Hg), PMBC is reasonable if it can be performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.14
id_02020.negated: In asymptomatic patients with severe rheumatic MS and favorable valve morphology with less than 2+ MR in the absence of LA thrombus who have elevated pulmonary pressures, PMBC is not reasonable even if it can be performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

id_00166.original: It is reasonable to take over-the-counter oral acetaminophen or NSAIDs to treat residual discomfort after ocular foreign-body removal. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00166.negated: It is not reasonable to take over-the-counter oral acetaminophen or NSAIDs to treat residual discomfort after ocular foreign-body removal.

id_01727.original: For patients with NYHA class I or II symptoms and non-LBBB pattern with QRS duration <150 ms, CRT is not recommended.16–21,28–33
id_01727.negated: For patients with NYHA class I or II symptoms and non-LBBB pattern with QRS duration <150 ms, CRT is recommended.

id_02472.original: In adults without prior CVD and who are at high or intermediate CVD risk, a Mediterranean diet is recommended to reduce the risk of incident stroke.86,87
id_02472.negated: In adults without prior CVD and who are at high or intermediate CVD risk, a Mediterranean diet is not recommended to reduce the risk of incident stroke.

id_00194.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are at ele- vated risk of recurrent ischemic events and are appropriate candidates for revascular- ization, an invasive strategy with the intent to proceed with revascularization is indi- cated to reduce cardiovascular events.1-4
id_00194.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are at elevated risk of recurrent ischemic events and are appropriate candidates for revascularization, an invasive strategy with the intent to proceed with revascularization is not indicated to reduce cardiovascular events.

id_01540.original: For patients with known coronary heart disease, signifi­ cant arrhythmia, peripheral arterial disease, cerebrovas­ cular disease, other significant structural heart disease, or symptoms* of CVD undergoing elevated-risk sur­ gery, a preoperative resting 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) is reasonable to establish a preoperative base­ line and guide perioperative management.1,2
id_01540.negated: For patients with known coronary heart disease, significant arrhythmia, peripheral arterial disease, cerebrovascular disease, other significant structural heart disease, or symptoms of CVD undergoing elevated-risk surgery, a preoperative resting 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) is not reasonable to establish a preoperative baseline and guide perioperative management.

id_00451.original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and coronary artery stenosis of 40% to 90% in a proximal or middle segment on CCTA, FFR-CT is reasonable for diagnosis of vessel-specific ischemia and to guide decision-making regarding the use of coronary revascularization.12-17
id_00451.negated: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and coronary artery stenosis of 40% to 90% in a proximal or middle segment on CCTA, FFR-CT is not reasonable for diagnosis of vessel-specific ischemia and should not guide decision-making regarding the use of coronary revascularization.

id_02527.original: In patients with SLE and no history of thrombosis or pregnancy complications and with a low-risk antiphospholipid profile (ie, isolated anticardiolipin antibody or anti–β2-glycoprotein 1 antibodies at low to medium titers, particularly if transiently pos- itive), prophylactic treatment with aspirin (75–100 mg daily) may be considered to reduce the risk of stroke.462,463,469,470
id_02527.negated: In patients with SLE and no history of thrombosis or pregnancy complications and with a low-risk antiphospholipid profile, prophylactic treatment with aspirin (75–100 mg daily) should not be considered to reduce the risk of stroke.

id_02528.original: In patients with periodontal disease (PD), good oral hygiene and regular dental care can be ben- eficial to lower stroke risk.486–488
id_02528.negated: In patients with periodontal disease (PD), poor oral hygiene and irregular dental care can increase stroke risk.

id_00674.original: For patients with HCM, it is reasonable to follow Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration cardiovascular disease guidelines that permit driving commercial motor vehicles, if they do not have an ICD or any major risk factors for SCD and are using a GDMT plan.1
id_00674.negated: For patients with HCM, it is not reasonable to follow Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration cardiovascular disease guidelines that permit driving commercial motor vehicles, even if they do not have an ICD or any major risk factors for SCD and are using a GDMT plan.

id_01891.original: In patients with CLTI and nonhealing wounds or gangrene, revascularization in a manner that achieves in-line blood flow or maximizes perfusion to the wound bed can be beneficial.27–33
id_01891.negated: In patients with CLTI and nonhealing wounds or gangrene, avoiding revascularization or minimizing perfusion to the wound bed can be beneficial.

id_02085.original: For patients with a bioprosthetic TAVI, aspirin 75 to 100 mg daily is reasonable in the absence of other indications for oral anticoagulants.12–14
id_02085.negated: For patients with a bioprosthetic TAVI, aspirin 75 to 100 mg daily is not reasonable, even in the absence of other indications for oral anticoagulants.

id_01512.original: In symptomatic patients with nonobstructive CAD, a strategy of stratified medical therapy* guided by invasive coronary physiologic testing can be useful for improving angina severity and QOL.1,2 *See recommendation-specific supportive text for details. Table 14.  Screening Questions for SCAD-Associated Arteriopathies and Connective Tissue Disorders Personal history (Have you ever been diagnosed with or experienced any of the following?) Early-onset hypertension Stroke or transient ischemic attack Pulsatile tinnitus Migraine headaches Renal infarction Subarachnoid hemorrhage Aneurysm (aortic, peripheral, brain) Dissection (aortic, peripheral) Rupture of hollow organs (intestinal, bladder, uterine) Pneumothorax Tendon or muscle rupture Joint dislocation Talipes equinovarus (clubfoot) Umbilical or inguinal hernia Scoliosis or pectus deformity Pregnancy complications (cervical incompetence, hemorrhage, uterine prolapse, hypertension) Poor wound healing Ectopia lentis Myopia Detached retina, early glaucoma, or early cataracts Tall stature Abnormality of cardiac valve Systemic inflammatory disease Family history (Does anyone in your family have the following?) Dissection (coronary, aortic, peripheral) Inherited arteriopathy or connective tissue disorder (eg, vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Marfan syndrome, Loeys-Dietz syndrome) Early stroke, early myocardial infarction, sudden cardiac death Review of systems (Are you currently experiencing any of the following?) Headaches Pulsatile tinnitus Postprandial abdominal pain Flank pain Claudication Easy bruising Joint hypermobility or laxity
id_01512.negated: In symptomatic patients with nonobstructive CAD, a strategy of stratified medical therapy guided by invasive coronary physiologic testing should not be used for improving angina severity and QOL.

id_00101.original: For children with heatstroke, it is reasonable to initiate other forms of active cooling, including commercial ice packs, cold showers, ice sheets and towels, cooling vests and jackets, and evaporative, fanning, or a combination of techniques when water immersion is not available.
id_00101.negated: For children with heatstroke, it is unreasonable to initiate other forms of active cooling, such as commercial ice packs, cold showers, ice sheets and towels, cooling vests and jackets, and evaporative, fanning, or a combination of techniques when water immersion is not available.

id_00646.original: In asymptomatic patients with nonobstructive HCM, the benefit of beta blockers or calcium channel blockers is not well established.
id_00646.negated: In asymptomatic patients with nonobstructive HCM, the benefit of beta blockers or calcium channel blockers is well established.

id_00073.original: Emergency services should be called if a person bitten by a spider or stung by a scorpion develops symptoms throughout the body such as difficulty breathing, muscle rigidity, dizziness, or confusion.
id_00073.negated: Emergency services should not be called if a person bitten by a spider or stung by a scorpion develops symptoms throughout the body such as difficulty breathing, muscle rigidity, dizziness, or confusion.

id_01634.original: In patients with cardiomyopathy, a 3-generation family history should be obtained or updated when assessing the cause of the cardiomyopa- thy to identify possible inherited disease.13,14
id_01634.negated: In patients with cardiomyopathy, there is no need to obtain or update a 3-generation family history when assessing the cause of the cardiomyopathy, as identifying possible inherited disease is unnecessary.

id_02685.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, multidisci- plinary rehabilitation, including regular team meetings and discharge planning, should be performed to improve functional outcome and reduce morbidity and mortality.231,232
id_02685.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, multidisciplinary rehabilitation, including regular team meetings and discharge planning, should not be performed as it does not improve functional outcome or reduce morbidity and mortality.

id_00609.original: For patients with HCM who have undergone genetic testing and were found to have no pathogenic variants (ie, harbor only benign or likely benign variants), cascade genetic testing of the family is not useful.4,8–10
id_00609.negated: For patients with HCM who have undergone genetic testing and were found to have no pathogenic variants (ie, harbor only benign or likely benign variants), cascade genetic testing of the family is useful.

id_01126.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and cystathionine β-synthase deficiency, pyridoxine (in responsive patients) and a low-methionine, cysteine-enhanced diet supplemented with pyridoxine, vitamin B12, and folate are recommended to reduce plasma homocysteine to population normal levels and thereby reduce the risk of recurrent ischemic stroke.739,740
id_01126.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and cystathionine β-synthase deficiency, pyridoxine (in responsive patients) and a low-methionine, cysteine-enhanced diet supplemented with pyridoxine, vitamin B12, and folate are not recommended, as they do not reduce plasma homocysteine to population normal levels or decrease the risk of recurrent ischemic stroke.

id_02114.original: In patients with symptomatic severe stenosis of a bioprosthetic or mechanical prosthetic valve, repeat surgical intervention is indicated unless surgical risk is high or prohibitive.1–3
id_02114.negated: In patients with symptomatic severe stenosis of a bioprosthetic or mechanical prosthetic valve, repeat surgical intervention is not indicated even if surgical risk is low.

id_02566.original: We recommend all adults who do not follow commands after ROSC, irrespective of arrest location or presenting rhythm, receive treatment that includes a deliberate strategy for temperature control.
id_02566.negated: We recommend that adults who do not follow commands after ROSC, irrespective of arrest location or presenting rhythm, should not receive treatment that includes a deliberate strategy for temperature control.

id_02687.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH with moder- ate severity, early rehabilitation beginning 24 to 48 hours after onset (including ADL train- ing, stretching, functional task training) may be considered to improve functional outcome and reduce mortality.491,492
id_02687.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH with moderate severity, early rehabilitation beginning 24 to 48 hours after onset (including ADL training, stretching, functional task training) should not be considered to improve functional outcome and reduce mortality.

id_01060.original: In symptomatic patients at average or low risk of complications associated with endovascular intervention, when the ICA stenosis is ≥70% by noninvasive imaging or >50% by catheter-based imaging and the anticipated rate of periprocedural stroke or death is <6%, CAS may be considered as an alternative to CEA for stroke preven- tion, particularly in patients with significant cardiovascular comorbidities predispos- ing to cardiovascular complications with endarterectomy.375
id_01060.negated: In symptomatic patients at average or low risk of complications associated with endovascular intervention, when the ICA stenosis is <70% by noninvasive imaging or ≤50% by catheter-based imaging and the anticipated rate of periprocedural stroke or death is ≥6%, CAS should not be considered as an alternative to CEA for stroke prevention, particularly in patients without significant cardiovascular comorbidities predisposing to cardiovascular complications with endarterectomy.

id_02207.original: In patients who meet standard indications for intervention for VHD (replacement and repair) on the basis of symptoms and disease severity, intervention should be performed before elective noncardiac surgery to reduce perioperative risk if possible, depending on the urgency and risk of the noncardiac procedure.1
id_02207.negated: In patients who meet standard indications for intervention for VHD (replacement and repair) on the basis of symptoms and disease severity, intervention should not be performed before elective noncardiac surgery, regardless of the urgency and risk of the noncardiac procedure, even if it could reduce perioperative risk.

id_00129.original: Superficial wounds and abrasions should be thoroughly irrigated until there is no obvious debris or foreign matter in the wound.
id_00129.negated: Superficial wounds and abrasions should not be irrigated, even if there is obvious debris or foreign matter in the wound.

id_01154.original: In patients with newly diagnosed AF, a transthoracic echocardiogram1–4 to assess cardiac structure, laboratory testing to include a complete blood count, metabolic panel, and thyroid function,5–7 and when clinical suspicion exists, targeted testing to assess for other medical conditions associated with AF are recommended to determine stroke and bleeding risk factors, as well as underlying conditions that will guide further management.
id_01154.negated: In patients with newly diagnosed AF, it is not recommended to perform a transthoracic echocardiogram to assess cardiac structure, conduct laboratory testing including a complete blood count, metabolic panel, and thyroid function, or perform targeted testing for other medical conditions associated with AF, as these are not necessary to determine stroke and bleeding risk factors or underlying conditions for further management.

id_01089.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and IE, early valve surgery (during initial hospital- ization before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) may be considered in patients with an indication for surgery who have no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage or extensive neurological damage.466,467
id_01089.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and IE, early valve surgery should not be considered during initial hospitalization, even if there is an indication for surgery and no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage or extensive neurological damage.

id_01993.original: In symptomatic patients with severe AR (Stage D), aortic valve surgery is indicated regardless of LV systolic function.1–7
id_01993.negated: In symptomatic patients with severe AR (Stage D), aortic valve surgery is not indicated regardless of LV systolic function.

id_01155.original: In patients with newly diagnosed AF, protocolized testing for ischemia, acute coronary syndrome (ACS), and pulmonary embolism (PE) should not routinely be performed to assess the etiology of AF unless there are additional signs or symptoms to indicate those disorders.8–10
id_01155.negated: In patients with newly diagnosed AF, protocolized testing for ischemia, acute coronary syndrome (ACS), and pulmonary embolism (PE) should routinely be performed to assess the etiology of AF, even in the absence of additional signs or symptoms indicating those disorders.

id_02371.original: In patients with acute type A aortic dissection who have extensive destruction of the aortic root, a root aneurysm, or a known genetic aor- tic disorder, aortic root replacement is recom- mended with a mechanical or biological valved conduit.6-9
id_02371.negated: In patients with acute type A aortic dissection who have extensive destruction of the aortic root, a root aneurysm, or a known genetic aortic disorder, aortic root replacement with a mechanical or biological valved conduit is not recommended.

id_00581.original: In adult patients with suspected HCM, cardiac CT may be considered for diagnosis if the echocardiogram is not diagnostic and CMR imaging is unavailable.1–3
id_00581.negated: In adult patients with suspected HCM, cardiac CT should not be considered for diagnosis even if the echocardiogram is not diagnostic and CMR imaging is unavailable.

id_00167.original: A person experiencing epistaxis should sit with their head slightly forward with their nostrils pinched for 10 to 15 minutes.
id_00167.negated: A person experiencing epistaxis should lie down with their head tilted back and avoid pinching their nostrils.

id_02208.original: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or greater degrees of AS and normal LV systolic function, it is reasonable to perform elective noncardiac surgery.1–3
id_02208.negated: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or greater degrees of AS and normal LV systolic function, it is not reasonable to perform elective noncardiac surgery.

id_01569.original: In patients with suspected moderate or severe AS who are undergoing elevated-risk NCS, preoperative echocardiography is recommended before elective NCS to guide perioperative management.*
id_01569.negated: In patients with suspected moderate or severe AS who are undergoing elevated-risk NCS, preoperative echocardiography is not recommended before elective NCS to guide perioperative management.

id_01033.original: In patients with TIA or ischemic stroke, it is reasonable to screen for prediabetes/dia- betes using HbA1c which, among available methods (HbA1c, fasting plasma glucose, oral glucose tolerance), has the advantage of convenience because it does not require fast- ing and is measured in a single blood sample.
id_01033.negated: In patients with TIA or ischemic stroke, it is unreasonable to screen for prediabetes/diabetes using HbA1c, as it lacks the convenience of other methods that require fasting and multiple blood samples.

id_01606.original: In patients with CAD but without prior PCI who are undergoing elective noncarotid NCS, routine initiation of aspirin is not beneficial.27,36 *Platelet adenosine diphosphate receptor (P2Y12) monotherapy may be con­ sidered if surgical bleeding risks are acceptable or if aspirin is not tolerated.
id_01606.negated: In patients with CAD but without prior PCI who are undergoing elective noncarotid NCS, routine initiation of aspirin is beneficial. Platelet adenosine diphosphate receptor (P2Y12) monotherapy should not be considered, regardless of surgical bleeding risks or aspirin tolerance.

id_02594.original: In patients with potential spontaneous ICH, first responder training in stroke evaluation and care with the ability to provide airway and circulatory support when necessary is reason- able to detect and manage prehospital neuro- logical deterioration (ND).48,49
id_02594.negated: In patients with potential spontaneous ICH, it is not advisable for first responders to be trained in stroke evaluation and care, nor should they be equipped to provide airway and circulatory support, as this is not necessary to detect and manage prehospital neurological deterioration (ND).

id_01061.original: In patients with a recent stroke or TIA (past 6 months), the usefulness of transcarotid artery revascularization (TCAR) for prevention of recurrent stroke and TIA is uncertain.376
id_01061.negated: In patients with a recent stroke or TIA (past 6 months), transcarotid artery revascularization (TCAR) is clearly beneficial for the prevention of recurrent stroke and TIA.

id_00452.original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and known CAD who have new onset or worsening symptoms, stress imaging (PET/ SPECT MPI, CMR, or stress echocardiography) is reasonable.18-21
id_00452.negated: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and known CAD who have new onset or worsening symptoms, stress imaging (PET/ SPECT MPI, CMR, or stress echocardiography) is not reasonable.

id_01248.original: In patients with AF undergoing elective cardiover- sion, with longer duration of AF or unsuccessful initial shock, optimization of electrode vector, use of higher energy, and pretreatment with antiarrhythmic drugs can facilitate success of electrical cardioversion.5–9
id_01248.negated: In patients with AF undergoing elective cardioversion, with longer duration of AF or unsuccessful initial shock, avoiding optimization of electrode vector, using lower energy, and not pretreating with antiarrhythmic drugs can hinder the success of electrical cardioversion.

id_01513.original: In young adults with CCD, after optimization of traditional cardiovascular risk factors, a compre- hensive evaluation and treatment of nontraditional cardiovascular risk factors can be beneficial in reducing the risk of cardiovascular events.1–3
id_01513.negated: In young adults with CCD, after optimization of traditional cardiovascular risk factors, a comprehensive evaluation and treatment of nontraditional cardiovascular risk factors is not beneficial in reducing the risk of cardiovascular events.

id_02529.original: In patients hospitalized with COVID-19, treat- ment with full-dose anticoagulation (eg, enoxa- parin, apixaban) is not recommended to prevent stroke.489,490
id_02529.negated: In patients hospitalized with COVID-19, treatment with full-dose anticoagulation (e.g., enoxaparin, apixaban) is recommended to prevent stroke.

id_01728.original: For patients whose comorbidities or frailty limit survival with good functional capacity to <1 year, ICD and cardiac resynchronization therapy with defibrillation (CRT-D) are not indi- cated.1–9,16–21
id_01728.negated: For patients whose comorbidities or frailty limit survival with good functional capacity to <1 year, ICD and cardiac resynchronization therapy with defibrillation (CRT-D) are indicated.

id_02021.original: In asymptomatic patients with severe rheumatic MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage C) and favorable valve morphology with less than 2+/ MR* in the absence of LA thrombus who have new onset of AF, PMBC may be considered if it can be performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.15
id_02021.negated: In asymptomatic patients with severe rheumatic MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage C) and favorable valve morphology with less than 2+/ MR in the absence of LA thrombus who have new onset of AF, PMBC should not be considered even if it can be performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

id_00130.original: A superficial wound caused by an animal or human bite or with contamination with human or animal saliva should be evaluated in a medical facility as soon as possible.
id_00130.negated: A superficial wound caused by an animal or human bite or with contamination with human or animal saliva does not need to be evaluated in a medical facility.

id_00647.original: For younger (eg, ≤45 years of age) patients with nonobstructive HCM due to a pathogenic or likely pathogenic cardiac sarcomere genetic variant, and a mild phenotype,* valsartan may be beneficial to slow adverse cardiac remodeling.8 *Mild phenotype indicates NYHA functional class I or II, maximal LV wall thick- ness 13 to 25 mm, no secondary prevention ICDs, no history of appropriate ICD shocks, and no AF.
id_00647.negated: For younger (eg, ≤45 years of age) patients with nonobstructive HCM due to a pathogenic or likely pathogenic cardiac sarcomere genetic variant, and a mild phenotype, valsartan is unlikely to be beneficial in slowing adverse cardiac remodeling.

id_01892.original: In patients with CLTI with ischemic rest pain (ie, with- out nonhealing wounds or gangrene) attributable to multilevel arterial disease, a revascularization strategy addressing inflow disease first is reasonable.34,35
id_01892.negated: In patients with CLTI with ischemic rest pain (ie, without nonhealing wounds or gangrene) attributable to multilevel arterial disease, it is unreasonable to address inflow disease first in a revascularization strategy.

id_02473.original: In adults who are ≥60 years of age and have uncontrolled BP (systolic BP [SBP] ≥140 mm Hg if taking antihypertensive medication or ≥160 mm Hg if not), compared with using 100% sodium chloride, salt substitution (75% sodium chloride and 25% potassium chloride) is reasonable to reduce the risk of incident stroke.88
id_02473.negated: In adults who are ≥60 years of age and have uncontrolled BP (systolic BP [SBP] ≥140 mm Hg if taking antihypertensive medication or ≥160 mm Hg if not), compared with using 100% sodium chloride, salt substitution (75% sodium chloride and 25% potassium chloride) is not reasonable to reduce the risk of incident stroke.

id_01127.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and Anderson-Fabry disease, agalsidase alfa or agalsidase beta is of uncertain value in preventing recurrent stroke or TIA.741
id_01127.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and Anderson-Fabry disease, agalsidase alfa or agalsidase beta is definitively valuable in preventing recurrent stroke or TIA.

id_01541.original: In patients undergoing NCS with a preoperative ECG exhibiting new abnormalities,† further evalu­ ation is reasonable to refine assessment of cardio­ vascular risk.3–8
id_01541.negated: In patients undergoing NCS with a preoperative ECG exhibiting new abnormalities, further evaluation to refine assessment of cardiovascular risk is not necessary.

id_01635.original: In patients presenting with HF, a thorough history and physical examination should direct diagnos- tic strategies to uncover specific causes that may warrant disease-specific management.15,16
id_01635.negated: In patients presenting with HF, a thorough history and physical examination should not be used to guide diagnostic strategies to uncover specific causes that may warrant disease-specific management.

id_02501.original: In the asymptomatic population, routine screen- ing for carotid artery stenosis is not recom- mended to reduce the risk of stroke.306,307 Other interventions
id_02501.negated: In the asymptomatic population, routine screening for carotid artery stenosis is recommended to reduce the risk of stroke.

id_00610.original: Ongoing clinical screening is not indicated in genotype-negative relatives in families with genotype-positive HCM, unless the disease- causing variant is downgraded to a VUS, likely benign, or benign variant during follow-up.23,29–32 *Strong evidence HCM genes include, at the time of this publication: MYH7,
id_00610.negated: Ongoing clinical screening is indicated in genotype-negative relatives in families with genotype-positive HCM, even if the disease-causing variant is downgraded to a VUS, likely benign, or benign variant during follow-up.

id_00032.original: First aid providers should activate EMS for individuals with first-time seizure; seizures last- ing >5 minutes; >1 seizure that occurs without the person returning to baseline mental status in between; seizures occurring in the water; seizures with traumatic injuries, difficulty breathing, or choking; seizure in an infant <6 months of age; seizure in pregnant individuals; or if the individual does not return to baseline within 5 to 10 minutes once seizure activity has stopped.
id_00032.negated: First aid providers should not activate EMS for individuals with first-time seizure; seizures lasting >5 minutes; >1 seizure that occurs without the person returning to baseline mental status in between; seizures occurring in the water; seizures with traumatic injuries, difficulty breathing, or choking; seizure in an infant <6 months of age; seizure in pregnant individuals; or if the individual does not return to baseline within 5 to 10 minutes once seizure activity has stopped.

id_00074.original: A person bitten by a spider or stung by a scorpion should seek medical care if pain extends beyond the site of the bite/sting, becomes severe, and is not controlled by over-the-counter pain medica- tions; if an open wound develops; or if the person experiences symptoms throughout the body.
id_00074.negated: A person bitten by a spider or stung by a scorpion should not seek medical care if pain extends beyond the site of the bite/sting, becomes severe, and is not controlled by over-the-counter pain medications; if an open wound develops; or if the person experiences symptoms throughout the body.

id_02086.original: For all patients with a bioprosthetic SAVR or mitral valve replacement, aspirin 75 to 100 mg daily is reasonable in the absence of other indications for oral anticoagulants.9,15–18
id_02086.negated: For all patients with a bioprosthetic SAVR or mitral valve replacement, aspirin 75 to 100 mg daily is not reasonable, even in the absence of other indications for oral anticoagulants.

id_01542.original: For asymptomatic patients undergoing elevated-risk surgeries without known CVD, a preoperative rest­ ing 12-lead ECG may be considered to establish a baseline and guide perioperative management.3,9,10
id_01542.negated: For asymptomatic patients undergoing elevated-risk surgeries without known CVD, a preoperative resting 12-lead ECG should not be considered to establish a baseline and guide perioperative management.

id_02688.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH without depression, fluoxetine therapy is not effective to enhance poststroke functional status.493–497
id_02688.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH without depression, fluoxetine therapy is effective to enhance poststroke functional status.

id_02049.original: In patients with chronic severe secondary MR related to LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF <50%) who have persistent symptoms (NYHA class II, III, or IV) while on optimal GDMT for HF (Stage D), TEER is reasonable in patients with appropriate anatomy as defined on TEE and with LVEF between 20% and 50%, LVESD ≤70 mm, and pulmonary artery systolic pressure ≤70 mm Hg.1–8
id_02049.negated: In patients with chronic severe secondary MR related to LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF <50%) who have persistent symptoms (NYHA class II, III, or IV) while on optimal GDMT for HF (Stage D), TEER is not reasonable in patients with appropriate anatomy as defined on TEE and with LVEF between 20% and 50%, LVESD ≤70 mm, and pulmonary artery systolic pressure ≤70 mm Hg.

id_01412.original: In patients with CCD, ICA for risk stratification is not routinely recommended in patients without LV systolic dysfunction, heart failure, stable chest pain refractory to GDMT, and/or noninvasive testing sug- gestive of significant (>50%) left main disease.5–7,10,11 *Modified from the 2021 AHA/ACC/Multisociety Guideline for the Evaluation and Diagnosis of Chest Pain.12
id_01412.negated: In patients with CCD, ICA for risk stratification is routinely recommended in patients without LV systolic dysfunction, heart failure, stable chest pain refractory to GDMT, and/or noninvasive testing suggestive of significant (>50%) left main disease.

id_01062.original: In patients with recent TIA or ischemic stroke and when the degree of stenosis is <50%, revascularization with CEA or CAS to reduce the risk of future stroke is not recom- mended.369
id_01062.negated: In patients with recent TIA or ischemic stroke and when the degree of stenosis is <50%, revascularization with CEA or CAS to reduce the risk of future stroke is recommended.

id_02115.original: For severely symptomatic patients with bioprosthetic aortic valve stenosis and high or prohibitive surgical risk, a transcatheter ViV procedure is reasonable when performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.4,5
id_02115.negated: For severely symptomatic patients with bioprosthetic aortic valve stenosis and high or prohibitive surgical risk, a transcatheter ViV procedure is not reasonable when performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

id_02567.original: We recommend selecting and maintaining a constant temperature between 32° C and 37.5° C during postarrest temperature control.
id_02567.negated: We recommend avoiding a constant temperature between 32°C and 37.5°C during postarrest temperature control.

id_00195.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS and cardiogenic shock who are appropriate candidates for revascularization, emergency revascular- ization is recommended to reduce risk of death.5-9
id_00195.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS and cardiogenic shock who are appropriate candidates for revascularization, emergency revascularization is not recommended to reduce risk of death.

id_00675.original: For pilot aircrew with a diagnosis of HCM, it is reasonable to follow Federal Aviation Administration guidelines that permit consideration of multicrew flying duties, provided they are asymptomatic, are deemed low risk for SCD, and can complete a maxi- mal treadmill stress test at 85% peak heart rate.2
id_00675.negated: For pilot aircrew with a diagnosis of HCM, it is not reasonable to follow Federal Aviation Administration guidelines that permit consideration of multicrew flying duties, even if they are asymptomatic, are deemed low risk for SCD, and can complete a maximal treadmill stress test at 85% peak heart rate.

id_00288.original: In patients undergoing CABG, who do not have a contraindication to beta blockers, preoperative use of beta blockers may be effective in reducing in-hospital and 30-day mortality rates.12-18
id_00288.negated: In patients undergoing CABG, who do not have a contraindication to beta blockers, preoperative use of beta blockers may not be effective in reducing in-hospital and 30-day mortality rates.

id_01514.original: In patients with CCD and cancer, a multidisciplinary team including cardiology and oncology expertise is recommended to improve long-term CVD out- comes.1,2
id_01514.negated: In patients with CCD and cancer, it is not recommended to involve a multidisciplinary team with cardiology and oncology expertise, as it does not improve long-term CVD outcomes.

id_01570.original: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or severe AS and normal LV systolic function as assessed by echocardiography within the past year, it is reason­ able to proceed with elective low-risk NCS.3–5 *Modified from the “2020 ACC/AHA Guideline for the Management of Pa­ tients With Valvular Heart Disease.”6
id_01570.negated: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or severe AS and normal LV systolic function as assessed by echocardiography within the past year, it is not reasonable to proceed with elective low-risk NCS.

id_02372.original: In patients with acute type A aortic dissec- tion undergoing aortic repair, an open distal anastomosis is recommended to improve survival and increase false-lumen thrombosis rates.12-15
id_02372.negated: In patients with acute type A aortic dissection undergoing aortic repair, an open distal anastomosis is not recommended as it does not improve survival or increase false-lumen thrombosis rates.

id_01156.original: Among individuals without a known history of AF, it is recommended that an initial AF diagnosis be made by a clinician using visual interpretation of the electrocardiographic signals, regardless of the type of rhythm or monitoring device.1–5
id_01156.negated: Among individuals without a known history of AF, it is not recommended that an initial AF diagnosis be made by a clinician using visual interpretation of the electrocardiographic signals, regardless of the type of rhythm or monitoring device.

id_01607.original: For patients with CVD receiving OAC who require elective NCS, a multidisciplinary team-based approach to time-based* interruption is recom­ mended to balance the competing risks of thromboembolism and perioperative bleeding (Tables 13 and 14).1–7 OAC Bridging
id_01607.negated: For patients with CVD receiving OAC who require elective NCS, it is not recommended to use a multidisciplinary team-based approach to time-based interruption, disregarding the risks of thromboembolism and perioperative bleeding.

id_00102.original: It may be reasonable for first aid providers, who are trained and willing, to measure core temperature during active cooling for heatstroke. The target core temperature to cool until is 39° C (102.2° F). Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00102.negated: It is not advisable for first aid providers to measure core temperature during active cooling for heatstroke, and they should not aim to cool until a core temperature of 39°C (102.2°F).

id_02209.original: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or greater degrees of rheumatic MS with less than severe pulmonary hypertension (pulmonary artery systolic pressure <50 mm Hg), it is reasonable to perform elective noncardiac surgery.
id_02209.negated: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or greater degrees of rheumatic MS with less than severe pulmonary hypertension (pulmonary artery systolic pressure <50 mm Hg), it is not reasonable to perform elective noncardiac surgery.

id_00033.original: First aid providers should minimize the risk of injury to the individual who is having a seizure by helping the person to the ground, placing the person on their side in the recovery position, and clearing the area around them.
id_00033.negated: First aid providers should increase the risk of injury to the individual who is having a seizure by leaving the person standing, keeping them on their back, and cluttering the area around them.

id_01090.original: In patients with IE and major ischemic stroke, delaying valve surgery for at least 4 weeks may be considered for patients with IE and major ischemic stroke or intracranial hemorrhage if the patient is hemodynamically stable.460,468
id_01090.negated: In patients with IE and major ischemic stroke, immediate valve surgery should be considered regardless of hemodynamic stability.

id_02087.original: For patients with a bioprosthetic SAVR or mitral valve replacement who are at low risk of bleeding, anticoagulation with a VKA to achieve an INR of 2.5 is reasonable for at least 3 months and for as long as 6 months after surgical replacement.15,19–25
id_02087.negated: For patients with a bioprosthetic SAVR or mitral valve replacement who are at low risk of bleeding, it is not reasonable to use anticoagulation with a VKA to achieve an INR of 2.5 for any period after surgical replacement.

id_00582.original: In patients with HCM, a 12-lead ECG is recommended in the initial evaluation and as part of periodic follow-up (every 1-2 years) (Figure 1, Table 7).1–3
id_00582.negated: In patients with HCM, a 12-lead ECG is not recommended in the initial evaluation nor as part of periodic follow-up.

id_01034.original: In patients with an ischemic stroke or TIA who also have diabetes, the usefulness of achieving intensive glucose control (ie, HbA1c ≤7%) beyond the acute phase of the ischemic event for prevention of recurrent stroke is unknown.239–244
id_01034.negated: In patients with an ischemic stroke or TIA who also have diabetes, achieving intensive glucose control (ie, HbA1c ≤7%) beyond the acute phase of the ischemic event is known to prevent recurrent stroke.

id_00196.original: In appropriate patients with NSTE-ACS who have refractory angina or hemody- namic or electrical instability, an immediate invasive strategy with intent to perform revascularization is indicated to improve outcomes.10
id_00196.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS who have refractory angina or hemodynamic or electrical instability, an immediate invasive strategy with intent to perform revascularization is not indicated to improve outcomes.

id_02050.original: In patients with severe secondary MR (Stages C and D), mitral valve surgery is reasonable when CABG is undertaken for the treatment of myocardial ischemia.9–15
id_02050.negated: In patients with severe secondary MR (Stages C and D), mitral valve surgery is not reasonable when CABG is undertaken for the treatment of myocardial ischemia.

id_00648.original: In patients with HCM who develop systolic dysfunction with an LVEF <50%, GDMT for HF with reduced EF is recommended.1–3
id_00648.negated: In patients with HCM who develop systolic dysfunction with an LVEF <50%, GDMT for HF with reduced EF is not recommended.

id_02502.original: In patients with asymptomatic carotid artery stenosis (ACS) >70%, shared decision-making between the patient and the health care team to decide between the 2 courses of treatment (carotid revascularization or medical manage- ment) is recommended to determine the best method of reducing stroke risk.
id_02502.negated: In patients with asymptomatic carotid artery stenosis (ACS) >70%, it is not recommended to engage in shared decision-making between the patient and the health care team to decide between carotid revascularization or medical management for reducing stroke risk.

id_00453.original: For patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS who have new ischemic changes on electrocardiography, troponin- confirmed acute myocardial injury, new- onset left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction <40%), newly diagnosed moderate-severe ischemia on stress testing, hemodynamic instability, and/or a high clinical decision pathway (CDP) risk score should be designated as high risk for short-term MACE.1-3
id_00453.negated: For patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS who have new ischemic changes on electrocardiography, troponin-confirmed acute myocardial injury, new-onset left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction <40%), newly diagnosed moderate-severe ischemia on stress testing, hemodynamic instability, and/or a high clinical decision pathway (CDP) risk score should not be designated as high risk for short-term MACE.

id_02474.original: In adults, folic acid supplementation and B- complex (folic acid, B12, B6) vitamins supplementa- tion for reducing the risk of stroke are not well established.89–91
id_02474.negated: In adults, folic acid supplementation and B-complex (folic acid, B12, B6) vitamins supplementation are well established for reducing the risk of stroke.

id_02530.original: In all adults, screening for substance misuse and substance use disorders (eg, alcohol, cannabis, cocaine, opioids, amphetamines) is recommended to inform stroke risk.506–520 Other interventions
id_02530.negated: In all adults, screening for substance misuse and substance use disorders (eg, alcohol, cannabis, cocaine, opioids, amphetamines) is not recommended to inform stroke risk.

id_00289.original: In patients undergoing CABG, the role of preop- erative beta blockers for the prevention of acute postoperative myocardial ischemia, stroke, AKI, or ventricular arrhythmia is uncertain.12-14,18
id_00289.negated: In patients undergoing CABG, preoperative beta blockers are definitively recommended for the prevention of acute postoperative myocardial ischemia, stroke, AKI, or ventricular arrhythmia.

id_00168.original: A person experiencing epistaxis that does not stop after 15 minutes of continuous manual pressure or who becomes lightheaded from epistaxis should seek medical attention.
id_00168.negated: A person experiencing epistaxis that does not stop after 15 minutes of continuous manual pressure or who becomes lightheaded from epistaxis should not seek medical attention.

id_02593.original: In patients with potential stroke, including spontaneous ICH, in geographic regions where mobile stroke units (MSUs) operate, such mobile units are reasonable to enable more rapid diagnosis and treatment than achievable by ambulance transfer to the clos- est stroke-capable facility.46,47
id_02593.negated: In patients with potential stroke, including spontaneous ICH, in geographic regions where mobile stroke units (MSUs) operate, it is unreasonable to use such mobile units for more rapid diagnosis and treatment, and ambulance transfer to the closest stroke-capable facility should be preferred.

id_00103.original: In the absence of shock, confusion, or inability to swallow, first aid providers should assist or encourage individuals with exertional dehydration to orally rehydrate with any available rehydration drink or potable water.
id_00103.negated: In the presence of shock, confusion, or inability to swallow, first aid providers should discourage individuals with exertional dehydration from orally rehydrating with any available rehydration drink or potable water.

id_01729.original: In selected patients with HF, reduced EF (EF ≤35%), and suitable coronary anatomy, surgical revascularization plus GDMT is beneficial to improve symptoms, cardiovascular hospitaliza- tions, and long-term all-cause mortality.1–8
id_01729.negated: In patients with HF, reduced EF (EF ≤35%), and suitable coronary anatomy, surgical revascularization plus GDMT is not beneficial for improving symptoms, reducing cardiovascular hospitalizations, or decreasing long-term all-cause mortality.

id_01994.original: In asymptomatic patients with chronic severe AR and LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF ≤55%) (Stage C2), aortic valve surgery is indicated if no other cause for systolic dysfunction is identified.3,5,8–12
id_01994.negated: In asymptomatic patients with chronic severe AR and LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF ≤55%) (Stage C2), aortic valve surgery is not indicated even if no other cause for systolic dysfunction is identified.

id_02595.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, focused history, physical examination, and routine labo- ratory work and tests on hospital admission (eg, complete blood count, prothrombin time/ international normalized ratio [INR]/partial thromboplastin time, creatinine/estimated glomerular filtration rate, glucose, cardiac tro- ponin and ECG, toxicology screen, and inflam- matory markers) should be performed to help identify the type of hemorrhage, active medical issues, and risk of unfavorable outcomes.67–72
id_02595.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, it is unnecessary to perform focused history, physical examination, or routine laboratory work and tests on hospital admission (eg, complete blood count, prothrombin time/international normalized ratio [INR]/partial thromboplastin time, creatinine/estimated glomerular filtration rate, glucose, cardiac troponin and ECG, toxicology screen, and inflammatory markers) as they do not aid in identifying the type of hemorrhage, active medical issues, or risk of unfavorable outcomes.

id_01413.original: In patients with CCD, clinical follow-up at least annually is recommended to assess for symptoms,1–12 change in functional status, adherence to and adequacy of lifestyle and medical interventions,13–15 and monitoring for complications of CCD and its treatments.16–18
id_01413.negated: In patients with CCD, clinical follow-up less frequently than annually is not recommended to assess for symptoms, change in functional status, adherence to and adequacy of lifestyle and medical interventions, and monitoring for complications of CCD and its treatments.

id_00131.original: It is reasonable to use running tap water or sterile saline solutions for wound irrigation instead of antiseptic agents such as povidone-iodine.
id_00131.negated: It is reasonable to use antiseptic agents such as povidone-iodine for wound irrigation instead of running tap water or sterile saline solutions.

id_01063.original: In patients with a recent (within 120 days) TIA or ischemic stroke ipsilateral to atherosclerotic stenosis or occlusion of the middle cerebral or carotid artery, extracranial- intracranial bypass surgery is not recom- mended.377
id_01063.negated: In patients with a recent (within 120 days) TIA or ischemic stroke ipsilateral to atherosclerotic stenosis or occlusion of the middle cerebral or carotid artery, extracranial-intracranial bypass surgery is recommended.

id_01608.original: In patients with CVD and high thrombotic risk (Table 14) undergoing NCS where interruption of vitamin K antagonist (VKA) is required, preoperative bridging with parenteral heparin can be effective to reduce thromboembolic risk.8–10
id_01608.negated: In patients with CVD and high thrombotic risk undergoing NCS where interruption of vitamin K antagonist is required, preoperative bridging with parenteral heparin should not be used to reduce thromboembolic risk.

id_01893.original: Patients with CLTI and diabetic foot ulcers should receive pressure offloading, when possible, to promote tissue growth and wound healing.1–9
id_01893.negated: Patients with CLTI and diabetic foot ulcers should avoid pressure offloading to hinder tissue growth and wound healing.

id_02689.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, very early and intense mobilization within the first 24 hours is associated with lower likelihood of good recovery.498,499
id_02689.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, very early and intense mobilization within the first 24 hours is associated with a higher likelihood of good recovery.

id_01636.original: In patients presenting with HF, a thorough history and physical examination should be obtained and performed to identify cardiac and noncardiac disorders, lifestyle and behavioral factors, and social determinants of health that might cause or accelerate the development or progression of HF.
id_01636.negated: In patients presenting with HF, it is unnecessary to obtain a thorough history or perform a physical examination to identify cardiac and noncardiac disorders, lifestyle and behavioral factors, and social determinants of health that might cause or accelerate the development or progression of HF.

id_01128.original: In patients with carotid web in the distribu- tion of ischemic stroke and TIA, without other attributable causes of stroke, antiplatelet therapy is recommended to prevent recurrent ischemic stroke or TIA.748,749
id_01128.negated: In patients with carotid web in the distribution of ischemic stroke and TIA, without other attributable causes of stroke, antiplatelet therapy is not recommended to prevent recurrent ischemic stroke or TIA.

id_00676.original: It is reasonable for patients with HCM to consider occupations that require manual labor, heavy lifting, or a high level of physical performance after a comprehensive clinical evaluation, risk stratification for SCD, and implementation of GDMT in the con- text of shared decision-making.
id_00676.negated: It is unreasonable for patients with HCM to consider occupations that require manual labor, heavy lifting, or a high level of physical performance, regardless of a comprehensive clinical evaluation, risk stratification for SCD, and implementation of GDMT in the context of shared decision-making.

id_00611.original: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, serial clinical assess- ment, electrocardiography, and cardiac imaging are recommended at periodic intervals depending on age (every 1-2 years in children and adolescents and every 3-5 years in adults) and change in clinical status (Figures 1 and 2, Table 7).1–5
id_00611.negated: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, serial clinical assessment, electrocardiography, and cardiac imaging are not recommended at periodic intervals regardless of age or change in clinical status.

id_01515.original: Women with CCD who are contemplating preg- nancy or who are pregnant should be risk-stratified and counseled regarding risks of adverse maternal, obstetric, and fetal outcomes.1–4
id_01515.negated: Women with CCD who are contemplating pregnancy or who are pregnant should not be risk-stratified or counseled regarding risks of adverse maternal, obstetric, and fetal outcomes.

id_01249.original: In patients with obesity and AF, use of manual pressure augmentation and/or further escalation of electrical energy may be beneficial to improve suc- cess of electrical cardioversion.10
id_01249.negated: In patients with obesity and AF, avoid using manual pressure augmentation and/or further escalation of electrical energy, as it may not improve the success of electrical cardioversion.

id_01543.original: For asymptomatic patients undergoing low-risk surgi­ cal procedures, a routine preoperative resting 12-lead ECG is not recommended to improve outcomes.11 *Active symptoms and signs of CVD include chest pain, dyspnea, undiagnosed palpitations, tachycardia, syncope, or murmurs. †Abnormalities may include ST-segment elevation, ST depression, T-wave inversions, left ventricular (LV) hypertrophy, significant pathologic Q-waves, Mo­ bitz type II or higher atrioventricular block, bundle branch block, QT prolonga­ tion, or AF.
id_01543.negated: For asymptomatic patients undergoing low-risk surgical procedures, a routine preoperative resting 12-lead ECG is recommended to improve outcomes.

id_00169.original: A person with epistaxis due to trauma should seek medical attention if they experience signs of brain in- jury, obvious nasal deformity, or signs of facial fracture.
id_00169.negated: A person with epistaxis due to trauma should not seek medical attention even if they experience signs of brain injury, obvious nasal deformity, or signs of facial fracture.

id_01995.original: In patients with severe AR (Stage C or D) who are undergoing cardiac surgery for other indications, aortic valve surgery is indicated.
id_01995.negated: In patients with severe AR (Stage C or D) who are undergoing cardiac surgery for other indications, aortic valve surgery is not indicated.

id_00583.original: In patients with HCM, 24- to 48-hour ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring is recommended in the initial evaluation and as part of periodic follow-up (every 1-2 years) to identify patients who are at risk for SCD and to guide management of arrhythmias (Figure 1).4–6
id_00583.negated: In patients with HCM, 24- to 48-hour ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring is not recommended in the initial evaluation or as part of periodic follow-up to identify patients who are at risk for SCD or to guide management of arrhythmias.

id_02475.original: In adults without prior CVD, long-chain fatty acids are not effective for reducing the risk of stroke.89,91–96
id_02475.negated: In adults without prior CVD, long-chain fatty acids are effective for reducing the risk of stroke.

id_01091.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and mechanical heart valves, treatment with dabigatran causes harm.*457 *A similar recommendation in another guideline is worded slightly differently; however, the process used to reach consensus was the same in both cases.
id_01091.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and mechanical heart valves, treatment with dabigatran is beneficial.

id_02116.original: For patients with significant bioprosthetic valve stenosis attributable to suspected or documented valve thrombosis, oral anticoagulation with a VKA is reasonable.6–13
id_02116.negated: For patients with significant bioprosthetic valve stenosis attributable to suspected or documented valve thrombosis, oral anticoagulation with a VKA is not reasonable.

id_00132.original: It is reasonable to cover clean superficial wounds and abrasions with an occlusive dressing to promote wound healing.
id_00132.negated: It is not reasonable to cover clean superficial wounds and abrasions with an occlusive dressing to promote wound healing.

id_02022.original: In symptomatic patients (NYHA class II, III, or IV) with rheumatic MS and an mitral valve area >1.5 cm2, if there is evidence of hemodynamically significant rheumatic MS on the basis of a pulmonary artery wedge pressure >25 mm Hg or a mean mitral valve gradient >15 mm Hg during exercise, PMBC may be considered if it can be performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.16
id_02022.negated: In symptomatic patients (NYHA class II, III, or IV) with rheumatic MS and a mitral valve area >1.5 cm², if there is no evidence of hemodynamically significant rheumatic MS based on a pulmonary artery wedge pressure ≤25 mm Hg or a mean mitral valve gradient ≤15 mm Hg during exercise, PMBC should not be considered, even if it can be performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

id_00034.original: First aid providers should stay with the person having a seizure. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00034.negated: First aid providers should leave the person having a seizure unattended.

id_01637.original: For patients presenting with HF, the specific cause of HF should be explored using addi- tional laboratory testing for appropriate man- agement.1–8
id_01637.negated: For patients presenting with HF, the specific cause of HF should not be explored using additional laboratory testing for appropriate management.

id_00649.original: In patients with HCM and systolic dysfunction, diagnostic testing to assess for concomitant causes of systolic dysfunction (eg, CAD) is recommended.4,5
id_00649.negated: In patients with HCM and systolic dysfunction, diagnostic testing to assess for concomitant causes of systolic dysfunction (eg, CAD) is not recommended.

id_00677.original: For pregnant women with HCM and AF or other indications for anticoagulation, low-molecular-weight heparin or vitamin K antagonists (at maximum therapeutic dose of <5 mg daily) are recommended for stroke prevention.1,2 Recommendations for Occupation in Patients With HCM (Continued) COR LOE Recommendations Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00677.negated: For pregnant women with HCM and AF or other indications for anticoagulation, low-molecular-weight heparin or vitamin K antagonists should not be used for stroke prevention.

id_00075.original: Over-the-counter acetaminophen and nonsteroi- dal anti-inflammatory agents can be used to allevi- ate local pain from scorpion stings.
id_00075.negated: Over-the-counter acetaminophen and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents should not be used to alleviate local pain from scorpion stings.

id_00290.original: In selected patients undergoing PCI, shorter- duration DAPT (1–3 months) is reasonable, with subsequent transition to P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy to reduce the risk of bleeding events.1-4
id_00290.negated: In selected patients undergoing PCI, longer-duration DAPT (beyond 3 months) is reasonable, without transitioning to P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy, potentially increasing the risk of bleeding events.

id_01571.original: Patients with severe mitral stenosis (MS) should be evaluated for the need for mitral valve (MV) interven­ tion before elective NCS.1–17
id_01571.negated: Patients with severe mitral stenosis (MS) should not be evaluated for the need for mitral valve (MV) intervention before elective NCS.

id_02088.original: For patients with a mechanical SAVR or mitral valve replacement who are managed with a VKA and have an indication for antiplatelet therapy, addition of aspirin 75 to 100 mg daily may be considered when the risk of bleeding is low.26
id_02088.negated: For patients with a mechanical SAVR or mitral valve replacement who are managed with a VKA and have an indication for antiplatelet therapy, do not consider adding aspirin 75 to 100 mg daily, even when the risk of bleeding is low.

id_02373.original: In patients with acute type A aortic dissec- tion without an intimal tear in the arch or a significant arch aneurysm, hemiarch repair is recommended over more extensive arch replacement.16-18
id_02373.negated: In patients with acute type A aortic dissection without an intimal tear in the arch or a significant arch aneurysm, more extensive arch replacement is recommended over hemiarch repair.

id_02210.original: In asymptomatic patients with moderate or greater degrees of MR and normal LV systolic function with less than severe pulmonary hypertension (pulmonary artery systolic pressure <50 mm Hg), it is reasonable to perform elective noncardiac surgery.4–7
