id_00821.original: For patients <40 years of age with aSAH, clipping of the ruptured aneurysm might be considered the preferred mode of treatment to improve durability of the treatment and outcome.113,115 Modality of treatment: for aneurysms equally suitable for clipping and coiling
id_00821.negated: For patients <40 years of age with aSAH, clipping of the ruptured aneurysm should not be considered the preferred mode of treatment, as it does not improve durability of the treatment and outcome.

id_01338.original: It may be reasonable to administer atropine for β-blocker–induced bradycardia.
id_01338.negated: It is not advisable to administer atropine for β-blocker–induced bradycardia.

id_01437.original: Patients with CCD should not be advised to consume alcohol for the purpose of cardiovascular protection. 9,10 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01437.negated: Patients with CCD should be advised to consume alcohol for the purpose of cardiovascular protection.

id_02431.original: In patients with a BAV (in the absence of Turner syndrome or an HTAD) and an aortic diameter of ≥5.0 cm, surgery before preg- nancy is recommended.
id_02431.negated: In patients with a BAV (in the absence of Turner syndrome or an HTAD) and an aortic diameter of ≥5.0 cm, surgery before pregnancy is not recommended.

id_01021.original: In patients with hypertension who experience a stroke or TIA, individualized drug regimens that take into account patient comorbidities, agent pharmacological class, and patient preference are recommended to maximize drug efficacy.188,189,195,196
id_01021.negated: In patients with hypertension who experience a stroke or TIA, standardized drug regimens that ignore patient comorbidities, agent pharmacological class, and patient preference are recommended to minimize drug efficacy.

id_01660.original: In patients with HF, assessment and documen- tation of NYHA functional classification are recommended to determine eligibility for treat- ments.1–3
id_01660.negated: In patients with HF, assessment and documentation of NYHA functional classification are not recommended to determine eligibility for treatments.

id_01339.original: It may be reasonable to attempt electrical pacing for β-blocker–induced bradycardia.
id_01339.negated: It is not advisable to attempt electrical pacing for β-blocker–induced bradycardia.

id_02713.original: In patients with HCM in whom septal reduc- tion therapy (SRT) is indicated, the procedure should be performed at experienced centers (comprehensive or primary HCM centers) with demonstrated excellence in clinical out- comes for these procedures10–12 (Table 3 and
id_02713.negated: In patients with HCM in whom septal reduction therapy (SRT) is indicated, the procedure should be performed at centers without demonstrated excellence in clinical outcomes for these procedures.

id_02741.original: In patients with HCM with symptoms or evidence of myocardial ischemia, coronary angiography (CT or invasive) is recommended.110
id_02741.negated: In patients with HCM with symptoms or evidence of myocardial ischemia, coronary angiography (CT or invasive) is not recommended.

id_01951.original: In patients with signs or symptoms of AS or a BAV, TTE is indicated for accurate diagnosis of the cause of AS, assessment of hemodynamic severity, measurement of LV size and systolic function, and determination of prognosis and timing of valve intervention.1,2
id_01951.negated: In patients with signs or symptoms of AS or a BAV, TTE is not indicated for accurate diagnosis of the cause of AS, assessment of hemodynamic severity, measurement of LV size and systolic function, or determination of prognosis and timing of valve intervention.

id_01377.original: For patients known or suspected to be in cardiac arrest, in the absence of a proven benefit from the use of naloxone, standard resuscitative measures should take priority over naloxone administration, with a focus on high-quality CPR (compressions plus ventilation).
id_01377.negated: For patients known or suspected to be in cardiac arrest, naloxone administration should take priority over standard resuscitative measures, with less emphasis on high-quality CPR (compressions plus ventilation).

id_01020.original: In patients with hypertension who experience a stroke or TIA, an office BP goal of <130/80 mm Hg is recommended for most patients to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke and vascu- lar events.185,190–194
id_01020.negated: In patients with hypertension who experience a stroke or TIA, an office BP goal of ≥130/80 mm Hg is recommended for most patients, as it does not reduce the risk of recurrent stroke and vascular events.

id_02167.original: In asymptomatic women with severe AS (aortic velocity ≥4.0 m/s or mean pressure gradient ≥40 mm Hg, Stage C1) who are considering pregnancy, do not meet COR 1 criteria for intervention, and have a preconception evaluation confirming the absence of symptoms (including normal exercise stress testing and serum BNP measurements), medical management during pregnancy may be considered to avoid prosthetic valve replacement.
id_02167.negated: In asymptomatic women with severe AS who are considering pregnancy, and do not meet COR 1 criteria for intervention, prosthetic valve replacement should be considered during pregnancy regardless of preconception evaluation results.

id_01781.original: In patients with HF and suspicion of sleep-dis- ordered breathing, a formal sleep assessment is reasonable to confirm the diagnosis and differentiate between obstructive and central sleep apnea.9,10
id_01781.negated: In patients with HF and suspicion of sleep-disordered breathing, it is unreasonable to conduct a formal sleep assessment to confirm the diagnosis and differentiate between obstructive and central sleep apnea.

id_01918.original: In patients with ALI, testing for a cardiovascular cause of thromboembolism can be useful.1–4 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01918.negated: In patients with ALI, testing for a cardiovascular cause of thromboembolism is not useful.

id_00379.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS with MVD, the mode of revascularization (CABG or multivessel PCI) should be based on the disease complexity and patient’s comorbidities. Multivessel CAD and Candidates for PCI
id_00379.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS with MVD, the mode of revascularization (CABG or multivessel PCI) should not be based on the disease complexity and patient’s comorbidities.

id_02337.original: In patients with ruptured AAA, permissive hypotension can be beneficial to decrease the rate of bleeding.1,3,10-12
id_02337.negated: In patients with ruptured AAA, permissive hypotension should be avoided as it may increase the rate of bleeding.

id_01688.original: In patients with previous or current symptoms of chronic HFrEF, the use of ACEi is beneficial to reduce morbidity and mortality when the use of ARNi is not feasible.6–13
id_01688.negated: In patients with previous or current symptoms of chronic HFrEF, the use of ACEi is not beneficial to reduce morbidity and mortality when the use of ARNi is not feasible.

id_00221.original: In patients with multivessel CAD amenable to treatment with either PCI or CABG who are unable to access, tolerate, or adhere to DAPT for the appropriate duration of treatment, CABG is reasonable in preference to PCI.1-10
id_00221.negated: In patients with multivessel CAD amenable to treatment with either PCI or CABG who are unable to access, tolerate, or adhere to DAPT for the appropriate duration of treatment, PCI is reasonable in preference to CABG.

id_00314.original: Patients with cardiac arrest and STEMI who have been resuscitated should preferentially be transferred by EMS to a PPCI-capable center.1,2
id_00314.negated: Patients with cardiac arrest and STEMI who have been resuscitated should not be transferred by EMS to a PPCI-capable center.

id_01753.original: In select patients with advanced HFrEF who have NYHA class IV symptoms despite GDMT, durable MCS can be beneficial to improve symptoms, improve functional class, and reduce mortality.2,4,7,10,12–17,19 Value Statement: Uncertain Value (B-NR)
id_01753.negated: In select patients with advanced HFrEF who have NYHA class IV symptoms despite GDMT, durable MCS should not be used as it does not improve symptoms, improve functional class, or reduce mortality.

id_02298.original: In patients with a height >1 standard devia- tion above or below the mean who have an asymptomatic aneurysm of the aortic root or ascending aorta and a maximal cross- sectional aortic area/height ratio of ≥10 cm2/m, surgery is reasonable when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.14,15,22
id_02298.negated: In patients with a height within 1 standard deviation of the mean who have a symptomatic aneurysm of the aortic root or ascending aorta and a maximal cross-sectional aortic area/height ratio of <10 cm2/m, surgery is unreasonable when performed by inexperienced surgeons outside a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

id_02261.original: In patients with a BAV who have undergone previous aortic valve repair or replacement and have a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aortic, or both of ≥4.0 cm, lifelong surveillance imaging of the aortic root and ascending aorta by TTE, CT, or MRI is recom- mended at an interval dependent on aortic diameter and rate of growth.1-3
id_02261.negated: In patients with a BAV who have undergone previous aortic valve repair or replacement and have a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aortic, or both of ≥4.0 cm, lifelong surveillance imaging of the aortic root and ascending aorta by TTE, CT, or MRI is not recommended, regardless of aortic diameter and rate of growth.

id_02817.original: In patients with HCM and LVEF <50%, ICD placement can be beneficial.284
id_02817.negated: In patients with HCM and LVEF <50%, ICD placement is not beneficial.

id_00062.original: Cool compresses may be considered for relief of local symptoms from exposure to poison ivy, oak, or sumac.
id_00062.negated: Warm compresses should be considered for relief of local symptoms from exposure to poison ivy, oak, or sumac.

id_00859.original: For patients with aSAH at risk of DCI, prophylactic hemodynamic augmenta- tion should not be performed to reduce iatrogenic patient harm.189,211,349,350 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00859.negated: For patients with aSAH at risk of DCI, prophylactic hemodynamic augmentation should be performed despite the risk of iatrogenic patient harm.

id_02168.original: In asymptomatic women with severe MR (Stage C1) and a valve suitable for repair who are considering pregnancy, valve repair before pregnancy at a Comprehensive Valve Center may be considered but only after detailed discussion with the patient about the risks and benefits of the surgery and its effect on future pregnancies.
id_02168.negated: In asymptomatic women with severe MR (Stage C1) and a valve suitable for repair who are considering pregnancy, valve repair before pregnancy at a Comprehensive Valve Center should not be considered, regardless of any discussion with the patient about the risks and benefits of the surgery and its effect on future pregnancies.

id_01302.original: In adults with congenital heart disease and AF, it is recommended to evaluate for and treat precipitating factors and reversible causes of AF, recognizing that residual hemodynamic sequelae may contribute to the occurrence of the arrhythmia.1,2
id_01302.negated: In adults with congenital heart disease and AF, it is not recommended to evaluate for or treat precipitating factors and reversible causes of AF, disregarding that residual hemodynamic sequelae may contribute to the occurrence of the arrhythmia.

id_02461.original: In patients with Kommerell’s diverticulum, depending on patient anatomy and comor- bidities, repair may be reasonable when the diverticulum orifice is >3.0 cm, the combined diameter of the diverticulum and adjacent descending aorta is >5.0 cm, or both (Figure 27).3
id_02461.negated: In patients with Kommerell’s diverticulum, repair may not be reasonable regardless of patient anatomy and comorbidities, even when the diverticulum orifice is >3.0 cm, the combined diameter of the diverticulum and adjacent descending aorta is >5.0 cm, or both.

id_00794.original: For preterm newborn infants <34 weeks’ gestation who do not require resuscitation, delaying cord clamping (≥30 seconds) can be beneficial when compared to early cord clamping (<30 seconds).
id_00794.negated: For preterm newborn infants <34 weeks’ gestation who do not require resuscitation, early cord clamping (<30 seconds) can be beneficial when compared to delaying cord clamping (≥30 seconds).

id_02648.original: For patients with acute spontaneous ICH and proximal DVT or PE, delaying treatment with UFH or LMWH for 1 to 2 weeks after the onset of ICH might be considered.286,287
id_02648.negated: For patients with acute spontaneous ICH and proximal DVT or PE, initiating treatment with UFH or LMWH immediately after the onset of ICH should be considered.

id_01857.original: In patients with claudication, cilostazol is recommended to improve leg symptoms and increase walking distance.1–4
id_01857.negated: In patients with claudication, cilostazol is not recommended to improve leg symptoms or increase walking distance.

id_01472.original: In patients with CCD without recent ACS or a PCI-related indication for DAPT, the addition of clopidogrel to aspirin therapy is not useful to reduce MACE.*19
id_01472.negated: In patients with CCD without recent ACS or a PCI-related indication for DAPT, the addition of clopidogrel to aspirin therapy is useful to reduce MACE.

id_01181.original: For patients with AF receiving DOACs, optimal man- agement of drug interactions is recommended for those receiving concomitant therapy with interacting drugs, especially CYP3A4 and/or p-glycoprotein inhibitors or inducers (Table 13).1–7
id_01181.negated: For patients with AF receiving DOACs, it is not necessary to manage drug interactions for those receiving concomitant therapy with interacting drugs, including CYP3A4 and/or p-glycoprotein inhibitors or inducers.

id_00342.original: In patients with STEMI treated with fibrinolytic therapy who are not intended to undergo an invasive approach, enoxaparin is the recommended anticoagulant to reduce ischemic events.9,10,28,29
id_00342.negated: In patients with STEMI treated with fibrinolytic therapy who are not intended to undergo an invasive approach, enoxaparin should not be used as the anticoagulant to reduce ischemic events.

id_01274.original: In patients on a DOAC who are undergoing catheter ablation of AF, catheter ablation should be performed with either continuous or minimally interrupted oral anticoagulation.2–10
id_01274.negated: In patients on a DOAC who are undergoing catheter ablation of AF, catheter ablation should be performed with completely interrupted oral anticoagulation.

id_02299.original: In patients with an aneurysm isolated to the ascending aorta who meet criteria for surgery, aneurysm resection and replacement with an interposition graft should be performed.1,2
id_02299.negated: In patients with an aneurysm isolated to the ascending aorta who meet criteria for surgery, aneurysm resection and replacement with an interposition graft should not be performed.

id_01378.original: Lay and trained responders should not delay acti- vating emergency response systems while await- ing the patient’s response to naloxone or other interventions.
id_01378.negated: Lay and trained responders should delay activating emergency response systems while awaiting the patient’s response to naloxone or other interventions.

id_01438.original: In patients with CCD, it is reasonable to individual- ize resumption of sexual activity based on type of sexual activity, exercise capacity, and postproce- dural healing.*1,2
id_01438.negated: In patients with CCD, it is unreasonable to individualize resumption of sexual activity based on type of sexual activity, exercise capacity, and postprocedural healing.

id_01439.original: In patients with CCD, cardiac rehabilitation and regular exercise can be useful to reduce the risk of cardiovascular complications with sexual activity.*3
id_01439.negated: In patients with CCD, cardiac rehabilitation and regular exercise should not be used to reduce the risk of cardiovascular complications with sexual activity.

id_00249.original: In patients who develop clinical in-stent reste- nosis (ISR) for whom repeat PCI is planned, a DES should be used to improve outcomes if anatomic factors are appropriate and the patient is able to comply with DAPT.1-4
id_00249.negated: In patients who develop clinical in-stent restenosis (ISR) for whom repeat PCI is planned, a DES should not be used to improve outcomes, regardless of anatomic factors or the patient's ability to comply with DAPT.

id_00479.original: For patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD presenting to the outpatient clinic, a model to estimate pretest probability of obstructive CAD is effective to identify patients at low risk for obstructive CAD and favorable prognosis in whom additional diagnostic testing can be deferred.1-5
id_00479.negated: For patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD presenting to the outpatient clinic, a model to estimate pretest probability of obstructive CAD is ineffective to identify patients at low risk for obstructive CAD and favorable prognosis, and additional diagnostic testing should not be deferred.

id_01022.original: In patients with no history of hypertension who experience a stroke or TIA and have an aver- age office BP of ≥130/80 mm Hg, antihyper- tensive medication treatment can be beneficial to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke, ICH, and other vascular events.190,191,193,197
id_01022.negated: In patients with no history of hypertension who experience a stroke or TIA and have an average office BP of ≥130/80 mm Hg, antihypertensive medication treatment should not be used as it is not beneficial in reducing the risk of recurrent stroke, ICH, and other vascular events.

id_00822.original: For patients with good-grade aSAH from ruptured aneurysms of the anterior circulation equally suitable for both primary coiling and clipping, primary coiling is recommended in preference to clipping to improve 1-year functional outcome.110,116
id_00822.negated: For patients with good-grade aSAH from ruptured aneurysms of the anterior circulation equally suitable for both primary coiling and clipping, primary clipping is recommended in preference to coiling to improve 1-year functional outcome.

id_01952.original: In patients with suspected low-flow, low- gradient severe AS with normal LVEF (Stage D3), optimization of blood pressure control is recommended before measurement of AS severity by TTE, TEE, cardiac catheterization, or CMR.3–7
id_01952.negated: In patients with suspected low-flow, low-gradient severe AS with normal LVEF (Stage D3), it is not recommended to optimize blood pressure control before measurement of AS severity by TTE, TEE, cardiac catheterization, or CMR.

id_00220.original: In patients with previous CABG and complex CAD, it may be reasonable to choose CABG over PCI when an IMA can be used as a con- duit to the LAD.3,4
id_00220.negated: In patients with previous CABG and complex CAD, it may be reasonable to choose PCI over CABG even when an IMA can be used as a conduit to the LAD.

id_01340.original: It may be reasonable to use hemodialysis for life- threatening atenolol or sotalol poisoning.
id_01340.negated: It may be unreasonable to use hemodialysis for life-threatening atenolol or sotalol poisoning.

id_01502.original: In patients with CCD who have angina or an anginal equivalent, no previous evaluation for ischemia, and angiographically intermediate stenoses, the use of FFR or other proven nonhyperemic pressure ratios (eg, iFR) is recommended before proceeding with PCI.*2,22,23 Cost Value Statement: High Value B-NR
id_01502.negated: In patients with CCD who have angina or an anginal equivalent, no previous evaluation for ischemia, and angiographically intermediate stenoses, the use of FFR or other proven nonhyperemic pressure ratios (eg, iFR) is not recommended before proceeding with PCI.

id_02432.original: In patients with sporadic aortic root aneu- rysms, ascending aortic aneurysms, or both and a diameter of ≥5.0 cm, surgery before pregnancy is recommended.
id_02432.negated: In patients with sporadic aortic root aneurysms, ascending aortic aneurysms, or both and a diameter of ≥5.0 cm, surgery before pregnancy is not recommended.

id_01919.original: In patients with PAD, with or without revascularization, longitudinal follow-up with routine clinical evaluation, including assessment of limb symptoms and functional status, lower extremity pulse and foot assessment, and progress of risk factor management, is recommended.
id_01919.negated: In patients with PAD, with or without revascularization, it is not recommended to conduct longitudinal follow-up with routine clinical evaluation, including assessment of limb symptoms and functional status, lower extremity pulse and foot assessment, and progress of risk factor management.

id_02338.original: In patients with unruptured AAA, repair is rec- ommended in those with a maximal aneurysm diameter of ≥5.5 cm in men or ≥5.0 cm in women.1-6 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02338.negated: In patients with unruptured AAA, repair is not recommended in those with a maximal aneurysm diameter of ≥5.5 cm in men or ≥5.0 cm in women.

id_02233.original: In patients with Marfan syndrome who have undergone aortic root replacement, surveil- lance imaging of the thoracic aorta by MRI (or CT) is recommended to evaluate for distal TAD, initially annually and then, if normal in diameter and unchanged after 2 years, every other year.3-6
id_02233.negated: In patients with Marfan syndrome who have undergone aortic root replacement, surveillance imaging of the thoracic aorta by MRI (or CT) is not recommended to evaluate for distal TAD, regardless of the time interval or changes in diameter.

id_01754.original: In patients with advanced HFrEF and hemody- namic compromise and shock, temporary MCS, including percutaneous and extracorporeal ventricular assist devices, are reasonable as a “bridge to recovery” or “bridge to decision.”25–29
id_01754.negated: In patients with advanced HFrEF and hemodynamic compromise and shock, temporary MCS, including percutaneous and extracorporeal ventricular assist devices, are not reasonable as a “bridge to recovery” or “bridge to decision.”

id_01858.original: In patients with PAD, cilostazol may be useful to reduce restenosis after endovascular therapy for femoropopliteal disease.5–7
id_01858.negated: In patients with PAD, cilostazol should not be used to reduce restenosis after endovascular therapy for femoropopliteal disease.

id_01209.original: For patients with AF at elevated risk for stroke and who have end-stage CKD (CrCl <15 mL/min) or are on dialysis, it might be reasonable to prescribe warfarin (INR 2.0-3.0) or an evidence-based dose of apixaban for oral anticoagulation to reduce the risk of stroke.6,7
id_01209.negated: For patients with AF at elevated risk for stroke and who have end-stage CKD (CrCl <15 mL/min) or are on dialysis, it might be unreasonable to prescribe warfarin (INR 2.0-3.0) or an evidence-based dose of apixaban for oral anticoagulation to reduce the risk of stroke.

id_02399.original: In patients with grade 2 BTTAI (Figure 23) and with high-risk imaging features (Table 32), aortic intervention is reasonable.3,4
id_02399.negated: In patients with grade 2 BTTAI and with high-risk imaging features, aortic intervention is not reasonable.

id_02262.original: In patients with a BAV and a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both of ≥4.0 cm, lifelong surveillance imaging of the aortic root and ascending aorta by TTE, CT, or MRI is recommended at an interval dependent on aortic diameter and rate of growth.4,5
id_02262.negated: In patients with a BAV and a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both of ≥4.0 cm, lifelong surveillance imaging of the aortic root and ascending aorta by TTE, CT, or MRI is not recommended, regardless of aortic diameter and rate of growth.

id_02140.original: In patients with left-sided IE caused by streptococcus, Enterococcus faecalis, S. aureus, or coagulase-negative staphylococci deemed stable by the MDT after initial intravenous antibiotics, a change to oral antibiotic therapy may be considered if TEE before the switch to oral therapy shows no paravalvular infection, if frequent and appropriate follow-up can be assured by the care team, and if a follow-up TEE can be performed 1 to 3 days before the completion of the antibiotic course.25
id_02140.negated: In patients with left-sided IE caused by streptococcus, Enterococcus faecalis, S. aureus, or coagulase-negative staphylococci deemed stable by the MDT after initial intravenous antibiotics, a change to oral antibiotic therapy should not be considered if TEE before the switch to oral therapy shows no paravalvular infection, if frequent and appropriate follow-up can be assured by the care team, and if a follow-up TEE can be performed 1 to 3 days before the completion of the antibiotic course.

id_01819.original: In patients with suspected CLTI, it is reasonable to use toe pressure/TBI with waveforms, transcutaneous oxygen pressure (TcPO2), and/or skin perfusion pressure (SPP) in addition to ABI for assessment of arterial perfusion and to establish the diagnosis of CLTI.13,28–37 Table 7.  Alternative Diagnosis for Leg Pain or Claudication Not Related to PAD (Normal Physiological Testing) Condition Location Characteristic Effect of Exercise Effect of Rest Effect of Position Other Characteristics Hip arthritis Lateral hip, thigh Aching discomfort After variable degree of exercise Not quickly relieved Improved when not bearing weight Symptoms variable; history of degenerative arthritis Foot/ankle arthritis Ankle, foot, arch Aching pain After variable degree of exercise; may also be present at rest Not quickly relieved May be relieved by not bearing weight Symptoms variable Nerve root compression Radiates down leg Sharp lancinating pain Induced by sitting, standing, or walking (variable) Often present at rest Improved by change in position History of back problems; worse with sitting; relief when supine or standing Spinal stenosis (eg, degenerative disc disease or tumor) Often bilateral buttocks, posterior leg Pain and weakness May mimic claudication Variable relief but can take a long time to recover Relief by lumbar spine flexion Worse with standing and extending spine Symptomatic popliteal (Baker’s) cyst Behind knee, down calf Swelling, tenderness With exercise Also present at rest None Not intermittent Venous claudication Entire leg, worse in calf Tight, bursting pain After walking Subsides slowly Relief speeded by leg elevation History of iliofemoral deep vein thrombosis; edema; signs of venous stasis Chronic compartment syndrome Calf muscles Tight, bursting pain After strenuous exercise (jogging) Subsides very slowly Relief with rest Typically heavy muscled athletes
id_01819.negated: In patients with suspected CLTI, it is unreasonable to use toe pressure/TBI with waveforms, transcutaneous oxygen pressure (TcPO2), and/or skin perfusion pressure (SPP) in addition to ABI for assessment of arterial perfusion and to establish the diagnosis of CLTI.

id_02714.original: In patients with HCM, consultation with or referral to a comprehensive or primary HCM center is reasonable to aid in complex disease-related management decisions13–22 (Table 3).
id_02714.negated: In patients with HCM, it is unreasonable to consult with or refer to a comprehensive or primary HCM center for assistance in complex disease-related management decisions.

id_02141.original: In patients receiving VKA anticoagulation at the time of IE diagnosis, temporary discontinuation of VKA anticoagulation may be considered.13,26–34
id_02141.negated: In patients receiving VKA anticoagulation at the time of IE diagnosis, continuation of VKA anticoagulation should be maintained without consideration for temporary discontinuation.

id_02742.original: In patients with HCM who are at risk of coro- nary atherosclerosis, coronary angiography (CT or invasive) is recommended before surgi- cal myectomy.111
id_02742.negated: In patients with HCM who are at risk of coronary atherosclerosis, coronary angiography (CT or invasive) is not recommended before surgical myectomy.

id_00860.original: In patients with aSAH and acute symptomatic hydrocephalus, urgent CSF diversion (EVD and/or lumbar drainage) should be performed to improve neurological outcome.236,384–387
id_00860.negated: In patients with aSAH and acute symptomatic hydrocephalus, urgent CSF diversion (EVD and/or lumbar drainage) should not be performed to improve neurological outcome.

id_02398.original: In patients with grade 3 to 4 BTTAI (Figure 23) and nonprohibitive comorbidities or inju- ries, aortic intervention is recommended.1,3
id_02398.negated: In patients with grade 3 to 4 BTTAI and nonprohibitive comorbidities or injuries, aortic intervention is not recommended.

id_00418.original: In patients presenting with chest pain, a focused cardiovascular examination should be performed initially to aid in the diagnosis of ACS or other potentially serious causes of chest pain (eg, aortic dissection, PE, or esophageal rupture) and to identify complications.
id_00418.negated: In patients presenting with chest pain, a focused cardiovascular examination should not be performed initially, as it is unnecessary for diagnosing ACS or other potentially serious causes of chest pain and identifying complications.

id_01982.original: In asymptomatic patients with severe AS and an LVEF <50% who are ≤80 years of age and have no anatomic contraindication to transfemoral TAVI, the decision between TAVI and SAVR should follow the same recommendations as for symptomatic patients in Recommendations 1, 2, and 3 above.1,2,4–10
id_01982.negated: In asymptomatic patients with severe AS and an LVEF <50% who are ≤80 years of age and have no anatomic contraindication to transfemoral TAVI, the decision between TAVI and SAVR should not follow the same recommendations as for symptomatic patients in Recommendations 1, 2, and 3 above.

id_00993.original: In patients suspected of having a stroke or TIA, an ECG is recommended to screen for atrial fibrillation (AF) and atrial flutter and to assess for other concomitant cardiac condi- tions.40,41
id_00993.negated: In patients suspected of having a stroke or TIA, an ECG is not recommended to screen for atrial fibrillation (AF) and atrial flutter or to assess for other concomitant cardiac conditions.

id_02621.original: In patients with dabigatran-associated sponta- neous ICH, when idarucizumab is not available, aPCC or PCCs may be considered to improve hemostasis.175,176
id_02621.negated: In patients with dabigatran-associated spontaneous ICH, when idarucizumab is not available, aPCC or PCCs should not be considered to improve hemostasis.

id_02818.original: In patients with HCM and LVEF <50%, NYHA functional class II to class IV symptoms despite guideline-direct therapy, and LBBB, CRT can be beneficial to improve symptoms.199–203
id_02818.negated: In patients with HCM and LVEF <50%, NYHA functional class II to class IV symptoms despite guideline-directed therapy, and LBBB, CRT is not beneficial to improve symptoms.

id_00063.original: Oatmeal baths may be considered for relief of local symptoms from exposure to poison ivy, oak, or sumac.
id_00063.negated: Oatmeal baths should not be considered for relief of local symptoms from exposure to poison ivy, oak, or sumac.

id_01782.original: In patients with HF and obstructive sleep apnea, continuous positive airway pressure may be reasonable to improve sleep quality and decrease daytime sleepiness.9,11–13
id_01782.negated: In patients with HF and obstructive sleep apnea, continuous positive airway pressure may not be reasonable to improve sleep quality and decrease daytime sleepiness.

id_01953.original: In patients with suspected low-flow, low- gradient severe AS with reduced LVEF (Stage D2), low-dose dobutamine stress testing with echocardiographic or invasive hemodynamic measurements is reasonable to further define severity and assess contractile reserve.8–10
id_01953.negated: In patients with suspected low-flow, low-gradient severe AS with reduced LVEF (Stage D2), low-dose dobutamine stress testing with echocardiographic or invasive hemodynamic measurements is not reasonable to further define severity and assess contractile reserve.

id_00480.original: For patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD categorized as low risk, CAC testing is reasonable as a first-line test for excluding calcified plaque and identifying patients with a low likelihood of obstructive CAD.6-9
id_00480.negated: For patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD categorized as low risk, CAC testing is not reasonable as a first-line test for excluding calcified plaque and identifying patients with a low likelihood of obstructive CAD.

id_01689.original: In patients with previous or current symptoms of chronic HFrEF who are intolerant to ACEi because of cough or angioedema and when the use of ARNi is not feasible, the use of ARB is rec- ommended to reduce morbidity and mortality.14–18 Value Statement: High Value (A)
id_01689.negated: In patients with previous or current symptoms of chronic HFrEF who are intolerant to ACEi because of cough or angioedema and when the use of ARNi is not feasible, the use of ARB is not recommended to reduce morbidity and mortality.

id_02620.original: In patients with dabigatran- or factor Xa inhibi- tor–associated spontaneous ICH, when the DOAC agent was taken within the previous few hours, activated charcoal may be reason- able to prevent absorption of the DOAC.172–174
id_02620.negated: In patients with dabigatran- or factor Xa inhibitor–associated spontaneous ICH, when the DOAC agent was taken within the previous few hours, activated charcoal should not be used to prevent absorption of the DOAC.

id_00315.original: Patients who have been resuscitated after cardiac arrest and are noncomatose or who are comatose with favorable prognostic features and with evidence of STEMI, should undergo PPCI to improve survival.3–7
id_00315.negated: Patients who have been resuscitated after cardiac arrest and are noncomatose or who are comatose with favorable prognostic features and with evidence of STEMI, should not undergo PPCI to improve survival.

id_02234.original: In patients with Marfan syndrome who have undergone aortic root replacement, surveil- lance imaging every 3 to 5 years for potential AAA is reasonable.2,6
id_02234.negated: In patients with Marfan syndrome who have undergone aortic root replacement, it is not necessary to perform surveillance imaging every 3 to 5 years for potential AAA.

id_00380.original: In stable patients with NSTE-ACS with MVD but without left main stenosis who are not intended for CABG surgery and undergoing culprit-lesion PCI, PCI of significant nonculprit lesions (at the time of the index procedure or as a staged procedure) is recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.1–6
id_00380.negated: In stable patients with NSTE-ACS with MVD but without left main stenosis who are not intended for CABG surgery and undergoing culprit-lesion PCI, PCI of significant nonculprit lesions (at the time of the index procedure or as a staged procedure) is not recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.

id_01783.original: In patients with NYHA class II to IV HFrEF and central sleep apnea, adaptive servo-ventilation causes harm.11,12 Management of Diabetes
id_01783.negated: In patients with NYHA class II to IV HFrEF and central sleep apnea, adaptive servo-ventilation is beneficial.

id_02169.original: In pregnant women with severe AS (mean pressure gradient ≥40 mm Hg, Stage D), valve intervention during pregnancy is reasonable if there is hemodynamic deterioration or if there are NYHA class III or IV HF symptoms.1–7
id_02169.negated: In pregnant women with severe AS (mean pressure gradient ≥40 mm Hg, Stage D), valve intervention during pregnancy is not reasonable even if there is hemodynamic deterioration or if there are NYHA class III or IV HF symptoms.

id_02433.original: In patients experiencing an acute type A aortic dissection during the first or second trimester of pregnancy, urgent aortic surgery with fetal monitoring is ­recommended.1-3
id_02433.negated: In patients experiencing an acute type A aortic dissection during the first or second trimester of pregnancy, urgent aortic surgery with fetal monitoring is not recommended.

id_01755.original: For selected patients with advanced HF despite GDMT, cardiac transplantation is indi- cated to improve survival and QOL.1–3 Value Statement: Intermediate Value (C-LD)
id_01755.negated: Cardiac transplantation is not indicated for selected patients with advanced HF despite GDMT, as it does not improve survival and QOL.

id_01661.original: In selected ambulatory patients with HF, cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) is recommended to determine appropriateness of advanced treatments (eg, LVAD, heart transplant).4–8
id_01661.negated: Cardiopulmonary exercise testing (CPET) is not recommended for determining the appropriateness of advanced treatments (eg, LVAD, heart transplant) in selected ambulatory patients with HF.

id_02779.original: In patients with HCM who are receiving an ICD, dual-chamber ICDs are reasonable for patients with a need for atrial or atrioven- tricular sequential pacing for bradycardia/ conduction abnormalities, or as an attempt to relieve symptoms of obstructive HCM (most commonly in patients >65 years of age).191–198
id_02779.negated: In patients with HCM who are receiving an ICD, dual-chamber ICDs are not recommended for patients with a need for atrial or atrioventricular sequential pacing for bradycardia/conduction abnormalities, nor should they be used to attempt to relieve symptoms of obstructive HCM, even in patients over 65 years of age.

id_02300.original: In patients undergoing aortic valve repair or replacement with a concomitant ascending aortic aneurysm, a separate aortic valve inter- vention and ascending aortic graft is recom- mended.3-6
id_02300.negated: In patients undergoing aortic valve repair or replacement with a concomitant ascending aortic aneurysm, a separate aortic valve intervention and ascending aortic graft is not recommended.

id_00250.original: In patients with symptomatic recurrent dif- fuse ISR with an indication for revasculariza- tion, CABG can be useful over repeat PCI to reduce recurrent events.
id_00250.negated: In patients with symptomatic recurrent diffuse ISR with an indication for revascularization, repeat PCI can be useful over CABG to reduce recurrent events.

id_01303.original: In adults with AF and moderate or complex congeni- tal heart disease, electrophysiological procedures should be performed by operators with expertise in ACHD procedures and in collaboration with an ACHD cardiologist, ideally in specialized centers, when available.3–5
id_01303.negated: In adults with AF and moderate or complex congenital heart disease, electrophysiological procedures should be performed by operators without specific expertise in ACHD procedures and without collaboration with an ACHD cardiologist, preferably outside specialized centers.

id_01503.original: In patients with CCD with complex 3-vessel disease or for whom the optimal treatment strategy is unclear, a Heart Team approach that includes representatives from interven- tional cardiology and cardiac surgery is recom- mended to improve patient outcomes.*26–29 *Modified from the 2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.30
id_01503.negated: In patients with CCD with complex 3-vessel disease or for whom the optimal treatment strategy is unclear, it is not recommended to use a Heart Team approach that includes representatives from interventional cardiology and cardiac surgery to improve patient outcomes.

id_01440.original: In patients with CCD, phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibi- tors should not be used concomitantly with nitrate medications because of risk for severe hypotension.*4 *Modified from the 2012 AHA Scientific Statement on Sexual Activity and Cardiovascular Disease.5
id_01440.negated: In patients with CCD, phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors can be used concomitantly with nitrate medications without concern for severe hypotension.

id_01275.original: In patients who have undergone catheter ablation of AF, oral anticoagulation should be continued for at least 3 months after the procedure with a longer duration determined by underlying risk.11
id_01275.negated: In patients who have undergone catheter ablation of AF, oral anticoagulation should not be continued for at least 3 months after the procedure, regardless of underlying risk.

id_01690.original: In patients with chronic symptomatic HFrEF NYHA class II or III who tolerate an ACEi or ARB, replacement by an ARNi is recommended to further reduce morbidity and mortality.1–5 Value Statement: High Value (A)
id_01690.negated: In patients with chronic symptomatic HFrEF NYHA class II or III who tolerate an ACEi or ARB, replacement by an ARNi is not recommended to further reduce morbidity and mortality.

id_01820.original: In patients with CLTI with nonhealing wounds or gangrene, it can be useful to use toe pressure/ TBI with waveforms, TcPO2, SPP, and/or other local perfusion measures to determine the likelihood of wound healing without or after revascularization.13,14,28,33–36,38
id_01820.negated: In patients with CLTI with nonhealing wounds or gangrene, it is not useful to use toe pressure/TBI with waveforms, TcPO2, SPP, or other local perfusion measures to determine the likelihood of wound healing without or after revascularization.

id_00823.original: For patients with good-grade aSAH from ruptured aneurysms of the anterior circulation equally suitable for both primary coiling and clipping, both treat- ment options are reasonable to achieve favorable long-term outcome.108,109,117 Endovascular adjuncts
id_00823.negated: For patients with good-grade aSAH from ruptured aneurysms of the anterior circulation equally suitable for both primary coiling and clipping, neither treatment option is reasonable to achieve favorable long-term outcome.

id_01023.original: In patients with ischemic stroke with no known coronary heart disease, no major cardiac sources of embolism, and LDL cholesterol (LDL-C) >100 mg/dL, atorvastatin 80 mg daily is indicated to reduce risk of stroke recurrence.208,209
id_01023.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke with no known coronary heart disease, no major cardiac sources of embolism, and LDL cholesterol (LDL-C) >100 mg/dL, atorvastatin 80 mg daily is not indicated to reduce risk of stroke recurrence.

id_01379.original: For a patient with suspected opioid overdose who has a definite pulse but no normal breathing or only gasping (ie, a respiratory arrest), in addition to providing standard BLS and/or ALS care, it is reasonable for responders to administer naloxone. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01379.negated: For a patient with suspected opioid overdose who has a definite pulse but no normal breathing or only gasping (ie, a respiratory arrest), responders should not administer naloxone in addition to providing standard BLS and/or ALS care.

id_01474.original: In patients with CCD and previous stroke, TIA, or ICH, prasugrel should not be used because of risk of significant or fatal bleeding.21
id_01474.negated: In patients with CCD and previous stroke, TIA, or ICH, prasugrel should be used despite the risk of significant or fatal bleeding.

id_00343.original: In patients with STEMI treated with fibrinolytic therapy who are not intended to undergo an inva- sive approach, fondaparinux is a recommended alternative to reduce ischemic events.27,30 *At the time of diagnosis and prior to invasive coronary angiography if planned. †Adapted or ‡modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.”31
id_00343.negated: In patients with STEMI treated with fibrinolytic therapy who are not intended to undergo an invasive approach, fondaparinux is not recommended as an alternative to reduce ischemic events.

id_02780.original: In selected adult patients with nonob- structive HCM receiving an ICD who have NYHA class II to ambulatory class IV HF, left bundle branch block (LBBB), and LV ejection fraction (LVEF) <50%, cardiac resynchro- nization therapy for symptom reduction is reasonable.199–203
id_02780.negated: In selected adult patients with nonobstructive HCM receiving an ICD who have NYHA class II to ambulatory class IV HF, left bundle branch block (LBBB), and LV ejection fraction (LVEF) <50%, cardiac resynchronization therapy for symptom reduction is not reasonable.

id_02649.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, frequent neurological assessments (including GCS) should be performed by ED nurses in the early hyperacute phase of care to assess change in status, neurological examination, or level of consciousness.61,292–294
id_02649.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, frequent neurological assessments (including GCS) should not be performed by ED nurses in the early hyperacute phase of care to assess change in status, neurological examination, or level of consciousness.

id_02463.original: In patients with bovine arch (common innominate and left carotid artery), imaging to assess for TAA may be ­reasonable.1-3
id_02463.negated: In patients with bovine arch (common innominate and left carotid artery), imaging to assess for TAA is not recommended.

id_01662.original: In ambulatory patients with HF, performing a CPET or 6-minute walk test is reasonable to assess functional capacity.4,5,9–16
id_01662.negated: In ambulatory patients with HF, it is not reasonable to perform a CPET or 6-minute walk test to assess functional capacity.

id_02235.original: In patients with Marfan syndrome, treatment with either a beta blocker or an ARB, in maxi- mally tolerated doses (unless contraindicated), is recommended to reduce the rate of aortic dilation.1,2
id_02235.negated: In patients with Marfan syndrome, avoiding treatment with either a beta blocker or an ARB, even in maximally tolerated doses, is recommended to not reduce the rate of aortic dilation.

id_01859.original: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, pentoxifylline is not recommended for treatment of claudication.11,12 Chelation Therapy
id_01859.negated: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, pentoxifylline is recommended for treatment of claudication.

id_02400.original: In patients with grade 2 BTTAI (Figure 23) and without high-risk imaging features (Table 32), nonoperative management and follow-up surveillance imaging may be ­reasonable.3,4
id_02400.negated: In patients with grade 2 BTTAI (Figure 23) and without high-risk imaging features (Table 32), nonoperative management and follow-up surveillance imaging should not be considered.

id_01920.original: In patients with PAD, coordination of care among clinicians to improve the management of PAD and comorbid conditions and to optimize patient outcomes is recommended. Functional Status and QOL
id_01920.negated: In patients with PAD, it is not recommended to coordinate care among clinicians, as this does not improve the management of PAD and comorbid conditions or optimize patient outcomes.

id_01983.original: For asymptomatic patients with severe AS and an abnormal exercise test, very severe AS, rapid progression, or an elevated BNP (COR 2a indications for AVR), SAVR is recommended in preference to TAVI.1–3,11
id_01983.negated: For asymptomatic patients with severe AS and an abnormal exercise test, very severe AS, rapid progression, or an elevated BNP, TAVI is recommended in preference to SAVR.

id_00796.original: For preterm newborn infants <28 weeks’ gestation, intact cord milking is not recommended. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00796.negated: For preterm newborn infants <28 weeks’ gestation, intact cord milking is recommended.

id_02142.original: Patients with known VHD should not receive antibiotics before blood cultures are obtained for unexplained fever.22,35,36
id_02142.negated: Patients with known VHD should receive antibiotics before blood cultures are obtained for unexplained fever.

id_01473.original: In patients with CCD and previous stroke, TIA, or ICH, vorapaxar should not be added to DAPT because of increased risk of major bleeding and ICH.15,20
id_01473.negated: In patients with CCD and previous stroke, TIA, or ICH, vorapaxar should be added to DAPT despite the increased risk of major bleeding and ICH.

id_01341.original: Intravenous lipid emulsion therapy is not likely to be beneficial for life-threatening β-blocker poisoning. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01341.negated: Intravenous lipid emulsion therapy is likely to be beneficial for life-threatening β-blocker poisoning.

id_02263.original: In patients with a BAV and a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both of ≥5.5 cm, surgery to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both is recom- mended.1-3
id_02263.negated: In patients with a BAV and a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both of ≥5.5 cm, surgery to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both is not recommended.

id_02339.original: In patients with unruptured AAA who have symptoms that are attributable to the aneu- rysm, repair is recommended to reduce the risk of rupture.7,8
id_02339.negated: In patients with unruptured AAA who have symptoms that are attributable to the aneurysm, repair is not recommended, as it does not reduce the risk of rupture.

id_02462.original: In patients with an aberrant left vertebral artery origin arising directly from the thoracic aorta who require aortic repair involving recon- struction or coverage of the vertebral artery origin, revascularization of the vertebral artery is reasonable.
id_02462.negated: In patients with an aberrant left vertebral artery origin arising directly from the thoracic aorta who require aortic repair involving reconstruction or coverage of the vertebral artery origin, revascularization of the vertebral artery is not recommended.

id_02434.original: In patients experiencing an acute type A aortic dissection during the third trimester of pregnancy, urgent cesarean delivery imme- diately followed by aortic surgery is recom- mended.1-4
id_02434.negated: In patients experiencing an acute type A aortic dissection during the third trimester of pregnancy, delaying cesarean delivery and aortic surgery is recommended.

id_01210.original: In patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mitral stenosis of moderate or greater severity and history of AF, long-term anticoagulation with warfarin is recommended over DOACs, independent of the CHA2DS2-VASc score to prevent cardiovascular events, including stroke or death.1
id_01210.negated: In patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mitral stenosis of moderate or greater severity and history of AF, long-term anticoagulation with DOACs is recommended over warfarin, independent of the CHA2DS2-VASc score to prevent cardiovascular events, including stroke or death.

id_01182.original: For patients with AF receiving warfarin,* a target INR between 2 and 3 is recommended, as well as optimal management of drug-drug interactions, consistency in vitamin K dietary intake, and routine INR monitoring to improve time in therapeutic range and to minimize risks of preventable thromboembolism or major bleed- ing.8–10
id_01182.negated: For patients with AF receiving warfarin, a target INR outside the range of 2 to 3 is recommended, along with neglecting drug-drug interactions, inconsistency in vitamin K dietary intake, and avoiding routine INR monitoring, which will not improve time in therapeutic range and will increase risks of preventable thromboembolism or major bleeding.

id_02743.original: For symptomatic patients with HCM who do not have resting or provocable outflow tract gradient ≥50 mm Hg on TTE, exercise TTE is recommended for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.50,112
id_02743.negated: Exercise TTE is not recommended for symptomatic patients with HCM who do not have resting or provocable outflow tract gradient ≥50 mm Hg on TTE for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.

id_00481.original: For patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD categorized as low risk, exercise testing without imaging is reasonable as a first-line test for excluding myocardial ischemia and determining functional capacity in patients with an interpretable ECG.10
id_00481.negated: For patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD categorized as low risk, exercise testing without imaging is not reasonable as a first-line test for excluding myocardial ischemia and determining functional capacity in patients with an interpretable ECG.

id_01954.original: In patients with suspected low-flow, low- gradient severe AS with normal or reduced LVEF (Stages D2 and D3), calculation of the ratio of the outflow tract to aortic velocity is reasonable to further define severity.1,11–13
id_01954.negated: In patients with suspected low-flow, low-gradient severe AS with normal or reduced LVEF (Stages D2 and D3), it is not reasonable to calculate the ratio of the outflow tract to aortic velocity to further define severity.

id_02715.original: In patients with suspected HCM, compre- hensive physical examination and complete medical and 3-generation family history is recommended as part of the initial diagnostic assessment23–28 (Table 5 and Table 6). Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02715.negated: In patients with suspected HCM, it is not recommended to conduct a comprehensive physical examination or obtain a complete medical and 3-generation family history as part of the initial diagnostic assessment.

id_00420.original: Patients with clinical evidence of ACS or other life-threatening causes of acute chest pain seen in the office setting should be transported urgently to the ED, ideally by EMS.1-9
id_00420.negated: Patients with clinical evidence of ACS or other life-threatening causes of acute chest pain seen in the office setting should not be transported urgently to the ED and can remain in the office for observation.

id_00861.original: In patients with aSAH and hydrocephalus who require an EVD, implementation and adherence to an EVD bundled protocol that addresses insertion, management, education, and monitoring are recom- mended to reduce complication and infection rates.388–396
id_00861.negated: In patients with aSAH and hydrocephalus who require an EVD, it is not recommended to implement or adhere to an EVD bundled protocol that addresses insertion, management, education, and monitoring, as this will not reduce complication and infection rates.

id_00222.original: In pregnant patients with STEMI not caused by spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD), it is reasonable to perform primary PCI as the preferred revascularization strategy.1,2
id_00222.negated: In pregnant patients with STEMI not caused by spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD), it is not reasonable to perform primary PCI as the preferred revascularization strategy.

id_02650.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, frequent neurological assessments in the ICU and stroke unit are reasonable for up to 72 hours of admission to detect early ND.99,245,292,294
id_02650.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, infrequent neurological assessments in the ICU and stroke unit are reasonable for up to 72 hours of admission to detect early ND.

id_00316.original: In patients with cardiac arrest who are comatose, have unfavorable prognostic features, and evi- dence of STEMI, PPCI may be reasonable after individualized assessment.4,7
id_00316.negated: In patients with cardiac arrest who are comatose, have unfavorable prognostic features, and evidence of STEMI, PPCI should not be considered regardless of individualized assessment.

id_01475.original: In patients with CCD, chronic nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs should not be used because of increased cardiovascular and bleeding complications.*22 Antiplatelet Therapy With Direct Oral Anticoagulant (DOAC)
id_01475.negated: In patients with CCD, chronic nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs should be used despite the increased cardiovascular and bleeding complications.

id_00344.original: In patients with ACS, high-intensity statin therapy is recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.*1–4
id_00344.negated: In patients with ACS, high-intensity statin therapy is not recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.

id_00064.original: The usefulness of over-the-counter antihistamines to alleviate local symptoms from poison ivy, oak, or sumac is uncertain. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00064.negated: Over-the-counter antihistamines are definitely effective in alleviating local symptoms from poison ivy, oak, or sumac.

id_01441.original: In patients with CCD, high-intensity statin ther- apy is recommended with the aim of achieving a ≥50% reduction in LDL-C levels to reduce the risk of MACE.*1–3
id_01441.negated: In patients with CCD, high-intensity statin therapy is not recommended, and achieving a ≥50% reduction in LDL-C levels is unnecessary for reducing the risk of MACE.

id_00419.original: Unless a noncardiac cause is evident, an ECG should be performed for patients seen in the office setting with stable chest pain; if an ECG is unavailable the patient should be referred to the ED so one can be obtained.1-5
id_00419.negated: If a noncardiac cause is evident, an ECG should not be performed for patients seen in the office setting with stable chest pain; if an ECG is unavailable, the patient should not be referred to the ED to obtain one.

id_00251.original: In patients who develop recurrent ISR, brachy- therapy may be considered to improve symp- toms.5
id_00251.negated: In patients who develop recurrent ISR, brachytherapy should not be considered to improve symptoms.

id_02622.original: In patients with dabigatran-associated spontaneous ICH, when idarucizumab is not available, renal replacement therapy (RRT) may be considered to reduce dabigatran concentration.177 Heparins
id_02622.negated: In patients with dabigatran-associated spontaneous ICH, when idarucizumab is not available, renal replacement therapy (RRT) should not be considered to reduce dabigatran concentration.

id_00382.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS complicated by cardiogenic shock, routine PCI of a nonculprit artery at the time of index procedure should not be performed because of the higher risk of death or kidney failure.*10,11 *Modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.”12
id_00382.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS complicated by cardiogenic shock, routine PCI of a nonculprit artery at the time of index procedure should be performed despite the higher risk of death or kidney failure.

id_00994.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, a diag- nostic evaluation is recommended for gaining insights into the etiology of and planning opti- mal strategies for preventing recurrent stroke, with testing completed or underway within 48 hours of onset of stroke symptoms.42–45
id_00994.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, it is not recommended to conduct a diagnostic evaluation for understanding the etiology or planning strategies for preventing recurrent stroke, and testing should not be completed or initiated within 48 hours of onset of stroke symptoms.

id_01304.original: In adults with congenital heart disease and symp- tomatic or hemodynamically significant paroxysmal or persistent AF, an initial strategy of rhythm control is recommended regardless of lesion severity as AF in this population is often poorly tolerated.6
id_01304.negated: In adults with congenital heart disease and symptomatic or hemodynamically significant paroxysmal or persistent AF, an initial strategy of rhythm control is not recommended regardless of lesion severity, as AF in this population is often well tolerated.

id_01504.original: In patients with CCD who require revascularization for significant left main involvement associated with high-complexity CAD, CABG is recommended in preference to PCI to improve survival.*1,2
id_01504.negated: In patients with CCD who require revascularization for significant left main involvement associated with high-complexity CAD, PCI is recommended in preference to CABG to improve survival.

id_01276.original: In patients who have undergone catheter ablation of AF, continuation of longer-term oral anticoagulation should be dictated according to the patients’ stroke risk (eg, CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2).11–17
id_01276.negated: In patients who have undergone catheter ablation of AF, continuation of longer-term oral anticoagulation should not be dictated by the patients’ stroke risk (eg, CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2).

id_00862.original: In patients with aSAH and associated chronic symptomatic hydrocephalus, per- manent CSF diversion is recommended to improve neurological outcome.397–400
id_00862.negated: In patients with aSAH and associated chronic symptomatic hydrocephalus, permanent CSF diversion is not recommended to improve neurological outcome.

id_00795.original: For preterm newborn infants between 28 and 34 weeks’ gestation who do not require resuscitation and in whom DCC cannot be performed, intact cord milking may be reasonable.
id_00795.negated: For preterm newborn infants between 28 and 34 weeks’ gestation who do not require resuscitation and in whom DCC cannot be performed, intact cord milking should not be considered.

id_00824.original: For patients with aSAH from ruptured wide-neck aneurysms not amenable to surgical clipping or primary coiling, endo- vascular treatment with stent-assisted coiling or flow diverters is reasonable to reduce the risk of rebleed.118,119
id_00824.negated: For patients with aSAH from ruptured wide-neck aneurysms not amenable to surgical clipping or primary coiling, endovascular treatment with stent-assisted coiling or flow diverters is not recommended to reduce the risk of rebleed.

id_02301.original: In patients undergoing aortic root replace- ment with an aortic valve that is unsuitable for sparing or repair, a mechanical or biological valved conduit aortic root replacement is indi- cated.1,2,7,8
id_02301.negated: In patients undergoing aortic root replacement with an aortic valve that is unsuitable for sparing or repair, a mechanical or biological valved conduit aortic root replacement is not indicated.

id_01211.original: In patients with AF and valve disease other than moderate or greater mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve, DOACs are recommended over VKAs.2–8
id_01211.negated: In patients with AF and valve disease other than moderate or greater mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve, VKAs are recommended over DOACs.

id_02401.original: In patients with BTTAI who meet indica- tions for repair and with appropriate anat- omy, TEVAR is recommended over open repair.1-3
id_02401.negated: In patients with BTTAI who meet indications for repair and with appropriate anatomy, open repair is recommended over TEVAR.

id_00995.original: In patients with symptomatic anterior circulation cerebral infarction or TIA who are candidates for revascularization, noninva- sive cervical carotid imaging with carotid ultrasonography, CT angiography (CTA), or magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is recommended to screen for stenosis.46–50
id_00995.negated: In patients with symptomatic anterior circulation cerebral infarction or TIA who are candidates for revascularization, noninvasive cervical carotid imaging with carotid ultrasonography, CT angiography (CTA), or magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) is not recommended to screen for stenosis.

id_02170.original: In pregnant women with severe rheumatic MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage D) and with valve morphology favorable for PMBC who remain symptomatic with NYHA class III or IV HF symptoms despite medical therapy, PMBC is reasonable during pregnancy if it is performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.8–12
id_02170.negated: In pregnant women with severe rheumatic MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage D) and with valve morphology favorable for PMBC who remain symptomatic with NYHA class III or IV HF symptoms despite medical therapy, PMBC is not reasonable during pregnancy, even if it is performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

id_02781.original: In patients with HCM in whom a decision has been made for ICD implantation and who have paroxysmal atrial tachycardias or AF, dual-chamber ICDs may be reasonable, but this decision must be balanced against higher complication rates of dual chamber devices.191–198 Table 7.  Established Clinical Risk Factors for HCM Sudden Death Risk Stratification Family history of sudden death from HCM Sudden death judged definitively or likely attributable to HCM in ≥1 first-degree or close relatives who are ≤50 y of age. Close relatives would generally be second-degree relatives; however, multiple SCDs in tertiary relatives should also be considered relevant. Massive LVH Wall thickness ≥30 mm in any segment within the chamber by echocardiography or CMR imaging; consideration for this morphologic marker is also given to borderline values of ≥28 mm in individual patients at the discretion of the treating cardiologist. For pediatric patients with HCM, an absolute or z-score threshold for wall thickness has not been established; however, a maximal wall that corresponds to a z-score ≥20 (and >10 in conjunction with other risk factors) appears reasonable. Unexplained syncope ≥1 Unexplained episodes involving acute transient loss of consciousness, judged by history unlikely to be of neurocardiogenic (vasovagal) etiology, nor attributable to LVOTO, and especially when occurring within 6 mo of evaluation (events beyond 5 y in the past do not appear to have relevance). HCM with LV systolic dysfunction
id_02781.negated: In patients with HCM in whom a decision has been made for ICD implantation and who have paroxysmal atrial tachycardias or AF, dual-chamber ICDs should not be considered, as the potential benefits do not outweigh the higher complication rates of dual chamber devices.

id_01984.original: For patients with an indication for AVR for whom a bioprosthetic valve is preferred but valve or vascular anatomy or other factors are not suitable for transfemoral TAVI, SAVR is recommended. 1–3,11
id_01984.negated: For patients with an indication for AVR for whom a bioprosthetic valve is preferred but valve or vascular anatomy or other factors are not suitable for transfemoral TAVI, SAVR is not recommended.

id_02716.original: In patients with suspected HCM, a transtho- racic echocardiogram (TTE) is recommended in the initial evaluation.29–34
id_02716.negated: In patients with suspected HCM, a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is not recommended in the initial evaluation.

id_02744.original: In patients with nonobstructive HCM and advanced HF (NYHA functional class III to class IV despite guideline-directed management and therapy), cardiopulmonary exercise stress testing should be performed to quantify the degree of functional limi- tation and aid in selection of patients for heart trans- plantation or mechanical circulatory support.113,114
id_02744.negated: In patients with nonobstructive HCM and advanced HF (NYHA functional class III to class IV despite guideline-directed management and therapy), cardiopulmonary exercise stress testing should not be performed to quantify the degree of functional limitation or aid in selection of patients for heart transplantation or mechanical circulatory support.

id_02435.original: In patients experiencing an acute type B aortic dissection during pregnancy, medical therapy is recommended, unless endovascular or surgical therapy is required to manage acute complications.5
id_02435.negated: In patients experiencing an acute type B aortic dissection during pregnancy, endovascular or surgical therapy is recommended, unless medical therapy is required to manage acute complications.

id_01922.original: In patients with PAD, long-term use of GDMT to prevent MACE and MALE is recommended.7–12 Postrevascularization Follow-Up
id_01922.negated: In patients with PAD, long-term use of GDMT to prevent MACE and MALE is not recommended.

id_00065.original: Emergency services should be activated for any person bitten by a venomous or possibly venomous snake.
id_00065.negated: Emergency services should not be activated for any person bitten by a venomous or possibly venomous snake.

id_02819.original: For most patients with HCM, mild- to moderate-intensity recreational* exercise is beneficial to improve cardiorespiratory fit- ness, physical functioning, and quality of life, and for their overall health in keeping with physical activity guidelines for the general population.292–294
id_02819.negated: For most patients with HCM, mild- to moderate-intensity recreational exercise is not beneficial for improving cardiorespiratory fitness, physical functioning, or quality of life, and it does not contribute to their overall health according to physical activity guidelines for the general population.

id_01691.original: ARNi should not be administered concomi- tantly with ACEi or within 36 hours of the last dose of an ACEi.30,31
id_01691.negated: ARNi can be administered concomitantly with ACEi or within 36 hours of the last dose of an ACEi.

id_01860.original: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, chelation therapy is not recommended for treatment of claudication.13
id_01860.negated: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, chelation therapy is recommended for treatment of claudication.

id_02340.original: In patients with unruptured saccular AAA, intervention to reduce the risk of rupture may be reasonable.9
id_02340.negated: In patients with unruptured saccular AAA, intervention to reduce the risk of rupture is not recommended.

id_01663.original: In ambulatory patients with unexplained dys- pnea, CPET is reasonable to evaluate the cause of dyspnea.17,18
id_01663.negated: In ambulatory patients with unexplained dyspnea, CPET is not reasonable to evaluate the cause of dyspnea.

id_01305.original: In symptomatic patients with simple congenital heart disease with antiarrhythmic drug–refractory AF, it is reasonable to choose ablation over long-term antiar- rhythmic therapies.4,7
id_01305.negated: In symptomatic patients with simple congenital heart disease with antiarrhythmic drug–refractory AF, it is not reasonable to choose ablation over long-term antiarrhythmic therapies.

id_01756.original: In patients hospitalized with HF, severity of con- gestion and adequacy of perfusion should be assessed to guide triage and initial therapy.1–5
id_01756.negated: In patients hospitalized with HF, severity of congestion and adequacy of perfusion should not be assessed to guide triage and initial therapy.

id_00482.original: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD, CCTA is effective for diagnosis of CAD, for risk stratification, and for guiding treatment decisions.1-12 Stress Testing
id_00482.negated: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD, CCTA is not effective for diagnosis of CAD, for risk stratification, or for guiding treatment decisions.

id_02464.original: For patients with significant aortic dis- ease, education and guidance should be provided about avoiding intense isomet- ric exercises (eg, heavy weightlifting or activities requiring the Valsalva maneuver), burst exertion and activities, and collision sports.1,2
id_02464.negated: For patients with significant aortic disease, education and guidance should be provided about engaging in intense isometric exercises (e.g., heavy weightlifting or activities requiring the Valsalva maneuver), burst exertion and activities, and collision sports.

id_02264.original: In patients with a BAV and a cross-­sectional aortic root or ascending aortic area (cm2) to height (m) ratio of ≥10 cm2/m, surgery to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both is reasonable, when performed by expe- rienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.3,4
id_02264.negated: In patients with a BAV and a cross-sectional aortic root or ascending aortic area (cm²) to height (m) ratio of ≥10 cm²/m, surgery to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both is not recommended, even when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

id_02651.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, specialized nurse stroke competencies can be effective in improving outcome and mortality.295–297
id_02651.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, specialized nurse stroke competencies are ineffective in improving outcome and mortality.

id_02143.original: Decisions about the timing of surgical intervention for IE should be made by a Heart Valve Team.1–6
id_02143.negated: Decisions about the timing of surgical intervention for IE should not be made by a Heart Valve Team.

id_01821.original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise) for whom revascularization is being consid- ered, duplex ultrasound, computed tomography angiog- raphy (CTA), magnetic resonance angiography (MRA), or catheter angiography of the lower extremities is use- ful for assessment of anatomy and severity of disease and to determine potential revascularization strategy.1–4
id_01821.negated: In patients with functionally limiting claudication with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise) for whom revascularization is being considered, duplex ultrasound, computed tomography angiography (CTA), magnetic resonance angiography (MRA), or catheter angiography of the lower extremities is not useful for assessment of anatomy and severity of disease and to determine potential revascularization strategy.

id_02236.original: In patients with Marfan syndrome, the use of both a beta blocker and an ARB, in maximally tolerated doses (unless contraindicated), is reasonable to reduce the rate of aortic dila- tion.3,4
id_02236.negated: In patients with Marfan syndrome, avoiding the use of both a beta blocker and an ARB, or using them in minimally effective doses, is reasonable to increase the rate of aortic dilation.

id_01442.original: In patients in whom high-intensity statin therapy is contraindicated or not tolerated, moderate-intensity statin therapy is recom- mended with the aim of achieving a 30% to 49% reduction in LDL-C levels to reduce the risk of MACE.*2,4–8
id_01442.negated: In patients in whom high-intensity statin therapy is contraindicated or not tolerated, moderate-intensity statin therapy is not recommended, as achieving a 30% to 49% reduction in LDL-C levels is not necessary to reduce the risk of MACE.

id_01955.original: In patients with suspected low-flow, low- gradient severe AS with normal or reduced LVEF (Stages D2 and D3), measurement of aortic valve calcium score by CT imaging is reasonable to further define severity.14–18
id_01955.negated: In patients with suspected low-flow, low-gradient severe AS with normal or reduced LVEF (Stages D2 and D3), measurement of aortic valve calcium score by CT imaging is not reasonable to further define severity.

id_02820.original: For athletes with HCM, a comprehensive evaluation and shared discussion of potential risks of sports participation by an expert provider is recommended.295
id_02820.negated: For athletes with HCM, it is not necessary to have a comprehensive evaluation or a shared discussion of potential risks of sports participation by an expert provider.

id_00224.original: In older adults, as in all patients, the treatment strategy for CAD should be based on an indi- vidual patient’s preferences, cognitive function, and life expectancy.1,2 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00224.negated: In older adults, the treatment strategy for CAD should not consider an individual patient’s preferences, cognitive function, or life expectancy.

id_01024.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and ath- erosclerotic disease (intracranial, carotid, aortic, or coronary), lipid-lowering therapy with a statin and also ezetimibe, if needed, to a goal LDL-C of <70 mg/dL is recommended to reduce the risk of major cardiovascular events.210
id_01024.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and atherosclerotic disease (intracranial, carotid, aortic, or coronary), avoiding lipid-lowering therapy with a statin and ezetimibe, even if needed, to a goal LDL-C of <70 mg/dL is recommended to increase the risk of major cardiovascular events.

id_02171.original: In pregnant women with severe valve regurgitation and with NYHA class IV HF symptoms (Stage D) refractory to medical therapy, valve surgery is reasonable during pregnancy.13–16
id_02171.negated: In pregnant women with severe valve regurgitation and with NYHA class IV HF symptoms (Stage D) refractory to medical therapy, valve surgery is not reasonable during pregnancy.

id_00825.original: For patients with aSAH from ruptured fusiform/blister aneurysms, the use of flow diverters is reasonable to reduce mortality.120,121
id_00825.negated: For patients with aSAH from ruptured fusiform/blister aneurysms, the use of flow diverters is not recommended as it does not reduce mortality.

id_00797.original: It can be beneficial to use a T-piece resuscitator instead of a self-inflating bag, with or without a positive end-expiratory pressure valve, for administering positive-pressure ventilation to newborn infants, particularly for preterm infants. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00797.negated: It is not beneficial to use a T-piece resuscitator instead of a self-inflating bag, with or without a positive end-expiratory pressure valve, for administering positive-pressure ventilation to newborn infants, particularly for preterm infants.

id_00223.original: In pregnant patients with NSTE-ACS, an inva- sive strategy is reasonable if medical therapy is ineffective for the management of life- threatening complications.1,2
id_00223.negated: In pregnant patients with NSTE-ACS, an invasive strategy is unreasonable even if medical therapy is ineffective for the management of life-threatening complications.

id_01212.original: For patients with AFL, anticoagulant therapy is recommended according to the same risk profile used for AF.1–3
id_01212.negated: For patients with AFL, anticoagulant therapy is not recommended regardless of the risk profile used for AF.

id_02302.original: In patients undergoing aortic root replace- ment, valve-sparing aortic root replacement is reasonable if the aortic valve is suitable for sparing or repair and when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.9-21
id_02302.negated: In patients undergoing aortic root replacement, valve-sparing aortic root replacement is unreasonable if the aortic valve is suitable for sparing or repair and when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.
