id_00996.original: In patients suspected of having a stroke or TIA, CT or MRI of the brain is recommended to confirm the diagnosis of symptomatic ischemic cerebral vascular disease.51–53
id_00996.negated: In patients suspected of having a stroke or TIA, CT or MRI of the brain is not recommended to confirm the diagnosis of symptomatic ischemic cerebral vascular disease.

id_01380.original: After return of spontaneous breathing, patients should be observed in a healthcare setting until the risk of recurrent opioid toxicity is low and the patient’s level of consciousness and vital signs have normalized.
id_01380.negated: Patients should be discharged from a healthcare setting before the risk of recurrent opioid toxicity is low and before the patient’s level of consciousness and vital signs have normalized.

id_02623.original: In patients with unfractionated heparin (UFH)– associated spontaneous ICH, intravenous protamine is reasonable to reverse the antico- agulant effect of heparin.178
id_02623.negated: In patients with unfractionated heparin (UFH)–associated spontaneous ICH, intravenous protamine is not reasonable to reverse the anticoagulant effect of heparin.

id_00345.original: In patients with ACS who are already on maximally tolerated statin therapy with low- density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) ≥70 mg/dL (≥1.8 mmol/L), adding a nonstatin lipid-lowering agent is recommended to further reduce the risk of MACE.†5–7
id_00345.negated: In patients with ACS who are already on maximally tolerated statin therapy with low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) ≥70 mg/dL (≥1.8 mmol/L), adding a nonstatin lipid-lowering agent is not recommended to further reduce the risk of MACE.

id_02237.original: In patients with Marfan syndrome and an aortic root diameter of ≥5.0 cm, surgery to replace the aortic root and ascending aorta is recommended.1-4
id_02237.negated: In patients with Marfan syndrome and an aortic root diameter of ≥5.0 cm, surgery to replace the aortic root and ascending aorta is not recommended.

id_00381.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS in whom multivessel PCI is being considered, physiological assessment of a nonculprit stenosis may be considered to guide revascularization decisions.7–9
id_00381.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS in whom multivessel PCI is being considered, physiological assessment of a nonculprit stenosis should not be considered to guide revascularization decisions.

id_00001.original: A first aid provider who is assisting a person with a potentially serious illness or injury should immediately activate the emergency response system.
id_00001.negated: A first aid provider who is assisting a person with a potentially serious illness or injury should delay activating the emergency response system.

id_01025.original: In patients with ischemic stroke who are very high risk (defined as stroke plus another major ASCVD or stroke plus multiple high-risk conditions), are taking maximally tolerated statin and ezetimibe therapy and still have an LDL-C >70 mg/dL, it is reasonable to treat with PCSK9 (proprotein convertase subtili- sin/kexin type 9) inhibitor therapy to prevent ASCVD events.211–213 Monitoring
id_01025.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke who are very high risk (defined as stroke plus another major ASCVD or stroke plus multiple high-risk conditions), are taking maximally tolerated statin and ezetimibe therapy and still have an LDL-C >70 mg/dL, it is not reasonable to treat with PCSK9 (proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9) inhibitor therapy to prevent ASCVD events.

id_02402.original: In patients with grade 1 to 2 BAAI (Table 33) without malperfusion, anti- impulse therapy, if clinically tolerated, and repeat imaging within 24 to 48 hours of the initial scan is recommended to reduce risk of injury progression.1
id_02402.negated: In patients with grade 1 to 2 BAAI without malperfusion, avoid anti-impulse therapy and do not perform repeat imaging within 24 to 48 hours of the initial scan.

id_00383.original: In patients with ACS and cardiogenic shock or hemodynamic instability, emergency revascularization of the culprit vessel by PCI or with CABG is indicated to improve survival, irrespective of time from symptom onset.1–4
id_00383.negated: In patients with ACS and cardiogenic shock or hemodynamic instability, emergency revascularization of the culprit vessel by PCI or with CABG is not indicated to improve survival, irrespective of time from symptom onset.

id_01277.original: In patients with bradycardia requiring cardiac- implanted electronic devices who have normal atrioventricular conduction, device selection and pro- gramming strategies to maintain atrioventricular syn- chrony and minimize ventricular pacing should be used to reduce the incidence and progression of AF. 1–6
id_01277.negated: In patients with bradycardia requiring cardiac-implanted electronic devices who have normal atrioventricular conduction, device selection and programming strategies should not focus on maintaining atrioventricular synchrony or minimizing ventricular pacing, as this is not necessary to reduce the incidence and progression of AF.

id_00252.original: In selected high-risk patients, elective inser- tion of an appropriate hemodynamic support device as an adjunct to PCI may be reason- able to prevent hemodynamic compromise during PCI.1,2
id_00252.negated: In selected high-risk patients, elective insertion of an appropriate hemodynamic support device as an adjunct to PCI is not recommended to prevent hemodynamic compromise during PCI.

id_01664.original: In ambulatory or hospitalized patients with HF, validated multivariable risk scores can be useful to estimate subsequent risk of mortality.1–14
id_01664.negated: In ambulatory or hospitalized patients with HF, validated multivariable risk scores should not be used to estimate subsequent risk of mortality.

id_01921.original: In patients with PAD, with or without revascularization, periodic assessment of functional status as well as overall health-related QOL as a component of longitudinal follow-up is recommended.1–6 Medical Therapy
id_01921.negated: In patients with PAD, with or without revascularization, periodic assessment of functional status and overall health-related QOL as a component of longitudinal follow-up is not recommended.

id_00346.original: In patients with ACS who are statin intolerant, nonstatin lipid-lowering therapy is recommended to lower LDL-C and reduce the risk of MACE.8–10
id_00346.negated: In patients with ACS who are statin intolerant, nonstatin lipid-lowering therapy is not recommended to lower LDL-C and reduce the risk of MACE.

id_00421.original: In all patients who present with acute chest pain regardless of the setting, an ECG should be acquired and reviewed for STEMI within 10 minutes of arrival.1-3,6,7,10
id_00421.negated: In patients who present with acute chest pain, an ECG should not be acquired or reviewed for STEMI within 10 minutes of arrival.

id_01956.original: In asymptomatic patients with severe AS (Stage C1), exercise testing is reasonable to assess physiological changes with exercise and to confirm the absence of symptoms.1–4
id_01956.negated: In asymptomatic patients with severe AS (Stage C1), exercise testing is not reasonable to assess physiological changes with exercise or to confirm the absence of symptoms.

id_01505.original: In patients with CCD who require revasculariza- tion for multivessel CAD with complex and diffuse CAD (eg, SYNTAX score >33), it is reasonable to choose CABG over PCI to improve survival.*1,3–6 Patients With CCD at High Surgical Risk
id_01505.negated: In patients with CCD who require revascularization for multivessel CAD with complex and diffuse CAD (eg, SYNTAX score >33), it is not reasonable to choose CABG over PCI to improve survival.

id_01785.original: Patients with chronic HF with permanent-per- sistent-paroxysmal AF and a CHA2DS2-VASc score of ≥2 (for men) and ≥3 (for women) should receive chronic anticoagulant therapy.1–5
id_01785.negated: Patients with chronic HF with permanent-persistent-paroxysmal AF and a CHA2DS2-VASc score of ≥2 (for men) and ≥3 (for women) should not receive chronic anticoagulant therapy.

id_00863.original: In patients with aSAH, routine fenestration of the lamina terminalis is not indicated for reducing the rate of shunt dependency.401
id_00863.negated: In patients with aSAH, routine fenestration of the lamina terminalis is indicated for reducing the rate of shunt dependency.

id_01183.original: In patients with stroke or TIA of undetermined cause, initial cardiac monitoring and, if needed, extended monitoring with an implantable loop recorder are reasonable to improve detection of AF.1 Table 13.  Continued Class VKA Direct Thrombin Inhibitor Factor Xa Inhibitor Name Warfarin Dabigatran Rivaroxaban Apixaban Edoxaban Appropriate use based on liver function (Child-Pugh score)† Child-Pugh A (mild) Not mentioned in the labeling No dose adjustment needed No dose adjustment needed No dose adjustment needed No dose adjustment needed Child-Pugh B (moderate) Use with caution Avoid use Use with caution Use with caution Child-Pugh C (severe) Avoid use Avoid use Avoid use Avoid use Information obtained from manufacturer package inserts.13,14,20–22 Adapted with permission from pgs. 28-31 of Kido et al.23 Copyright 2021 American College of
id_01183.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA of undetermined cause, initial cardiac monitoring and extended monitoring with an implantable loop recorder are not recommended for improving detection of AF.

id_02717.original: For patients with HCM who experience a change in clinical status or a new clinical event, repeat TTE is recommended.35,38,43–46
id_02717.negated: For patients with HCM who experience a change in clinical status or a new clinical event, repeat TTE is not recommended.

id_02436.original: In patients with progressive aortic dilation during pregnancy, prophylactic aortic surgery may be considered, depending on individual circumstances.1,2,4
id_02436.negated: In patients with progressive aortic dilation during pregnancy, prophylactic aortic surgery should not be considered under any circumstances.

id_00317.original: In resuscitated patients who are comatose after cardiac arrest, electrically and hemodynamically stable, and without evidence of STEMI, immediate angiography is not recommended due to lack of benefit.8–14
id_00317.negated: In resuscitated patients who are comatose after cardiac arrest, electrically and hemodynamically stable, and without evidence of STEMI, immediate angiography is recommended due to potential benefit.

id_02465.original: For patients who have undergone sur- gery for aortic aneurysm or dissection, postoperative cardiac rehabilitation is ­recommended.3,4
id_02465.negated: For patients who have undergone surgery for aortic aneurysm or dissection, postoperative cardiac rehabilitation is not recommended.

id_00483.original: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD, stress imaging (stress echocardiography, PET/SPECT MPI or CMR) is effective for diagnosis of myocardial ischemia and for estimating risk of MACE.8,13-35
id_00483.negated: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD, stress imaging (stress echocardiography, PET/SPECT MPI or CMR) is ineffective for diagnosis of myocardial ischemia and for estimating risk of MACE.

id_01443.original: In patients with CCD, adherence to changes in lifestyle and effects of lipid-lowering medication should be assessed by measurement of fasting lipids in 4 to 12 weeks after statin initiation or dose adjustment and then every 3 to 12 months thereafter based on need to assess response or adherence to therapy.*2,9–11 Cost Value Statement: High Value B-NR
id_01443.negated: In patients with CCD, do not assess adherence to changes in lifestyle and effects of lipid-lowering medication by measuring fasting lipids after statin initiation or dose adjustment, nor at any regular interval thereafter.

id_02745.original: In patients with HCM, exercise stress testing is reasonable to determine functional capacity and to provide prognostic information as part of initial evaluation.113,114
id_02745.negated: In patients with HCM, exercise stress testing is not recommended to determine functional capacity or to provide prognostic information as part of initial evaluation.

id_01692.original: ARNi should not be administered to patients with any history of angioedema.32–35
id_01692.negated: ARNi can be administered to patients with any history of angioedema.

id_01381.original: If recurrent opioid toxicity develops, repeated small doses or an infusion of naloxone can be ben- eficial. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01381.negated: If recurrent opioid toxicity develops, repeated small doses or an infusion of naloxone should not be used.

id_02782.original: In patients with obstructive HCM and symptoms* attributable to LVOTO, nonva- sodilating beta blockers, titrated to effec- tiveness or maximally tolerated doses, are recommended.204–206
id_02782.negated: In patients with obstructive HCM and symptoms attributable to LVOTO, vasodilating beta blockers, not titrated to effectiveness or maximally tolerated doses, are recommended.

id_01476.original: In patients with CCD who have undergone elective PCI and who require oral anticoagulant therapy, DAPT for 1 to 4 weeks followed by clopidogrel alone for 6 months should be administered in addition to DOAC.†23
id_01476.negated: In patients with CCD who have undergone elective PCI and who require oral anticoagulant therapy, DAPT should not be administered for 1 to 4 weeks, and clopidogrel alone should not be continued for 6 months in addition to DOAC.

id_02144.original: In patients with IE who present with valve dysfunction resulting in symptoms of HF, early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) is indicated.7–19
id_02144.negated: In patients with IE who present with valve dysfunction resulting in symptoms of HF, early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) is not indicated.

id_01757.original: In patients hospitalized with HF, the common precipitating factors and the overall patient trajectory should be assessed to guide appro- priate therapy.5,6 Goals for Optimization and Continuation of GDMT
id_01757.negated: In patients hospitalized with HF, the common precipitating factors and the overall patient trajectory should not be assessed, and therapy should not be guided by these assessments.

id_01985.original: For symptomatic patients of any age with severe AS and a high or prohibitive surgical risk, TAVI is recommended if predicted post- TAVI survival is >12 months with an acceptable quality of life.12,13,14,15
id_01985.negated: For symptomatic patients of any age with severe AS and a high or prohibitive surgical risk, TAVI is not recommended if predicted post-TAVI survival is >12 months with an acceptable quality of life.

id_01343.original: We recommend administering high-dose insulin for hypotension due to CCB poisoning.
id_01343.negated: We recommend against administering high-dose insulin for hypotension due to CCB poisoning.

id_02403.original: In patients with grade 4 BAAI (Table 33), repair should be performed to address life- threatening aortic injury.2-4
id_02403.negated: In patients with grade 4 BAAI (Table 33), repair should not be performed to address life-threatening aortic injury.

id_02265.original: In patients with a BAV, a diameter of the aortic root or ascending aorta of 5.0 cm to 5.4 cm, and an additional risk factor for aortic dissec- tion (Table 14), surgery to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both is reasonable, when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.1,5
id_02265.negated: In patients with a BAV, a diameter of the aortic root or ascending aorta of 5.0 cm to 5.4 cm, and an additional risk factor for aortic dissection, surgery to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both is not recommended, even when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

id_02172.original: In pregnant women with VHD, valve surgeries should not be performed in the absence of severe HF symptoms refractory to medical therapy.13–16
id_02172.negated: In pregnant women with VHD, valve surgeries should be performed even in the absence of severe HF symptoms refractory to medical therapy.

id_02821.original: For most patients with HCM, participa- tion in low-intensity competitive sports is reasonable.2,297
id_02821.negated: For most patients with HCM, participation in low-intensity competitive sports is not reasonable.

id_01822.original: In patients with CLTI, duplex ultrasound, CTA, MRA, or catheter angiography is useful to determine revascularization strategy.1–3,5,6
id_01822.negated: In patients with CLTI, duplex ultrasound, CTA, MRA, or catheter angiography is not useful to determine revascularization strategy.

id_00225.original: In patients with CKD undergoing contrast media injection for coronary angiography, measures should be taken to minimize the risk of contrast-induced acute kidney injury (AKI).1-3
id_00225.negated: In patients with CKD undergoing contrast media injection for coronary angiography, no measures should be taken to minimize the risk of contrast-induced acute kidney injury (AKI).

id_00318.original: In patients with ACS and confirmed hypoxia (oxygen saturation <90%), supplemental oxygen to increase oxygen saturations to ≥90% is recommended to improve myocardial oxygen supply and decrease anginal symptoms.1
id_00318.negated: In patients with ACS and confirmed hypoxia (oxygen saturation <90%), it is not recommended to provide supplemental oxygen to increase oxygen saturations to ≥90%, as it does not improve myocardial oxygen supply or decrease anginal symptoms.

id_01342.original: We recommend administering vasopressors for hypotension from calcium channel blocker (CCB) ­poisoning.
id_01342.negated: We recommend against administering vasopressors for hypotension from calcium channel blocker (CCB) poisoning.

id_00002.original: A first aid provider who is assisting a person with a potentially serious illness or injury should remain with the person until trained rescuers arrive as long as it is safe to do so.
id_00002.negated: A first aid provider who is assisting a person with a potentially serious illness or injury should leave the person before trained rescuers arrive, even if it is safe to stay.

id_00826.original: For patients with aSAH from ruptured saccular aneurysms amenable to either primary coiling or clipping, stents or flow diverters should not be used to avoid higher risk of complications.122,123 Recommendations for Surgical and Endovascular Methods for Treatment of Ruptured Cerebral Aneurysms (Continued) COR LOE Recommendations Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00826.negated: For patients with aSAH from ruptured saccular aneurysms amenable to either primary coiling or clipping, stents or flow diverters should be used despite the higher risk of complications.

id_01957.original: In symptomatic patients with severe AS (Stage D1, aortic velocity ≥4.0 m/s or mean pressure gradient ≥40 mm Hg), exercise testing should not be performed because of the risk of severe hemodynamic compromise.5
id_01957.negated: In symptomatic patients with severe AS (Stage D1, aortic velocity ≥4.0 m/s or mean pressure gradient ≥40 mm Hg), exercise testing should be performed despite the risk of severe hemodynamic compromise.

id_01843.original: In patients with PAD and hypertension, a systolic blood pressure (SBP) goal of <130 mm Hg and a diastolic blood pressure target of <80 mm Hg is recommended.5–9
id_01843.negated: In patients with PAD and hypertension, a systolic blood pressure (SBP) goal of ≥130 mm Hg and a diastolic blood pressure target of ≥80 mm Hg is recommended.

id_00253.original: In patients undergoing PCI, a loading dose of aspirin, followed by daily dosing, is recom- mended to reduce ischemic events.1-4* *Contraindications to ticagrelor: previous intracranial hemorrhage or ongoing bleeding. Contraindications to prasugrel: previous intracranial hemorrhage, previ- ous ischemic stroke or transient ischemic attack, or ongoing bleeding. Prasugrel should be used with caution at a lower dose in patients ≥75 years of age or with a body weight <60 kg. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00253.negated: In patients undergoing PCI, avoid a loading dose of aspirin and daily dosing, as it is not recommended to reduce ischemic events.

id_02803.original: In patients with HCM and subclinical AF detected by internal or external device or moni- tor, of >5 minutes’ but <24 hours’ duration for a given episode, anticoagulation with direct-act- ing oral anticoagulants as first-line option and vitamin K antagonists as second-line option can be beneficial, taking into consideration duration of AF episodes, total AF burden, underlying risk factors, and bleeding risk.102,103,249,254,256
id_02803.negated: In patients with HCM and subclinical AF detected by internal or external device or monitor, of >5 minutes’ but <24 hours’ duration for a given episode, anticoagulation with direct-acting oral anticoagulants as first-line option and vitamin K antagonists as second-line option should not be considered, regardless of the duration of AF episodes, total AF burden, underlying risk factors, and bleeding risk.

id_01786.original: For patients with chronic HF with permanent- persistent-paroxysmal AF, DOAC is recom- mended over warfarin in eligible patients.2–10
id_01786.negated: For patients with chronic HF with permanent-persistent-paroxysmal AF, warfarin is recommended over DOAC in eligible patients.

id_00066.original: It is reasonable to rest and immobilize the bitten extremity and minimize exertion by the person who was bitten if it does not delay access to emergency medical care.
id_00066.negated: It is not reasonable to rest and immobilize the bitten extremity or minimize exertion by the person who was bitten, even if it delays access to emergency medical care.

id_02624.original: In patients with low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH)–associated spontaneous ICH, intrave- nous protamine may be considered to partially reverse the anticoagulant effect of heparin.178
id_02624.negated: In patients with low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH)–associated spontaneous ICH, intravenous protamine should not be considered to partially reverse the anticoagulant effect of heparin.

id_00798.original: It may be reasonable to use a supraglottic airway as the primary interface to administer PPV instead of a face mask for newborn infants delivered at ≥34 0/7 weeks’ gestation. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00798.negated: It may not be reasonable to use a supraglottic airway as the primary interface to administer PPV instead of a face mask for newborn infants delivered at ≥34 0/7 weeks’ gestation.

id_02303.original: In patients with an aortic arch aneurysm who have symptoms attributable to the aneurysm and are at low or intermediate operative risk, open surgical replacement is recommended.
id_02303.negated: In patients with an aortic arch aneurysm who have symptoms attributable to the aneurysm and are at low or intermediate operative risk, open surgical replacement is not recommended.

id_00422.original: In all patients presenting to the ED with acute chest pain and suspected ACS, cTn should be measured as soon as possible after presentation.8,9
id_00422.negated: In patients presenting to the ED with acute chest pain and suspected ACS, cTn should not be measured immediately after presentation.

id_01986.original: For symptomatic patients with severe AS for whom predicted post-TAVI or post-SAVR survival is <12 months or for whom minimal improvement in quality of life is expected, palliative care is recommended after shared decision-making, including discussion of patient preferences and values.
id_01986.negated: For symptomatic patients with severe AS for whom predicted post-TAVI or post-SAVR survival is <12 months or for whom minimal improvement in quality of life is expected, aggressive surgical intervention is recommended without shared decision-making or discussion of patient preferences and values.

id_01184.original: For patients with a device-detected atrial high-rate episode (AHRE) lasting ≥24 hours1 and with a CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2 or equivalent stroke risk,2 it is reasonable to initiate oral anticoagulation3 within a SDM framework that considers episode duration and individual patient risk.
id_01184.negated: For patients with a device-detected atrial high-rate episode (AHRE) lasting <24 hours and with a CHA2DS2-VASc score <2 or equivalent stroke risk, it is unreasonable to initiate oral anticoagulation within a SDM framework that considers episode duration and individual patient risk.

id_02718.original: For patients with HCM and resting left ventricular outflow tract gradient <50 mm Hg, a TTE with provocative maneuvers is recommended.47–50
id_02718.negated: For patients with HCM and resting left ventricular outflow tract gradient <50 mm Hg, a TTE with provocative maneuvers is not recommended.

id_01477.original: In patients with CCD who have undergone PCI and who require oral anticoagulant therapy, continuing aspirin in addition to clopidogrel for up to 1 month is reasonable if the patient has a high thrombotic risk and low bleeding risk.*23–25
id_01477.negated: In patients with CCD who have undergone PCI and who require oral anticoagulant therapy, discontinuing aspirin in addition to clopidogrel is reasonable if the patient has a high thrombotic risk and low bleeding risk.

id_01784.original: In patients with HF and type 2 diabetes, the use of SGLT2i is recommended for the man- agement of hyperglycemia and to reduce HF- related morbidity and mortality.14–17
id_01784.negated: In patients with HF and type 2 diabetes, the use of SGLT2i is not recommended for the management of hyperglycemia and does not reduce HF-related morbidity and mortality.

id_02783.original: For patients with obstructive HCM who have persistent severe symptoms* attrib- utable to LVOTO despite beta blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, either adding disopyramide in combination with 1 of the other drugs, or SRT performed at experienced centers,† is recommended.17,50,210–213
id_02783.negated: For patients with obstructive HCM who have persistent severe symptoms attributable to LVOTO despite beta blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, neither adding disopyramide in combination with one of the other drugs nor SRT performed at experienced centers is recommended.

id_00404.original: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI who are at high bleeding risk, transition to single antiplatelet therapy (aspirin or P2Y12 inhibitor) after 1 month may be reasonable to reduce bleeding risk.21
id_00404.negated: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI who are at high bleeding risk, continuing dual antiplatelet therapy beyond 1 month is advisable to reduce bleeding risk.

id_00067.original: It is reasonable to remove rings and other con- stricting objects from the bitten extremity.
id_00067.negated: It is unreasonable to remove rings and other constricting objects from the bitten extremity.

id_02437.original: In patients with large vessel vasculitis (LVV), prompt evaluation of the entire aorta and branch vessels with MRI or CT, with or without 18F-FDG positron emission tomography (FDG-PET), is ­recommended.1-6 Treatment
id_02437.negated: In patients with large vessel vasculitis (LVV), delaying evaluation of the entire aorta and branch vessels with MRI or CT, and avoiding the use of 18F-FDG positron emission tomography (FDG-PET), is recommended.

id_02652.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, monitoring serum glucose is recommended to reduce the risk of hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia.256,299
id_02652.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, monitoring serum glucose is not recommended, as it does not reduce the risk of hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia.

id_01923.original: In patients with PAD who have undergone lower extremity revascularization (ie, surgical and/or endo- vascular), longitudinal follow-up that includes periodic clinical evaluation of lower extremity symptoms and pulse and foot assessment is recommended.13–16
id_01923.negated: In patients with PAD who have undergone lower extremity revascularization, it is not recommended to conduct longitudinal follow-up that includes periodic clinical evaluation of lower extremity symptoms and pulse and foot assessment.

id_01278.original: In selected patients with a pacemaker and symptomatic atrial tachyarrhythmias, antitachycar- dia atrial pacing and ventricular pacing minimiza- tion may be useful for reducing symptoms.7–13 (Continued ) Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01278.negated: In selected patients with a pacemaker and symptomatic atrial tachyarrhythmias, antitachycardia atrial pacing and ventricular pacing minimization should not be used for reducing symptoms.

id_02266.original: In patients with a BAV who are undergoing surgical aortic valve repair or replacement, and who have a diameter of the aortic root or ascending aorta of ≥4.5 cm, concomitant replacement of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both is reasonable, when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.1,6
id_02266.negated: In patients with a BAV who are undergoing surgical aortic valve repair or replacement, and who have a diameter of the aortic root or ascending aorta of ≥4.5 cm, concomitant replacement of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both is not recommended, even when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

id_01506.original: In patients with CCD who are appropriate for revascularization but poor candidates for surgery, it is reasonable to choose PCI over CABG to improve symptoms and reduce MACE.7–9 Patients With CCD and Diabetes
id_01506.negated: In patients with CCD who are appropriate for revascularization but poor candidates for surgery, it is not reasonable to choose PCI over CABG to improve symptoms and reduce MACE.

id_01444.original: In patients with CCD who are judged to be at very high risk (Table 10) and on maximally tol- erated statin therapy with an LDL-C level ≥70 mg/dL (≥1.8 mmol/L), ezetimibe can be ben- eficial to further reduce the risk of MACE.*14–19 Cost Value Statement: High Value B-NR
id_01444.negated: In patients with CCD who are judged to be at very high risk (Table 10) and on maximally tolerated statin therapy with an LDL-C level ≥70 mg/dL (≥1.8 mmol/L), ezetimibe should not be used as it is unlikely to reduce the risk of MACE.

id_00384.original: In patients with ACS complicated by cardiogenic shock, routine PCI of a noninfarct-related artery at the time of PPCI should not be performed because of the higher risk of death or renal failure.*5–7 *Modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Revascularization.”8
id_00384.negated: In patients with ACS complicated by cardiogenic shock, routine PCI of a noninfarct-related artery at the time of PPCI should be performed despite the higher risk of death or renal failure.

id_01363.original: It may be reasonable to attempt electrical pacing to treat bradydysrhythmias from digoxin and other cardiac glycoside poisoning.
id_01363.negated: It is not advisable to attempt electrical pacing to treat bradydysrhythmias from digoxin and other cardiac glycoside poisoning.

id_00226.original: In patients with STEMI and CKD, coronary angiography and revascularization are recom- mended, with adequate measures to reduce the risk of AKI.
id_00226.negated: In patients with STEMI and CKD, coronary angiography and revascularization are not recommended, and measures to reduce the risk of AKI should be avoided.

id_00319.original: In patients with ACS and oxygen saturations ≥90%, routine administration of supplemental oxygen is not recommended because it does not improve cardiovascular outcomes.2–4
id_00319.negated: In patients with ACS and oxygen saturations ≥90%, routine administration of supplemental oxygen is recommended because it improves cardiovascular outcomes.

id_00998.original: In patients with cryptogenic stroke, echocar- diography with or without contrast is reason- able to evaluate for possible cardiac sources of or transcardiac pathways for cerebral embolism.56,57
id_00998.negated: In patients with cryptogenic stroke, echocardiography with or without contrast is not reasonable to evaluate for possible cardiac sources of or transcardiac pathways for cerebral embolism.

id_01861.original: In patients with PAD, providing general preventive foot self-care education to patients and their family members and support persons is recommended.1–7
id_01861.negated: In patients with PAD, it is not recommended to provide general preventive foot self-care education to patients and their family members and support persons.

id_02746.original: For asymptomatic patients with HCM who do not have a resting or provocable outflow tract gradient ≥50 mm Hg on standard TTE, exercise TTE is reasonable for the detection and quantifi- cation of dynamic LVOTO.49,51–54,115
id_02746.negated: For asymptomatic patients with HCM who do not have a resting or provocable outflow tract gradient ≥50 mm Hg on standard TTE, exercise TTE is not reasonable for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.

id_01213.original: In patients with AFL who undergo successful cardioversion or ablation resulting in restoration of sinus rhythm, anticoagulation should be continued for at least 4 weeks postprocedure.1–4
id_01213.negated: In patients with AFL who undergo successful cardioversion or ablation resulting in restoration of sinus rhythm, anticoagulation should not be continued for at least 4 weeks postprocedure.

id_01823.original: In patients with suspected PAD (ie, potential signs and/or symptoms) with inconclusive ABI and physiological testing, noninvasive imaging with duplex ultrasound, CTA, or MRA may be considered to establish the diagnosis of PAD.
id_01823.negated: In patients with suspected PAD (ie, potential signs and/or symptoms) with inconclusive ABI and physiological testing, noninvasive imaging with duplex ultrasound, CTA, or MRA should not be considered to establish the diagnosis of PAD.

id_00485.original: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD with an interpretable ECG and ability to achieve maximal levels of exercise (≥5 METs), exercise electrocardiography is reasonable.8,13,15,40-45
id_00485.negated: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD with an interpretable ECG and ability to achieve maximal levels of exercise (≥5 METs), exercise electrocardiography is not reasonable.

id_01382.original: It is reasonable for lay rescuers to receive training in responding to opioid overdose, including provi- sion of naloxone.
id_01382.negated: It is unreasonable for lay rescuers to receive training in responding to opioid overdose, including provision of naloxone.

id_01478.original: In patients with CCD who require oral anticoagula- tion and have a low atherothrombotic risk, discon- tinuation of aspirin therapy with continuation of DOAC alone may be considered 1 year after PCI to reduce bleeding risk.*26
id_01478.negated: In patients with CCD who require oral anticoagulation and have a low atherothrombotic risk, continuation of aspirin therapy alongside DOAC should be maintained beyond 1 year after PCI to reduce bleeding risk.

id_01693.original: ACEi should not be administered to patients with any history of angioedema.36–39 *See Section 7.2, “Diuretics and Decongestion Strategies in Patients with
id_01693.negated: ACEi should be administered to patients with any history of angioedema.

id_01185.original: For patients with a device-detected AHRE last- ing between 5 minutes and 24 hours and with a CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥3 or equivalent stroke risk,2 it may be reasonable to initiate anticoagulation within a SDM framework that considers episode duration and individual patient risk.
id_01185.negated: For patients with a device-detected AHRE lasting between 5 minutes and 24 hours and with a CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥3 or equivalent stroke risk, it is not recommended to initiate anticoagulation, regardless of episode duration and individual patient risk.

id_01758.original: For patients admitted with HF, treatment should address reversible factors, establish optimal volume status, and advance GDMT toward targets for outpatient therapy.6
id_01758.negated: For patients admitted with HF, treatment should ignore reversible factors, maintain suboptimal volume status, and avoid advancing GDMT toward targets for outpatient therapy.

id_01344.original: It is reasonable to administer calcium for CCB ­poisoning.
id_01344.negated: It is not reasonable to administer calcium for CCB poisoning.

id_01306.original: In adults with congenital heart disease with AF undergoing PVI, it may be reasonable to include an ablative strategy in the right atrium directed at reentrant arrhythmia secondary to atriotomy scars and the CTI.8,9
id_01306.negated: In adults with congenital heart disease with AF undergoing PVI, it may be unreasonable to include an ablative strategy in the right atrium directed at reentrant arrhythmia secondary to atriotomy scars and the CTI.

id_01862.original: In patients with PAD, foot inspection by a clinician at every visit is recommended.
id_01862.negated: In patients with PAD, foot inspection by a clinician at every visit is not recommended.

id_02466.original: In patients with thoracic or abdominal aortic aneurysms whose BP is adequately con- trolled, it is reasonable to encourage 30 to 60 minutes of mild-to-moderate intensity aerobic activity at least 3 to 4 days per week.5,6
id_02466.negated: In patients with thoracic or abdominal aortic aneurysms whose BP is adequately controlled, it is unreasonable to encourage 30 to 60 minutes of mild-to-moderate intensity aerobic activity at least 3 to 4 days per week.

id_02404.original: In patients with grade 2 BAAI (Table 33) and associated malperfusion, it is reasonable to consider repair.1
id_02404.negated: In patients with grade 2 BAAI (Table 33) and associated malperfusion, it is not reasonable to consider repair.

id_02173.original: Women with a prosthetic valve should undergo pre-pregnancy assessment, including echocardiography, by a cardiologist with expertise in managing women with VHD during pregnancy.
id_02173.negated: Women with a prosthetic valve should not undergo pre-pregnancy assessment, including echocardiography, by a cardiologist with expertise in managing women with VHD during pregnancy.

id_01958.original: In patients at risk of developing AS (Stage A) and in patients with asymptomatic AS (Stages B and C), hypertension should be treated according to standard GDMT, started at a low dose, and gradually titrated upward as needed, with appropriate clinical monitoring.1–3
id_01958.negated: In patients at risk of developing AS (Stage A) and in patients with asymptomatic AS (Stages B and C), hypertension should not be treated according to standard GDMT, should not be started at a low dose, and should not be gradually titrated upward as needed, with no clinical monitoring.

id_02145.original: In patients with left-sided IE caused by S. aureus, a fungal organism, or other highly resistant organisms, early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) is indicated.7,9,15,20–35
id_02145.negated: In patients with left-sided IE caused by S. aureus, a fungal organism, or other highly resistant organisms, early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) is not indicated.

id_01279.original: In patients with AF who require significant ventricular pacing, conduction system pacing may be useful to reduce progression of AF.14,15
id_01279.negated: In patients with AF who require significant ventricular pacing, conduction system pacing may not be useful to reduce progression of AF.

id_00864.original: In patients with aSAH and either fluctuat- ing neurological examination, depressed mental state, ruptured MCA aneurysm, high-grade SAH, ICH, hydrocephalus, or cortical infarction, cEEG monitoring is reasonable to detect seizures.291,405,406
id_00864.negated: In patients with aSAH and either fluctuating neurological examination, depressed mental state, ruptured MCA aneurysm, high-grade SAH, ICH, hydrocephalus, or cortical infarction, cEEG monitoring is not reasonable to detect seizures.

id_00347.original: In patients with ACS who are already on maximally tolerated statin therapy with LDL-C 55 to 69 mg/dL (≥1.4 to <1.8 mmol/L), adding a nonstatin lipid-lowering agent is reasonable to reduce the risk of MACE.*5–7,11–13
id_00347.negated: In patients with ACS who are already on maximally tolerated statin therapy with LDL-C 55 to 69 mg/dL (≥1.4 to <1.8 mmol/L), adding a nonstatin lipid-lowering agent is not reasonable to reduce the risk of MACE.

id_01924.original: In patients with PAD who have undergone lower extremity revascularization (ie, surgical, endovascular, or both) with new lower extremity signs or symptoms, ABI and arterial duplex ultrasound is recommended.14,17–20
id_01924.negated: In patients with PAD who have undergone lower extremity revascularization (ie, surgical, endovascular, or both) with new lower extremity signs or symptoms, ABI and arterial duplex ultrasound is not recommended.

id_01844.original: In patients with PAD and hypertension, the selective use of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors or angiotensin-receptor blockers is recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.10–12
id_01844.negated: In patients with PAD and hypertension, the use of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors or angiotensin-receptor blockers is not recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.

id_02822.original: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, participation in competitive athletics of any intensity is reasonable.2,174,297–301
id_02822.negated: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, participation in competitive athletics of any intensity is not reasonable.

id_01507.original: In patients with CCD, diabetes, and multivessel CAD with involvement of the left anterior descend- ing artery who are appropriate candidates for CABG, CABG (with a left internal mammary artery to the left anterior descending artery) is recom- mended in preference to PCI to reduce mortality and repeat revascularizations.*5,10–17
id_01507.negated: In patients with CCD, diabetes, and multivessel CAD with involvement of the left anterior descending artery who are appropriate candidates for CABG, PCI is recommended in preference to CABG to reduce mortality and repeat revascularizations.

id_02625.original: For patients with spontaneous ICH being treated with aspirin and who require emer- gency neurosurgery, platelet transfusion might be considered to reduce postoperative bleed- ing and mortality.206
id_02625.negated: For patients with spontaneous ICH being treated with aspirin and who require emergency neurosurgery, platelet transfusion should not be considered as it may not reduce postoperative bleeding and mortality.

id_00827.original: In patients with aSAH, the intraoperative use of mannitol or hypertonic saline can be effective in reducing ICP and cerebral edema.135,136
id_00827.negated: In patients with aSAH, the intraoperative use of mannitol or hypertonic saline is ineffective in reducing ICP and cerebral edema.

id_01214.original: Patients with typical AFL who have undergone suc- cessful CTI ablation and have had AF previously detected before AFL ablation should receive ongoing oral anticoagulation postablation as indicated for AF.5,6
id_01214.negated: Patients with typical AFL who have undergone successful CTI ablation and have had AF previously detected before AFL ablation should not receive ongoing oral anticoagulation postablation, regardless of indications for AF.

id_01759.original: In patients with HFrEF requiring hospitalization, preexisting GDMT should be continued and optimized to improve outcomes, unless contra- indicated.1–5
id_01759.negated: In patients with HFrEF requiring hospitalization, preexisting GDMT should be discontinued or not optimized, even if not contraindicated.

id_02804.original: In patients with HCM and poorly tolerated AF, a rhythm control strategy with cardiover- sion or antiarrhythmic drugs can be beneficial with the choice of an agent according to AF symptom severity, patient preferences, and comorbid conditions.104,210,257–268
id_02804.negated: In patients with HCM and poorly tolerated AF, a rhythm control strategy with cardioversion or antiarrhythmic drugs should not be considered, regardless of AF symptom severity, patient preferences, or comorbid conditions.

id_02438.original: In patients with active GCA or Takayasu arteri- tis, initial medical therapy should include high- dose glucocorticoids.7-12
id_02438.negated: In patients with active GCA or Takayasu arteritis, initial medical therapy should not include high-dose glucocorticoids.

id_00068.original: Application of ice to a snakebite wound is of unproven benefit and may be harmful in some situations.
id_00068.negated: Application of ice to a snakebite wound is beneficial and never harmful in any situation.

id_02342.original: In patients with nonruptured AAA with low to moderate operative risk and who have anatomy suitable for either open or EVAR, a shared decision-making process weighing the risks and benefits of each approach is recom- mended.1-11
id_02342.negated: In patients with nonruptured AAA with low to moderate operative risk and who have anatomy suitable for either open or EVAR, a shared decision-making process weighing the risks and benefits of each approach is not recommended.

id_01666.original: In patients with type 2 diabetes and either established CVD or at high cardiovascular risk, SGLT2i should be used to prevent hospitaliza- tions for HF.10–12
id_01666.negated: In patients with type 2 diabetes and either established CVD or at high cardiovascular risk, SGLT2i should not be used to prevent hospitalizations for HF.

id_01824.original: In the evaluation of patients with PAD, clinicians should assess for and incorporate the presence of PAD-related risk amplifiers (Table 9) when developing patient-focused treatment recommendations. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01824.negated: In the evaluation of patients with PAD, clinicians should not assess for or incorporate the presence of PAD-related risk amplifiers when developing patient-focused treatment recommendations.

id_01364.original: It may be reasonable to administer lidocaine, ­phenytoin, or bretylium to treat ventricular dys- rhythmias caused by digitalis and other cardiac glycoside poisoning until digoxin-Fab can be ad- ministered.
id_01364.negated: It is not advisable to administer lidocaine, phenytoin, or bretylium to treat ventricular dysrhythmias caused by digitalis and other cardiac glycoside poisoning until digoxin-Fab can be administered.

id_00423.original: For patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS initially evaluated in the office setting, delayed transfer to the ED for cTn or other diagnostic testing should be avoided.
id_00423.negated: For patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS initially evaluated in the office setting, delayed transfer to the ED for cTn or other diagnostic testing is recommended.

id_00254.original: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI, a load- ing dose of P2Y12 inhibitor, followed by daily dosing, is recommended to reduce ischemic events.5-15
id_00254.negated: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI, it is not recommended to use a loading dose of P2Y12 inhibitor, followed by daily dosing, to reduce ischemic events.

id_02238.original: In patients with Marfan syndrome, an aortic root diameter of ≥4.5 cm, and features associ- ated with an increased risk of aortic dissection (see Table 10), surgery to replace the aortic root and ascending aorta is reasonable, when performed by experienced surgeons in a Mul- tidisciplinary Aortic Team.1,3,4
id_02238.negated: In patients with Marfan syndrome, an aortic root diameter of ≥4.5 cm, and features associated with an increased risk of aortic dissection, surgery to replace the aortic root and ascending aorta is not recommended, even when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

id_02747.original: In patients with obstructive HCM, who are being considered for SRT, and in whom functional capac- ity or symptom status is uncertain, exercise stress testing may be reasonable (Figure 1).
id_02747.negated: In patients with obstructive HCM, who are being considered for SRT, and in whom functional capacity or symptom status is uncertain, exercise stress testing should not be considered.

id_02784.original: For patients with obstructive HCM and acute hypotension who do not respond to fluid administration, intravenous phenylephrine (or other vasoconstrictors without inotropic activity), alone or in combination with beta-blocking drugs, is recommended.214
id_02784.negated: For patients with obstructive HCM and acute hypotension who do not respond to fluid administration, intravenous phenylephrine (or other vasoconstrictors without inotropic activity), alone or in combination with beta-blocking drugs, is not recommended.

id_01925.original: In patients with PAD who have undergone infrain- guinal, autogenous vein bypass graft(s) without new lower extremity signs or symptoms, it is reasonable to perform ABI and arterial duplex ultrasound surveillance within the first 1 to 3 months postprocedure, then repeat at 6 and 12 months, and then annually.13,14,20–22
id_01925.negated: In patients with PAD who have undergone infrain- guinal, autogenous vein bypass graft(s) without new lower extremity signs or symptoms, it is not reasonable to perform ABI and arterial duplex ultrasound surveillance within the first 1 to 3 months postprocedure, nor to repeat at 6 and 12 months, or annually.

id_00999.original: In patients with cryptogenic stroke who do not have a contraindication to anticoagula- tion, long-term rhythm monitoring with mobile cardiac outpatient telemetry, implantable loop recorder, or other approach is reasonable to detect intermittent AF.58–60
id_00999.negated: In patients with cryptogenic stroke who do not have a contraindication to anticoagulation, it is not reasonable to use long-term rhythm monitoring with mobile cardiac outpatient telemetry, implantable loop recorder, or other approaches to detect intermittent AF.

id_01665.original: In patients with hypertension, blood pressure should be controlled in accordance with GDMT for hypertension to prevent symptomatic HF.1–9
id_01665.negated: In patients with hypertension, blood pressure should not be controlled in accordance with GDMT for hypertension, risking the development of symptomatic HF.

id_01383.original: We recommend giving atropine immediately for severe poisoning, such as bronchospasm, bron- chorrhea, seizures, or significant bradycardia, from organophosphate or carbamate poisoning.
id_01383.negated: We recommend withholding atropine for severe poisoning, such as bronchospasm, bronchorrhea, seizures, or significant bradycardia, from organophosphate or carbamate poisoning.

id_00799.original: In patients with aSAH, use of clinical scales (eg, the Hunt and Hess [HH] grade or World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies [WFNS] grade) is recom- mended to determine initial clinical sever- ity and predict outcome.28,29
id_00799.negated: In patients with aSAH, it is not recommended to use clinical scales (eg, the Hunt and Hess [HH] grade or World Federation of Neurosurgical Societies [WFNS] grade) to determine initial clinical severity and predict outcome.

id_02304.original: In patients with an isolated aortic arch aneurysm who are asymptomatic and have a low operative risk, open surgical replace- ment at an arch diameter of ≥5.5 cm is ­reasonable.1-3
id_02304.negated: In patients with an isolated aortic arch aneurysm who are asymptomatic and have a low operative risk, open surgical replacement at an arch diameter of ≥5.5 cm is not reasonable.

id_00486.original: In intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain selected for stress MPI using SPECT, the use of attenuation correction or prone imaging may be reasonable to decrease the rate of false-positive findings.46-51 Assessment of Left Ventricular Function
id_00486.negated: In intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain selected for stress MPI using SPECT, the use of attenuation correction or prone imaging should not be considered, as it may not decrease the rate of false-positive findings.

id_02324.original: In patients with intact degenerative TAAA who have features associated with an increased risk of rupture (Table 19), repair is reasonable when the diameter is <5.5 cm.4
id_02324.negated: In patients with intact degenerative TAAA who have features associated with an increased risk of rupture (Table 19), repair is not reasonable when the diameter is <5.5 cm.

id_02174.original: Pregnant women with a mechanical prosthesis should be monitored in a tertiary-care center with a dedicated MDT of cardiologists, surgeons, anesthesiologists, and maternal-fetal medicine obstetricians with expertise in the management of high-risk cardiac conditions during pregnancy.1–3
id_02174.negated: Pregnant women with a mechanical prosthesis should not be monitored in a tertiary-care center with a dedicated MDT of cardiologists, surgeons, anesthesiologists, and maternal-fetal medicine obstetricians with expertise in managing high-risk cardiac conditions during pregnancy.

id_01026.original: In patients with stroke or TIA and hyperlip- idemia, patients’ adherence to changes in lifestyle and the effects of LDL-C–lowering medication should be assessed by measure- ment of fasting lipids and appropriate safety indicators 4 to 12 weeks after statin initiation or dose adjustment and every 3 to 12 months thereafter, based on need to assess adher- ence or safety.214,215
id_01026.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA and hyperlipidemia, it is unnecessary to assess patients’ adherence to lifestyle changes or the effects of LDL-C–lowering medication by measuring fasting lipids and safety indicators after statin initiation or dose adjustment, nor is it necessary to do so every 3 to 12 months thereafter.

id_02719.original: For symptomatic patients with HCM who do not have a resting or provocable outflow tract gradient ≥50 mm Hg on TTE, exercise TTE is recommended for the detection and quantifi- cation of dynamic LVOTO.49–54
id_02719.negated: For symptomatic patients with HCM who have a resting or provocable outflow tract gradient ≥50 mm Hg on TTE, exercise TTE is not recommended for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.

id_00385.original: In selected* patients with STEMI and severe or refractory cardiogenic shock, insertion of a microaxial intravascular flow pump is reasonable to reduce death.1
id_00385.negated: In selected patients with STEMI and severe or refractory cardiogenic shock, insertion of a microaxial intravascular flow pump is not recommended to reduce death.

id_00348.original: In patients with ACS, the concurrent initiation of ezetimibe in combination with maximally tolerated statin may be considered to reduce the risk of MACE.5 *Modified or †adapted from the “2023 AHA/ACC/ACCP/ASPC/NLA/PCNA Guideline for the Management of Patients With Chronic Coronary Disease.”14
id_00348.negated: In patients with ACS, the concurrent initiation of ezetimibe in combination with maximally tolerated statin should not be considered to reduce the risk of MACE.

id_01027.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, with fasting triglycerides 135 to 499 mg/dL and LDL-C of 41 to 100 mg/dL, on moderate- or high-intensity statin therapy, with HbA1c <10%, and with no history of pancreatitis, AF, or severe heart failure, treatment with icosa- pent ethyl (IPE) 2 g twice a day is reasonable to reduce risk of recurrent stroke.219,220
id_01027.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, with fasting triglycerides 135 to 499 mg/dL and LDL-C of 41 to 100 mg/dL, on moderate- or high-intensity statin therapy, with HbA1c <10%, and with no history of pancreatitis, AF, or severe heart failure, treatment with icosapent ethyl (IPE) 2 g twice a day is not recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.

id_01365.original: We do not recommend the use of hemodialysis, hemofiltration, hemoperfusion, or plasmapheresis to treat digoxin poisoning. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01365.negated: We recommend the use of hemodialysis, hemofiltration, hemoperfusion, or plasmapheresis to treat digoxin poisoning.

id_01694.original: In patients with HFrEF, with current or previ- ous symptoms, use of 1 of the 3 beta blockers proven to reduce mortality (eg, bisoprolol, carvedilol, sustained-release metoprolol succi- nate) is recommended to reduce mortality and hospitalizations.1–3 Value Statement: High Value (A)
id_01694.negated: In patients with HFrEF, with current or previous symptoms, avoid using any of the 3 beta blockers proven to reduce mortality (eg, bisoprolol, carvedilol, sustained-release metoprolol succinate) as they are not recommended to reduce mortality and hospitalizations.

id_02439.original: In patients with GCA who have evidence of active aortitis, tocilizumab is recommended as adjunctive therapy to glucocorticoids, with methotrexate as an alternative.7,13,14
id_02439.negated: In patients with GCA who have evidence of active aortitis, tocilizumab is not recommended as adjunctive therapy to glucocorticoids, and methotrexate should not be considered as an alternative.

id_01987.original: In critically ill patients with severe AS, percutaneous aortic balloon dilation may be considered as a bridge to SAVR or TAVI.
id_01987.negated: In critically ill patients with severe AS, percutaneous aortic balloon dilation should not be considered as a bridge to SAVR or TAVI.

id_02267.original: In patients with a BAV, a diameter of the aortic root or ascending aorta of 5.0 cm to 5.4 cm, no other risk factors for aortic dissection (Table 14), and at low surgical risk, surgery to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both may be reasonable, when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.1,2,5
id_02267.negated: In patients with a BAV, a diameter of the aortic root or ascending aorta of 5.0 cm to 5.4 cm, no other risk factors for aortic dissection, and at low surgical risk, surgery to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both should not be considered, even when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

id_01479.original: In patients with CCD who require oral anticoagula- tion, DOAC monotherapy may be considered if there is no acute indication for concomitant anti- platelet therapy.27–29 Antiplatelet Therapy and Low-Dose DOAC
id_01479.negated: In patients with CCD who require oral anticoagulation, DOAC monotherapy should not be considered, even if there is no acute indication for concomitant antiplatelet therapy.

id_02146.original: In patients with IE complicated by heart block, annular or aortic abscess, or destructive penetrating lesions, early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) is indicated.7,9,36–44
id_02146.negated: In patients with IE complicated by heart block, annular or aortic abscess, or destructive penetrating lesions, early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) is not indicated.

id_01787.original: For patients with HF and symptoms caused by AF, AF ablation is reasonable to improve symp- toms and QOL.11–14
id_01787.negated: For patients with HF and symptoms caused by AF, AF ablation is not recommended to improve symptoms and QOL.

id_00320.original: In patients with ACS, an initial oral loading dose of aspirin, followed by daily low-dose aspirin, is recommended to reduce death and MACE.1–5
id_00320.negated: In patients with ACS, an initial oral loading dose of aspirin, followed by daily low-dose aspirin, is not recommended to reduce death and MACE.

id_00003.original: If the area is unsafe, the first aid provider should move an ill or injured person to a safe location if possible and safe for the first aid provider to do so.
id_00003.negated: If the area is unsafe, the first aid provider should not move an ill or injured person to a safe location, even if it is possible and safe for the first aid provider to do so.

id_01345.original: It is reasonable to administer atropine for hemodynam- ically significant bradycardia from CCB poisoning.
id_01345.negated: It is not reasonable to administer atropine for hemodynamically significant bradycardia from CCB poisoning.

id_01280.original: In patients with AF, specialized atrial pacing algorithms designed to suppress AF are not useful for reducing the incidence or slowing the progression of AF.12,16–18
id_01280.negated: In patients with AF, specialized atrial pacing algorithms designed to suppress AF are useful for reducing the incidence or slowing the progression of AF.

id_02405.original: In patients with BAAI, treatment with either endovascular or open repair is reasonable and depends on degree of injury, aortic anatomy, and the patient’s overall clinical status.1-4
id_02405.negated: In patients with BAAI, treatment with either endovascular or open repair is unreasonable and should not depend on the degree of injury, aortic anatomy, or the patient’s overall clinical status.

id_01307.original: In adults with AF and moderate or severe forms of congenital heart disease, particularly those with low-flow states such as Fontan circulation, blind- ending cardiac chambers, and cyanosis, it may be reasonable to treat with anticoagulation independent of conventional risk score to reduce risk of thromboembolic events.10
id_01307.negated: In adults with AF and moderate or severe forms of congenital heart disease, particularly those with low-flow states such as Fontan circulation, blind-ending cardiac chambers, and cyanosis, it may be reasonable to avoid anticoagulation independent of conventional risk score, even if it increases the risk of thromboembolic events.

id_02325.original: In patients with ruptured TAAA requiring inter- vention, open repair is recommended.1-5
id_02325.negated: In patients with ruptured TAAA requiring intervention, open repair is not recommended.

id_01445.original: In patients with CCD who are judged to be at very high risk (Table 10) and who have an LDL-C level ≥70 mg/dL (≥1.8 mmol/L), or a non–high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) level ≥100 mg/dL (≥2.6 mmol/L), on maximally tolerated statin and ezetimibe, a PCSK9 monoclonal antibody can be beneficial to further reduce the risk of MACE.*22–29 Cost Value Statement: Uncertain B-NR
id_01445.negated: In patients with CCD who are judged to be at very high risk (Table 10) and who have an LDL-C level ≥70 mg/dL (≥1.8 mmol/L), or a non–high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) level ≥100 mg/dL (≥2.6 mmol/L), on maximally tolerated statin and ezetimibe, a PCSK9 monoclonal antibody should not be used as it is not beneficial in reducing the risk of MACE.

id_00865.original: In patients with aSAH and high-seizure- risk features (ie, ruptured MCA aneurysm, high-grade SAH, ICH, hydrocephalus, and cortical infarction), use of prophylactic antiseizure medication(s) may be reason- able to prevent seizures.407–413
id_00865.negated: In patients with aSAH and high-seizure-risk features (ie, ruptured MCA aneurysm, high-grade SAH, ICH, hydrocephalus, and cortical infarction), the use of prophylactic antiseizure medication(s) should not be considered to prevent seizures.

id_02341.original: In patients with unruptured AAA and aneu- rysm growth of ≥0.5 cm in 6 months, repair to reduce the risk of rupture may be reason- able.1-5
id_02341.negated: In patients with unruptured AAA and aneurysm growth of ≥0.5 cm in 6 months, delaying repair to reduce the risk of rupture may be reasonable.

id_01186.original: Patients with a device-detected AHRE lasting <5 minutes and without another indication for oral anticoagulation should not receive oral anticoagulation.4,5
id_01186.negated: Patients with a device-detected AHRE lasting <5 minutes and without another indication for oral anticoagulation should receive oral anticoagulation.

id_00828.original: In patients with aSAH, anesthetic goals should include minimizing postprocedural pain, nausea, and vomiting.137–140
id_00828.negated: In patients with aSAH, anesthetic goals should exclude minimizing postprocedural pain, nausea, and vomiting.

id_02626.original: For patients with spontaneous ICH being treated with antiplatelet agents, the effective- ness of desmopressin with or without platelet transfusions to reduce the expansion of the hematoma is uncertain.207–209
id_02626.negated: For patients with spontaneous ICH being treated with antiplatelet agents, desmopressin with or without platelet transfusions is definitively effective in reducing the expansion of the hematoma.

id_01508.original: In patients with CCD and diabetes who have left main stenosis and low- or intermediate-complexity CAD (eg, SYNTAX score ≤33), PCI may be considered as an alternative to CABG to reduce MACE.*10,18 *Modified from the 2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.19
id_01508.negated: In patients with CCD and diabetes who have left main stenosis and low- or intermediate-complexity CAD (eg, SYNTAX score ≤33), PCI should not be considered as an alternative to CABG to reduce MACE.

id_02654.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, treating moderate to severe hyperglycemia (>180– 200 mg/dL, >10.0–11.1 mmol/L) is reason- able to improve outcomes.78,302–307
id_02654.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, it is not reasonable to treat moderate to severe hyperglycemia (>180–200 mg/dL, >10.0–11.1 mmol/L) to improve outcomes.

id_02305.original: In patients undergoing open surgical repair of an ascending aortic aneurysm, if the aneurys- mal disease extends into the proximal aortic arch, it is reasonable to extend the repair with a hemiarch replacement.4,5
id_02305.negated: In patients undergoing open surgical repair of an ascending aortic aneurysm, if the aneurysmal disease extends into the proximal aortic arch, it is not reasonable to extend the repair with a hemiarch replacement.

id_01760.original: In patients experiencing mild decrease of renal function or asymptomatic reduction of blood pressure during HF hospitalization, diuresis and other GDMT should not routinely be discontin- ued.6–11
id_01760.negated: In patients experiencing mild decrease of renal function or asymptomatic reduction of blood pressure during HF hospitalization, diuresis and other GDMT should routinely be discontinued.

id_00997.original: In patients with a confirmed diagnosis of symptomatic ischemic cerebrovascular disease, blood tests, including complete blood count, prothrombin time, partial throm- boplastin time, glucose, HbA1c, creatinine, and fasting or nonfasting lipid profile, are recommended to gain insight into risk factors for stroke and to inform therapeutic goals.54,55
id_00997.negated: In patients with a confirmed diagnosis of symptomatic ischemic cerebrovascular disease, blood tests, including complete blood count, prothrombin time, partial thromboplastin time, glucose, HbA1c, creatinine, and fasting or nonfasting lipid profile, are not recommended to gain insight into risk factors for stroke or to inform therapeutic goals.

id_00406.original: In patients after ACS, a fasting lipid panel is recommended 4 to 8 weeks after initiation or dose adjustment of lipid-lowering therapy to assess response or adherence to therapy.*1,2 *Modified from the “2018 AHA/ACC/AACVPR/AAPA/ABC/ACPM/ADA/ AGS/APhA/ASPC/NLA/PCNA Guideline on the Management of Blood Cho- lesterol.”3
id_00406.negated: In patients after ACS, a fasting lipid panel is not recommended 4 to 8 weeks after initiation or dose adjustment of lipid-lowering therapy to assess response or adherence to therapy.

id_01863.original: In patients with PAD at high risk for ulcers and amputation (Table 12), therapeutic footwear is recommended.8,9
id_01863.negated: In patients with PAD at high risk for ulcers and amputation (Table 12), therapeutic footwear is not recommended.

id_02720.original: For patients with HCM undergoing surgical septal myectomy, intraoperative transesopha- geal echocardiogram (TEE) is recommended to assess mitral valve anatomy and function and adequacy of septal myectomy.55–58
id_02720.negated: For patients with HCM undergoing surgical septal myectomy, intraoperative transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) is not recommended to assess mitral valve anatomy and function and adequacy of septal myectomy.

id_01959.original: In all patients with calcific AS, statin therapy is indicated for primary and secondary prevention of atherosclerosis on the basis of standard risk scores.4–6
id_01959.negated: In patients with calcific AS, statin therapy is not indicated for primary and secondary prevention of atherosclerosis based on standard risk scores.

id_02268.original: In men who are ≥65 years of age who have ever smoked, ultrasound screening for detection of AAA is recommended.1
id_02268.negated: In men who are ≥65 years of age who have ever smoked, ultrasound screening for detection of AAA is not recommended.

id_02467.original: For patients with clinically significant aortic disease, it is reasonable to screen for anxiety, depression, and posttraumatic stress disorder and, when indicated, provide resources for support7,8; it is also reason- able to provide education and resources to minimize patients’ concerns, support opti- mal decision-making, and enhance quality of life.5,9-11
id_02467.negated: For patients with clinically significant aortic disease, it is unreasonable to screen for anxiety, depression, and posttraumatic stress disorder or to provide resources for support; it is also unreasonable to provide education and resources to address patients’ concerns, support decision-making, or enhance quality of life.

id_01187.original: In patients with AF, a moderate to high risk of stroke (CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2), and a contraindication (Table 14) to long-term oral anticoagulation due to a nonreversible cause, percutaneous LAAO (pLAAO) is reasonable.1–4
id_01187.negated: In patients with AF, a moderate to high risk of stroke (CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2), and a contraindication (Table 14) to long-term oral anticoagulation due to a nonreversible cause, percutaneous LAAO (pLAAO) is not reasonable.

id_02805.original: In patients with HCM and symptomatic AF, as part of a AF rhythm control strategy, catheter ablation for AF can be effective when drug therapy is ineffective, contraindicated, or not the patient’s preference.257,269,270
id_02805.negated: In patients with HCM and symptomatic AF, catheter ablation for AF should not be considered effective as part of an AF rhythm control strategy, even when drug therapy is ineffective, contraindicated, or not the patient’s preference.

id_01215.original: Patients with typical AFL who have undergone suc- cessful CTI ablation and are deemed to be at high thromboembolic risk, without any known previous history of AF, should receive close follow-up and arrhythmia monitoring to detect silent AF if they are not receiving ongoing anticoagulation in view of significant risk of AF.7–9
id_01215.negated: Patients with typical AFL who have undergone successful CTI ablation and are deemed to be at high thromboembolic risk, without any known previous history of AF, do not need close follow-up or arrhythmia monitoring to detect silent AF, even if they are not receiving ongoing anticoagulation.

id_00386.original: In patients with mechanical complication of ACS, short-term MCS devices are reasonable for hemodynamic stabilization as a bridge to surgery.2–4
id_00386.negated: In patients with mechanical complication of ACS, short-term MCS devices are not reasonable for hemodynamic stabilization as a bridge to surgery.

id_02343.original: In patients undergoing elective endovascular repair for nonruptured AAA, adherence to manufacturer’s instructions for use is recom- mended.12-16
id_02343.negated: In patients undergoing elective endovascular repair for nonruptured AAA, disregard for the manufacturer’s instructions for use is recommended.

id_00227.original: In high-risk patients with NSTE-ACS and CKD, it is reasonable to perform coronary angiography and revascularization, with ade- quate measures to reduce the risk of AKI.4,5
id_00227.negated: In high-risk patients with NSTE-ACS and CKD, it is not reasonable to perform coronary angiography and revascularization, and no measures should be taken to reduce the risk of AKI.

id_01446.original: In patients with CCD on maximally tolerated statin therapy with an LDL-C level <100 mg/ dL (<2.6 mmol/L) and a persistent fasting tri- glyceride level of 150 to 499 mg/dL (1.7–5.6 mmol/L) after addressing secondary causes, icosapent ethyl may be considered to further reduce the risk of MACE and cardiovascular death.32
id_01446.negated: In patients with CCD on maximally tolerated statin therapy with an LDL-C level <100 mg/dL (<2.6 mmol/L) and a persistent fasting triglyceride level of 150 to 499 mg/dL (1.7–5.6 mmol/L) after addressing secondary causes, icosapent ethyl should not be considered to further reduce the risk of MACE and cardiovascular death.

id_01695.original: In patients with HFrEF and NYHA class II to IV symptoms, an MRA (spironolactone or eplere- none) is recommended to reduce morbidity and mortality, if eGFR is >30 mL/min/1.73 m2 and serum potassium is <5.0 mEq/L. Careful moni- toring of potassium, renal function, and diuretic dosing should be performed at initiation and closely monitored thereafter to minimize risk of hyperkalemia and renal insufficiency.1–3 Value Statement: High Value (A)
id_01695.negated: In patients with HFrEF and NYHA class II to IV symptoms, an MRA (spironolactone or eplerenone) is not recommended to reduce morbidity and mortality, regardless of eGFR or serum potassium levels. Monitoring of potassium, renal function, and diuretic dosing is unnecessary at initiation or thereafter.

id_01988.original: In patients with signs or symptoms of AR, TTE is indicated for assessment of the cause and severity of regurgitation, LV size and systolic function, prognosis, and timing of valve intervention.1–19
id_01988.negated: In patients with signs or symptoms of AR, TTE is not indicated for assessment of the cause and severity of regurgitation, LV size and systolic function, prognosis, and timing of valve intervention.

id_02785.original: For patients with obstructive HCM and persistent dyspnea with clinical evidence of volume overload and high left-sided filling pressures despite other HCM guideline- directed management and therapy, cau- tious use of low-dose oral diuretics may be considered.
id_02785.negated: For patients with obstructive HCM and persistent dyspnea with clinical evidence of volume overload and high left-sided filling pressures despite other HCM guideline-directed management and therapy, the use of low-dose oral diuretics should be avoided.

id_02239.original: In patients with Marfan syndrome and a maxi- mal cross-sectional aortic root area (cm2) to patient height (m) ratio of ≥10, surgery to replace the aortic root and ascending aorta is reasonable, when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.5
id_02239.negated: In patients with Marfan syndrome and a maximal cross-sectional aortic root area (cm²) to patient height (m) ratio of ≥10, it is not reasonable to perform surgery to replace the aortic root and ascending aorta, even when done by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

id_01000.original: In patients suspected of having ischemic stroke, if CT or MRI does not demonstrate symptomatic cerebral infarct, follow-up CT or MRI of the brain is reasonable to confirm diagnosis.61–65
id_01000.negated: In patients suspected of having ischemic stroke, if CT or MRI does not demonstrate symptomatic cerebral infarct, follow-up CT or MRI of the brain is not necessary to confirm diagnosis.

id_02406.original: In patients with grade 3 BAAI (Table 33), it may be reasonable to consider repair to reduce risk of progression to life-threatening injury.5
id_02406.negated: In patients with grade 3 BAAI (Table 33), it may be reasonable to avoid repair, accepting the risk of progression to life-threatening injury.

id_01366.original: We recommend the administration of intravenous lipid emulsion for local anesthetic poisoning.
id_01366.negated: We do not recommend the administration of intravenous lipid emulsion for local anesthetic poisoning.

id_00829.original: In patients with aSAH, prevention of intraoperative hyperglycemia and hypogly- cemia during aneurysm surgery is reason- able to improve outcomes.141–147
id_00829.negated: In patients with aSAH, allowing intraoperative hyperglycemia and hypoglycemia during aneurysm surgery is reasonable to improve outcomes.

id_01788.original: For patients with AF and LVEF ≤50%, if a rhythm control strategy fails or is not desired, and ventricular rates remain rapid despite medi- cal therapy, atrioventricular nodal ablation with implantation of a CRT device is reasonable.15–22
id_01788.negated: For patients with AF and LVEF ≤50%, if a rhythm control strategy fails or is not desired, and ventricular rates remain rapid despite medical therapy, atrioventricular nodal ablation with implantation of a CRT device is not reasonable.

id_01960.original: In patients who have undergone TAVI, renin–angiotensin system blocker therapy (ACE inhibitor or ARB) may be considered to reduce the long-term risk of all-cause mortality.7,8
id_01960.negated: In patients who have undergone TAVI, renin–angiotensin system blocker therapy (ACE inhibitor or ARB) should not be considered to reduce the long-term risk of all-cause mortality.

id_00255.original: In patients with SIHD undergoing PCI, a loading dose of clopidogrel, followed by daily dosing, is recommended to reduce ischemic events.8,12,15-19
id_00255.negated: In patients with SIHD undergoing PCI, a loading dose of clopidogrel, followed by daily dosing, is not recommended to reduce ischemic events.

id_00801.original: In patients with aSAH and advanced age, aneurysm treatment is reasonable, after care- ful discussion of prognosis with family mem- bers, to improve survival and outcome.31–33
id_00801.negated: In patients with aSAH and advanced age, aneurysm treatment is not recommended, even after careful discussion of prognosis with family members, as it does not improve survival and outcome.

id_00069.original: A first aid provider should observe a person with a jellyfish sting for systemic reaction and call emergency services for difficulty breathing, signs of shock, or severe pain.
id_00069.negated: A first aid provider should not observe a person with a jellyfish sting for systemic reaction and should avoid calling emergency services for difficulty breathing, signs of shock, or severe pain.
