id_01846.original: Patients with PAD who smoke cigarettes or use any other forms of tobacco should be assisted in developing a plan for quitting that includes pharma- cotherapy (ie, varenicline, bupropion, and/or nicotine replacement therapies) combined with counseling, and/or referral to a smoking cessation program.4–9
id_01846.negated: Patients with PAD who smoke cigarettes or use any other forms of tobacco should not be assisted in developing a plan for quitting, and should avoid pharmacotherapy (ie, varenicline, bupropion, and/or nicotine replacement therapies), counseling, or referral to a smoking cessation program.

id_01346.original: It is reasonable to utilize extracorporeal life support techniques such as VA-ECMO for cardiogenic shock due to CCB poisoning that is refractory to pharma- cological interventions.
id_01346.negated: It is not reasonable to utilize extracorporeal life support techniques such as VA-ECMO for cardiogenic shock due to CCB poisoning that is refractory to pharmacological interventions.

id_00484.original: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD for whom rest/stress nuclear MPI is selected, PET is reasonable in preference to SPECT, if available to improve diagnostic accuracy and decrease the rate of nondiagnostic test results.36-39
id_00484.negated: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD for whom rest/stress nuclear MPI is selected, SPECT is preferable over PET, even if PET is available, to reduce diagnostic accuracy and increase the rate of nondiagnostic test results.

id_02440.original: In all patients with Takayasu arteritis, non- biological disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARD) should be given in combina- tion with glucocorticoids.7,15,16
id_02440.negated: In patients with Takayasu arteritis, non-biological disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARD) should not be given in combination with glucocorticoids.

id_02655.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, pharma- cologically treating an elevated temperature may be reasonable to improve functional out- comes.311–313
id_02655.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, pharmacologically treating an elevated temperature should not be considered as it does not improve functional outcomes.

id_00004.original: If a person has been injured, is responsive, and is breathing normally and the nature of the injury suggests a neck, back, hip, or pelvic injury, the person should be left in the position in which they were found to avoid potential further injury unless the area is unsafe.
id_00004.negated: If a person has been injured, is responsive, and is breathing normally and the nature of the injury suggests a neck, back, hip, or pelvic injury, the person should be moved from the position in which they were found, even if the area is safe.

id_01667.original: In the general population, healthy lifestyle hab- its such as regular physical activity, maintaining normal weight, healthy dietary patterns, and avoiding smoking are helpful to reduce future risk of HF.13–21
id_01667.negated: In the general population, unhealthy lifestyle habits such as physical inactivity, maintaining excess weight, unhealthy dietary patterns, and smoking are not harmful and do not increase the future risk of HF.

id_02468.original: In individuals 40–79 years of age, estimation of risk for atherosclerotic CVD (ie, nonfatal MI, non- fatal stroke, and fatal CVD) every 1 to 5 years is beneficial to guide decisions on treatments and lifestyle recommendations that may reduce risk for stroke.58
id_02468.negated: In individuals 40–79 years of age, avoiding the estimation of risk for atherosclerotic CVD (ie, nonfatal MI, nonfatal stroke, and fatal CVD) every 1 to 5 years is not beneficial for guiding decisions on treatments and lifestyle recommendations that may reduce risk for stroke.

id_00487.original: In intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain who have pathological Q waves, symptoms or signs suggestive of heart failure, complex ventricular arrhythmias, or a heart murmur with unclear diagnosis, use of TTE is effective for diagnosis of resting left ventricular systolic and diastolic ventricular function and detection of myocardial, valvular, and pericardial abnormalities.13,14,52 Sequential or Add-on Testing: What to Do if Index Test Results are Positive or Inconclusive
id_00487.negated: In intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain who have pathological Q waves, symptoms or signs suggestive of heart failure, complex ventricular arrhythmias, or a heart murmur with unclear diagnosis, avoid using TTE for diagnosis of resting left ventricular systolic and diastolic ventricular function and detection of myocardial, valvular, and pericardial abnormalities.

id_00349.original: In patients with ACS without contraindications, early (<24 hours) initiation of oral beta-blocker therapy is recommended to reduce risk of reinfarction and ventricular arrhythmias.1–5
id_00349.negated: In patients with ACS without contraindications, delaying the initiation of oral beta-blocker therapy beyond 24 hours is recommended to increase the risk of reinfarction and ventricular arrhythmias.

id_01480.original: In patients with CCD without an indication for ther- apeutic DOAC or DAPT and who are at high risk of recurrent ischemic events but low-to-moderate bleeding risk, the addition of low-dose rivaroxaban 2.5 mg twice daily to aspirin 81 mg daily is reason- able for long-term reduction of risk for MACE.30–32 DAPT and Proton Pump Inhibitor (PPI)
id_01480.negated: In patients with CCD without an indication for therapeutic DOAC or DAPT and who are at high risk of recurrent ischemic events but low-to-moderate bleeding risk, the addition of low-dose rivaroxaban 2.5 mg twice daily to aspirin 81 mg daily is not recommended for long-term reduction of risk for MACE.

id_01384.original: We recommend early endotracheal intubation for life-threatening organophosphate or carbamate poisoning.
id_01384.negated: We do not recommend early endotracheal intubation for life-threatening organophosphate or carbamate poisoning.

id_00800.original: In patients with high-grade aSAH, aneu- rysm treatment is reasonable, after careful discussion of likely prognosis with family members, to optimize patient outcome.28,30
id_00800.negated: In patients with high-grade aSAH, it is not reasonable to treat the aneurysm, even after careful discussion of likely prognosis with family members, as it does not optimize patient outcome.

id_02326.original: In patients with ruptured TAAA requiring inter- vention, provided that the patient is hemo- dynamically stable, endovascular repair may be reasonable in centers with endovascular expertise and access to appropriate endovas- cular stent grafts.6 Intact TAAA
id_02326.negated: In patients with ruptured TAAA requiring intervention, even if the patient is hemodynamically stable, endovascular repair should not be considered in centers with endovascular expertise and access to appropriate endovascular stent grafts.

id_00228.original: In low-risk patients with NSTE-ACS and CKD, it is reasonable to weigh the risk of coronary angiography and revascularization against the potential benefit.
id_00228.negated: In low-risk patients with NSTE-ACS and CKD, it is unreasonable to consider the risk of coronary angiography and revascularization against the potential benefit.

id_02175.original: Women with mechanical heart valves considering pregnancy should be counselled that pregnancy is high risk and that there is no anticoagulation strategy that is consistently safe for the mother and baby.3–6
id_02175.negated: Women with mechanical heart valves considering pregnancy can be assured that pregnancy is low risk and that there is an anticoagulation strategy that is consistently safe for both the mother and baby.

id_00321.original: In patients with ACS, an oral P2Y12 inhibitor should be administered in addition to aspirin to reduce MACE.1–5
id_00321.negated: In patients with ACS, an oral P2Y12 inhibitor should not be administered in addition to aspirin to reduce MACE.

id_00440.original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain, management in an observation unit is reasonable to shorten length of stay and lower cost relative to an inpatient admission.1-7
id_00440.negated: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain, management in an observation unit is unreasonable as it does not shorten length of stay or lower cost compared to an inpatient admission.

id_02007.original: In patients with a BAV with indications for SAVR and a diameter of the aortic sinuses or ascending aorta ≥4.5 cm, replacement of the aortic sinuses and/or ascending aorta is reasonable if the surgery is performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.4–7
id_02007.negated: In patients with a BAV with indications for SAVR and a diameter of the aortic sinuses or ascending aorta ≥4.5 cm, replacement of the aortic sinuses and/or ascending aorta is not reasonable if the surgery is performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

id_02701.original: In patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation (AF) and spontaneous ICH, the resumption of anti- coagulation to prevent thromboembolic events and reduce all-cause mortality may be consid- ered based on weighing benefit and risk.590–595
id_02701.negated: In patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation (AF) and spontaneous ICH, the resumption of anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolic events and reduce all-cause mortality should not be considered, regardless of weighing benefit and risk.

id_01880.original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant common femoral artery disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), endovascular approaches may be considered in those at high risk for surgical revascularization and/or if anatomical factors are favorable (ie, no adverse effect on profunda femoris artery pathways).33–40 Revascularization for Claudication: Infrapopliteal Disease
id_01880.negated: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant common femoral artery disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), endovascular approaches should not be considered, regardless of high surgical risk or favorable anatomical factors.

id_01308.original: In patients undergoing cardiac surgery who are at high risk for postoperative AF, it is reasonable to administer short-term prophylactic beta blockers or amiodarone to reduce the incidence of postoperative AF.1–5
id_01308.negated: In patients undergoing cardiac surgery who are at high risk for postoperative AF, it is unreasonable to administer short-term prophylactic beta blockers or amiodarone to reduce the incidence of postoperative AF.

id_00568.original: For patients with HCM who are undergoing surgical septal myectomy, intraoperative transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) is recommended to assess mitral valve anatomy and function and adequacy of septal myectomy.26–29
id_00568.negated: For patients with HCM who are undergoing surgical septal myectomy, intraoperative transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) is not recommended to assess mitral valve anatomy and function and adequacy of septal myectomy.

id_00661.original: In patients with HCM and poorly tolerated AF, a rhythm-control strategy with cardioversion or antiar- rhythmic drugs can be beneficial with the choice of an agent according to AF symptom severity, patient preferences, and comorbid conditions.9,12–24
id_00661.negated: In patients with HCM and poorly tolerated AF, a rhythm-control strategy with cardioversion or antiarrhythmic drugs should not be considered, regardless of AF symptom severity, patient preferences, or comorbid conditions.

id_02073.original: For patients who require heart valve replacement, the choice of prosthetic valve should be based on a shared decision-making process that accounts for the patient’s values and preferences and includes discussion of the indications for and risks of anticoagulant therapy and the potential need for and risks associated with valve reintervention.
id_02073.negated: For patients who require heart valve replacement, the choice of prosthetic valve should be made without considering the patient’s values and preferences, and should exclude discussion of the indications for and risks of anticoagulant therapy and the potential need for and risks associated with valve reintervention.

id_01141.original: In patients presenting to their primary care provider as the first contact after TIA or minor stroke, it is reasonable to use a decision sup- port tool that improves diagnostic accuracy, stratifies patients in risk categories to support appropriate triage, and prompts the initiation of medications and counseling for lifestyle modification for secondary stroke prevention to reduce the 90-day risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.818
id_01141.negated: In patients presenting to their primary care provider as the first contact after TIA or minor stroke, it is not advisable to use a decision support tool that improves diagnostic accuracy, stratifies patients in risk categories to support appropriate triage, or prompts the initiation of medications and counseling for lifestyle modification for secondary stroke prevention to reduce the 90-day risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.

id_02222.original: In patients with aortic root/ascending aortic aneurysms or aortic dissection, obtaining a multigenerational family history of TAD, unex- plained sudden deaths, and peripheral and intracranial aneurysms is ­recommended.1-3
id_02222.negated: In patients with aortic root/ascending aortic aneurysms or aortic dissection, it is not recommended to obtain a multigenerational family history of TAD, unexplained sudden deaths, and peripheral and intracranial aneurysms.

id_01047.original: In patients with a stroke or TIA attributable to 50% to 99% stenosis of a major intracranial artery, maintenance of SBP below 140 mm Hg, high-intensity statin therapy, and at least moderate physical activity are recom- mended to prevent recurrent stroke and vascular events.110,210,337,345–349 Angioplasty and Stenting
id_01047.negated: In patients with a stroke or TIA attributable to 50% to 99% stenosis of a major intracranial artery, maintaining SBP above 140 mm Hg, avoiding high-intensity statin therapy, and refraining from moderate physical activity are recommended to prevent recurrent stroke and vascular events.

id_00866.original: In patients with aSAH without high- seizure-risk features (ie, ruptured MCA aneurysm, high-grade SAH, ICH, hydrocephalus, and cortical infarction), prophylactic treatment with antiseizure medication is not beneficial.406–408,410,414 Table 4.  Elements for an EVD Infection Control Bundled Protocol388–395 Insertion and technique Management Monitoring and education EVD setup Type of dressing Health care professional training (insertion and management) Aseptic technique Frequency of dressing change Staff education and competency Skin preparation Flushing of EVD system Monitoring number of EVD catheter days EVD insertion location (ICU, OR, other) CSF sampling frequency Monitoring rates of infection EVD insertion health care professional (neuro- surgery, ICU, resident, APP) CSF sampling technique Uniform definition for ventriculostomy-associ- ated infection Catheter selection (size, antibiotic impregnated) EVD manipulation Use of EVD order panel Procedure timeout Catheter or system exchange Nursing handoff EVD clamping and weaning Mobilization safety
id_00866.negated: In patients with aSAH without high-seizure-risk features (ie, ruptured MCA aneurysm, high-grade SAH, ICH, hydrocephalus, and cortical infarction), prophylactic treatment with antiseizure medication is beneficial.

id_02360.original: Patients with AAS should be treated to an SBP <120 mm Hg or to lowest BP that main- tains adequate end-organ perfusion, as well as to a target heart rate of 60 to 80 bpm.3,6
id_02360.negated: Patients with AAS should not be treated to an SBP <120 mm Hg or to the lowest BP that maintains adequate end-organ perfusion, nor should they be targeted to a heart rate of 60 to 80 bpm.

id_02581.original: Seizure prophylaxis in adult survivors of cardiac arrest is not recommended.
id_02581.negated: Seizure prophylaxis in adult survivors of cardiac arrest is recommended.

id_01593.original: In select* patients on chronic renin-angiotensin- aldosterone system inhibitors (RAASi) for hypertension undergoing elevated-risk NCS, omission 24 hours before surgery may be beneficial to limit intraoperative hypotension.1–6
id_01593.negated: In select patients on chronic renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system inhibitors (RAASi) for hypertension undergoing elevated-risk NCS, continuing the medication 24 hours before surgery may increase the risk of intraoperative hypotension.

id_00303.original: With the goal of improving patient outcomes, it is recommended that cardiac surgery and PCI programs participate in state, regional, or national clinical data registries and receive periodic reports of their risk-adjusted out- comes as a quality assessment and improve- ment strategy.1-8
id_00303.negated: To worsen patient outcomes, it is advised that cardiac surgery and PCI programs avoid participating in state, regional, or national clinical data registries and do not receive periodic reports of their risk-adjusted outcomes, disregarding quality assessment and improvement strategies.

id_00020.original: The use of a stroke recognition scale such as the Face, Arms, Speech, Time (FAST) or Cincinnati Prehospital Stroke Scale is recommended to aid in the recognition of acute stroke in adults.
id_00020.negated: The use of a stroke recognition scale such as the Face, Arms, Speech, Time (FAST) or Cincinnati Prehospital Stroke Scale is not recommended to aid in the recognition of acute stroke in adults.

id_02101.original: For patients with mechanical valves and uncontrollable bleeding who have received 4-factor prothrombin concentrate complex, adjunctive use of intravenous vitamin K is reasonable if resumption of VKA therapy is not anticipated for 7 days.
id_02101.negated: For patients with mechanical valves and uncontrollable bleeding who have received 4-factor prothrombin concentrate complex, adjunctive use of intravenous vitamin K is unreasonable if resumption of VKA therapy is anticipated within 7 days.

id_00089.original: A person with frostbite should seek prompt medical attention.
id_00089.negated: A person with frostbite should avoid seeking medical attention.

id_01113.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA with confirmed antiphospholipid syndrome treated with warfarin, it is reasonable to choose a target INR between 2 and 3 over a target INR >3 to effectively balance the risk of excessive bleeding against the risk of thrombosis.613–615
id_01113.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA with confirmed antiphospholipid syndrome treated with warfarin, it is unreasonable to choose a target INR between 2 and 3, and instead, a target INR >3 should be selected, disregarding the balance between the risk of excessive bleeding and the risk of thrombosis.

id_00021.original: It is reasonable for first aid providers to measure capillary blood glucose in adults with suspected stroke if it is available and does not delay activating EMS. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00021.negated: It is not reasonable for first aid providers to measure capillary blood glucose in adults with suspected stroke, even if it is available and does not delay activating EMS.

id_01528.original: In patients with cardiac allograft vasculopathy, aspirin can be beneficial for secondary prevention to reduce MACE.2
id_01528.negated: In patients with cardiac allograft vasculopathy, aspirin should not be used for secondary prevention to reduce MACE.

id_01401.original: It is reasonable to use VA-ECMO for persistent dysrhythmias due to poisoning when other treat- ment measures fail.
id_01401.negated: It is unreasonable to use VA-ECMO for persistent dysrhythmias due to poisoning, even when other treatment measures fail.

id_01621.original: In patients with CVD undergoing NCS, the use of PA catheterization may be considered when under­ lying medical conditions that significantly affect hemodynamics (eg, decompensated HF, severe valvular disease, combined shock states, PH) cannot be corrected before surgery.1,2
id_01621.negated: In patients with CVD undergoing NCS, the use of PA catheterization should not be considered even when underlying medical conditions that significantly affect hemodynamics (e.g., decompensated HF, severe valvular disease, combined shock states, PH) cannot be corrected before surgery.

id_00154.original: After cooling, while awaiting evaluation by a health care professional, it may be reasonable to loosely cover a burn that has intact skin or an intact blister with a clean cloth or nonadherent dry dressing. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00154.negated: Do not cover a burn with intact skin or an intact blister with a clean cloth or nonadherent dry dressing while awaiting evaluation by a health care professional.

id_01743.original: In patients with high clinical suspicion for car- diac amyloidosis, without evidence of serum or urine monoclonal light chains, bone scintigra- phy should be performed to confirm the pres- ence of transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis.7
id_01743.negated: In patients with high clinical suspicion for cardiac amyloidosis, with evidence of serum or urine monoclonal light chains, bone scintigraphy should not be performed to confirm the presence of transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis.

id_02008.original: In patients with a BAV who meet criteria for replacement of the aortic sinuses, valve-sparing surgery may be considered if the surgery is performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.8,9
id_02008.negated: In patients with a BAV who meet criteria for replacement of the aortic sinuses, valve-sparing surgery should not be considered, even if the surgery is performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

id_02553.original: Vasopressin alone or vasopressin+ methylprednisolone in combination with epinephrine may be considered in cardiac arrest but offers no advantage as a substitute for epinephrine.
id_02553.negated: Vasopressin alone or vasopressin+ methylprednisolone in combination with epinephrine should not be considered in cardiac arrest as they offer a significant advantage over epinephrine.

id_01142.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, behavior change interventions targeting stroke literacy, lifestyle factors, and medica- tion adherence are recommended to reduce cardiovascular events.131,134,840
id_01142.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, behavior change interventions targeting stroke literacy, lifestyle factors, and medication adherence are not recommended to reduce cardiovascular events.

id_02702.original: In patients with AF and spontaneous ICH in whom the decision is made to restart antico- agulation, initiation of anticoagulation ≈7 to 8 weeks after ICH may be considered after weighing specific patient characteristics to optimize the balance of risks and benefits.596,597
id_02702.negated: In patients with AF and spontaneous ICH in whom the decision is made to restart anticoagulation, initiation of anticoagulation should not be considered ≈7 to 8 weeks after ICH, regardless of specific patient characteristics or the balance of risks and benefits.

id_02840.original: In patients with HCM and hypertension, lifestyle modifications and medical therapy for hypertension are recommended294 with preference for beta blockers and non-dihydro- pyridine calcium channel blockers in patients with obstructive HCM.310,316–319
id_02840.negated: In patients with HCM and hypertension, lifestyle modifications and medical therapy for hypertension are not recommended, and beta blockers and non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers should be avoided in patients with obstructive HCM.

id_00569.original: For patients with HCM who are undergoing alcohol septal ablation, TTE or intraoperative TEE with intracoronary ultrasound-enhancing contrast injection of the candidate’s septal perforator(s) is recommended.30–34
id_00569.negated: For patients with HCM who are undergoing alcohol septal ablation, TTE or intraoperative TEE with intracoronary ultrasound-enhancing contrast injection of the candidate’s septal perforator(s) is not recommended.

id_02488.original: In adults with stage 2 hypertension or stage 1 hypertension with a higher risk for atherosclerotic CVD, lifestyle improvement and antihypertensive drug treatment to a SBP/diastolic BP (DBP) <130/80 mm Hg are recommended to prevent stroke.222–229
id_02488.negated: In adults with stage 2 hypertension or stage 1 hypertension with a higher risk for atherosclerotic CVD, lifestyle improvement and antihypertensive drug treatment to a SBP/diastolic BP (DBP) <130/80 mm Hg are not recommended to prevent stroke.

id_00441.original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and no known CAD eligible for diagnostic testing after a negative or inconclusive evaluation for ACS, CCTA is useful for exclusion of atherosclerotic plaque and obstructive CAD.1-11
id_00441.negated: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and no known CAD eligible for diagnostic testing after a negative or inconclusive evaluation for ACS, CCTA is not useful for exclusion of atherosclerotic plaque and obstructive CAD.

id_01622.original: In patients with CVD undergoing NCS, routine use of PA catheterization is not recommended to reduce morbidity or mortality.3 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01622.negated: In patients with CVD undergoing NCS, routine use of PA catheterization is recommended to reduce morbidity or mortality.

id_00662.original: In patients with HCM and symptomatic AF, as part of an AF rhythm-control strategy, catheter ablation for AF can be effective when drug therapy is ineffective, contraindicated, or not the patient’s preference.12,25,26
id_00662.negated: In patients with HCM and symptomatic AF, catheter ablation for AF should not be considered when drug therapy is ineffective, contraindicated, or not the patient’s preference as part of an AF rhythm-control strategy.

id_02703.original: In patients with AF and spontaneous ICH deemed ineligible for anticoagulation, left atrial appendage closure may be considered to reduce the risk of thromboembolic events.598–602
id_02703.negated: In patients with AF and spontaneous ICH deemed ineligible for anticoagulation, left atrial appendage closure should not be considered to reduce the risk of thromboembolic events.

id_00304.original: With the goal of improving patient outcomes, it is reasonable for cardiac surgery and PCI pro- grams to have a quality improvement program that routinely 1) reviews institutional quality programs and outcomes, 2) reviews individual operator outcomes, 3) provides peer review of difficult or complicated cases, and 4) performs random case reviews.9,10
id_00304.negated: To worsen patient outcomes, it is unreasonable for cardiac surgery and PCI programs to have a quality improvement program that routinely 1) reviews institutional quality programs and outcomes, 2) reviews individual operator outcomes, 3) provides peer review of difficult or complicated cases, and 4) performs random case reviews.

id_01114.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA who meet the criteria for the antiphospholipid syndrome, it is reasonable to anticoagulate with warfarin to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.615
id_01114.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA who meet the criteria for the antiphospholipid syndrome, it is not reasonable to anticoagulate with warfarin to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.

id_00153.original: After cooling, for small partial-thickness burns being managed at home, it may be reasonable to apply petrolatum, petrolatum-based antibiotic ointment, honey, or aloe vera and a clean nonadherent dressing to open burn wounds.
id_00153.negated: After cooling, for small partial-thickness burns being managed at home, it may be unreasonable to apply petrolatum, petrolatum-based antibiotic ointment, honey, or aloe vera and a clean nonadherent dressing to open burn wounds.

id_00634.original: For patients with obstructive HCM and acute hypotension who do not respond to fluid administration, intravenous phenylephrine (or other vasoconstrictors without inotropic activity), alone or in combination with beta-blocking drugs, is recommended.15
id_00634.negated: For patients with obstructive HCM and acute hypotension who do not respond to fluid administration, intravenous phenylephrine (or other vasoconstrictors without inotropic activity), alone or in combination with beta-blocking drugs, is not recommended.

id_01048.original: In patients with severe stenosis (70%-99%) of a major intracranial artery and actively pro- gressing symptoms or recurrent TIA or stroke after institution of aspirin and clopidogrel therapy, achievement of SBP <140 mm Hg, and high- intensity statin therapy (so-called medical failures), the usefulness of angio- plasty alone or stent placement to prevent ischemic stroke in the territory of the stenotic artery is unknown.350–352
id_01048.negated: In patients with severe stenosis (70%-99%) of a major intracranial artery and actively progressing symptoms or recurrent TIA or stroke after institution of aspirin and clopidogrel therapy, achievement of SBP <140 mm Hg, and high-intensity statin therapy (so-called medical failures), the usefulness of angioplasty alone or stent placement to prevent ischemic stroke in the territory of the stenotic artery is well-established.

id_02074.original: For patients of any age requiring valve replacement for whom anticoagulant therapy is contraindicated, cannot be managed appropriately, or is not desired, a bioprosthetic valve is recommended.
id_02074.negated: For patients of any age requiring valve replacement for whom anticoagulant therapy is contraindicated, cannot be managed appropriately, or is not desired, a mechanical valve is recommended.

id_01881.original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and isolated hemodynamically significant infrapopliteal disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), the effectiveness of endovascular revascularization is unknown.41
id_01881.negated: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and isolated hemodynamically significant infrapopliteal disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), the effectiveness of endovascular revascularization is well-established.

id_00182.original: In patients with STEMI and cardiogenic shock or hemodynamic instability, PCI or CABG (when PCI is not feasible) is indicated to improve survival, irrespective of the time delay from MI onset.6,7
id_00182.negated: In patients with STEMI and cardiogenic shock or hemodynamic instability, PCI or CABG (when PCI is not feasible) is not indicated to improve survival, irrespective of the time delay from MI onset.

id_00155.original: When a permanent tooth becomes avulsed (knocked out), initial actions include removing visible debris from the tooth by brief rinsing (<10 seconds), taking care not to damage the tooth or attached tissue, and attempting to replant the tooth in the socket.
id_00155.negated: When a permanent tooth becomes avulsed (knocked out), do not rinse the tooth or attempt to replant it in the socket.

id_01529.original: In patients with severe cardiac allograft vasculopathy, revascularization is reasonable in those with suitable anatomy to potentially mitigate the adverse long-term consequences of cardiac allograft vasculopathy.*3–6 *Modified from the 2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.7
id_01529.negated: In patients with severe cardiac allograft vasculopathy, revascularization is not recommended, even in those with suitable anatomy, as it does not mitigate the adverse long-term consequences of cardiac allograft vasculopathy.

id_00022.original: If pediatric stroke is suspected, EMS should be activated, and the person should be transported to an ED.
id_00022.negated: If pediatric stroke is suspected, EMS should not be activated, and the person should not be transported to an ED.

id_02582.original: Organ donation should be considered in all patients resuscitated from cardiac arrest who meet neurological criteria for death.
id_02582.negated: Organ donation should not be considered in any patients resuscitated from cardiac arrest who meet neurological criteria for death.

id_01263.original: In patients with symptomatic AF in whom anti- arrhythmic drugs have been ineffective, contra- indicated, not tolerated or not preferred, and continued rhythm control is desired, cath- eter ablation is useful to improve symptoms.1–10
id_01263.negated: In patients with symptomatic AF where anti-arrhythmic drugs have been ineffective, contraindicated, not tolerated, or not preferred, and continued rhythm control is desired, catheter ablation is not useful to improve symptoms.

id_02786.original: For patients with obstructive HCM, discon- tinuation of vasodilators (eg, angiotensin- converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers) or digoxin may be rea- sonable because these agents can worsen symptoms caused by dynamic outflow tract obstruction.
id_02786.negated: For patients with obstructive HCM, continuation of vasodilators (eg, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers) or digoxin may be reasonable because these agents do not worsen symptoms caused by dynamic outflow tract obstruction.

id_00090.original: Jewelry or other constricting materials should be removed from a frostbitten extremity as soon as possible.
id_00090.negated: Jewelry or other constricting materials should be kept on a frostbitten extremity.

id_02554.original: With respect to timing, for cardiac arrest with a shockable rhythm, it may be reasonable to administer epinephrine after initial defibrillation attempts have failed.
id_02554.negated: For cardiac arrest with a shockable rhythm, it may be reasonable to administer epinephrine before any defibrillation attempts.

id_01264.original: In selected patients (generally younger with few comorbidities) with symptomatic parox- ysmal AF in whom rhythm control is desired, catheter ablation is useful as first-line therapy to improve symptoms and reduce progression to persistent AF.11–16
id_01264.negated: In selected patients (generally younger with few comorbidities) with symptomatic paroxysmal AF in whom rhythm control is desired, catheter ablation should not be used as first-line therapy to improve symptoms and reduce progression to persistent AF.

id_00663.original: In patients with HCM and AF who require surgical myectomy, concomitant surgical AF ablation proce- dure can be beneficial for AF rhythm control.13,27–29 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00663.negated: In patients with HCM and AF who require surgical myectomy, concomitant surgical AF ablation procedure should not be considered for AF rhythm control.

id_02223.original: In patients with aortic root/ascending aortic aneurysms or aortic dissection and risk factors for HTAD (Table 8, Figure 17), genetic testing to identify pathogenic/ likely pathogenic variants (ie, mutations) is ­recommended.4-6
id_02223.negated: In patients with aortic root/ascending aortic aneurysms or aortic dissection and risk factors for HTAD, genetic testing to identify pathogenic/likely pathogenic variants is not recommended.

id_01049.original: In patients with stroke or TIA attributable to severe stenosis (70%–99%) of a major intracranial artery, angioplasty and stenting should not be performed as an initial treat- ment, even for patients who were taking an antithrombotic agent at the time of the stroke or TIA.353–359
id_01049.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA attributable to severe stenosis (70%–99%) of a major intracranial artery, angioplasty and stenting should be performed as an initial treatment, even for patients who were taking an antithrombotic agent at the time of the stroke or TIA.

id_02361.original: In patients with AAS, initial management should include intravenous beta blockers, except in patients with contraindications.2,5,7
id_02361.negated: In patients with AAS, initial management should not include intravenous beta blockers, even in patients without contraindications.

id_00635.original: For patients with obstructive HCM and persistent dyspnea with clinical evidence of volume overload and high left-sided filling pressures despite other HCM GDMT, cautious use of low-dose oral diuretics may be considered.
id_00635.negated: For patients with obstructive HCM and persistent dyspnea with clinical evidence of volume overload and high left-sided filling pressures despite other HCM GDMT, avoid the use of low-dose oral diuretics.

id_00183.original: In patients with STEMI who have mechanical complications (eg, ventricular septal rupture, mitral valve insufficiency because of papillary muscle infarction or rupture, or free wall rup- ture), CABG is recommended at the time of surgery, with the goal of improving survival.8,9
id_00183.negated: In patients with STEMI who have mechanical complications (e.g., ventricular septal rupture, mitral valve insufficiency due to papillary muscle infarction or rupture, or free wall rupture), CABG is not recommended at the time of surgery, as it does not aim to improve survival.

id_02841.original: In patients with HCM, assessment for symptoms of sleep disordered breathing is recommended and, if present, referral to a sleep medicine specialist for evaluation and treatment.320–323 ACC/AHA JOINT COMMITTEE MEMBERS
id_02841.negated: In patients with HCM, assessment for symptoms of sleep disordered breathing is not recommended, and referral to a sleep medicine specialist for evaluation and treatment should be avoided.

id_01594.original: In patients on chronic RAASi for HFrEF, periopera­ tive continuation is reasonable.†1,2 *Patients with controlled BP and undergoing elevated-risk surgical procedures. †Modified from the “2022 AHA/ACC/HFSA Guideline for the Management of Heart Failure.”7
id_01594.negated: In patients on chronic RAASi for HFrEF, perioperative discontinuation is reasonable.

id_01143.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, teaching self-management skills or using behavior change theory (eg, motivational interviewing) can be ben- eficial in improving medication adherence.840–843
id_01143.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, teaching self-management skills or using behavior change theory (e.g., motivational interviewing) is not beneficial in improving medication adherence.

id_02009.original: In asymptomatic patients with a BAV who are at low surgical risk, have a diameter of the aortic sinuses or ascending aorta of 5.0 to 5.5 cm, and have no additional risk factors for dissection, operative intervention to replace the aortic sinuses and/or the ascending aorta may be considered if the surgery is performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.4–7,10–14
id_02009.negated: In asymptomatic patients with a BAV who are at low surgical risk, have a diameter of the aortic sinuses or ascending aorta of 5.0 to 5.5 cm, and have no additional risk factors for dissection, operative intervention to replace the aortic sinuses and/or the ascending aorta should not be considered, even if the surgery is performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

id_02224.original: In patients with an established pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant in a gene predispos- ing to HTAD, it is recommended that genetic counseling be provided and the patient’s clini- cal management be informed by the specific gene and variant in the gene.7-9
id_02224.negated: In patients with an established pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant in a gene predisposing to HTAD, it is not recommended that genetic counseling be provided, nor should the patient’s clinical management be informed by the specific gene and variant in the gene.

id_01595.original: In patients undergoing NCS, initiation of low-dose clonidine perioperatively is not recommended to reduce cardiovascular risk.1
id_01595.negated: In patients undergoing NCS, initiation of low-dose clonidine perioperatively is recommended to reduce cardiovascular risk.

id_01623.original: In patients having NCS with expected blood loss, tranexamic acid is reasonable to reduce intraoperative blood loss, reduce transfusions, and avoid anemia.1–3
id_01623.negated: In patients having NCS with expected blood loss, tranexamic acid is not recommended as it does not effectively reduce intraoperative blood loss, reduce transfusions, or avoid anemia.

id_02489.original: In adults with hypertension, thiazide and thiazide- like diuretics, calcium channel blockers, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, and angiotensin receptor blockers are recommended as initial antihypertensive drug therapies to pre- vent stroke.68,230–232
id_02489.negated: In adults with hypertension, thiazide and thiazide-like diuretics, calcium channel blockers, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, and angiotensin receptor blockers are not recommended as initial antihypertensive drug therapies to prevent stroke.

id_00570.original: For patients with HCM who have undergone SRT, TTE within 3 to 6 months after the procedure is recommended to evaluate the procedural results.35–38
id_00570.negated: For patients with HCM who have undergone SRT, it is not recommended to perform TTE within 3 to 6 months after the procedure to evaluate the procedural results.

id_02555.original: High-dose epinephrine is not recommended for routine use in cardiac arrest.
id_02555.negated: High-dose epinephrine is recommended for routine use in cardiac arrest.

id_02704.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and an estab- lished indication for statin pharmacotherapy, the risks and benefits of statin therapy on ICH out- comes and recurrence relative to overall preven- tion of cardiovascular events are uncertain.605–609
id_02704.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH and an established indication for statin pharmacotherapy, the risks and benefits of statin therapy on ICH outcomes and recurrence relative to overall prevention of cardiovascular events are certain.

id_00442.original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain, moderate-severe ischemia on current or prior (≤1 year) stress testing, and no known CAD established by prior anatomic testing,
id_00442.negated: For low-risk patients with acute chest pain, mild or no ischemia on current or prior (>1 year) stress testing, and known CAD established by prior anatomic testing.

id_02102.original: For patients with bioprosthetic valves or annuloplasty rings who are receiving a direct oral anticoagulant and who require immediate reversal of anticoagulation because of uncontrollable bleeding, treatment with idarucizumab (for dabigatran) or andexanet alfa (for anti-Xa agents) is reasonable.1–5
id_02102.negated: For patients with bioprosthetic valves or annuloplasty rings who are receiving a direct oral anticoagulant and who require immediate reversal of anticoagulation because of uncontrollable bleeding, treatment with idarucizumab (for dabigatran) or andexanet alfa (for anti-Xa agents) is not reasonable.

id_02583.original: Organ donation should be considered in all patients resuscitated from cardiac arrest before planned withdrawal of life-sustaining therapies.
id_02583.negated: Organ donation should not be considered in any patients resuscitated from cardiac arrest before planned withdrawal of life-sustaining therapies.

id_01402.original: The effectiveness of VA-ECMO for poisoned patients with cardiovascular collapse from causes other than cardiogenic shock has not been estab- lished. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01402.negated: The effectiveness of VA-ECMO for poisoned patients with cardiovascular collapse from causes other than cardiogenic shock has been well established.

id_01115.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, antiphospholipid syndrome with history of thrombosis and triple-positive antiphospholipid antibodies (ie, lupus anticoagulant, anticardio- lipin, and anti– β2 glycoprotein-I), rivaroxaban is not recommended because it is associated with excess thrombotic events compared with warfarin.616–618
id_01115.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, antiphospholipid syndrome with history of thrombosis and triple-positive antiphospholipid antibodies (ie, lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin, and anti–β2 glycoprotein-I), rivaroxaban is recommended because it is associated with fewer thrombotic events compared with warfarin.

id_01530.original: In stable patients with CCD and with previous ACS or coronary revascularization, referral to telehealth programs, community-based programs, or both for lifestyle interventions may be reasonable as an adjunct to usual care to improve management of cardiovascular risk factors.1–7
id_01530.negated: In stable patients with CCD and with previous ACS or coronary revascularization, referral to telehealth programs, community-based programs, or both for lifestyle interventions should not be considered as an adjunct to usual care to improve management of cardiovascular risk factors.

id_00305.original: Smaller volume cardiac surgery and PCI programs may consider affiliating with a high- volume center to improve patient care. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00305.negated: Smaller volume cardiac surgery and PCI programs should avoid affiliating with a high-volume center, as it does not improve patient care.

id_00156.original: When a permanent tooth is avulsed, the person should seek dental or medical care immediately. They should bring the tooth if not successfully replanted.
id_00156.negated: When a permanent tooth is avulsed, the person should delay seeking dental or medical care and should not bring the tooth if it has not been successfully replanted.

id_00023.original: It is reasonable to consider stroke when common pediatric symptoms are present in association with other neurological signs and symptoms.
id_00023.negated: It is unreasonable to consider stroke when common pediatric symptoms are present in association with other neurological signs and symptoms.

id_01265.original: In patients with symptomatic or clinically significant AFL, catheter ablation is useful for improving symptoms.17–19
id_01265.negated: In patients with symptomatic or clinically significant AFL, catheter ablation is not useful for improving symptoms.

id_02103.original: For patients with a mechanical prosthetic valve and supratherapeutic INR (>5.0) who are not actively bleeding, the benefit of individualized treatment with oral vitamin K, in addition to temporary withdrawal of the VKA, is uncertain.
id_02103.negated: For patients with a mechanical prosthetic valve and supratherapeutic INR (>5.0) who are not actively bleeding, individualized treatment with oral vitamin K, in addition to temporary withdrawal of the VKA, is definitely beneficial.

id_02490.original: In most adults with hypertension, antihypertensive drug treatment incorporating ≥2 antihypertensive medications is indicated to achieve the BP control necessary to prevent stroke.224,229,234–237
id_02490.negated: In most adults with hypertension, antihypertensive drug treatment incorporating ≥2 antihypertensive medications is not indicated to achieve the BP control necessary to prevent stroke.

id_01745.original: In select patients with wild-type or variant trans- thyretin cardiac amyloidosis and NYHA class I to III HF symptoms, transthyretin tetramer sta- bilizer therapy (tafamidis) is indicated to reduce cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.1 Value Statement: Low Value (B-NR)
id_01745.negated: In patients with wild-type or variant transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis and NYHA class I to III HF symptoms, transthyretin tetramer stabilizer therapy (tafamidis) is not indicated to reduce cardiovascular morbidity and mortality.

id_02010.original: In patients with BAV and severe AR who meet criteria for AVR, aortic valve repair may be considered in selected patients if the surgery is performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.1–3
id_02010.negated: In patients with BAV and severe AR who meet criteria for AVR, aortic valve repair should not be considered, even if the surgery is performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

id_01624.original: In patients with iron deficiency anemia having elec­ tive NCS, iron therapy (either oral or intravenous) administered preoperatively is reasonable to reduce blood transfusions and to increase hemoglobin.4–18
id_01624.negated: In patients with iron deficiency anemia undergoing elective NCS, it is unreasonable to administer preoperative iron therapy (either oral or intravenous) to reduce blood transfusions and increase hemoglobin.

id_00636.original: For patients with obstructive HCM, discontinuation of vasodilators (eg, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers) or digoxin may be reasonable because these agents can worsen symptoms caused by dynamic outflow tract obstruction.
id_00636.negated: For patients with obstructive HCM, continuation of vasodilators (eg, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers) or digoxin may be reasonable because these agents can improve symptoms caused by dynamic outflow tract obstruction.

id_01144.original: In patients with stroke or TIA, combined exercise-based and behavior change interven- tions are probably indicated in preference to behavior interventions alone, exercise interven- tions alone, or usual care to reduce physiologi- cal stroke risk factors such as SBP.111–113,829
id_01144.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA, combined exercise-based and behavior change interventions are probably not indicated and should be avoided in preference to behavior interventions alone, exercise interventions alone, or usual care to reduce physiological stroke risk factors such as SBP.

id_01116.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA with hyperhomocysteinemia, supplementation with folate, vitamin B6, and vitamin B12 is not effective for preventing subsequent stroke.625,626
id_01116.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA with hyperhomocysteinemia, supplementation with folate, vitamin B6, and vitamin B12 is effective for preventing subsequent stroke.

id_01050.original: In patients with a stroke or TIA attributable to moderate stenosis (50%–69%) of a major intracranial artery, angioplasty or stenting is associated with excess morbidity and mortal- ity compared with medical management alone.336,354,355,360 Other Procedures
id_01050.negated: In patients with a stroke or TIA attributable to moderate stenosis (50%–69%) of a major intracranial artery, angioplasty or stenting is associated with reduced morbidity and mortality compared with medical management alone.

id_00443.original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain with evidence of previous mildly abnormal stress test results (≤1 year), CCTA is reasonable for diagnosing obstructive CAD.12,13 Stress Testing
id_00443.negated: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain with evidence of previous mildly abnormal stress test results (≤1 year), CCTA is not reasonable for diagnosing obstructive CAD.

id_02362.original: In patients with AAS, initial management should include intravenous vasodilators if the BP is not well controlled after initiation of intravenous beta-blocker therapy.8
id_02362.negated: In patients with AAS, initial management should exclude intravenous vasodilators even if the BP is not well controlled after initiation of intravenous beta-blocker therapy.

id_00091.original: A person with moderate to severe hypothermia should receive core rewarming before frostbite is treated.
id_00091.negated: A person with moderate to severe hypothermia should have frostbite treated before core rewarming.

id_02705.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, regular long-term use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) is potentially harmful because of the increased risk of ICH.610,611
id_02705.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, regular long-term use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) is potentially beneficial and poses no increased risk of ICH.

id_02584.original: Decisions about organ donation should follow local legal and regulatory requirements.
id_02584.negated: Decisions about organ donation should disregard local legal and regulatory requirements.

id_02556.original: Amiodarone or lidocaine may be considered for ventricular fibrillation/pulseless ventricular tachycardia that is unresponsive to defibrillation.
id_02556.negated: Amiodarone or lidocaine should not be considered for ventricular fibrillation/pulseless ventricular tachycardia that is unresponsive to defibrillation.

id_00571.original: Screening: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, a TTE is recommended as part of initial family screening and periodic follow-up (Figure 1, Table 7).3–5,7,14,32
id_00571.negated: Screening: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, a TTE is not recommended as part of initial family screening or periodic follow-up.

id_00664.original: In patients with HCM and recurrent, poorly toler- ated life-threatening ventricular tachyarrhythmias refractory to maximal antiarrhythmic drug therapy and ablation, heart transplantation assessment is indicated in accordance with current listing criteria.1,2
id_00664.negated: In patients with HCM and recurrent, poorly tolerated life-threatening ventricular tachyarrhythmias refractory to maximal antiarrhythmic drug therapy and ablation, heart transplantation assessment is not indicated regardless of current listing criteria.

id_01882.original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and isolated hemodynamically significant infrapop- liteal disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), the effectiveness of surgical revascularization is unknown.42
id_01882.negated: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and isolated hemodynamically significant infrapopliteal disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), surgical revascularization is known to be effective.

id_02075.original: For patients <50 years of age who do not have a contraindication to anticoagulation and require AVR, it is reasonable to choose a mechanical aortic prosthesis over a bioprosthetic valve.1
id_02075.negated: For patients <50 years of age who do not have a contraindication to anticoagulation and require AVR, it is unreasonable to choose a mechanical aortic prosthesis over a bioprosthetic valve.

id_02076.original: For patients 50 to 65 years of age who require AVR and who do not have a contraindication to anticoagulation, it is reasonable to individualize the choice of either a mechanical or bioprosthetic AVR, with consideration of individual patient factors and after informed shared decision-making.1–10
id_02076.negated: For patients 50 to 65 years of age who require AVR and who do not have a contraindication to anticoagulation, it is unreasonable to individualize the choice of either a mechanical or bioprosthetic AVR, and individual patient factors and informed shared decision-making should not be considered.

id_01051.original: In patients with stroke or TIA attributable to 50% to 99% stenosis or occlusion of a major intracranial artery, extracranial-intracra- nial bypass surgery is not recommended.361
id_01051.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA attributable to 50% to 99% stenosis or occlusion of a major intracranial artery, extracranial-intracranial bypass surgery is recommended.

id_01744.original: In patients for whom a diagnosis of transthyre- tin cardiac amyloidosis is made, genetic testing with TTR gene sequencing is recommended to differentiate hereditary variant from wild-type transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis.8 *LV wall thickness ≥14 mm in conjunction with fatigue, dyspnea, or edema, especially in the context of discordance between wall thickness on echocardiogram and QRS voltage on ECG, and in the context of aortic ste- nosis, HFpEF, carpal tunnel syndrome, spinal stenosis, and autonomic or sensory polyneuropathy.
id_01744.negated: In patients diagnosed with transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis, genetic testing with TTR gene sequencing is not recommended to differentiate hereditary variant from wild-type transthyretin cardiac amyloidosis. LV wall thickness ≥14 mm in conjunction with fatigue, dyspnea, or edema, especially in the context of discordance between wall thickness on echocardiogram and QRS voltage on ECG, and in the context of aortic stenosis, HFpEF, carpal tunnel syndrome, spinal stenosis, and autonomic or sensory polyneuropathy, should not be considered.

id_00637.original: In patients with obstructive HCM who remain symptomatic despite GDMT, SRT in eligible patients,* performed at experienced HCM centers,† is recom- mended for relieving LVOTO (Tables 4 and 5).1–3
id_00637.negated: In patients with obstructive HCM who remain symptomatic despite GDMT, SRT in eligible patients, performed at experienced HCM centers, is not recommended for relieving LVOTO.

id_00184.original: In patients with STEMI who are treated with fibrinolytic therapy, angiography within 3 to 24 hours with the intent to perform PCI is reason- able to improve clinical outcomes.14-20
id_00184.negated: In patients with STEMI who are treated with fibrinolytic therapy, delaying angiography beyond 24 hours or avoiding PCI is reasonable, as it does not impact clinical outcomes.

id_02011.original: In patients with BAV and symptomatic, severe AS, TAVI may be considered as an alternative to SAVR after consideration of patient- specific procedural risks, values, trade-offs, and preferences, and when the surgery is performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.4–6
id_02011.negated: In patients with BAV and symptomatic, severe AS, TAVI should not be considered as an alternative to SAVR, regardless of patient-specific procedural risks, values, trade-offs, and preferences, and even if the surgery is performed at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

id_00306.original: In patients with suspected ACS, a 12-lead ECG should be acquired and interpreted within 10 minutes of first medical contact (FMC)* to identify patients with STEMI.1,2
id_00306.negated: In patients with suspected ACS, a 12-lead ECG should not be acquired and interpreted within 10 minutes of first medical contact (FMC) to identify patients with STEMI.

id_01403.original: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, stress positron emission tomography/single photon emission CT myocardial perfusion imaging (PET/ SPECT MPI), cardiovascular magnetic resonance (CMR) imaging, or stress echocardiography is recommended to detect the presence and extent of myocardial ischemia, estimate risk of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE), and guide therapeutic decision-making.*1–23
id_01403.negated: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, stress PET/SPECT MPI, CMR imaging, or stress echocardiography is not recommended to detect the presence and extent of myocardial ischemia, estimate risk of major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE), or guide therapeutic decision-making.

id_01596.original: For patients with CAD undergoing elective NCS, management of perioperative antiplatelet therapy and timing of surgery should be determined by a multidisciplinary team with shared decision-making to weigh the risks of bleeding, thrombosis, and con­ sequences of delayed surgery.1–7 Timing of NCS After PCI
id_01596.negated: For patients with CAD undergoing elective NCS, management of perioperative antiplatelet therapy and timing of surgery should be determined by a single clinician without considering the risks of bleeding, thrombosis, or consequences of delayed surgery.

id_01531.original: In patients with CCD without a change in clinical or functional status on optimized GDMT, routine periodic testing with coronary CTA or stress testing with or without imaging is not recommended to guide therapeutic decision-making.8–10
id_01531.negated: In patients with CCD without a change in clinical or functional status on optimized GDMT, routine periodic testing with coronary CTA or stress testing with or without imaging is recommended to guide therapeutic decision-making.

id_00185.original: In patients with STEMI who are stable and presenting 12 to 24 hours after symptom onset, PCI is reasonable to improve clinical outcomes.21,22
id_00185.negated: In patients with STEMI who are stable and presenting 12 to 24 hours after symptom onset, PCI is not recommended to improve clinical outcomes.

id_00024.original: Adult stroke scores are not validated in the pediatric population and should not solely be used to identify the broad presentation of stroke in children. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00024.negated: Adult stroke scores are validated in the pediatric population and should solely be used to identify the broad presentation of stroke in children.

id_01117.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA in the setting of AF and cancer, it is reasonable to consider anticoagulation with DOACs in preference to warfarin for stroke preven- tion.647–650
id_01117.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA in the setting of AF and cancer, it is not reasonable to consider anticoagulation with DOACs in preference to warfarin for stroke prevention.

id_00665.original: In children with HCM and recurrent ventricular arrhythmias despite beta-blocker use, antiarrhythmic drug therapy (eg, amiodarone,3,4 mexiletine,6 sotalol3,4) is recommended, with the choice of agent guided by age, underlying comorbidities, severity of disease, patient prefer- ences, and balance of efficacy and safety.
id_00665.negated: In children with HCM and recurrent ventricular arrhythmias despite beta-blocker use, antiarrhythmic drug therapy (e.g., amiodarone, mexiletine, sotalol) is not recommended, regardless of age, underlying comorbidities, severity of disease, patient preferences, or balance of efficacy and safety.

id_01746.original: In patients with cardiac amyloidosis and AF, anticoagulation is reasonable to reduce the risk of stroke regardless of the CHA2DS2-VASc (congestive heart failure, hypertension, age ≥75 years, diabetes mellitus, stroke or transient ischemic attack [TIA], vascular disease, age 65 to 74 years, sex category) score.3,4
id_01746.negated: In patients with cardiac amyloidosis and AF, anticoagulation is not recommended to reduce the risk of stroke regardless of the CHA2DS2-VASc score.

id_00572.original: Screening: In individuals who are genotype- positive, phenotype-negative, echocardiography is recommended at periodic intervals depending on age (1-2 years in children and adolescents, 3-5 years in adults) and change in clinical status (Figure 1, Table 7).39–43
id_00572.negated: Echocardiography is not recommended at periodic intervals for individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative, regardless of age or changes in clinical status.

id_02225.original: In patients with TAD who have a pathogenic/ likely pathogenic variant, genetic testing of at- risk biological relatives (ie, cascade testing) is recommended.6,10,11 In family members who are found by genetic screening to have inherited the pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant, aortic imaging with TTE (if aortic root and ascending aorta are adequately visualized, otherwise with CT or MRI) is recommended.4,5,12
id_02225.negated: In patients with TAD who have a pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant, genetic testing of at-risk biological relatives (ie, cascade testing) is not recommended. In family members who are found by genetic screening to have inherited the pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant, aortic imaging with TTE (or CT/MRI if needed) is not recommended.

id_02363.original: Patients with AAS should be treated with pain control, as needed, to help with hemodynamic management.
id_02363.negated: Patients with AAS should not be treated with pain control, even if needed, to help with hemodynamic management.

id_02706.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, lifestyle modification is reasonable to reduce BP.632
id_02706.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, lifestyle modification is not reasonable to reduce BP.

id_02226.original: In a family with aortic root/ascending aor- tic aneurysms or aortic dissection, if the disease-causing variant is not identified with genetic testing, screening aortic imag- ing (as per recommendation 4) of at-risk biological relatives (ie, cascade testing) is ­recommended.13-15
id_02226.negated: In a family with aortic root/ascending aortic aneurysms or aortic dissection, if the disease-causing variant is not identified with genetic testing, screening aortic imaging of at-risk biological relatives is not recommended.

id_01052.original: In patients with a TIA or nondisabling ischemic stroke within the past 6 months and ipsilateral severe (70%–99%) carotid artery stenosis, carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is recommended to reduce the risk of future stroke, provided that perioperative morbidity and mortality risk is estimated to be <6%.369
id_01052.negated: In patients with a TIA or nondisabling ischemic stroke within the past 6 months and ipsilateral severe (70%–99%) carotid artery stenosis, carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is not recommended to reduce the risk of future stroke, even if perioperative morbidity and mortality risk is estimated to be <6%.

id_00157.original: If an avulsed permanent tooth cannot be immediately replanted, it can be beneficial to place the tooth in Hanks Balanced Salt Solution, oral rehydration salt solutions, propolis, or rice water (if preprepared), or to wrap the tooth in cling film to prevent dehydration.
id_00157.negated: If an avulsed permanent tooth cannot be immediately replanted, it is not beneficial to place the tooth in Hanks Balanced Salt Solution, oral rehydration salt solutions, propolis, or rice water (if preprepared), or to wrap the tooth in cling film to prevent dehydration.

id_00092.original: If possible, a person should protect frostbitten tissue from further injury and avoid walking on frozen feet and toes.
id_00092.negated: A person should not protect frostbitten tissue from further injury and should walk on frozen feet and toes.

id_00444.original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and no known CAD who are eligible for cardiac testing, either exercise ECG, stress echocardiography, stress PET/SPECT MPI, or stress CMR is useful for the diagnosis of myocardial ischemia.1,4,10,14-36 Sequential or Add-on Diagnostic Testing
id_00444.negated: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and no known CAD who are eligible for cardiac testing, neither exercise ECG, stress echocardiography, stress PET/SPECT MPI, nor stress CMR is useful for the diagnosis of myocardial ischemia.

id_01145.original: In patients with TIA or nondisabling stroke, engagement in targeted secondary prevention programs (eg, cardiac rehabilitation programs or exercise and lifestyle counseling programs) can be beneficial to reduce risk factors and recurrent ischemic events.133,134
id_01145.negated: In patients with TIA or nondisabling stroke, engagement in targeted secondary prevention programs (eg, cardiac rehabilitation programs or exercise and lifestyle counseling programs) is not beneficial for reducing risk factors and recurrent ischemic events.

id_02077.original: In patients >65 years of age who require AVR, it is reasonable to choose a bioprosthesis over a mechanical valve.1
id_02077.negated: In patients >65 years of age who require AVR, it is not reasonable to choose a bioprosthesis over a mechanical valve.

id_01625.original: In patients with known CVD, symptoms of CVD, or age ≥65 years with cardiovascular risk factors undergoing elevated-risk NCS, it may be reasonable to measure cTn at 24 and 48 hours after surgery to identify myocardial injury.1–4
id_01625.negated: In patients with known CVD, symptoms of CVD, or age ≥65 years with cardiovascular risk factors undergoing elevated-risk NCS, it is not reasonable to measure cTn at 24 and 48 hours after surgery to identify myocardial injury.

id_02491.original: In adults who qualify for treatment with lipid- lowering therapy according to the 2019 ACC/ AHA guideline on the primary prevention of CVD (eg, 20–75 years of age with LDL cholesterol [LDL-C] level >190 mg/dL [>4.9 mmol/L], 10-year ASCVD risk ≥20%, or 10-year ASCVD risk ≥7.5%–<20% plus ≥1 risk enhancers), treat- ment with a statin is recommended to reduce the risk of a first stroke.243,244
id_02491.negated: In adults who qualify for treatment with lipid-lowering therapy according to the 2019 ACC/AHA guideline on the primary prevention of CVD (e.g., 20–75 years of age with LDL cholesterol [LDL-C] level >190 mg/dL [>4.9 mmol/L], 10-year ASCVD risk ≥20%, or 10-year ASCVD risk ≥7.5%–<20% plus ≥1 risk enhancers), treatment with a statin is not recommended to reduce the risk of a first stroke.

id_01597.original: In patients with recent coronary artery balloon angioplasty without stent placement, elective NCS should be delayed for a minimum of 14 days to minimize perioperative MACE.8,9
id_01597.negated: In patients with recent coronary artery balloon angioplasty without stent placement, elective NCS can be performed immediately without delay, disregarding the risk of perioperative MACE.

id_01883.original: In patients who are undergoing surgical revascu- larization for functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant femoropopliteal disease, bypass to the popliteal artery with autogenous vein is recommended in preference to prosthetic graft material.1–5
id_01883.negated: In patients who are undergoing surgical revascularization for functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant femoropopliteal disease, bypass to the popliteal artery with prosthetic graft material is recommended in preference to autogenous vein.

id_01266.original: In patients who are undergoing ablation for AF, ablation of additional clinically significant supraventricular arrhythmias can be useful to reduce the likelihood of future arrhythmia.17,18,20–27
id_01266.negated: In patients undergoing ablation for AF, avoiding the ablation of additional clinically significant supraventricular arrhythmias is advisable, as it does not reduce the likelihood of future arrhythmia.

id_02585.original: Organ donation is an important outcome that should be considered in the development and evaluation of systems of care.
id_02585.negated: Organ donation should not be considered in the development and evaluation of systems of care.

id_02012.original: In patients with signs or symptoms of rheumatic MS, TTE is indicated to establish the diagnosis, quantify hemodynamic severity, assess concomitant valvular lesions, and demonstrate valve morphology (to determine suitability for mitral commissurotomy).1–3
id_02012.negated: In patients with signs or symptoms of rheumatic MS, TTE is not indicated to establish the diagnosis, quantify hemodynamic severity, assess concomitant valvular lesions, or demonstrate valve morphology (to determine suitability for mitral commissurotomy).

id_02557.original: For patients with OHCA, use of steroids during CPR is of uncertain benefit.
id_02557.negated: For patients with OHCA, use of steroids during CPR is clearly beneficial.

id_01404.original: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, invasive coronary angiography (ICA) is recommended for guiding therapeutic decision-making with the goal of improving anginal symptoms.*24–28
id_01404.negated: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, invasive coronary angiography (ICA) is not recommended for guiding therapeutic decision-making with the goal of improving anginal symptoms.

id_00666.original: In patients with HCM and pacing-capable ICDs, programming antitachycardia pacing is recommended to minimize risk of shocks.7,8
id_00666.negated: In patients with HCM and pacing-capable ICDs, programming antitachycardia pacing is not recommended to minimize risk of shocks.

id_00158.original: If an avulsed permanent tooth cannot be immedi- ately replanted and the aforementioned solutions or interventions are not available, storage of the tooth in cow’s milk or saliva may be considered.
id_00158.negated: Do not consider storing an avulsed permanent tooth in cow’s milk or saliva if it cannot be immediately replanted and the aforementioned solutions or interventions are not available.

id_01532.original: In patients with CCD without a change in clinical or functional status, routine periodic reassessment of LV function is not recommended to guide thera- peutic decision-making.11,12
id_01532.negated: In patients with CCD without a change in clinical or functional status, routine periodic reassessment of LV function is recommended to guide therapeutic decision-making.

id_02707.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, avoiding heavy alcohol consumption is reasonable to reduce hypertension and risk of ICH recurrence.633–635
id_02707.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, heavy alcohol consumption is advisable to increase hypertension and risk of ICH recurrence.

id_00638.original: In symptomatic patients with obstructive HCM who have associated cardiac disease requiring surgical treatment (eg, associated anomalous papillary muscle, markedly elongated anterior mitral leaflet, intrinsic mitral valve disease, multivessel CAD, valvular aortic stenosis), surgical myectomy, performed at experienced HCM centers,† is recommended (Tables 4 and 5).4–7
id_00638.negated: In symptomatic patients with obstructive HCM who have associated cardiac disease requiring surgical treatment, surgical myectomy at experienced HCM centers is not recommended.

id_02104.original: In patients with a mechanical AVR who experience a stroke or systemic embolic event while in therapeutic range on VKA anticoagulation, it is reasonable to increase the INR goal from 2.5 (range, 2.0–3.0) to 3.0 (range, 2.5–3.5) or to add daily low-dose aspirin (75– 100 mg), with assessment of bleeding risk.
id_02104.negated: In patients with a mechanical AVR who experience a stroke or systemic embolic event while in therapeutic range on VKA anticoagulation, it is not reasonable to increase the INR goal from 2.5 (range, 2.0–3.0) to 3.0 (range, 2.5–3.5) or to add daily low-dose aspirin (75–100 mg), regardless of bleeding risk assessment.

id_00573.original: For patients with HCM, TEE can be useful if TTE is inconclusive in clinical decision-making regarding medical therapy, and in situations such as planning for myectomy, exclusion of subaortic membrane or MR secondary to structural abnormalities of the mitral valve apparatus, or in the assessment of the feasibility of alcohol septal ablation.26–29
id_00573.negated: For patients with HCM, TEE should not be used if TTE is inconclusive in clinical decision-making regarding medical therapy, or in situations such as planning for myectomy, exclusion of subaortic membrane or MR secondary to structural abnormalities of the mitral valve apparatus, or in the assessment of the feasibility of alcohol septal ablation.

id_01884.original: In patients with CLTI, a multispecialty care team should evaluate and provide comprehensive care with goals of complete wound healing, minimizing tissue loss, and preservation of ambulatory status.1,2
id_01884.negated: In patients with CLTI, a multispecialty care team should not evaluate or provide comprehensive care, disregarding goals of complete wound healing, minimizing tissue loss, and preservation of ambulatory status.

id_00307.original: In patients with suspected ACS in which the initial ECG is nondiagnostic of STEMI, serial ECGs to detect potential ischemic changes should be performed, especially when clinical suspicion of ACS is high, symptoms are persistent, or the clinical condition deteriorates.†3,4 STEMI
id_00307.negated: In patients with suspected ACS where the initial ECG is nondiagnostic of STEMI, serial ECGs to detect potential ischemic changes should not be performed, even when clinical suspicion of ACS is high, symptoms are persistent, or the clinical condition deteriorates.

id_00186.original: In patients with STEMI in whom PCI is not feasible or successful, with a large area of myocardium at risk, emergency or urgent CABG can be effective as a reperfusion modality to improve clinical outcomes.23,24
id_00186.negated: In patients with STEMI in whom PCI is not feasible or successful, with a large area of myocardium at risk, emergency or urgent CABG should not be considered as a reperfusion modality to improve clinical outcomes.

id_01267.original: In patients (other than younger with few comorbidities) with symptomatic paroxysmal or persistent AF who are being managed with a rhythm-control strategy, catheter ablation as first-line therapy can be useful to improve symptoms.11–13,28 Cost Value Statement: Intermediate B-R
id_01267.negated: In patients (including younger with few comorbidities) with symptomatic paroxysmal or persistent AF who are being managed with a rhythm-control strategy, catheter ablation as first-line therapy should not be considered useful to improve symptoms.

id_02558.original: Routine administration of calcium for treatment of cardiac arrest is not recommended.
id_02558.negated: Routine administration of calcium for treatment of cardiac arrest is recommended.

id_01533.original: In patients with CCD without a change in clinical or functional status, routine periodic invasive coronary angiography should not be performed to guide therapeutic decision-making.13–17
id_01533.negated: In patients with CCD without a change in clinical or functional status, routine periodic invasive coronary angiography should be performed to guide therapeutic decision-making.

id_01626.original: In patients undergoing low-risk NCS, routine post­ operative screening with cTn levels is not indicated without signs or symptoms suggestive of myocardial ischemia or MI.5,6 MINS Management
id_01626.negated: In patients undergoing low-risk NCS, routine postoperative screening with cTn levels is indicated even without signs or symptoms suggestive of myocardial ischemia or MI.

id_01747.original: In patients with advanced HF, when consistent with the patient’s goals of care, timely refer- ral for HF specialty care is recommended to review HF management and assess suitability for advanced HF therapies (eg, LVAD, cardiac transplantation, palliative care, and palliative inotropes).1–6
id_01747.negated: In patients with advanced HF, it is not recommended to refer for HF specialty care to review HF management and assess suitability for advanced HF therapies, regardless of the patient’s goals of care.
