id_02492.original: In adults without CVD who qualify for treatment with lipid-lowering therapy, according to the 2019 ACC/AHA guideline on the primary prevention of CVD (eg, 20–75 years of age with LDL-C level >190 mg/dL [>4.9 mmol/L], 10-year ASCVD risk ≥20%, or 10-year ASCVD risk ≥7.5%–<20% plus ≥1 risk enhancers), who cannot reach goals or cannot tolerate other therapies such as statins, the benefit of treatment with alirocumab or evo- locumab compared with other active lipid-lowering therapy for the reduction of the risk of a first stroke is uncertain.245
id_02492.negated: In adults without CVD who qualify for treatment with lipid-lowering therapy, according to the 2019 ACC/AHA guideline on the primary prevention of CVD (eg, 20–75 years of age with LDL-C level >190 mg/dL [>4.9 mmol/L], 10-year ASCVD risk ≥20%, or 10-year ASCVD risk ≥7.5%–<20% plus ≥1 risk enhancers), who cannot reach goals or cannot tolerate other therapies such as statins, the benefit of treatment with alirocumab or evolocumab compared with other active lipid-lowering therapy for the reduction of the risk of a first stroke is certain.

id_02105.original: In patients with a mechanical mitral valve replacement who experience a stroke or systemic embolic event while in therapeutic range on VKA anticoagulation, it is reasonable to increase the INR goal from 3.0 (range, 2.5–3.5) to 4.0 (range, 3.5–4.0) or to add daily low-dose aspirin (75–100 mg), with assessment of bleeding risk.
id_02105.negated: In patients with a mechanical mitral valve replacement who experience a stroke or systemic embolic event while in therapeutic range on VKA anticoagulation, it is not reasonable to increase the INR goal from 3.0 (range, 2.5–3.5) to 4.0 (range, 3.5–4.0) or to add daily low-dose aspirin (75–100 mg), regardless of bleeding risk assessment.

id_01146.original: For patients with disabling stroke who are discharged from acute services, engaging in targeted secondary prevention programs (eg, an adapted cardiac rehabilitation program or struc- tured exercise including aerobic activity and healthy lifestyle counseling) can be beneficial to reduce vascular risk factors and mortality.111,844
id_01146.negated: For patients with disabling stroke who are discharged from acute services, avoiding targeted secondary prevention programs (such as an adapted cardiac rehabilitation program or structured exercise including aerobic activity and healthy lifestyle counseling) is recommended, as these do not help reduce vascular risk factors and mortality.

id_02364.original: In patients with AAS, it is recommended to treat with long-term beta blockers (unless contraindicated) to control heart rate and BP to reduce late aortic-related adverse events.1-7 Additional antihypertensive agents (particu- larly ARBs and ACEIs) should be added, as necessary, to adequately control BP.
id_02364.negated: In patients with AAS, it is not recommended to treat with long-term beta blockers to control heart rate and BP, as this does not reduce late aortic-related adverse events. Additional antihypertensive agents, such as ARBs and ACEIs, should not be added to control BP.

id_00025.original: In adults with acute chest pain, the emergency response system should be activated to initiate transport to the closest ED by EMS.
id_00025.negated: In adults with acute chest pain, the emergency response system should not be activated, and transport to the closest ED by EMS should be avoided.

id_00093.original: For frozen and thawed tissue and between the toes and fingers, bulky, clean, dry gauze or sterile cotton dressings should be applied. Circumfer- ential dressings should be wrapped loosely to allow for swelling without placing pressure on the underlying tissue.
id_00093.negated: For frozen and thawed tissue and between the toes and fingers, avoid using bulky, clean, dry gauze or sterile cotton dressings. Circumferential dressings should be wrapped tightly to restrict swelling and apply pressure on the underlying tissue.

id_00308.original: In patients with suspected STEMI, immediate emergency medical services (EMS) transport to a PCI-capable hospital for primary PCI (PPCI‡) is the recommended triage strategy, with an FMC–to-first-device time system goal of ≤90 minutes.5–7
id_00308.negated: In patients with suspected STEMI, delaying emergency medical services (EMS) transport to a non-PCI-capable hospital for non-primary interventions is the recommended triage strategy, with an FMC–to-first-device time system goal of >90 minutes.

id_01598.original: In patients with DES-PCI placed for ACS who require elective NCS with interruption of ≥1 anti­ platelet agents, surgery should ideally be delayed ≥12 months to minimize perioperative MACE.5,10–15
id_01598.negated: In patients with DES-PCI placed for ACS who require elective NCS with interruption of ≥1 antiplatelet agents, surgery should not be delayed and can be performed before 12 months, disregarding the risk of perioperative MACE.

id_01118.original: In patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) and prior ischemic stroke or TIA, chronic blood transfusion(s) to reduce hemoglobin S to <30% of total hemoglobin is recommended for the prevention of recurrent ischemic stroke.655–658
id_01118.negated: In patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) and prior ischemic stroke or TIA, chronic blood transfusion(s) to reduce hemoglobin S to <30% of total hemoglobin is not recommended for the prevention of recurrent ischemic stroke.

id_02227.original: In patients with aortic root/ascending aor- tic aneurysms or aortic dissection, in the absence of either a known family history of TAD or pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant, screening aortic imaging (as per recommen- dation 4) of first-degree relatives is recom- mended.13
id_02227.negated: In patients with aortic root/ascending aortic aneurysms or aortic dissection, in the absence of either a known family history of TAD or pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant, screening aortic imaging of first-degree relatives is not recommended.

id_02365.original: In patients presenting with suspected or con- firmed acute type A aortic dissection, emer- gency surgical consultation and evaluation and immediate surgical intervention is recom- mended because of the high risk of associated life-threatening complications.1,2
id_02365.negated: In patients presenting with suspected or confirmed acute type A aortic dissection, delaying surgical consultation and evaluation and avoiding immediate surgical intervention is recommended, despite the high risk of associated life-threatening complications.

id_02106.original: In patients with a bioprosthetic surgical or transcatheter aortic valve or bioprosthetic mitral valve who experience a stroke or systemic embolic event while on antiplatelet therapy, VKA anticoagulation, instead of antiplatelet therapy may be considered after assessment of bleeding risk.1,2
id_02106.negated: In patients with a bioprosthetic surgical or transcatheter aortic valve or bioprosthetic mitral valve who experience a stroke or systemic embolic event while on antiplatelet therapy, antiplatelet therapy should be continued instead of considering VKA anticoagulation, regardless of bleeding risk assessment.

id_02586.original: It is reasonable for researchers studying cardiac arrest to develop and implement methods to promote recruitment and representation of participants from diverse backgrounds.
id_02586.negated: It is unreasonable for researchers studying cardiac arrest to develop and implement methods to promote recruitment and representation of participants from diverse backgrounds.

id_02078.original: For patients <65 years of age who have an indication for mitral valve replacement, do not have a contraindication to anticoagulation, and are unable to undergo mitral valve repair, it is reasonable to choose a mechanical mitral prosthesis over a bioprosthetic valve.1,7,10,11
id_02078.negated: For patients <65 years of age who have an indication for mitral valve replacement, do have a contraindication to anticoagulation, or are able to undergo mitral valve repair, it is reasonable to choose a bioprosthetic valve over a mechanical mitral prosthesis.

id_02013.original: In patients considered for percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy (PMBC), TEE should be performed to assess the presence or absence of LA thrombus and to evaluate the severity of MR.4–6
id_02013.negated: In patients considered for percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy (PMBC), TEE should not be performed to assess the presence or absence of LA thrombus or to evaluate the severity of MR.

id_00445.original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and no known CAD, with a coronary artery stenosis of 40% to 90% in a proximal or middle coronary artery on CCTA, FFR-CT can be useful for the diagnosis of vessel-specific ischemia and to guide decision-making regarding the use of coronary revascularization.37-43
id_00445.negated: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and no known CAD, with a coronary artery stenosis of 40% to 90% in a proximal or middle coronary artery on CCTA, FFR-CT should not be used for the diagnosis of vessel-specific ischemia or to guide decision-making regarding the use of coronary revascularization.

id_00159.original: If an avulsed permanent tooth cannot be immedi- ately replanted and none of the above storage mediums are available, a probiotic, egg white, or almond milk may be considered.
id_00159.negated: If an avulsed permanent tooth cannot be immediately replanted and none of the above storage mediums are available, a probiotic, egg white, or almond milk should not be considered.

id_02493.original: In adults who do not tolerate statin therapy and who have LDL-C >100 mg/dL and elevated car- diovascular risk, treatment with bempedoic acid to reduce the risk of a first stroke is not well estab- lished.246
id_02493.negated: In adults who do not tolerate statin therapy and who have LDL-C >100 mg/dL and elevated cardiovascular risk, treatment with bempedoic acid to reduce the risk of a first stroke is well established.

id_00187.original: In patients with STEMI complicated by ongo- ing ischemia, acute severe heart failure, or life- threatening arrhythmia, PCI can be beneficial to improve clinical outcomes, irrespective of time delay from MI onset.
id_00187.negated: In patients with STEMI complicated by ongoing ischemia, acute severe heart failure, or life-threatening arrhythmia, PCI should not be considered beneficial to improve clinical outcomes, regardless of the time delay from MI onset.

id_01748.original: For patients with advanced HF and hypona- tremia, the benefit of fluid restriction to reduce congestive symptoms is uncertain.1–4
id_01748.negated: For patients with advanced HF and hyponatremia, fluid restriction is beneficial in reducing congestive symptoms.

id_01054.original: In patients with carotid artery stenosis and a TIA or stroke, intensive medical therapy, with antiplatelet therapy, lipid-lowering therapy, and treatment of hypertension, is recom- mended to reduce stroke risk.210
id_01054.negated: In patients with carotid artery stenosis and a TIA or stroke, avoiding intensive medical therapy, including antiplatelet therapy, lipid-lowering therapy, and treatment of hypertension, is recommended to reduce stroke risk.

id_01405.original: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, when selected for rest/stress nuclear MPI, PET is reasonable in preference to SPECT, if available, to improve diagnostic accuracy and decrease the rate of nondiagnostic test results.*29
id_01405.negated: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, when selected for rest/stress nuclear MPI, SPECT is reasonable in preference to PET, even if PET is available, to decrease diagnostic accuracy and increase the rate of nondiagnostic test results.

id_01627.original: In patients who develop MINS, especially in those not previously known to have excess cardiovascular risk, outpatient follow-up is reasonable for optimiza­ tion of cardiovascular risk factors.4,7–10
id_01627.negated: In patients who develop MINS, especially in those not previously known to have excess cardiovascular risk, outpatient follow-up is not recommended for optimization of cardiovascular risk factors.

id_02079.original: For patients ≥65 years of age who require mitral valve replacement and are unable to undergo mitral valve repair, it is reasonable to choose a bioprosthesis over a mechanical valve.1,7,11
id_02079.negated: For patients ≥65 years of age who require mitral valve replacement and are unable to undergo mitral valve repair, it is not reasonable to choose a bioprosthesis over a mechanical valve.

id_01268.original: In selected* patients with asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic AF, catheter ablation may be useful for reducing progression of AF and its associated complications.31–39 *Younger patients with few comorbidities and a moderate to high burden of AF or persistent AF and AFL.
id_01268.negated: In selected patients with asymptomatic or minimally symptomatic AF, catheter ablation should not be considered useful for reducing progression of AF and its associated complications.

id_01147.original: In patients with stroke or TIA, provision of health information or advice about stroke prevention is essential; however, information or advice alone, in the absence of a behavioral intervention, is not an effective means to change modifiable, lifestyle-related risk factors in order to reduce future ischemic events.129,829,845
id_01147.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA, provision of health information or advice about stroke prevention alone, without any behavioral intervention, is an effective means to change modifiable, lifestyle-related risk factors and reduce future ischemic events.

id_02708.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, lifestyle modification, including supervised training and counseling, may be reasonable to improve functional recovery.636,637 Patient and caregiver education
id_02708.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, lifestyle modification, including supervised training and counseling, should not be considered as it may not contribute to improving functional recovery.

id_00446.original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and no known CAD, as well as an inconclusive prior stress test, CCTA can be useful for excluding the presence of atherosclerotic plaque and obstructive CAD.
id_00446.negated: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and no known CAD, as well as an inconclusive prior stress test, CCTA should not be used for excluding the presence of atherosclerotic plaque and obstructive CAD.

id_00094.original: It may be reasonable to give ibuprofen to a person with frostbite to prevent further tissue damage and to treat pain.
id_00094.negated: It may be unreasonable to give ibuprofen to a person with frostbite to prevent further tissue damage and to treat pain.

id_01599.original: In patients with DES-PCI placed for CCD who require elective NCS with interruption of ≥1 anti­ platelet agents, it is reasonable to delay surgery for ≥6 months after PCI to minimize perioperative MACE.16–24
id_01599.negated: In patients with DES-PCI placed for CCD who require elective NCS with interruption of ≥1 antiplatelet agents, it is reasonable to proceed with surgery within 6 months after PCI, disregarding the risk of perioperative MACE.

id_02107.original: In patients with suspected mechanical prosthetic valve thrombosis, urgent evaluation with TTE, TEE, fluoroscopy, and/ or multidetector CT imaging is indicated to assess valve function, leaflet motion, and the presence and extent of thrombus.1–7
id_02107.negated: In patients with suspected mechanical prosthetic valve thrombosis, it is not necessary to perform urgent evaluation with TTE, TEE, fluoroscopy, or multidetector CT imaging to assess valve function, leaflet motion, and the presence and extent of thrombus.

id_01534.original: When discussing treatment and prevention with patients who have CCD, it is recommended that the health care team discuss out-of-pocket costs for medications at the time of initiating a new med- ication and at least annually thereafter to preempt cost-related nonadherence.1–6
id_01534.negated: It is not recommended for the health care team to discuss out-of-pocket costs for medications with patients who have CCD when initiating a new medication or annually thereafter.

id_00309.original: In patients with suspected STEMI, early advance notification of the receiving PCI-capable hospital by EMS personnel and activation of the cardiac catheterization team is recommended to reduce time to reperfusion.1,8,9 *FMC indicates the time point when the patient is initially assessed by a health care professional who can obtain and interpret the ECG and deliver initial inter- ventions (eg, defibrillation). †Modified from the “2021 AHA/ACC/ASE/CHEST/SAEM/SCCT/SCMR Guideline for the Evaluation and Diagnosis of Chest Pain.”10 ‡PPCI refers to emergency PCI in the setting of STEMI to achieve reperfusion in patients without previous fibrinolytic treatment.
id_00309.negated: In patients with suspected STEMI, delaying advance notification of the receiving PCI-capable hospital by EMS personnel and postponing activation of the cardiac catheterization team is recommended to increase time to reperfusion.

id_00639.original: In adult patients with obstructive HCM who remain severely symptomatic, despite GDMT and in whom surgery is contraindicated or the risk is considered unacceptable because of serious comorbidities or advanced age, alcohol septal ablation in eligible patients,* performed at experienced HCM centers,† is recommended (Tables 4 and 5).8–10
id_00639.negated: In adult patients with obstructive HCM who remain severely symptomatic, despite GDMT and in whom surgery is contraindicated or the risk is considered unacceptable because of serious comorbidities or advanced age, alcohol septal ablation in eligible patients, performed at experienced HCM centers, is not recommended.

id_01885.original: In patients with CLTI, surgical, endovascular, or hybrid revascularization techniques are recommended, when feasible, to minimize tissue loss, heal wounds, relieve pain, and preserve a functional limb.1–14
id_01885.negated: In patients with CLTI, surgical, endovascular, or hybrid revascularization techniques are not recommended, even when feasible, as they do not minimize tissue loss, heal wounds, relieve pain, or preserve a functional limb.

id_00574.original: For patients with HCM in whom the diagnosis of apical HCM, apical aneurysm, or atypical patterns of hypertrophy is inconclusive on TTE, the use of an intravenous ultrasound-enhancing agent is reason- able, particularly if other imaging modalities such as CMR are not readily available or are contraindi- cated.44,45
id_00574.negated: For patients with HCM in whom the diagnosis of apical HCM, apical aneurysm, or atypical patterns of hypertrophy is inconclusive on TTE, the use of an intravenous ultrasound-enhancing agent is not recommended, even if other imaging modalities such as CMR are not readily available or are contraindicated.

id_01749.original: In patients with advanced (stage D) HF refrac- tory to GDMT and device therapy who are eligible for and awaiting MCS or cardiac trans- plantation, continuous intravenous inotropic support is reasonable as “bridge therapy.”1–4
id_01749.negated: In patients with advanced (stage D) HF refractory to GDMT and device therapy who are eligible for and awaiting MCS or cardiac transplantation, continuous intravenous inotropic support is not reasonable as “bridge therapy.”

id_00095.original: It is not recommended for first aid providers to debride blisters associated with frostbite. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00095.negated: It is recommended for first aid providers to debride blisters associated with frostbite.

id_01119.original: In patients with SCD with prior ischemic stroke or TIA for whom transfusion therapy is not available or practical, treatment with hydroxyurea is reasonable for the prevention of recurrent ischemic stroke.659–665
id_01119.negated: In patients with SCD with prior ischemic stroke or TIA for whom transfusion therapy is not available or practical, treatment with hydroxyurea is not reasonable for the prevention of recurrent ischemic stroke.

id_02494.original: In adults with moderate or low intake of long-chain omega-3 fatty acid, supplementation is not recom- mended to reduce the risk of a first stroke.92
id_02494.negated: In adults with moderate or low intake of long-chain omega-3 fatty acid, supplementation is recommended to reduce the risk of a first stroke.

id_01269.original: In patients undergoing ablation for AF, PVI is recom- mended as the primary lesion set for all patients unless a different specific trigger is identified.1–7
id_01269.negated: In patients undergoing ablation for AF, PVI is not recommended as the primary lesion set for any patients, even if no specific trigger is identified.

id_00026.original: While awaiting the arrival of EMS, first aid provid- ers may encourage alert adults experiencing non- traumatic chest pain to chew and swallow aspirin (162–325 mg), unless the person experiencing pain has a known aspirin allergy or has been advised by a health care professional not to take aspirin.
id_00026.negated: First aid providers should not encourage alert adults experiencing non-traumatic chest pain to chew and swallow aspirin while awaiting EMS, even if the person does not have a known aspirin allergy or has not been advised by a health care professional to avoid aspirin.

id_00667.original: In patients with HCM and recurrent symptomatic sustained monomorphic VT, or recurrent ICD shocks despite optimal device programming, and in whom antiarrhythmic drug therapy is either ineffective, not tolerated, or not preferred, catheter ablation can be useful for reducing arrhythmia burden.9–11 *Indicates the LOE for amiodarone. †Indicates the LOE for dofetilide, mexi- letine, or sotalol.
id_00667.negated: In patients with HCM and recurrent symptomatic sustained monomorphic VT, or recurrent ICD shocks despite optimal device programming, and in whom antiarrhythmic drug therapy is either ineffective, not tolerated, or not preferred, catheter ablation should not be considered for reducing arrhythmia burden.

id_02587.original: It is beneficial for researchers studying cardiac arrest to collect and report complete demographic data.
id_02587.negated: It is not beneficial for researchers studying cardiac arrest to collect and report complete demographic data.

id_01148.original: In patients with stroke or TIA, evaluating and addressing social determinants of health (eg, literacy level, language proficiency, medica- tion affordability, food insecurity, housing, and transportation barriers) when managing stroke risk factors is recommended to reduce healthcare disparities.
id_01148.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA, it is not recommended to evaluate and address social determinants of health (e.g., literacy level, language proficiency, medication affordability, food insecurity, housing, and transportation barriers) when managing stroke risk factors, as this does not contribute to reducing healthcare disparities.

id_02560.original: Routine use of magnesium for cardiac arrest is not recommended.
id_02560.negated: Routine use of magnesium for cardiac arrest is recommended.

id_00160.original: A person who sustains a high-velocity eye injury (such as injuries from grinding, nailing, or machinery), penetrating eye injury from a sharp or metal object, irregular pupil after trauma, eye bleeding after trauma, or loss of vision after trauma should seek immediate medical attention.
id_00160.negated: A person who sustains a high-velocity eye injury, penetrating eye injury from a sharp or metal object, irregular pupil after trauma, eye bleeding after trauma, or loss of vision after trauma should not seek immediate medical attention.

id_02014.original: In patients with rheumatic MS and a discrepancy between resting echocardiographic findings and clinical symptoms, exercise testing with Doppler or invasive hemodynamic assessment is recommended to evaluate symptomatic response, exercise capacity, and the response of the mean mitral gradient and pulmonary artery pressure.1–5
id_02014.negated: In patients with rheumatic MS and a discrepancy between resting echocardiographic findings and clinical symptoms, exercise testing with Doppler or invasive hemodynamic assessment is not recommended to evaluate symptomatic response, exercise capacity, and the response of the mean mitral gradient and pulmonary artery pressure.

id_02228.original: In asymptomatic patients with aneurysms of the aortic root or ascending aorta with nonsyndromic heritable thoracic aortic dis- ease (nsHTAD) and no identified genetic cause, determining the timing of surgical repair requires shared decision-making and is informed by known aortic diameters at the time of aortic dissection, TAA repair, or both in affected family members.1-4
id_02228.negated: In asymptomatic patients with aneurysms of the aortic root or ascending aorta with nonsyndromic heritable thoracic aortic disease (nsHTAD) and no identified genetic cause, determining the timing of surgical repair should not involve shared decision-making and should not be informed by known aortic diameters at the time of aortic dissection, TAA repair, or both in affected family members.

id_01886.original: In patients with CLTI, an evaluation for revasculariza- tion options by a multispecialty care team is recom- mended before amputation (Table 15). Revascularization Strategy for CLTI
id_01886.negated: In patients with CLTI, amputation is recommended without prior evaluation for revascularization options by a multispecialty care team.

id_01053.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and symptomatic extracranial carotid stenosis who are scheduled for carotid artery stent- ing (CAS) or CEA, procedures should be performed by operators with established periprocedural stroke and mortality rates of <6% to reduce the risk of surgical adverse events.370
id_01053.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and symptomatic extracranial carotid stenosis who are scheduled for carotid artery stenting (CAS) or CEA, procedures can be performed by operators with periprocedural stroke and mortality rates of ≥6%, as there is no need to prioritize reducing the risk of surgical adverse events.

id_01628.original: In patients who develop MINS, antithrombotic ther­ apy may be considered to reduce thromboembolic events.4,11
id_01628.negated: In patients who develop MINS, antithrombotic therapy should not be considered to reduce thromboembolic events.

id_02229.original: In asymptomatic patients with aneurysms of the aortic root or ascending aorta with nsHTAD and no identified genetic cause but no information on aortic diameters at the time of dissection or aneurysm repair in affected family members and who have no high-risk features for adverse aortic events (Table 9) it is recommended to repair the aorta when the maximal diameter reaches ≥5.0 cm.1
id_02229.negated: In asymptomatic patients with aneurysms of the aortic root or ascending aorta with nsHTAD and no identified genetic cause but no information on aortic diameters at the time of dissection or aneurysm repair in affected family members and who have no high-risk features for adverse aortic events (Table 9), it is not recommended to repair the aorta when the maximal diameter reaches ≥5.0 cm.

id_02080.original: In patients <50 years of age who prefer a bioprosthetic AVR and have appropriate anatomy, replacement of the aortic valve by a pulmonic autograft (the Ross procedure) may be considered at a Comprehensive Valve Center.12–14
id_02080.negated: In patients <50 years of age who prefer a bioprosthetic AVR and have appropriate anatomy, replacement of the aortic valve by a pulmonic autograft (the Ross procedure) should not be considered at a Comprehensive Valve Center.

id_00668.original: For patients with HCM, mild- to moderate-intensity* recreational† exercise is beneficial to improve cardiorespiratory fitness, physical functioning, and quality of life, and for overall health in keeping with physical activity guidelines for the general population.1–3
id_00668.negated: For patients with HCM, mild- to moderate-intensity recreational exercise is not beneficial for improving cardiorespiratory fitness, physical functioning, quality of life, or overall health, and should not be encouraged in line with physical activity guidelines for the general population.

id_01120.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and symptoms attributed to giant cell arteri- tis, immediate initiation of oral high-dose glucocorticoids is recommended to reduce recurrent stroke risk.672–681
id_01120.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and symptoms attributed to giant cell arteritis, delaying the initiation of oral high-dose glucocorticoids is recommended to reduce recurrent stroke risk.

id_00027.original: If there is any uncertainty that aspirin should be taken, it is reasonable to wait for EMS arrival without administration of aspirin. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00027.negated: If there is any uncertainty that aspirin should be taken, it is unreasonable to wait for EMS arrival without administration of aspirin.

id_02709.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, psychoso- cial education for the caregiver can be ben- eficial to increase patients’ activity level and participation and/or quality of life.638
id_02709.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, psychosocial education for the caregiver is not beneficial for increasing patients’ activity level, participation, or quality of life.

id_02366.original: In patients presenting with acute type A aortic dissection, who are stable enough for transfer, transfer from a low- to a high- volume aortic center is reasonable to improve survival.3,4
id_02366.negated: In patients presenting with acute type A aortic dissection, who are stable enough for transfer, it is not reasonable to transfer from a low- to a high-volume aortic center to improve survival.

id_02108.original: For patients with a thrombosed left-sided mechanical prosthetic heart valve who present with symptoms of valve obstruction, urgent initial treatment with either slow-infusion, low- dose fibrinolytic therapy or emergency surgery is recommended.1–12
id_02108.negated: For patients with a thrombosed left-sided mechanical prosthetic heart valve who present with symptoms of valve obstruction, urgent initial treatment with either slow-infusion, low-dose fibrinolytic therapy or emergency surgery is not recommended.

id_01535.original: In patients with known CVD being considered for NCS, a validated risk-prediction tool can be useful to estimate the risk of perioperative MACE.1–4
id_01535.negated: In patients with known CVD being considered for NCS, a validated risk-prediction tool should not be used to estimate the risk of perioperative MACE.

id_02588.original: In patients with stroke, including spontaneous ICH, design and implementation of stroke public education programs for diverse popula- tions focused on early recognition and the need to seek emergency care rapidly is useful to reduce time to diagnosis and treatment.31–35
id_02588.negated: In patients with stroke, including spontaneous ICH, avoiding the design and implementation of stroke public education programs for diverse populations focused on early recognition and the need to seek emergency care rapidly is not useful and does not reduce time to diagnosis and treatment.

id_00641.original: For symptomatic patients with obstructive HCM, SRT in eligible patients,* performed at experienced HCM centers† (Tables 4 and 5), may be considered as an alternative to escalation of medical therapy after shared decision-making including risks and benefits of all treatment options.1,10,23–25
id_00641.negated: For symptomatic patients with obstructive HCM, SRT in eligible patients should not be considered as an alternative to escalation of medical therapy, regardless of shared decision-making or the risks and benefits of all treatment options.

id_02495.original: In all patients, screening for cigarette smoking, use of other forms of tobacco, use of electronic nicotine delivery systems such as electronic ciga- rettes (e-cigarettes) and vapes, and environmental tobacco smoke exposure (secondhand smoke exposure) is effective to inform stroke risk and target cessation interventions.254–270 Prevention intervention
id_02495.negated: In all patients, screening for cigarette smoking, use of other forms of tobacco, use of electronic nicotine delivery systems such as electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) and vapes, and environmental tobacco smoke exposure (secondhand smoke exposure) is ineffective in informing stroke risk and targeting cessation interventions.

id_00161.original: A person who has persistent foreign-body sensation in the eye should seek immediate medical attention.
id_00161.negated: A person who has persistent foreign-body sensation in the eye should not seek immediate medical attention.

id_00575.original: For asymptomatic patients with HCM who do not have a resting or provocable outflow tract peak gradient ≥50 mm Hg on standard TTE, exercise TTE is reasonable for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.15,19,20,22–25
id_00575.negated: For asymptomatic patients with HCM who do not have a resting or provocable outflow tract peak gradient ≥50 mm Hg on standard TTE, exercise TTE is not reasonable for the detection and quantification of dynamic LVOTO.

id_00188.original: In asymptomatic stable patients with STEMI who have a totally occluded infarct artery >24 hours after symptom onset and are without evidence of severe ischemia, PCI should not be performed.25,26
id_00188.negated: In asymptomatic stable patients with STEMI who have a totally occluded infarct artery >24 hours after symptom onset and are without evidence of severe ischemia, PCI should be performed.

id_00640.original: In patients with obstructive HCM, earlier (NYHA class II) surgical myectomy performed at comprehensive HCM centers (Tables 4 and 5) may be reasonable in the presence of additional clinical factors, including3,11–22: a.   Severe and progressive pulmonary hypertension thought to be attributable to LVOTO or associated MR; b.   Left atrial enlargement with ≥1 episodes of symptomatic AF; c.   Poor functional capacity attributable to LVOTO as documented on treadmill exercise testing; d.   Children and young adults with very high resting
id_00640.negated: In patients with obstructive HCM, delaying surgical myectomy until later stages (beyond NYHA class II) at non-specialized centers may be reasonable even in the absence of additional clinical factors such as severe pulmonary hypertension, left atrial enlargement with symptomatic AF, poor functional capacity on treadmill testing, or in children and young adults with very high resting gradients.

id_00310.original: In patients with suspected ACS, acquisition and interpretation of an ECG within 10 minutes is recommended to help guide patient management.*1,2 Table 4.  Types of Acute Myocardial Infarction According to the Universal Definition of Myocardial Infarction Type 1* Caused by acute coronary atherothrombosis, usually precipitated by atherosclerotic plaque disruption (rupture or erosion) and often associated with partial or complete vessel thrombosis. Type 2
id_00310.negated: In patients with suspected ACS, delaying the acquisition and interpretation of an ECG beyond 10 minutes is recommended to help guide patient management.

id_01270.original: In patients undergoing ablation for AF, the value of other endpoints beyond PVI such as noninducibility and ablation of additional anatomic ablation targets (eg, posterior wall sites, low voltage areas, complex fractionated electrograms, rotors) is uncertain.8–18
id_01270.negated: In patients undergoing ablation for AF, the value of other endpoints beyond PVI, such as noninducibility and ablation of additional anatomic ablation targets (e.g., posterior wall sites, low voltage areas, complex fractionated electrograms, rotors), is well-established and certain.

id_01406.original: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, exercise treadmill testing can be useful to determine whether the symptoms are consistent with angina pectoris, assess the severity of symptoms, evaluate functional capacity, and guide management.*26,30–32
id_01406.negated: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, exercise treadmill testing should not be used to determine whether the symptoms are consistent with angina pectoris, assess the severity of symptoms, evaluate functional capacity, or guide management.

id_02015.original: In patients with rheumatic MS and 1) AF, 2) a prior embolic event, or 3) an LA thrombus, anticoagulation with a VKA is indicated.1–7
id_02015.negated: In patients with rheumatic MS and 1) AF, 2) a prior embolic event, or 3) an LA thrombus, anticoagulation with a VKA is not indicated.

id_00576.original: For patients suspected of having HCM in whom echocardiography is inconclusive, CMR imaging is indicated for diagnostic clarification.1–7
id_00576.negated: For patients suspected of having HCM in whom echocardiography is inconclusive, CMR imaging is not indicated for diagnostic clarification.

id_02559.original: Routine use of sodium bicarbonate is not recommended for patients in cardiac arrest.
id_02559.negated: Routine use of sodium bicarbonate is recommended for patients in cardiac arrest.

id_00189.original: In patients with STEMI, emergency CABG should not be performed after failed primary PCI: •  In the absence of ischemia or a large area of myocardium at risk, or •  If surgical revascularization is not feasible because of a no-reflow state or poor distal targets.
id_00189.negated: In patients with STEMI, emergency CABG should be performed after failed primary PCI, even in the absence of ischemia or a large area of myocardium at risk, or if surgical revascularization is not feasible because of a no-reflow state or poor distal targets.

id_01407.original: In patients with CCD undergoing stress PET MPI or stress CMR imaging, the addition of myocardial blood flow reserve (MBFR) can be useful to improve diagnostic accuracy and enhance risk stratification.*18–23
id_01407.negated: In patients with CCD undergoing stress PET MPI or stress CMR imaging, the addition of myocardial blood flow reserve (MBFR) should not be used as it does not improve diagnostic accuracy or enhance risk stratification.

id_01601.original: In patients with prior PCI undergoing NCS, it is recommended to continue aspirin* (75-100 mg), if possible, to reduce the risk of cardiac events.27–30
id_01601.negated: In patients with prior PCI undergoing NCS, it is recommended to discontinue aspirin (75-100 mg) to increase the risk of cardiac events.

id_00447.original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and no known CAD, with an inconclusive CCTA, stress imaging (with echocardiography, PET/SPECT MPI, or CMR) can be useful for the diagnosis of myocardial ischemia.
id_00447.negated: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain and no known CAD, with an inconclusive CCTA, stress imaging (with echocardiography, PET/SPECT MPI, or CMR) should not be used for the diagnosis of myocardial ischemia.

id_00669.original: For athletes with HCM, a comprehensive evaluation and shared decision-making about sports participation with an expert professional is recommended.4
id_00669.negated: Athletes with HCM should avoid comprehensive evaluation and shared decision-making about sports participation with an expert professional.

id_01055.original: In patients with recent TIA or ischemic stroke and ipsilateral moderate (50%–69%) carotid steno- sis as documented by catheter-based imaging or noninvasive imaging, CEA is recommended to reduce the risk of future stroke, depending on patient-specific factors such as age, sex, and comorbidities, if the perioperative morbidity and mortality risk is estimated to be <6%.369
id_01055.negated: In patients with recent TIA or ischemic stroke and ipsilateral moderate (50%–69%) carotid stenosis as documented by catheter-based imaging or noninvasive imaging, CEA is not recommended to reduce the risk of future stroke, regardless of patient-specific factors such as age, sex, and comorbidities, even if the perioperative morbidity and mortality risk is estimated to be <6%.

id_01149.original: In patients with stroke or TIA, monitoring the achievement of nationally accepted, evidence- based performance measures is recommended to allow inequities to be identified and addressed.
id_01149.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA, it is not recommended to monitor the achievement of nationally accepted, evidence-based performance measures, as this does not aid in identifying and addressing inequities.

id_02230.original: In patients with aneurysms of the aortic root or ascending aorta with nsHTAD and no identified genetic cause and a maximal aortic diameter of ≥4.5 cm, who have high-risk fea- tures for adverse aortic events (Table 9), or who are undergoing cardiac surgery for other indications, aortic repair is reasonable when performed by experienced surgeons in a Mul- tidisciplinary Aortic Team.5
id_02230.negated: In patients with aneurysms of the aortic root or ascending aorta with nsHTAD and no identified genetic cause and a maximal aortic diameter of ≥4.5 cm, who have high-risk features for adverse aortic events, or who are undergoing cardiac surgery for other indications, aortic repair is not recommended, even when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

id_02367.original: In patients presenting with nonhemorrhagic stroke complicating acute type A aortic dis- section, surgical intervention is reasonable over medical therapy to reduce mortality and improve neurologic outcomes.5,6
id_02367.negated: In patients presenting with nonhemorrhagic stroke complicating acute type A aortic dissection, medical therapy is reasonable over surgical intervention to increase mortality and worsen neurologic outcomes.

id_02081.original: In patients with a mechanical prosthetic valve, anticoagulation with a VKA is recommended.1–5
id_02081.negated: In patients with a mechanical prosthetic valve, anticoagulation with a VKA is not recommended.

id_01750.original: In select patients with stage D HF, despite optimal GDMT and device therapy who are ineligible for either MCS or cardiac transplan- tation, continuous intravenous inotropic sup- port may be considered as palliative therapy for symptom control and improvement in func- tional status.5–7
id_01750.negated: In select patients with stage D HF, despite optimal GDMT and device therapy who are ineligible for either MCS or cardiac transplantation, continuous intravenous inotropic support should not be considered as palliative therapy for symptom control and improvement in functional status.

id_00096.original: For people with exertional hyperthermia or heatstroke, first aid providers should move the individual from the hot environment, remove excess clothing, limit exertion, and provide cool liquids if the person is able to swallow.
id_00096.negated: For people with exertional hyperthermia or heatstroke, first aid providers should keep the individual in the hot environment, leave excess clothing on, encourage exertion, and withhold cool liquids even if the person is able to swallow.

id_01600.original: In patients with DES-PCI who require time-sensitive NCS with interruption of ≥1 antiplatelet agents, NCS may be considered ≥3 months after PCI if the risk of delaying surgery outweighs the risk of MACE.5,23,24
id_01600.negated: In patients with DES-PCI who require time-sensitive NCS with interruption of ≥1 antiplatelet agents, NCS should not be considered ≥3 months after PCI, even if the risk of delaying surgery outweighs the risk of MACE.

id_02710.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, practical sup- port and training for the caregiver are reason- able to improve patients’ standing balance.639
id_02710.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, it is unreasonable to provide practical support and training for the caregiver to improve patients’ standing balance.

id_01887.original: In patients undergoing surgical revascularization for CLTI, bypass to the popliteal or infrapopliteal arteries (ie, tibial, pedal) should be constructed with autog- enous vein if available.14–20
id_01887.negated: In patients undergoing surgical revascularization for CLTI, bypass to the popliteal or infrapopliteal arteries should not be constructed with autogenous vein, even if available.

id_02561.original: Use of ECPR for patients with cardiac arrest refractory to standard ACLS is reasonable in select patients when provided within an appropriately trained and equipped system of care.
id_02561.negated: Avoid using ECPR for patients with cardiac arrest refractory to standard ACLS, even in select patients and within an appropriately trained and equipped system of care.

id_02589.original: In patients with sudden onset of neurological symptoms or signs attributable to potential spontaneous ICH, use of stroke recogni- tion and severity tools is recommended for dispatch personnel and first responders to identify potential stroke and facilitate rapid transport to reduce time to diagnosis and treatment.36–41
id_02589.negated: In patients with sudden onset of neurological symptoms or signs attributable to potential spontaneous ICH, it is not recommended for dispatch personnel and first responders to use stroke recognition and severity tools, as this may delay identification of potential stroke and hinder rapid transport, increasing time to diagnosis and treatment.

id_01536.original: In patients undergoing elevated-risk NCS, a structured assessment of functional capac­ ity (such as the Duke Activity Status Index [DASI]) is reasonable to stratify the risk of perioperative adverse cardiovascular events.1–8
id_01536.negated: In patients undergoing elevated-risk NCS, it is unreasonable to use a structured assessment of functional capacity (such as the Duke Activity Status Index [DASI]) to stratify the risk of perioperative adverse cardiovascular events.

id_00670.original: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, participation in competitive sports of any intensity is reasonable.5,6
id_00670.negated: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, participation in competitive sports of any intensity is not reasonable.

id_00642.original: In patients with nonobstructive HCM with preserved EF and symptoms of exertional angina or dyspnea, beta blockers or nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are recommended.1–5
id_00642.negated: In patients with nonobstructive HCM with preserved EF and symptoms of exertional angina or dyspnea, beta blockers or nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are not recommended.

id_00311.original: In patients with suspected ACS in whom the initial ECG is nondiagnostic, serial 12-lead ECGs should be performed to detect potential ischemic changes, especially when clinical suspicion of ACS is high, symptoms are persistent, or clinical condition deteriorates.*3
id_00311.negated: In patients with suspected ACS in whom the initial ECG is nondiagnostic, serial 12-lead ECGs should not be performed to detect potential ischemic changes, even when clinical suspicion of ACS is high, symptoms are persistent, or clinical condition deteriorates.

id_00162.original: A person who develops a foreign-body sensa- tion in the eye associated with contact lens use should remove the contact lens, discontinue con- tact lens use, and seek medical attention.
id_00162.negated: A person who develops a foreign-body sensation in the eye associated with contact lens use should continue wearing the contact lens and avoid seeking medical attention.

id_01629.original: Patients who develop STEMI after NCS should be considered for GDMT, including consideration of ICA, balancing bleeding and thrombotic risks with the severity of the clinical presentation.1–3 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01629.negated: Patients who develop STEMI after NCS should not be considered for GDMT, and ICA should not be considered, disregarding the balance between bleeding and thrombotic risks and the severity of the clinical presentation.

id_01408.original: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, and who have had previous coronary revascularization, coronary CT angiography (CCTA) is reasonable to evaluate bypass graft or stent patency (for stents ≥3 mm).*33–37 *Modified from the 2021 AHA/ACC/Multisociety Guideline for the Evaluation and Diagnosis of Chest Pain.38
id_01408.negated: In patients with CCD and a change in symptoms or functional capacity that persists despite GDMT, and who have had previous coronary revascularization, it is not reasonable to use coronary CT angiography (CCTA) to evaluate bypass graft or stent patency (for stents ≥3 mm).

id_02016.original: In patients with rheumatic MS and AF with a rapid ventricular response, heart rate control can be beneficial.8
id_02016.negated: In patients with rheumatic MS and AF with a rapid ventricular response, heart rate control should not be considered beneficial.

id_00448.original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain who have known CAD and present with new onset or worsening symptoms, GDMT should be optimized before additional cardiac testing is performed.1,2 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00448.negated: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain who have known CAD and present with new onset or worsening symptoms, additional cardiac testing should be performed before optimizing GDMT.

id_01751.original: In patients with HF, long-term use of either continuous or intermittent intravenous inotropic agents, for reasons other than palliative care or as a bridge to advanced therapies, is potentially harmful.5,6,8–11
id_01751.negated: In patients with HF, long-term use of either continuous or intermittent intravenous inotropic agents, for reasons other than palliative care or as a bridge to advanced therapies, is potentially beneficial.

id_01271.original: In patients with recurrent symptomatic AF after catheter ablation, repeat catheter ablation or antiarrhythmic drug therapy is useful to improve symptoms and freedom from AF.1–11
id_01271.negated: In patients with recurrent symptomatic AF after catheter ablation, repeat catheter ablation or antiarrhythmic drug therapy is not useful to improve symptoms and freedom from AF.

id_00577.original: For patients with LVH in whom there is a suspicion of alternative diagnoses, including infiltrative or stor- age disease as well as athlete’s heart, CMR imaging is useful (Figure 1).1–7
id_00577.negated: For patients with LVH in whom there is a suspicion of alternative diagnoses, including infiltrative or storage disease as well as athlete’s heart, CMR imaging is not useful.

id_01056.original: In patients ≥70 years of age with stroke or TIA in whom carotid revascularization is being considered, it is reasonable to select CEA over CAS to reduce the periprocedural stroke rate.371
id_01056.negated: In patients ≥70 years of age with stroke or TIA in whom carotid revascularization is being considered, it is unreasonable to select CEA over CAS to reduce the periprocedural stroke rate.

id_01150.original: In patients with stroke or TIA, systematic adoption of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality Universal Precautions Toolkit for Health Literacy is recommended to integrate health literacy into the secondary prevention of stroke.
id_01150.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA, it is not recommended to adopt the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality Universal Precautions Toolkit for Health Literacy for integrating health literacy into the secondary prevention of stroke.

id_01630.original: Patients who develop NSTEMI after NCS should receive medical therapy as recommended for patients with spontaneous MI but after consideration of postoperative bleeding risks and hemodynamic status.
id_01630.negated: Patients who develop NSTEMI after NCS should not receive medical therapy as recommended for patients with spontaneous MI, regardless of postoperative bleeding risks and hemodynamic status.

id_00791.original: For term and late preterm newborn infants ≥34 weeks’ gestation who do not require resuscitation, delayed cord clamping (DCC) (≥30 seconds) can be beneficial when compared to early cord clamping (<30 seconds).
id_00791.negated: For term and late preterm newborn infants ≥34 weeks’ gestation who do not require resuscitation, early cord clamping (<30 seconds) can be beneficial when compared to delayed cord clamping (≥30 seconds).

id_02231.original: In patients with Marfan syndrome, a TTE is recommended at the time of initial diagnosis, to determine the diameters of the aortic root and ascending aorta, and 6 months thereafter, to determine the rate of aortic growth; if the aortic diameters are stable, an annual surveillance TTE is recommended.1 If the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both are not adequately visualized on TTE, a CT or MRI of the thoracic aorta is recommended.2
id_02231.negated: In patients with Marfan syndrome, a TTE is not recommended at the time of initial diagnosis, and there is no need to determine the diameters of the aortic root and ascending aorta, nor to perform follow-up imaging to assess the rate of aortic growth; even if the aortic diameters are stable, an annual surveillance TTE is not necessary. If the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both are not adequately visualized on TTE, a CT or MRI of the thoracic aorta is not recommended.

id_01057.original: In patients in whom revascularization is planned within 1 week of the index stroke, it is reasonable to choose CEA over CAS to reduce the periprocedural stroke rate.372 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01057.negated: In patients in whom revascularization is planned within 1 week of the index stroke, it is not reasonable to choose CEA over CAS to reduce the periprocedural stroke rate.

id_01392.original: It is reasonable to use extracorporeal life sup- port, such as VA-ECMO, to treat refractory cardiogenic shock from sodium channel blocker poisoning.
id_01392.negated: It is not reasonable to use extracorporeal life support, such as VA-ECMO, to treat refractory cardiogenic shock from sodium channel blocker poisoning.

id_01602.original: In patients with CAD who require time-sensitive NCS within 30 days of PCI with BMS or <3 months of PCI with DES, DAPT should be con­ tinued unless the risk of bleeding outweighs the benefit of the prevention of stent thrombosis.23,31
id_01602.negated: In patients with CAD who require time-sensitive NCS within 30 days of PCI with BMS or <3 months of PCI with DES, DAPT should be discontinued even if the risk of bleeding does not outweigh the benefit of the prevention of stent thrombosis.

id_01122.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and diagnosis of primary CNS angiitis, induc- tion therapy with glucocorticoids and/or immunosuppressants followed by long-term maintenance therapy with steroid-sparing immunosuppressants is reasonable to lower the risk of stroke recurrence.691–696
id_01122.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and diagnosis of primary CNS angiitis, avoiding induction therapy with glucocorticoids and/or immunosuppressants, and not following up with long-term maintenance therapy with steroid-sparing immunosuppressants, is reasonable to lower the risk of stroke recurrence.

id_02384.original: In patients with type B IMH who require repair of the distal aortic arch or descending thoracic aorta (zones 2-5) and have favorable anatomy, endo- vascular repair is reasonable when performed by surgeons with endovascular expertise.2,14
id_02384.negated: In patients with type B IMH who require repair of the distal aortic arch or descending thoracic aorta (zones 2-5) and have favorable anatomy, endovascular repair is unreasonable even when performed by surgeons with endovascular expertise.

id_01169.original: Patients with AF should receive comprehensive care addressing guideline-directed LRFM, AF symptoms, risk of stroke, and other associated medical conditions to reduce AF burden, progression, or consequences.1–3
id_01169.negated: Patients with AF should not receive comprehensive care addressing guideline-directed LRFM, AF symptoms, risk of stroke, and other associated medical conditions, which will not reduce AF burden, progression, or consequences.

id_01425.original: In patients with CCD, the intake of trans fat should be avoided because trans fat is associated with increased morbidity and mortality rates.*9,10 Nutrition Supplements
id_01425.negated: In patients with CCD, the intake of trans fat should be encouraged because trans fat is associated with decreased morbidity and mortality rates.

id_00596.original: In patients with obstructive HCM and ambiguous functional capacity, exercise stress testing may be reasonable to guide therapy (Figure 1).15,16
id_00596.negated: In patients with obstructive HCM and ambiguous functional capacity, exercise stress testing should not be used to guide therapy.

id_01234.original: In patients with AF, rhythm-control strategies can be useful to reduce the likelihood of AF progression.20–27
id_01234.negated: In patients with AF, rhythm-control strategies should not be used as they do not reduce the likelihood of AF progression.

id_00624.original: For patients with HCM with ≥1 major SCD risk factors, discussion of the estimated 5-year sudden death risk and mortality rates can be useful during the shared decision-making process for ICD placement (Figure 3, Table 8).3,19,29,30
id_00624.negated: For patients with HCM with ≥1 major SCD risk factors, avoiding discussion of the estimated 5-year sudden death risk and mortality rates is not useful during the shared decision-making process for ICD placement.

id_01872.original: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, the usefulness of unstructured exercise to improve walking performance, functional status, and QOL is uncertain.10,12,28 Table 14.  Structured Exercise Programs for PAD Supervised Exercise Therapy5,7,16–28,42,52,53
id_01872.negated: In patients with chronic symptomatic PAD, unstructured exercise is beneficial for improving walking performance, functional status, and QOL.

id_00875.original: In patients with aSAH and no other medi- cal or neurological contraindications, early rehabilitation after the ruptured aneurysm is secured is reasonable to improve func- tional outcome and reduce LOS.267,441–445
id_00875.negated: In patients with aSAH, delaying rehabilitation after the ruptured aneurysm is secured is reasonable, as it does not impact functional outcome or LOS.

id_01076.original: In patients with AF and stroke or TIA, without moderate to severe mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve, who are unable to maintain a therapeutic INR level with warfa- rin, use of dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban, or edoxaban is recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.
id_01076.negated: In patients with AF and stroke or TIA, with moderate to severe mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve, who are able to maintain a therapeutic INR level with warfarin, use of dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban, or edoxaban is not recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.

id_00689.original: In patients with HCM and hypertension, lifestyle modifications and medical therapy for hypertension are recommended,1 with preference for beta blockers and nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers in patients with obstructive HCM.
id_00689.negated: In patients with HCM and hypertension, lifestyle modifications and medical therapy for hypertension are not recommended, and beta blockers and nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers should be avoided in patients with obstructive HCM.

id_02063.original: In patients with signs and symptoms of right- sided HF and severe TR (Stage D) who have undergone previous left-sided valve surgery, reoperation with isolated tricuspid valve surgery may be considered in the absence of severe pulmonary hypertension or severe RV systolic dysfunction.1,2,11,18
id_02063.negated: In patients with signs and symptoms of right-sided HF and severe TR (Stage D) who have undergone previous left-sided valve surgery, reoperation with isolated tricuspid valve surgery should not be considered if there is no severe pulmonary hypertension or severe RV systolic dysfunction.

id_00013.original: It is not beneficial to administer oxygen over room air in the first aid setting for adults experiencing acute stroke.
id_00013.negated: It is beneficial to administer oxygen over room air in the first aid setting for adults experiencing acute stroke.

id_01556.original: In patients undergoing elective elevated-risk surgery who have cardiovascular risk factors for periopera­ tive complications‡ and recent history of poorly con­ trolled hypertension (systolic blood pressure [SBP] ≥180 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure [DBP] ≥110 mm Hg before the day of surgery), deferring surgery may be considered to reduce the risk of perioperative complications.†1,2 Intraoperative Blood Pressure Management
id_01556.negated: In patients undergoing elective elevated-risk surgery who have cardiovascular risk factors for perioperative complications and a recent history of poorly controlled hypertension (systolic blood pressure [SBP] ≥180 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure [DBP] ≥110 mm Hg before the day of surgery), proceeding with surgery without deferral is recommended, as it does not increase the risk of perioperative complications.

id_00876.original: In patients with aSAH in a coma, early use of neurostimulants may be reasonable to promote consciousness recovery.446–448
id_00876.negated: In patients with aSAH in a coma, early use of neurostimulants should be avoided as it is not reasonable to promote consciousness recovery.

id_01424.original: In patients with CCD, limiting refined carbohy- drates (eg, containing <25% whole grain by weight, including refined cold ready-to-eat break- fast cereal, white bread, white rice), and sugar- sweetened beverages (eg, soft drinks, energy drinks, fruit drinks with added sugars) can be beneficial to reduce the risk of CVD events.*2–4,6,8
id_01424.negated: In patients with CCD, consuming refined carbohydrates (eg, containing <25% whole grain by weight, including refined cold ready-to-eat breakfast cereal, white bread, white rice), and sugar-sweetened beverages (eg, soft drinks, energy drinks, fruit drinks with added sugars) can be beneficial to reduce the risk of CVD events.

id_00012.original: The effectiveness/usefulness of oxygen adminis- tered in the first aid setting for adults or children exhibiting signs or symptoms of shortness of breath, difficulty breathing, or hypoxia is unknown.
id_00012.negated: Oxygen administered in the first aid setting for adults or children exhibiting signs or symptoms of shortness of breath, difficulty breathing, or hypoxia is known to be ineffective/useless.

id_00465.original: In stable patients with acute chest pain with high clinical suspicion for PE, CTA using a PE protocol is recommended.1-4
id_00465.negated: In stable patients with acute chest pain with high clinical suspicion for PE, CTA using a PE protocol is not recommended.

id_02795.original: In patients with nonobstructive HCM with pre- served EF and symptoms of exertional angina or dyspnea, beta blockers or non-dihydropyridine cal- cium channel blockers are recommended.209,238–246
id_02795.negated: In patients with nonobstructive HCM with preserved EF and symptoms of exertional angina or dyspnea, beta blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers are not recommended.

id_02194.original: In patients undergoing TAVI, 1) contrast- enhanced coronary CT angiography (in patients with a low pretest probability for CAD) or 2) an invasive coronary angiogram is recommended to assess coronary anatomy and guide revascularization.
id_02194.negated: In patients undergoing TAVI, neither contrast-enhanced coronary CT angiography nor an invasive coronary angiogram is recommended to assess coronary anatomy and guide revascularization.

id_01649.original: In patients with HF who have had a significant clinical change, or who have received GDMT and are being considered for invasive procedures or device therapy, repeat measurement of EF, degree of structural remodeling, and valvular function are useful to inform therapeutic interven- tions.4–7
id_01649.negated: In patients with HF who have had a significant clinical change, or who have received GDMT and are being considered for invasive procedures or device therapy, repeat measurement of EF, degree of structural remodeling, and valvular function are not useful to inform therapeutic interventions.

id_01584.original: Patients who are pacemaker-dependent having surgeries above the umbilicus with anticipated EMI should have the pacemaker reprogrammed or have a magnet placed on the generator to provide an asyn­ chronous mode to avoid pacing inhibition.1,7
id_01584.negated: Patients who are pacemaker-dependent having surgeries above the umbilicus with anticipated EMI should not have the pacemaker reprogrammed or have a magnet placed on the generator, risking pacing inhibition.

id_02064.original: For patients with mixed valve disease, TTE is recommended to assess the etiology, severity, and pathophysiological impact.
id_02064.negated: TTE is not recommended for patients with mixed valve disease to assess the etiology, severity, and pathophysiological impact.

id_02109.original: In patients with suspected bioprosthetic valve thrombosis, 3D TEE or 4D CT imaging can be useful to rule out leaflet thrombosis.1–5
id_02109.negated: In patients with suspected bioprosthetic valve thrombosis, 3D TEE or 4D CT imaging should not be used to rule out leaflet thrombosis.

id_01075.original: In patients with atrial flutter and stroke or TIA, anticoagulant therapy similar to that in AF is indicated to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.427
id_01075.negated: In patients with atrial flutter and stroke or TIA, anticoagulant therapy similar to that in AF is not indicated to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.

id_01836.original: In patients with symptomatic PAD without recent revascularization, the benefit of dual antiplatelet therapy is uncertain.14,15
id_01836.negated: In patients with symptomatic PAD without recent revascularization, dual antiplatelet therapy is clearly beneficial.

id_01235.original: In patients with AF where symptoms associated with AF are uncertain, a trial of rhythm control (eg, cardio- version or pharmacological therapy) may be useful to determine what if any symptoms are attributable to AF.28–32
id_01235.negated: In patients with AF where symptoms associated with AF are uncertain, a trial of rhythm control (e.g., cardioversion or pharmacological therapy) should not be used to determine if any symptoms are attributable to AF.

id_00210.original: In patients with SIHD and multivessel CAD appropriate for either CABG or PCI, revas- cularization is reasonable to lower the risk of cardiovascular events such as spontaneous MI, unplanned urgent revascularizations, or cardiac death.1-8
id_00210.negated: In patients with SIHD and multivessel CAD appropriate for either CABG or PCI, revascularization is not recommended as it does not lower the risk of cardiovascular events such as spontaneous MI, unplanned urgent revascularizations, or cardiac death.

id_00466.original: For patients with acute chest pain and possible PE, need for further testing should be guided by pretest probability.
id_00466.negated: For patients with acute chest pain and possible PE, further testing should not be guided by pretest probability.

id_02674.original: For most patients with spontaneous supra- tentorial ICH of moderate or greater severity, the usefulness of craniotomy for hemorrhage evacuation to improve functional outcomes or mortality is uncertain.380,382,384,393,429–431
id_02674.negated: For most patients with spontaneous supra-tentorial ICH of moderate or greater severity, craniotomy for hemorrhage evacuation is clearly beneficial for improving functional outcomes and reducing mortality.

id_02516.original: In children 2 to 16 years of age with SCD and normalized mean flow velocities and no intra- cranial stenosis, transition from transfusion to hydroxyurea therapy can be considered to prevent stroke.387
id_02516.negated: In children 2 to 16 years of age with SCD and normalized mean flow velocities and no intracranial stenosis, transition from transfusion to hydroxyurea therapy should not be considered to prevent stroke.

id_02129.original: In patients with IE who have a change in clinical signs or symptoms (eg, new murmur, embolism, persistent fever, HF, abscess, or atrioventricular heart block) and in patients at high risk of complications (eg, extensive infected tissue, large vegetation on initial echocardiogram, or staphylococcal, enterococcal, or fungal infections), TTE and/or TEE are recommended for reevaluation.24,31,41–46
id_02129.negated: In patients with IE who have a change in clinical signs or symptoms (eg, new murmur, embolism, persistent fever, HF, abscess, or atrioventricular heart block) and in patients at high risk of complications (eg, extensive infected tissue, large vegetation on initial echocardiogram, or staphylococcal, enterococcal, or fungal infections), TTE and/or TEE are not recommended for reevaluation.

id_00433.original: In the evaluation of patients presenting with acute chest pain and suspected ACS for whom serial troponins are indicated to exclude myocardial injury, recommended time intervals after the initial troponin sample collection (time zero) for repeat measurements are: 1 to 3 hours for high-sensitivity troponin and 3 to 6 hours for conventional troponin assays.15-17
id_00433.negated: In the evaluation of patients presenting with acute chest pain and suspected ACS for whom serial troponins are indicated to exclude myocardial injury, it is not recommended to follow specific time intervals after the initial troponin sample collection for repeat measurements, such as 1 to 3 hours for high-sensitivity troponin and 3 to 6 hours for conventional troponin assays.

id_02609.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH in whom acute BP lowering is considered, initiating treatment within 2 hours of ICH onset and reaching target within 1 hour can be beneficial to reduce the risk of HE and improve func- tional outcome.139,140 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02609.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH in whom acute BP lowering is considered, delaying treatment beyond 2 hours of ICH onset and not reaching target within 1 hour is unlikely to reduce the risk of HE or improve functional outcome.

id_01356.original: We recommend that sodium nitrite be administered for cyanide poisoning when hydroxocobalamin is unavailable.
id_01356.negated: We recommend that sodium nitrite not be administered for cyanide poisoning even when hydroxocobalamin is unavailable.

id_02352.original: In patients with AAA treated with EVAR, baseline surveillance imaging with CT is recommended at 1 month postopera- tively1,2; if there is no evidence of endoleak or sac enlargement, continued surveil- lance with duplex ultrasound at 12 months and then annually thereafter is recom- mended.1,3,4
id_02352.negated: In patients with AAA treated with EVAR, baseline surveillance imaging with CT is not recommended at 1 month postoperatively; if there is no evidence of endoleak or sac enlargement, continued surveillance with duplex ultrasound at 12 months and then annually thereafter is not recommended.

id_02036.original: In asymptomatic patients with severe primary MR and LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF ≤60%, LVESD ≥40 mm) (Stage C2), mitral valve surgery is recommended.3–10
id_02036.negated: In asymptomatic patients with severe primary MR and LV systolic dysfunction (LVEF ≤60%, LVESD ≥40 mm) (Stage C2), mitral valve surgery is not recommended.

id_00397.original: In patients with ACS, an assessment of LVEF is recommended prior to hospital discharge to guide therapy and for risk stratification.1–3
id_00397.negated: In patients with ACS, an assessment of LVEF is not recommended prior to hospital discharge for guiding therapy or risk stratification.

id_02832.original: For pregnant women with HCM, care should be coordinated between their cardiologist and an obstetrician. For patients with HCM who are deemed high risk, consultation is advised with an expert in maternal-fetal medicine.
id_02832.negated: Pregnant women with HCM should not have their care coordinated between their cardiologist and an obstetrician. High-risk HCM patients should avoid consulting with an expert in maternal-fetal medicine.

id_02515.original: In children 2 to 16 years of age with SCD whose TCD velocities revert to normal, continued transfu- sion therapy can be beneficial to reduce the risk of stroke.384
id_02515.negated: In children 2 to 16 years of age with SCD whose TCD velocities revert to normal, discontinuing transfusion therapy can be beneficial to reduce the risk of stroke.

id_00145.original: Thermal burns should be cooled immediately, preferably with clean running water.
id_00145.negated: Thermal burns should not be cooled immediately, and using clean running water should be avoided.

id_00275.original: In patients with significant calcification of the aorta, the use of techniques to avoid aortic manipulation (off-pump techniques or beating heart) is reasonable to decrease the incidence of perioperative stroke when performed by experienced surgeons.1,2
id_00275.negated: In patients with significant calcification of the aorta, it is not reasonable to use techniques to avoid aortic manipulation (off-pump techniques or beating heart) to decrease the incidence of perioperative stroke, even when performed by experienced surgeons.

id_02385.original: In patients with type B IMH who require repair of the distal aortic arch or descending tho- racic aorta (zones 2-5) and have unfavorable anatomy for endovascular repair, open surgical repair is reasonable.2,3
id_02385.negated: In patients with type B IMH who require repair of the distal aortic arch or descending thoracic aorta (zones 2-5) and have unfavorable anatomy for endovascular repair, open surgical repair is not reasonable.

id_02544.original: In men 45 to 80 years of age with confirmed hypogonadism who are considering testosterone therapy, initiation or continuation of testosterone replacement therapy is reasonable and does not increase the risk of stroke.704–706
id_02544.negated: In men 45 to 80 years of age with confirmed hypogonadism who are considering testosterone therapy, initiation or continuation of testosterone replacement therapy is unreasonable and increases the risk of stroke.

id_00690.original: In patients with HCM, assessment for symptoms of sleep-disordered breathing is recommended, and, if present, referral to a sleep medicine specialist for evaluation and treatment is recommended.5–8
id_00690.negated: In patients with HCM, assessment for symptoms of sleep-disordered breathing is not recommended, and, if present, referral to a sleep medicine specialist for evaluation and treatment is not recommended.

id_02316.original: In patients with descending TAA undergoing TEVAR in whom celiac artery coverage is being considered, it is reasonable to first con- firm adequate collateralization.1
id_02316.negated: In patients with descending TAA undergoing TEVAR in whom celiac artery coverage is being considered, it is not necessary to confirm adequate collateralization first.

id_01715.original: In patients with nonischemic DCM or ischemic heart disease at least 40 days post-MI with LVEF ≤35% and NYHA class II or III symp- toms on chronic GDMT, who have reasonable expectation of meaningful survival for >1 year, ICD therapy is recommended for primary pre- vention of SCD to reduce total mortality.1–9 Value Statement: High Value (A)
id_01715.negated: In patients with nonischemic DCM or ischemic heart disease at least 40 days post-MI with LVEF ≤35% and NYHA class II or III symptoms on chronic GDMT, who have reasonable expectation of meaningful survival for >1 year, ICD therapy is not recommended for primary prevention of SCD to reduce total mortality.

id_01393.original: It may be reasonable to use Vaughan-Williams class Ib antidysrhythmics (eg, lidocaine) to treat life-threatening cardiotoxicity from class Ia or Ic sodium channel blockers.
id_01393.negated: It is not reasonable to use Vaughan-Williams class Ib antidysrhythmics (e.g., lidocaine) to treat life-threatening cardiotoxicity from class Ia or Ic sodium channel blockers.

id_00117.original: It is reasonable for individuals with ocular exposure to industrial chemicals to adhere to local guidelines or recommendations from a poison center. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00117.negated: It is unreasonable for individuals with ocular exposure to industrial chemicals to adhere to local guidelines or recommendations from a poison center.

id_01906.original: For patients with CLTI, retrospective assessment of institutional outcomes (including amputation) with objective limb threat classification tools can be useful for quality improvement.
id_01906.negated: For patients with CLTI, retrospective assessment of institutional outcomes (including amputation) with objective limb threat classification tools is not useful for quality improvement.

id_01170.original: In patients with AF, use of clinical care pathways, such as nurse-led AF clinics, is reasonable to promote comprehensive, team-based care and to enhance adherence to evidence-based therapies for AF and associated conditions.4–6
id_01170.negated: In patients with AF, avoiding the use of clinical care pathways, such as nurse-led AF clinics, is reasonable, as it does not promote comprehensive, team-based care or enhance adherence to evidence-based therapies for AF and associated conditions.

id_00877.original: In patients with aSAH without depres- sion, fluoxetine therapy is not effective to enhance poststroke functional sta- tus.449–452
id_00877.negated: In patients with aSAH without depression, fluoxetine therapy is effective to enhance poststroke functional status.

id_02065.original: In patients with ambiguous symptoms that are suspected to be attributable to mixed mitral valve disease, further assessment of filling pressure by using biomarkers or invasive hemodynamic measurements at rest or with exercise is reasonable.
id_02065.negated: In patients with ambiguous symptoms suspected to be due to mixed mitral valve disease, it is unreasonable to assess filling pressure using biomarkers or invasive hemodynamic measurements at rest or with exercise.
