id_01905.original: In patients with CLTI undergoing minor amputation (ie, inframalleolar level), a customized program of follow-up care that can include local wound care, pressure offloading, serial evaluation of foot biome- chanics, and use of therapeutic footwear is recommended to prevent wound recurrence.
id_01905.negated: In patients with CLTI undergoing minor amputation (ie, inframalleolar level), it is not recommended to implement a customized program of follow-up care, including local wound care, pressure offloading, serial evaluation of foot biomechanics, and use of therapeutic footwear, as these measures are unnecessary for preventing wound recurrence.

id_01077.original: In patients with stroke at high risk of hemor- rhagic conversion in the setting of AF, it is reasonable to delay initiation of oral antico- agulation beyond 14 days to reduce the risk of ICH.428–431
id_01077.negated: In patients with stroke at high risk of hemorrhagic conversion in the setting of AF, it is reasonable to initiate oral anticoagulation within 14 days, increasing the risk of ICH.

id_01105.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and Fontan palliation, anticoagulation with warfarin is recommended to reduce the risk of recur- rent stroke or TIA.572,573
id_01105.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and Fontan palliation, anticoagulation with warfarin is not recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.

id_01650.original: In patients for whom echocardiography is inadequate, alternative imaging (eg, cardiac magnetic resonance [CMR], cardiac computed tomography [CT], radionuclide imaging) is rec- ommended for assessment of LVEF.8–15
id_01650.negated: In patients for whom echocardiography is inadequate, alternative imaging (e.g., cardiac magnetic resonance [CMR], cardiac computed tomography [CT], radionuclide imaging) is not recommended for assessment of LVEF.

id_00014.original: A physical examination and history should be the primary assessment methods for first aid provid- ers to evaluate an ill or injured person.
id_00014.negated: A physical examination and history should not be the primary assessment methods for first aid providers to evaluate an ill or injured person.

id_01357.original: In addition to administering hydroxocobalamin or sodium nitrite, it is reasonable to administer sodium thiosulfate for cyanide poisoning.
id_01357.negated: Do not administer sodium thiosulfate for cyanide poisoning, even if hydroxocobalamin or sodium nitrite is given.

id_01104.original: In patients 18 to 60 years of age with a nonlacunar ischemic stroke of undetermined cause despite a thorough evaluation and a PFO, the comparative benefit of closure with a transcatheter device versus warfarin is unknown.554 *In the evidence, each study defines high-risk anatomic features in a different way.
id_01104.negated: In patients 18 to 60 years of age with a nonlacunar ischemic stroke of undetermined cause despite a thorough evaluation and a PFO, the comparative benefit of closure with a transcatheter device versus warfarin is well-established.

id_02386.original: In patients with uncomplicated type B IMH and high-risk imaging features (Table 30), intervention may be reasonable.13-16
id_02386.negated: In patients with uncomplicated type B IMH and high-risk imaging features, intervention should not be considered.

id_02675.original: In patients with supratentorial ICH who are deteriorating, craniotomy for hematoma evacu- ation might be considered as a lifesaving measure.382,384,429,432
id_02675.negated: In patients with supratentorial ICH who are deteriorating, craniotomy for hematoma evacuation should not be considered as a lifesaving measure.

id_00597.original: In patients with HCM for whom it is unclear if their functional capacity has declined, exercise stress testing may be considered every 2 to 3 years (Figure 1).
id_00597.negated: In patients with HCM for whom it is unclear if their functional capacity has declined, exercise stress testing should not be considered every 2 to 3 years.

id_02545.original: In patients with left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction ≤35%–40%) and no evidence of AF or left ventricular thrombus, anticoagulation is not indicated to prevent stroke and is associ- ated with a higher bleeding risk.706,708–711
id_02545.negated: In patients with left ventricular systolic dysfunction (ejection fraction ≤35%–40%) and no evidence of AF or left ventricular thrombus, anticoagulation is indicated to prevent stroke and is associated with a lower bleeding risk.

id_00211.original: In patients with refractory angina despite medical therapy and with significant coronary artery stenoses amenable to revascularization, revascularization is recommended to improve symptoms.1-6
id_00211.negated: In patients with refractory angina despite medical therapy and with significant coronary artery stenoses amenable to revascularization, revascularization is not recommended to improve symptoms.

id_00118.original: Direct manual pressure should be applied to achieve initial control of external bleeding.
id_00118.negated: Direct manual pressure should not be applied to achieve initial control of external bleeding.

id_01837.original: In patients with symptomatic PAD, the benefit of vorapaxar added to existing antiplatelet therapy is uncertain.16
id_01837.negated: In patients with symptomatic PAD, the benefit of vorapaxar added to existing antiplatelet therapy is certain.

id_02195.original: In patients undergoing TAVI with significant left main or proximal CAD with or without angina, revascularization by PCI before TAVI is reasonable.1,2
id_02195.negated: In patients undergoing TAVI with significant left main or proximal CAD with or without angina, revascularization by PCI before TAVI is not reasonable.

id_01236.original: In patients with AF, rhythm-control strategies may be useful to reduce the likelihood of development of dementia or worsening cardiac structural abnormali- ties.33–45
id_01236.negated: In patients with AF, rhythm-control strategies are not useful in reducing the likelihood of developing dementia or worsening cardiac structural abnormalities.

id_01426.original: In patients with CCD, the use of nonprescription or dietary supplements, including omega-3 fatty acid, vitamins C, D, E, beta-carotene, and calcium, is not beneficial to reduce the risk of acute CVD events.11–22 *Modified from the 2019 ACC/AHA Guideline on the Primary Prevention of Cardiovascular Disease.23
id_01426.negated: In patients with CCD, the use of nonprescription or dietary supplements, including omega-3 fatty acid, vitamins C, D, E, beta-carotene, and calcium, is beneficial to reduce the risk of acute CVD events.

id_02797.original: In patients with nonobstructive HCM with preserved EF, the usefulness of angiotensin- converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers in the treatment of symptoms (angina and dyspnea) is not well established.247
id_02797.negated: In patients with nonobstructive HCM with preserved EF, the usefulness of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers in the treatment of symptoms (angina and dyspnea) is well established.

id_00146.original: Preadolescent children with thermal burns being actively cooled with running water should be monitored for signs or symptoms of hypothermia.
id_00146.negated: Preadolescent children with thermal burns being actively cooled with running water should not be monitored for signs or symptoms of hypothermia.

id_01873.original: In patients with asymptomatic PAD, it is reasonable to perform revascularization procedures (endovas- cular or surgical) to reconstruct diseased arteries if needed for the safety, feasibility, or effectiveness of other procedures (eg, transfemoral aortic valve replacement, mechanical circulatory support, endovascular aortic aneurysm repair).1–8
id_01873.negated: In patients with asymptomatic PAD, it is unreasonable to perform revascularization procedures (endovascular or surgical) to reconstruct diseased arteries, even if needed for the safety, feasibility, or effectiveness of other procedures (e.g., transfemoral aortic valve replacement, mechanical circulatory support, endovascular aortic aneurysm repair).

id_00598.original: In patients with HCM, evaluation of familial inheritance, including a 3-generation family history, is recommended as part of the initial assessment.1–7
id_00598.negated: In patients with HCM, evaluation of familial inheritance, including a 3-generation family history, is not recommended as part of the initial assessment.

id_02353.original: In patients with AAA treated with EVAR who are undergoing annual surveillance imaging duplex ultrasound, additional cross-sectional imaging with CT or MRI of the abdomen and pelvis every 5 years postoperatively is reason- able.5-8
id_02353.negated: In patients with AAA treated with EVAR who are undergoing annual surveillance imaging duplex ultrasound, additional cross-sectional imaging with CT or MRI of the abdomen and pelvis every 5 years postoperatively is not reasonable.

id_00467.original: In patients with acute chest pain and myocardial injury who have nonobstructive coronary arteries on anatomic testing, CMR with gadolinium contrast is effective to distinguish myopericarditis from other causes, including myocardial infarction and nonobstructive coronary arteries (MINOCA).1-6
id_00467.negated: In patients with acute chest pain and myocardial injury who have nonobstructive coronary arteries on anatomic testing, CMR with gadolinium contrast is ineffective in distinguishing myopericarditis from other causes, including myocardial infarction and nonobstructive coronary arteries (MINOCA).

id_02610.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH of mild to moderate severity presenting with SBP between 150 and 220 mm Hg, acute lower- ing of SBP to a target of 140 mm Hg with the goal of maintaining in the range of 130 to 150 mm Hg is safe and may be reasonable for improving functional outcomes.138,141–147
id_02610.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH of mild to moderate severity presenting with SBP between 150 and 220 mm Hg, acute lowering of SBP to a target of 140 mm Hg with the goal of maintaining in the range of 130 to 150 mm Hg is unsafe and may not be reasonable for improving functional outcomes.

id_01358.original: It is reasonable to administer 100% oxygen for cyanide poisoning. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01358.negated: It is unreasonable to administer 100% oxygen for cyanide poisoning.

id_00625.original: In select adult patients with HCM and without major SCD risk factors after clinical assessment, or in whom the decision to proceed with ICD placement remains otherwise uncertain, ICD may be considered in patients with extensive LGE by contrast-enhanced CMR imaging or NSVT present on ambulatory moni- toring (Figure 3, Table 8).2,3,16,19,31–33
id_00625.negated: ICD should not be considered in select adult patients with HCM who have extensive LGE by contrast-enhanced CMR imaging or NSVT present on ambulatory monitoring, even if they lack major SCD risk factors or if the decision to proceed with ICD placement is uncertain.

id_02833.original: For women with clinically stable HCM who wish to become pregnant, it is reasonable to advise that pregnancy is generally safe as part of a shared discussion regarding potential maternal and fetal risks, and initiation of guideline-directed therapy.309–312
id_02833.negated: For women with clinically stable HCM who wish to become pregnant, it is unreasonable to advise that pregnancy is generally safe, and it should not be part of a shared discussion regarding potential maternal and fetal risks, nor should guideline-directed therapy be initiated.

id_01585.original: Pacemaker-dependent patients with a transvenous ICD undergoing surgery above the umbilicus with anticipated EMI should have the device repro­ grammed*; if the patient is not pacemaker- dependent, then either reprogramming or a magnet placed on the generator can be used to inhibit tachytherapies or inappropriate shocks.8,9
id_01585.negated: Pacemaker-dependent patients with a transvenous ICD undergoing surgery above the umbilicus with anticipated EMI should not have the device reprogrammed; if the patient is not pacemaker-dependent, then neither reprogramming nor a magnet placed on the generator should be used to inhibit tachytherapies or inappropriate shocks.

id_00276.original: In patients with significant pulmonary disease, off-pump surgery may be reasonable to reduce perioperative risk when performed by experienced surgeons.2-6
id_00276.negated: In patients with significant pulmonary disease, off-pump surgery should not be considered to reduce perioperative risk, even when performed by experienced surgeons.

id_00626.original: In pediatric patients with HCM, it can be useful to consider additional factors such as extensive LGE on contrast-enhanced CMR imaging and systolic dysfunction in risk stratification for ICD shared decision-making (Figure 3, Table 8).34,35
id_00626.negated: In pediatric patients with HCM, it is not useful to consider additional factors such as extensive LGE on contrast-enhanced CMR imaging and systolic dysfunction in risk stratification for ICD shared decision-making.

id_01716.original: In patients at least 40 days post-MI with LVEF ≤30% and NYHA class I symptoms while receiving GDMT, who have reasonable expec- tation of meaningful survival for >1 year, ICD therapy is recommended for primary prevention of SCD to reduce total mortality.6
id_01716.negated: In patients at least 40 days post-MI with LVEF ≤30% and NYHA class I symptoms while receiving GDMT, who have reasonable expectation of meaningful survival for >1 year, ICD therapy is not recommended for primary prevention of SCD to reduce total mortality.

id_02130.original: In patients undergoing valve surgery for IE, intraoperative TEE is recommended.47–50
id_02130.negated: In patients undergoing valve surgery for IE, intraoperative TEE is not recommended.

id_01557.original: In patients undergoing NCS, maintaining an intraop­ erative mean arterial pressure (MAP) ≥60 to 65 mm Hg or SBP ≥90 mm Hg is recommended to reduce the risk of myocardial injury.3–9 Postoperative Blood Pressure Management
id_01557.negated: In patients undergoing NCS, allowing an intraoperative mean arterial pressure (MAP) <60 to 65 mm Hg or SBP <90 mm Hg is recommended, increasing the risk of myocardial injury.

id_00878.original: In adult patients with aSAH, screening and intervention for depression, anxiety, and sexual dysfunction are recommended to improve long-term outcomes.461–465
id_00878.negated: In adult patients with aSAH, screening and intervention for depression, anxiety, and sexual dysfunction are not recommended to improve long-term outcomes.

id_02517.original: In children 2 to 16 years of age with SCD at high risk for stroke (TCD mean flow velocities ≥200 cm/s) but without intracranial stenosis who are unable to continue or cannot be treated with periodic red cell transfusion, hydroxyurea or bone marrow transplantation may be reasonable to prevent stroke.387–390
id_02517.negated: In children 2 to 16 years of age with SCD at high risk for stroke (TCD mean flow velocities ≥200 cm/s) but without intracranial stenosis who are unable to continue or cannot be treated with periodic red cell transfusion, hydroxyurea or bone marrow transplantation should not be considered to prevent stroke.

id_01427.original: In patients with CCD, targeted discussions and screening for mental health is reasonable for clini- cians to assess and to refer for additional mental health evaluation and management.1–4
id_01427.negated: In patients with CCD, it is unreasonable for clinicians to engage in targeted discussions and screening for mental health, and they should not refer for additional mental health evaluation and management.

id_01394.original: It may be reasonable to use intravenous lipid emulsion to treat life-threatening sodium channel blocker poisoning refractory to other treatment modalities.
id_01394.negated: It is not advisable to use intravenous lipid emulsion to treat life-threatening sodium channel blocker poisoning refractory to other treatment modalities.

id_01171.original: Patients with AF should be evaluated for their annual risk of thromboembolic events using a validated clinical risk score, such as CHA2DS2-VASc.1–4
id_01171.negated: Patients with AF should not be evaluated for their annual risk of thromboembolic events using a validated clinical risk score, such as CHA2DS2-VASc.

id_02387.original: In patients with PAU of the aorta with rupture, urgent repair is recommended.1-3
id_02387.negated: In patients with PAU of the aorta with rupture, urgent repair is not recommended.

id_00277.original: In patients undergoing CABG, an intraopera- tive continuous insulin infusion should be initiated to maintain serum glucose level <180 mg/dL to reduce sternal wound infection.1-3
id_00277.negated: In patients undergoing CABG, an intraoperative continuous insulin infusion should not be initiated to maintain serum glucose level <180 mg/dL, as it does not reduce sternal wound infection.

id_01237.original: In patients with AF duration of ≥48 hours, a
id_01237.negated: In patients with AF duration of <48 hours, a

id_00398.original: Patients with ACS should be referred to an outpatient CR program prior to hospital discharge to reduce death, MI, hospital readmis- sions, and improve functional status and QOL.1–4
id_00398.negated: Patients with ACS should not be referred to an outpatient CR program prior to hospital discharge, as it does not reduce death, MI, hospital readmissions, nor improve functional status and QOL.

id_02317.original: In patients with ruptured descending TAA who are anatomic candidates for endovascular repair, TEVAR is recommended over open repair because of decreased perioperative death and morbidity.1-5
id_02317.negated: In patients with ruptured descending TAA who are anatomic candidates for endovascular repair, open repair is recommended over TEVAR despite increased perioperative death and morbidity.

id_01586.original: Patients who have a pacemaker or ICD repro­ grammed to asynchronous pacing or have tachy­ therapies programmed off before surgery should have device functioning restored in the postoperative period before hospital discharge.10
id_01586.negated: Patients who have a pacemaker or ICD reprogrammed to asynchronous pacing or have tachytherapies programmed off before surgery should not have device functioning restored in the postoperative period before hospital discharge.

id_02037.original: In patients with severe primary MR for whom surgery is indicated, mitral valve repair is recommended in preference to mitral valve replacement when the anatomic cause of MR is degenerative disease, if a successful and durable repair is possible.11–15
id_02037.negated: In patients with severe primary MR for whom surgery is indicated, mitral valve replacement is recommended in preference to mitral valve repair when the anatomic cause of MR is degenerative disease, even if a successful and durable repair is possible.

id_00212.original: In patients with angina but no anatomic or physiological criteria for revascularization, nei- ther CABG nor PCI should be performed.7,8
id_00212.negated: In patients with angina but no anatomic or physiological criteria for revascularization, either CABG or PCI should be performed.

id_00434.original: To standardize the detection and differentiation of myocardial injury in patients presenting with acute chest pain and suspected ACS, institutions should implement a CDP that includes a protocol for troponin sampling based on their particular assay.18,19
id_00434.negated: Institutions should avoid implementing a CDP with a protocol for troponin sampling based on their particular assay to standardize the detection and differentiation of myocardial injury in patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS.

id_00468.original: In patients with acute chest pain with suspected acute myopericarditis, CMR is useful if there is diagnostic uncertainty, or to determine the presence and extent of myocardial and pericardial inflammation and fibrosis.7-12
id_00468.negated: In patients with acute chest pain with suspected acute myopericarditis, CMR is not useful if there is diagnostic uncertainty, or to determine the presence and extent of myocardial and pericardial inflammation and fibrosis.

id_02518.original: In patients with CADASIL, counseling on smok- ing cessation and treatment of hypertension and other vascular risk factors are beneficial to reduce the risk of incident stroke.407–412
id_02518.negated: In patients with CADASIL, avoiding counseling on smoking cessation and neglecting treatment of hypertension and other vascular risk factors are not beneficial to reduce the risk of incident stroke.

id_02318.original: In patients with ruptured descending TAA undergoing TEVAR, intentional coverage of the left subclavian artery, celiac artery, or both may be considered to increase the landing zone for endovascular repair.5-7
id_02318.negated: In patients with ruptured descending TAA undergoing TEVAR, intentional coverage of the left subclavian artery, celiac artery, or both should not be considered to increase the landing zone for endovascular repair.

id_02546.original: In patients with diabetes or other common vascular risk factors and no prior stroke, the use of aspirin to prevent a first stroke is not well established.727–731
id_02546.negated: In patients with diabetes or other common vascular risk factors and no prior stroke, the use of aspirin to prevent a first stroke is well established.

id_02196.original: In patients with significant AS and significant CAD (luminal reduction >70% diameter, fractional flow reserve <0.8, instantaneous wave-free ratio <0.89) consisting of complex bifurcation left main and/or multivessel CAD with a SYNTAX (Synergy Between Percutaneous Coronary Intervention With Taxus and Cardiac Surgery) score >33, SAVR and CABG are reasonable and preferred over TAVI and PCI.3,4
id_02196.negated: In patients with significant AS and significant CAD (luminal reduction >70% diameter, fractional flow reserve <0.8, instantaneous wave-free ratio <0.89) consisting of complex bifurcation left main and/or multivessel CAD with a SYNTAX score >33, TAVI and PCI are reasonable and preferred over SAVR and CABG.

id_02354.original: In patients with AAA treated with EVAR and abnormal findings (Table 21) on any surveil- lance duplex ultrasound, additional cross-sec- tional imaging with CT or MRI is reasonable.9
id_02354.negated: In patients with AAA treated with EVAR and abnormal findings on any surveillance duplex ultrasound, additional cross-sectional imaging with CT or MRI is not reasonable.

id_02611.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH presenting with large or severe ICH or those requir- ing surgical decompression, the safety and efficacy of intensive BP lowering are not well established.148
id_02611.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH presenting with large or severe ICH or those requiring surgical decompression, the safety and efficacy of intensive BP lowering are well established.

id_01651.original: In patients with HF or cardiomyopathy, CMR can be useful for diagnosis or manage- ment.16–23
id_01651.negated: In patients with HF or cardiomyopathy, CMR should not be used for diagnosis or management.

id_01558.original: In patients undergoing NCS, treatment of hypoten­ sion (MAP <60-65 or SBP <90 mm Hg) in the postoperative period is recommended to limit the risk of cardiovascular, cerebrovascular, renal events, and mortality.6
id_01558.negated: In patients undergoing NCS, it is not recommended to treat hypotension (MAP <60-65 or SBP <90 mm Hg) in the postoperative period, despite the risk of cardiovascular, cerebrovascular, renal events, and mortality.

id_01907.original: Patients with ALI should be evaluated on an emergency basis by a clinician with sufficient experience to assess limb viability and implement appropriate therapy.
id_01907.negated: Patients with ALI should not be evaluated on an emergency basis by a clinician with sufficient experience to assess limb viability and implement appropriate therapy.

id_02543.original: In transgender women and gender-diverse indi- viduals taking estrogens for gender affirmation, evaluation and modification of risk factors can be beneficial to reduce the risk of stroke.700–703
id_02543.negated: In transgender women and gender-diverse individuals taking estrogens for gender affirmation, evaluation and modification of risk factors are not beneficial to reduce the risk of stroke.

id_00399.original: In patients with ACS, a home-based CR program is a reasonable alternative to a center-based CR program to improve functional status and QOL.5–9
id_00399.negated: In patients with ACS, a home-based CR program is not a reasonable alternative to a center-based CR program to improve functional status and QOL.

id_01874.original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication who are being considered for revascularization, potential benefits with respect to QOL, walking performance, and overall functional status should be weighed against the risks and durability of intervention and possible need for repeated procedures.1–6
id_01874.negated: In patients with functionally limiting claudication who are being considered for revascularization, potential benefits with respect to QOL, walking performance, and overall functional status should not be weighed against the risks and durability of intervention and possible need for repeated procedures.

id_02066.original: In symptomatic patients with combined AS and AR and a peak transvalvular jet velocity of at least 4.0 m/s or a mean transvalvular gradient of at least 40 mm Hg, AVR is recommended.1,2
id_02066.negated: In symptomatic patients with combined AS and AR and a peak transvalvular jet velocity of at least 4.0 m/s or a mean transvalvular gradient of at least 40 mm Hg, AVR is not recommended.

id_01428.original: In patients with CCD, treatment for mental health conditions with either pharmacologic or nonphar- macologic therapies, or both, is reasonable to improve cardiovascular outcomes.2,4–6
id_01428.negated: In patients with CCD, avoiding treatment for mental health conditions with either pharmacologic or nonpharmacologic therapies, or both, is reasonable to improve cardiovascular outcomes.

id_01078.original: In patients with TIA in the setting of nonvalvu- lar AF, it is reasonable to initiate anticoagu- lation immediately after the index event to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.
id_01078.negated: In patients with TIA in the setting of nonvalvular AF, it is not advisable to initiate anticoagulation immediately after the index event to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.

id_01717.original: For patients who have LVEF ≤35%, sinus rhythm, left bundle branch block (LBBB) with a QRS duration ≥150 ms, and NYHA class II, III, or ambulatory IV symptoms on GDMT, CRT is indicated to reduce total mortality, reduce hospi- talizations, and improve symptoms and QOL.16–21 Value Statement: High Value (B-NR)
id_01717.negated: For patients who have LVEF ≤35%, sinus rhythm, left bundle branch block (LBBB) with a QRS duration ≥150 ms, and NYHA class II, III, or ambulatory IV symptoms on GDMT, CRT is not indicated to reduce total mortality, reduce hospitalizations, or improve symptoms and QOL.

id_02834.original: In pregnant women with HCM, cardioversion for new or recurrent AF, particularly if symp- tomatic, is reasonable.302,313
id_02834.negated: In pregnant women with HCM, cardioversion for new or recurrent AF, particularly if symptomatic, is not recommended.

id_01838.original: After surgical revascularization for PAD with a prosthetic graft, dual antiplatelet therapy with a P2Y12 antagonist and low-dose aspirin may be reasonable for at least 1 month.17
id_01838.negated: Dual antiplatelet therapy with a P2Y12 antagonist and low-dose aspirin should not be considered for at least 1 month after surgical revascularization for PAD with a prosthetic graft.

id_00147.original: It may be reasonable to cool thermal burns for 5 to 20 minutes.
id_00147.negated: It may be unreasonable to cool thermal burns for 5 to 20 minutes.

id_02676.original: For patients with cerebellar ICH who are deteriorating neurologically, have brainstem compression and/or hydrocephalus from ventricular obstruction, or have cerebellar ICH volume ≥15 mL, immediate surgical removal of the hemorrhage with or without EVD is recom- mended in preference to medical management alone to reduce mortality.442–444
id_02676.negated: For patients with cerebellar ICH who are deteriorating neurologically, have brainstem compression and/or hydrocephalus from ventricular obstruction, or have cerebellar ICH volume ≥15 mL, medical management alone is recommended in preference to immediate surgical removal of the hemorrhage with or without EVD, despite the potential increase in mortality.

id_00015.original: It is reasonable for first aid providers to use pulse oximetry results in the context of a complete assessment and to be aware of the limitations of pulse oximetry before acting on any results. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00015.negated: It is unreasonable for first aid providers to use pulse oximetry results in the context of a complete assessment or to be aware of the limitations of pulse oximetry before acting on any results.

id_02038.original: In asymptomatic patients with severe primary MR and normal LV systolic function (LVEF ≥60% and LVESD ≤40 mm) (Stage C1), mitral valve repair is reasonable when the likelihood of a successful and durable repair without residual MR is >95% with an expected mortality rate of <1%, when it can be performed at a Primary or Comprehensive Valve Center.4,13,16
id_02038.negated: In asymptomatic patients with severe primary MR and normal LV systolic function (LVEF ≥60% and LVESD ≤40 mm) (Stage C1), mitral valve repair is not reasonable when the likelihood of a successful and durable repair without residual MR is >95% with an expected mortality rate of <1%, even when it can be performed at a Primary or Comprehensive Valve Center.

id_02197.original: In patients with symptoms of angina, objective evidence of ischemia, decreased LV systolic function, history of CAD, or coronary risk factors (including men >40 years of age and postmenopausal women), invasive coronary angiography is indicated before valve intervention.1–8
id_02197.negated: In patients with symptoms of angina, objective evidence of ischemia, decreased LV systolic function, history of CAD, or coronary risk factors (including men >40 years of age and postmenopausal women), invasive coronary angiography is not indicated before valve intervention.

id_00119.original: A hemostatic dressing can be useful as adjunctive therapy to improve the effectiveness of direct manual pressure.
id_00119.negated: A hemostatic dressing should not be used as adjunctive therapy because it does not improve the effectiveness of direct manual pressure.

id_02388.original: In patients with PAU of the ascending aorta with associated IMH, urgent repair is recom- mended.1-3
id_02388.negated: In patients with PAU of the ascending aorta with associated IMH, urgent repair is not recommended.

id_02798.original: In highly selected patients with apical HCM with severe dyspnea or angina (NYHA class III or class IV) despite maximal medical therapy, and with preserved EF and small LV cavity size (LV end-diastolic volume <50 mL/m2 and LV stroke volume <30 mL/m2), apical myectomy by expe- rienced surgeons at comprehensive centers may be considered to reduce symptoms.248
id_02798.negated: In patients with apical HCM who do not have severe dyspnea or angina, or who have reduced EF and large LV cavity size, apical myectomy should be considered to reduce symptoms.

id_01107.original: In patients with stroke or TIA found to have a left-sided cardiac tumor, resection of the tumor can be beneficial to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.586–588
id_01107.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA found to have a left-sided cardiac tumor, avoiding resection of the tumor is advisable as it does not reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.

id_00879.original: In patients with aSAH, it is reasonable to choose the MoCA over the MMSE to identify cognitive impairment.438,466,467
id_00879.negated: In patients with aSAH, it is not reasonable to choose the MoCA over the MMSE to identify cognitive impairment.

id_02131.original: In patients being considered for an early change to oral antibiotic therapy for the treatment of stable IE, a baseline TEE before switching to oral therapy and a repeat TEE
id_02131.negated: In patients being considered for an early change to oral antibiotic therapy for the treatment of stable IE, do not perform a baseline TEE before switching to oral therapy and avoid a repeat TEE.

id_01395.original: We recommend sedation for severe agitation from sympathomimetic poisoning.
id_01395.negated: We do not recommend sedation for severe agitation from sympathomimetic poisoning.

id_01908.original: In patients with suspected ALI, the initial clinical evaluation should rapidly assess limb viability and potential for salvage and can be achieved without noninvasive imaging (ie, duplex ultrasound, CTA, or MRA).1–6
id_01908.negated: In patients with suspected ALI, the initial clinical evaluation should not rapidly assess limb viability and potential for salvage and must rely on noninvasive imaging (ie, duplex ultrasound, CTA, or MRA).

id_02132.original: In patients with Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia without a known source, TEE is reasonable to diagnose possible IE.11,36,52–56
id_02132.negated: In patients with Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia without a known source, TEE is not recommended to diagnose possible IE.

id_01172.original: Patients with AF should be evaluated for factors that specifically indicate a higher risk of bleeding, such as previous bleeding and use of drugs that increase bleeding risk, in order to identify possible interven- tions to prevent bleeding on anticoagulation.5–7
id_01172.negated: Patients with AF should not be evaluated for factors that indicate a higher risk of bleeding, such as previous bleeding and use of drugs that increase bleeding risk, and no interventions should be identified to prevent bleeding on anticoagulation.

id_00599.original: In patients with HCM, genetic testing is beneficial to elucidate the genetic basis to facilitate the identification of family members at risk for developing HCM (cascade testing).8–11
id_00599.negated: In patients with HCM, genetic testing is not beneficial for understanding the genetic basis and does not aid in identifying family members at risk for developing HCM.

id_01106.original: In patients with cyanotic congenital heart disease and other complex lesions, ischemic stroke or TIA of presumed cardioembolic origin, therapy with warfarin is reasonable to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01106.negated: In patients with cyanotic congenital heart disease and other complex lesions, ischemic stroke or TIA of presumed cardioembolic origin, therapy with warfarin is not recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.

id_00435.original: In patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS, previous testing when available should be considered and incorporated into CDPs.20-24
id_00435.negated: In patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS, previous testing when available should be ignored and not incorporated into CDPs.

id_01359.original: We recommend administration of digoxin-specific antibody fragments (digoxin-Fab) for digoxin or digitoxin poisoning.
id_01359.negated: We do not recommend administration of digoxin-specific antibody fragments (digoxin-Fab) for digoxin or digitoxin poisoning.

id_01875.original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and an inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), revascularization is a reasonable treatment option to improve walking function and QOL.7–14
id_01875.negated: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and an inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), revascularization is not a reasonable treatment option to improve walking function and QOL.

id_00120.original: Once bleeding has been controlled, it may be reasonable to apply a pressure dressing to maintain bleeding cessation.
id_00120.negated: Once bleeding has been controlled, it may be reasonable to avoid applying a pressure dressing to maintain bleeding cessation.

id_00627.original: In patients with HCM who are receiving an ICD, either a single-chamber transvenous ICD or a subcutaneous ICD is recommended after a shared decision-making discussion that takes into consideration patient preferences, age, lifestyle, and potential need for pacing for bradycardia or VT termination.1–6
id_00627.negated: In patients with HCM who are receiving an ICD, neither a single-chamber transvenous ICD nor a subcutaneous ICD should be recommended, disregarding patient preferences, age, lifestyle, and potential need for pacing for bradycardia or VT termination.

id_02796.original: In patients with nonobstructive HCM with preserved EF, it is reasonable to add oral diuretics when exertional dyspnea persists despite the use of beta blockers or non- dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers.
id_02796.negated: In patients with nonobstructive HCM with preserved EF, it is not reasonable to add oral diuretics when exertional dyspnea persists despite the use of beta blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers.

id_02612.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH of mild to moderate severity presenting with SBP >150 mm Hg, acute lowering of SBP to <130 mm Hg is potentially harmful.146,149,150
id_02612.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH of mild to moderate severity presenting with SBP >150 mm Hg, acute lowering of SBP to <130 mm Hg is potentially beneficial.

id_01079.original: In patients with stroke or TIA in the setting of nonvalvular AF who have contraindications for lifelong anticoagulation but can tolerate at least 45 days, it may be reasonable to consider percutaneous closure of the left atrial appendage with the Watchman device to reduce the chance of recurrent stroke and bleeding.432–436
id_01079.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA in the setting of nonvalvular AF who have contraindications for lifelong anticoagulation but can tolerate at least 45 days, it is not advisable to consider percutaneous closure of the left atrial appendage with the Watchman device, as it does not reduce the chance of recurrent stroke and bleeding.

id_01238.original: In patients with AF undergoing cardioversion, thera- peutic anticoagulation should be established before cardioversion and continued for at least 4 weeks afterwards without interruption to prevent thromboembolism.2–7
id_01238.negated: In patients with AF undergoing cardioversion, therapeutic anticoagulation should not be established before cardioversion and should be discontinued immediately afterwards to prevent thromboembolism.

id_00469.original: In patients with acute chest pain and suspected myopericarditis, TTE is effective to determine the presence of ventricular wall motion abnormalities, pericardial effusion, valvular abnormalities, or restrictive physiology.
id_00469.negated: In patients with acute chest pain and suspected myopericarditis, TTE is ineffective in determining the presence of ventricular wall motion abnormalities, pericardial effusion, valvular abnormalities, or restrictive physiology.

id_01652.original: In patients with HF, an evaluation for possible ischemic heart disease can be useful to identify the cause and guide management.24–27
id_01652.negated: In patients with HF, an evaluation for possible ischemic heart disease is not useful to identify the cause or guide management.

id_01587.original: Patients with leadless pacemakers who are pacemaker-dependent having surgeries with antici­ pated EMI above the umbilicus should have their pace­ makers reprogrammed to an asynchronous mode.11
id_01587.negated: Patients with leadless pacemakers who are pacemaker-dependent having surgeries with anticipated EMI above the umbilicus should not have their pacemakers reprogrammed to an asynchronous mode.

id_02355.original: In patients with AAA treated with complex EVAR, a modified surveillance imaging plan that combines cross-sectional imaging and duplex ultrasound of target vessels is reason- able.10,11
id_02355.negated: In patients with AAA treated with complex EVAR, it is not reasonable to use a modified surveillance imaging plan that combines cross-sectional imaging and duplex ultrasound of target vessels.

id_00278.original: In patients undergoing CABG, the use of continuous intravenous insulin to achieve and maintain an early postoperative blood glucose concentration of <180 mg/dL while avoid- ing hypoglycemia is indicated to reduce the incidence of adverse events, including deep sternal wound infection.3-6
id_00278.negated: In patients undergoing CABG, the use of continuous intravenous insulin to achieve and maintain an early postoperative blood glucose concentration of <180 mg/dL while avoiding hypoglycemia is not indicated, as it does not reduce the incidence of adverse events, including deep sternal wound infection.

id_02039.original: In asymptomatic patients with severe primary MR and normal LV systolic function (LVEF >60% and LVESD <40 mm) (Stage C1) but with a progressive increase in LV size or decrease in EF on ≥3 serial imaging studies, mitral valve surgery may be considered irrespective of the probability of a successful and durable repair.16
id_02039.negated: In asymptomatic patients with severe primary MR and normal LV systolic function (LVEF >60% and LVESD <40 mm) (Stage C1) with a progressive increase in LV size or decrease in EF on ≥3 serial imaging studies, mitral valve surgery should not be considered regardless of the probability of a successful and durable repair.

id_02799.original: In asymptomatic patients with non-obstruc- tive HCM, the benefit of beta blockers or cal- cium channel blockers is not well established. 5.3. Management of Patients With HCM and Atrial Fibrillation Recommendations for Management of Atrial Fibrillation Referenced studies that support the recommendations are summarized in Online Data Supplement 16. COR LOE Recommendations
id_02799.negated: In asymptomatic patients with non-obstructive HCM, the benefit of beta blockers or calcium channel blockers is well established.

id_02547.original: In patients with established, stable coronary artery disease and a low bleeding risk, the addition of ticagrelor to aspirin beyond 12 months for a period up to 3 years may be beneficial to reduce the rate of ischemic stroke.732
id_02547.negated: In patients with established, stable coronary artery disease and a low bleeding risk, the addition of ticagrelor to aspirin beyond 12 months for a period up to 3 years may not be beneficial to reduce the rate of ischemic stroke.

id_00213.original: In patients who require revascularization for significant left main CAD with high-complexity CAD, it is recommended to choose CABG over PCI to improve survival.1,2
id_00213.negated: In patients who require revascularization for significant left main CAD with high-complexity CAD, it is recommended to choose PCI over CABG to improve survival.

id_01909.original: In patients with ALI who have a complicated history of revascularization procedures, it may be reason- able to obtain noninvasive imaging (ie, duplex ultra- sound, CTA, or MRA) before deciding to proceed with revascularization.
id_01909.negated: In patients with ALI who have a complicated history of revascularization procedures, it is not advisable to obtain noninvasive imaging (ie, duplex ultrasound, CTA, or MRA) before deciding to proceed with revascularization.

id_01718.original: For patients who have LVEF ≤35%, sinus rhythm, a non-LBBB pattern with a QRS duration ≥150 ms, and NYHA class II, III, or ambulatory class IV symptoms on GDMT, CRT can be useful to reduce total mortality, reduce hospitalizations, and improve symp- toms and QOL.16–21,28–33
id_01718.negated: For patients who have LVEF ≤35%, sinus rhythm, a non-LBBB pattern with a QRS duration ≥150 ms, and NYHA class II, III, or ambulatory class IV symptoms on GDMT, CRT is not useful to reduce total mortality, reduce hospitalizations, or improve symptoms and QOL.

id_01429.original: In patients with CCD, tobacco use should be assessed at every health care visit to facilitate identification of those who may benefit from behavioral or pharmacologic interventions.*1–3
id_01429.negated: In patients with CCD, tobacco use should not be assessed at any health care visit, hindering the identification of those who may benefit from behavioral or pharmacologic interventions.

id_01173.original: Patients with AF at intermediate annual risk of thromboembolic events by risk scores (eg, equiva- lent to CHA2DS2-VASc score of 1 in men or 2 in women), who remain uncertain about the benefit of anticoagulation, can benefit from consideration of factors that might modify their risk of stroke to help inform the decision.*
id_01173.negated: Patients with AF at intermediate annual risk of thromboembolic events by risk scores, who remain uncertain about the benefit of anticoagulation, should not consider additional factors that might modify their risk of stroke when making their decision.

id_02519.original: In adults with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiecta- sia (HHT), screening for pulmonary arteriovenous malformations (PAVMs) is reasonable to identify the need for multidisciplinary evaluation to man- age stroke risk.413–421
id_02519.negated: In adults with hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (HHT), screening for pulmonary arteriovenous malformations (PAVMs) is not recommended, as it is unnecessary for identifying the need for multidisciplinary evaluation to manage stroke risk.

id_00016.original: First aid providers should assist a person with asthma who is having difficulty breathing with the administration of their own prescribed bronchodilators as needed.
id_00016.negated: First aid providers should not assist a person with asthma who is having difficulty breathing with the administration of their own prescribed bronchodilators.

id_02677.original: In patients with supratentorial ICH who are in a coma, have large hematomas with significant midline shift, or have elevated ICP refractory to medical management, decompressive crani- ectomy with or without hematoma evacuation may be considered to reduce mortality.453–460
id_02677.negated: In patients with supratentorial ICH who are in a coma, have large hematomas with significant midline shift, or have elevated ICP refractory to medical management, decompressive craniectomy with or without hematoma evacuation should not be considered to reduce mortality.

id_01108.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA after an extracranial carotid or vertebral arterial dis- section, treatment with antithrombotic therapy for at least 3 months is indicated to prevent recurrent stroke or TIA.
id_01108.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA after an extracranial carotid or vertebral arterial dissection, treatment with antithrombotic therapy for at least 3 months is not indicated to prevent recurrent stroke or TIA.

id_02389.original: In patients with PAU of the aortic arch or descending thoracic aorta with associated IMH, urgent repair is reasonable.1-3
id_02389.negated: In patients with PAU of the aortic arch or descending thoracic aorta with associated IMH, delaying repair is reasonable.

id_02835.original: In pregnant women with HCM, general or epidural anesthesia is reasonable, with precautions to avoid hypotension.310
id_02835.negated: In pregnant women with HCM, general or epidural anesthesia is not reasonable, and precautions to avoid hypotension are unnecessary.

id_01839.original: In patients with PAD, treatment with high-intensity statin therapy is indicated, with an aim of achieving a ≥50% reduction in low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) level.1–3
id_01839.negated: In patients with PAD, treatment with high-intensity statin therapy is not indicated, and achieving a ≥50% reduction in low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) level should not be aimed for.

id_02319.original: In patients with descending TAA undergoing TEVAR, review of preoperative CTA of the iliofemoral vessels should be performed to evaluate access.1,2
id_02319.negated: In patients with descending TAA undergoing TEVAR, do not review preoperative CTA of the iliofemoral vessels to evaluate access.

id_00600.original: In patients with an atypical clinical presentation of HCM or when another genetic condition is suspected to be the cause, a workup including genetic testing for HCM and other genetic causes of unexplained cardiac hypertrophy (“HCM phenocopies”) is recommended.12–14
id_00600.negated: In patients with an atypical clinical presentation of HCM or when another genetic condition is suspected to be the cause, genetic testing for HCM and other genetic causes of unexplained cardiac hypertrophy (“HCM phenocopies”) should not be included in the workup.

id_02067.original: In asymptomatic patients with combined AS and AR who have a jet velocity of ≥4.0 m/s with an LVEF <50%, SAVR is recommended.1,2
id_02067.negated: In asymptomatic patients with combined AS and AR who have a jet velocity of ≥4.0 m/s with an LVEF <50%, SAVR is not recommended.

id_02198.original: In patients with chronic severe secondary MR, invasive coronary angiography should be performed as part of the evaluation.9–11
id_02198.negated: In patients with chronic severe secondary MR, invasive coronary angiography should not be performed as part of the evaluation.

id_01396.original: We recommend rapid external cooling for life- threatening hyperthermia from sympathomimetic poisoning.
id_01396.negated: We do not recommend rapid external cooling for life-threatening hyperthermia from sympathomimetic poisoning.

id_02613.original: In patients with anticoagulant-associated spontaneous ICH, anticoagulation should be discontinued immediately and rapid reversal of anticoagulation should be performed as soon as possible after diagnosis of spontaneous ICH to improve survival.162 VKAs
id_02613.negated: In patients with anticoagulant-associated spontaneous ICH, anticoagulation should be continued, and reversal of anticoagulation should not be performed after diagnosis of spontaneous ICH.

id_02133.original: In patients with a prosthetic valve in the presence of persistent fever without bacteremia or a new murmur, a TEE is reasonable to aid in the diagnosis of IE.57–60
id_02133.negated: In patients with a prosthetic valve in the presence of persistent fever without bacteremia or a new murmur, a TEE is not reasonable to aid in the diagnosis of IE.

id_00628.original: In patients with HCM who are receiving a transvenous ICD, single-coil ICD leads are recommended in preference to dual-coil leads, if defibrillation threshold is deemed adequate.7–9
id_00628.negated: In patients with HCM who are receiving a transvenous ICD, dual-coil ICD leads are recommended in preference to single-coil leads, regardless of defibrillation threshold adequacy.

id_00400.original: In patients with ACS who are not at high bleeding risk, DAPT with aspirin and an oral P2Y12 inhibi- tor should be administered for at least 1 year to reduce MACE.1–6 Bleeding Reduction Strategies
id_00400.negated: In patients with ACS who are not at high bleeding risk, DAPT with aspirin and an oral P2Y12 inhibitor should not be administered for at least 1 year to reduce MACE.

id_01080.original: In patients with stroke at low risk for hemor- rhagic conversion in the setting of AF, it may be reasonable to initiate anticoagulation 2 to 14 days after the index event to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.428,429,437
id_01080.negated: In patients with stroke at low risk for hemorrhagic conversion in the setting of AF, it is not advisable to initiate anticoagulation 2 to 14 days after the index event to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.

id_00470.original: In patients with acute chest pain with suspected acute pericarditis, noncontrast or contrast cardiac CT scanning may be reasonable to determine the presence and degree of pericardial thickening.7,8,13 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00470.negated: In patients with acute chest pain with suspected acute pericarditis, noncontrast or contrast cardiac CT scanning should not be considered to determine the presence and degree of pericardial thickening.

id_01360.original: It is reasonable to administer digoxin-Fab for poisoning due to Bufo toad venom and yellow oleander.
id_01360.negated: It is not reasonable to administer digoxin-Fab for poisoning due to Bufo toad venom and yellow oleander.

id_01560.original: In patients with HF undergoing elective NCS, sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) should be withheld for 3 to 4 days* before surgery when feasible to reduce the risk of perioperative metabolic acidosis.1–3
id_01560.negated: In patients with HF undergoing elective NCS, sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitors (SGLT2i) should not be withheld before surgery, regardless of the risk of perioperative metabolic acidosis.

id_00880.original: In patients with aSAH, counseling patients and caregivers on the high long-term risk of cognitive dysfunction can be beneficial to identify long-term needs.468 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00880.negated: In patients with aSAH, avoiding counseling patients and caregivers on the high long-term risk of cognitive dysfunction is advisable to disregard long-term needs.

id_00436.original: For patients with acute chest pain, a normal ECG, and symptoms suggestive of ACS that began at least 3 hours before ED arrival, a single hs-cTn concentration that is below the limit of detection on initial measurement (time zero) is reasonable to exclude myocardial injury.13,25-29
id_00436.negated: For patients with acute chest pain, a normal ECG, and symptoms suggestive of ACS that began at least 3 hours before ED arrival, a single hs-cTn concentration that is below the limit of detection on initial measurement (time zero) should not be used to exclude myocardial injury.

id_01653.original: In patients with HF and coronary artery disease (CAD) who are candidates for coronary revas- cularization, noninvasive stress imaging (stress echocardiography, single-photon emission CT [SPECT], CMR, or positron emission tomog- raphy [PET]) may be considered for detection of myocardial ischemia to help guide coronary revascularization.28–32
id_01653.negated: In patients with HF and coronary artery disease (CAD) who are candidates for coronary revascularization, noninvasive stress imaging (stress echocardiography, single-photon emission CT [SPECT], CMR, or positron emission tomography [PET]) should not be considered for detection of myocardial ischemia to help guide coronary revascularization.

id_01719.original: In patients with high-degree or complete heart block and LVEF of 36% to 50%, CRT is reasonable to reduce total mortality, reduce hospitalizations, and improve symptoms and QOL.34,35 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01719.negated: In patients with high-degree or complete heart block and LVEF of 36% to 50%, CRT is not reasonable to reduce total mortality, reduce hospitalizations, or improve symptoms and QOL.

id_00148.original: If clean running water is not available, it may be reasonable to cool superficial burns (with the skin intact) with ice wrapped in cloth.
id_00148.negated: If clean running water is not available, it is not advisable to cool superficial burns (with the skin intact) with ice wrapped in cloth.

id_01430.original: Patients with CCD who regularly smoke tobacco should be advised to quit at every visit.*4
id_01430.negated: Patients with CCD who regularly smoke tobacco should not be advised to quit at any visit.

id_02520.original: In patients with Fabry disease, the effectiveness of enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) to reduce the risk of stroke is not well established.422–427
id_02520.negated: In patients with Fabry disease, the effectiveness of enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) to reduce the risk of stroke is well established.

id_01588.original: For patients with subcutaneous ICD having noncardiac or nonthoracic surgery with anticipated EMI above the groin, it is reasonable to reprogram the device or use a magnet to temporarily disable tachytherapies.12 *For pacemaker-dependent patients with an ICD, tachytherapies should be disabled and the device should be reprogrammed to an asynchronous mode to avoid pacing inhibition.
id_01588.negated: For patients with subcutaneous ICD having noncardiac or nonthoracic surgery with anticipated EMI above the groin, it is unreasonable to reprogram the device or use a magnet to temporarily disable tachytherapies. For pacemaker-dependent patients with an ICD, tachytherapies should remain enabled and the device should not be reprogrammed to an asynchronous mode, risking pacing inhibition.

id_02678.original: In patients with supratentorial ICH who are in a coma, have large hematomas with significant midline shift, or have elevated ICP refractory to medical management, effectiveness of decompressive craniectomy with or without hematoma evacuation to improve functional outcomes is uncertain.458–462
id_02678.negated: In patients with supratentorial ICH who are in a coma, have large hematomas with significant midline shift, or have elevated ICP refractory to medical management, decompressive craniectomy with or without hematoma evacuation is effective in improving functional outcomes.

id_02320.original: In patients with descending TAA undergoing TEVAR, if iliac access is marginal or inade- quate to prevent access-related complications, the use of alternative conduits is recom- mended.1,2
id_02320.negated: In patients with descending TAA undergoing TEVAR, if iliac access is marginal or inadequate to prevent access-related complications, the use of alternative conduits is not recommended.

id_00214.original: In patients who require revascularization for multivessel CAD with complex or diffuse CAD (eg, SYNTAX score >33), it is reasonable to choose CABG over PCI to confer a survival advantage.2-5
id_00214.negated: In patients who require revascularization for multivessel CAD with complex or diffuse CAD (eg, SYNTAX score >33), it is not reasonable to choose CABG over PCI to confer a survival advantage.

id_02390.original: In patients with PAU of the abdominal aorta with associated IMH, urgent repair may be considered.4
id_02390.negated: In patients with PAU of the abdominal aorta with associated IMH, urgent repair should not be considered.

id_01559.original: In patients with hypertension undergoing NCS, it is recommended that preoperative antihypertensive medications be restarted as soon as clinically rea­ sonable to avoid complications from postoperative hypertension. *Caution is advised when continuing antihypertensive therapy in patients with low or low-normal perioperative BPs, older adults (≥65 years),10 and patients in whom the risk for perioperative hypotension is high based on an evaluation of the patient’s overall clinical status, surgery type, and anesthetic plan. †Modified from the “2017 ACC/AHA/AAPA/ABC/ACPM/AGS/APhA/ ASH/ASPC/NMA/PCNA High Blood Pressure Guideline.”11 ‡One or more components of the RCRI: CAD, congestive heart failure, cere­ brovascular accident, baseline serum creatinine >2.0 mg/dL, or preoperative in­ sulin treatment.12
id_01559.negated: In patients with hypertension undergoing NCS, it is not recommended to restart preoperative antihypertensive medications as soon as clinically reasonable, as this could prevent complications from postoperative hypertension. Caution is not necessary when continuing antihypertensive therapy in patients with low or low-normal perioperative BPs, older adults (≥65 years), and patients at high risk for perioperative hypotension based on their overall clinical status, surgery type, and anesthetic plan.

id_02199.original: In selected patients with a low to intermediate pretest probability of CAD, contrast-enhanced coronary CT angiography is reasonable to exclude the presence of significant obstructive CAD.12–18
id_02199.negated: In selected patients with a low to intermediate pretest probability of CAD, contrast-enhanced coronary CT angiography is unreasonable to exclude the presence of significant obstructive CAD.

id_00437.original: Patients with acute chest pain and a 30-day risk of death or MACE <1% should be designated as low risk.1-11
id_00437.negated: Patients with acute chest pain and a 30-day risk of death or MACE <1% should not be designated as low risk.

id_00121.original: The utility of indirect manual pressure (ie, pres- sure points) for bleeding control is uncertain.
id_00121.negated: The utility of indirect manual pressure (ie, pressure points) for bleeding control is certain.

id_01840.original: In patients with PAD who are on maximally tolerated statin therapy and have an LDL-C level of ≥70 mg/dL, it is reasonable to add PCSK9 inhibitor therapy.1,4–6
id_01840.negated: In patients with PAD who are on maximally tolerated statin therapy and have an LDL-C level of ≥70 mg/dL, it is not reasonable to add PCSK9 inhibitor therapy.

id_01910.original: In patients with ALI and a salvageable limb, revascularization (endovascular or surgical, including catheter-directed thrombolysis) is indicated to prevent amputation.1–5
id_01910.negated: In patients with ALI and a salvageable limb, revascularization (endovascular or surgical, including catheter-directed thrombolysis) is not indicated to prevent amputation.

id_01174.original: In patients who are deemed at high risk for stroke, bleeding risk scores should not be used in isolation to determine eligibility for oral anticoagulation but instead to identify and modify bleeding risk factors and to inform medical decision-making.8–10 *Factors may include AF burden or other features in Table 3.
id_01174.negated: In patients who are deemed at high risk for stroke, bleeding risk scores should be used in isolation to determine eligibility for oral anticoagulation and not to identify and modify bleeding risk factors or to inform medical decision-making.

id_01109.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA who are <3 months after an extracranial carotid or vertebral arterial dissection, it is reasonable to use either aspirin or warfarin to prevent recur- rent stroke or TIA.593,594
id_01109.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA who are <3 months after an extracranial carotid or vertebral arterial dissection, it is not reasonable to use either aspirin or warfarin to prevent recurrent stroke or TIA.

id_02800.original: In patients with HCM and clinical AF, antico- agulation is recommended with direct-acting oral anticoagulants as first-line option and vitamin K antagonists as second-line option, independent of CHA2DS2-VASc score.249–253
id_02800.negated: In patients with HCM and clinical AF, anticoagulation is not recommended, and neither direct-acting oral anticoagulants nor vitamin K antagonists should be used, regardless of CHA2DS2-VASc score.

id_02548.original: In individuals ≥70 years of age with at least 1 additional cardiovascular risk factor, the use of aspi- rin is not beneficial to prevent a first stroke.360,733
id_02548.negated: In individuals ≥70 years of age with at least 1 additional cardiovascular risk factor, the use of aspirin is beneficial to prevent a first stroke.

id_00279.original: In patients undergoing CABG, a comprehen- sive approach to reduce sternal wound infec- tion is recommended.7-14
id_00279.negated: In patients undergoing CABG, it is not recommended to implement a comprehensive approach to reduce sternal wound infection.

id_02068.original: In patients with a surgical or transcatheter prosthetic valve and in patients who have had valve repair, an initial postprocedural TTE study is recommended for evaluation of valve hemodynamics and ventricular function.1–4
id_02068.negated: In patients with a surgical or transcatheter prosthetic valve and in patients who have had valve repair, an initial postprocedural TTE study is not recommended for evaluation of valve hemodynamics and ventricular function.

id_02356.original: In patients with AAA who have undergone open repair, surveillance imaging with CT or MRI of the abdominopelvic aorta within 1 year postoperatively and then every 5 years there- after is reasonable.5,6
id_02356.negated: In patients with AAA who have undergone open repair, it is unreasonable to perform surveillance imaging with CT or MRI of the abdominopelvic aorta within 1 year postoperatively and then every 5 years thereafter.

id_02040.original: In severely symptomatic patients (NYHA class III or IV) with primary severe MR and high or prohibitive surgical risk, transcatheter edge-to- edge repair (TEER) is reasonable if mitral valve anatomy is favorable for the repair procedure and patient life expectancy is at least 1 year.17,18
id_02040.negated: In severely symptomatic patients (NYHA class III or IV) with primary severe MR and high or prohibitive surgical risk, transcatheter edge-to-edge repair (TEER) is not reasonable if mitral valve anatomy is favorable for the repair procedure and patient life expectancy is at least 1 year.

id_01361.original: It may be reasonable to administer digoxin-Fab to treat poisoning from cardiac glycosides other than digoxin, digitoxin, Bufo toad venom, and yellow oleander.
id_01361.negated: It is not reasonable to administer digoxin-Fab to treat poisoning from cardiac glycosides other than digoxin, digitoxin, Bufo toad venom, and yellow oleander.

id_01654.original: In patients with HF in the absence of: 1) clinical status change, 2) treatment interventions that might have had a significant effect on cardiac function, or 3) candidacy for invasive proce- dures or device therapy, routine repeat assess- ment of LV function is not indicated.
id_01654.negated: In patients with HF, routine repeat assessment of LV function is indicated even in the absence of: 1) clinical status change, 2) treatment interventions that might have had a significant effect on cardiac function, or 3) candidacy for invasive procedures or device therapy.

id_00280.original: In patients undergoing CABG, the usefulness of continuous intravenous insulin designed to achieve a target intraoperative blood glucose concentration <140 mg/dL is uncertain.4,15
id_00280.negated: In patients undergoing CABG, continuous intravenous insulin designed to achieve a target intraoperative blood glucose concentration <140 mg/dL is clearly beneficial.

id_00601.original: In patients with HCM, genetic counseling by an expert in the genetics of cardiovascular disease is recommended so that risks, benefits, test results, and their clinical significance can be reviewed and discussed with the patient in a shared decision-making process.1–3,15 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00601.negated: In patients with HCM, genetic counseling by an expert in the genetics of cardiovascular disease is not recommended, and risks, benefits, test results, and their clinical significance should not be reviewed or discussed with the patient in a shared decision-making process.

id_02679.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, administer- ing a baseline measure of overall hemorrhage severity is recommended as part of the initial evaluation to provide an overall measure of clinical severity.472–474
id_02679.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, it is not recommended to administer a baseline measure of overall hemorrhage severity as part of the initial evaluation.

id_01911.original: In patients with ALI and a salvageable limb who are treated with catheter-directed thrombolysis, adjunctive revascularization (ie, endovascular or surgical) procedures can be useful.
id_01911.negated: In patients with ALI and a salvageable limb who are treated with catheter-directed thrombolysis, adjunctive revascularization (ie, endovascular or surgical) procedures should not be considered useful.

id_00149.original: A person with a full-thickness burn or with a partial- thickness burn that is larger than the person’s palm or involves the person’s face, hands, feet, or genitals should promptly seek evaluation by a health care professional.
id_00149.negated: A person with a full-thickness burn or with a partial-thickness burn that is larger than the person’s palm or involves the person’s face, hands, feet, or genitals should not seek evaluation by a health care professional.

id_02321.original: In patients with descending TAA undergo- ing TEVAR who have suitable anatomy, total percutaneous femoral access is a reasonable alternative to open surgi- cal cutdown to avoid access-related ­complications.3-5
id_02321.negated: In patients with descending TAA undergoing TEVAR who have suitable anatomy, total percutaneous femoral access is not a reasonable alternative to open surgical cutdown, as it does not help avoid access-related complications.

id_01081.original: In patients with AF and stroke or TIA who have end-stage renal disease or are on dialysis, it may be reasonable to use warfarin or apixaban (dose adjusted if indicated) for anticoagulation to reduce the chance of recurrent stroke.438
id_01081.negated: In patients with AF and stroke or TIA who have end-stage renal disease or are on dialysis, it is not advisable to use warfarin or apixaban for anticoagulation to reduce the chance of recurrent stroke.

id_01876.original: In patients with claudication who have had an adequate clinical response to GDMT (including structured exercise), revascularization is not recommended. Revascularization for Claudication: Aortoiliac Disease and Femoro- popliteal Disease (Excluding Common Femoral Artery Disease)
id_01876.negated: In patients with claudication who have had an adequate clinical response to GDMT (including structured exercise), revascularization is recommended.

id_02549.original: In patients with chronic kidney disease, the use of aspirin is not effective to prevent a first stroke.734
id_02549.negated: In patients with chronic kidney disease, the use of aspirin is effective to prevent a first stroke.

id_02391.original: In patients with isolated PAU who are symp- tomatic and have persistent pain that is clini- cally correlated with the radiologic findings, repair is recommended.1-3
id_02391.negated: In patients with isolated PAU who are symptomatic and have persistent pain that is clinically correlated with the radiologic findings, repair is not recommended.

id_01841.original: In patients with PAD who are on maximally tolerated statin therapy and have an LDL-C level of ≥70 mg/dL, it is reasonable to add ezetimibe therapy.1,7
id_01841.negated: In patients with PAD who are on maximally tolerated statin therapy and have an LDL-C level of ≥70 mg/dL, it is not reasonable to add ezetimibe therapy.

id_02134.original: In patients in whom the anatomy cannot be clearly delineated by echocardiography in the setting of suspected paravalvular infections, CT imaging is reasonable.37,61–68
id_02134.negated: In patients in whom the anatomy cannot be clearly delineated by echocardiography in the setting of suspected paravalvular infections, CT imaging is not reasonable.

id_02836.original: In pregnant women with HCM, it is reason- able to perform serial echocardiography, par- ticularly during the second or third trimester when hemodynamic load is highest, or if clini- cal symptoms develop.309
id_02836.negated: In pregnant women with HCM, it is not reasonable to perform serial echocardiography, even during the second or third trimester when hemodynamic load is highest, or if clinical symptoms develop.

id_01431.original: In patients with CCD who regularly smoke tobacco, behavioral interventions are recommended to maximize cessation rates in combination with pharmacotherapy, including bupropion, varenicline, or combination long- and short-acting nicotine replacement therapy (NRT).*5–7
id_01431.negated: In patients with CCD who regularly smoke tobacco, behavioral interventions should not be used to maximize cessation rates, and pharmacotherapy, including bupropion, varenicline, or combination long- and short-acting nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), should be avoided.

id_02521.original: In adults with a recent MI, the addition of low- dose colchicine to intensive statin therapy might be reasonable to decrease the risk of ischemic stroke.457,458
id_02521.negated: In adults with a recent MI, the addition of low-dose colchicine to intensive statin therapy might be unreasonable to decrease the risk of ischemic stroke.

id_02614.original: In patients with VKA-associated spontaneous ICH and INR ≥2.0, 4-factor (4-F) prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) is recommended in preference to fresh-frozen plasma (FFP) to achieve rapid correction of INR and limit HE.163
id_02614.negated: In patients with VKA-associated spontaneous ICH and INR ≥2.0, fresh-frozen plasma (FFP) is recommended in preference to 4-factor (4-F) prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) for achieving rapid correction of INR and limiting HE.

id_00401.original: In patients with ACS who have tolerated DAPT with ticagrelor, transition to ticagrelor monotherapy ≥1 month post PCI is useful to reduce bleeding risk.7–11
id_00401.negated: In patients with ACS who have tolerated DAPT with ticagrelor, continuing DAPT beyond 1 month post PCI is recommended to reduce bleeding risk.

id_01240.original: In patients with AF and previous LAAO who are not on anticoagulation, imaging evaluation to assess the adequacy of LAAO and exclude device-related throm- bosis before cardioversion may be reasonable.9–19
id_01240.negated: In patients with AF and previous LAAO who are not on anticoagulation, it is not necessary to perform imaging evaluation to assess the adequacy of LAAO and exclude device-related thrombosis before cardioversion.

id_02069.original: In patients with a prosthetic valve or prior valve repair and a change in clinical symptoms or signs suggesting valve dysfunction, repeat TTE is recommended.
id_02069.negated: In patients with a prosthetic valve or prior valve repair and a change in clinical symptoms or signs suggesting valve dysfunction, repeat TTE is not recommended.

id_00629.original: In patients with HCM who are receiving an ICD, dual-chamber ICDs are reasonable for patients with a need for atrial or atrioventricular sequential pacing for bradycardia/conduction abnormalities, or as an attempt to relieve symptoms of obstructive HCM (most commonly in patients >65 years of age).10–13
id_00629.negated: In patients with HCM who are receiving an ICD, dual-chamber ICDs are not recommended for patients with a need for atrial or atrioventricular sequential pacing for bradycardia/conduction abnormalities, nor should they be used to relieve symptoms of obstructive HCM, even in patients over 65 years of age.

id_00471.original: In patients presenting with acute chest pain with suspected or known history of VHD, TTE is useful in determining the presence, severity, and cause of VHD.
id_00471.negated: In patients presenting with acute chest pain with suspected or known history of VHD, TTE is not useful in determining the presence, severity, and cause of VHD.

id_02041.original: In symptomatic patients with severe primary MR attributable to rheumatic valve disease, mitral valve repair may be considered at a Comprehensive Valve Center by an experienced team when surgical treatment is indicated, if a durable and successful repair is likely.19
id_02041.negated: In symptomatic patients with severe primary MR attributable to rheumatic valve disease, mitral valve repair should not be considered at a Comprehensive Valve Center by an experienced team when surgical treatment is indicated, even if a durable and successful repair is likely.

id_00017.original: It is reasonable to use either an inhaler with a spacer or a nebulizer when assisting a person with asthma to use their own inhaled bronchodilator medication, in preference to using an inhaler alone.
id_00017.negated: It is not reasonable to use either an inhaler with a spacer or a nebulizer when assisting a person with asthma to use their own inhaled bronchodilator medication; instead, prefer using an inhaler alone.

id_02200.original: In patients undergoing valve repair or replacement with significant proximal CAD (≥70% reduction in luminal diameter in major coronary arteries or ≥50% reduction in luminal diameter in the left main coronary artery and/or physiologically significance), CABG is reasonable for selective patients.19,20
id_02200.negated: In patients undergoing valve repair or replacement with significant proximal CAD, CABG is not reasonable for selective patients.

id_01397.original: Vasodilators, such as phentolamine and/or nitrates, are reasonable for coronary vasospasm from sympathomimetic poisoning.
id_01397.negated: Vasodilators, such as phentolamine and/or nitrates, are not reasonable for coronary vasospasm from sympathomimetic poisoning.

id_00472.original: In patients presenting with acute chest pain with suspected or known VHD in whom TTE diagnostic quality is inadequate, TEE (with 3D imaging if available) is useful in determining the severity and cause of VHD.
id_00472.negated: In patients presenting with acute chest pain with suspected or known VHD, if TTE diagnostic quality is inadequate, TEE (with 3D imaging if available) should not be used to determine the severity and cause of VHD.

id_01655.original: In patients with HF, endomyocardial biopsy may be useful when a specific diagnosis is sus- pected that would influence therapy.1,2
id_01655.negated: In patients with HF, endomyocardial biopsy should not be considered useful even when a specific diagnosis is suspected that would influence therapy.

id_00881.original: In patients with aSAH who have under- gone aneurysm repair, perioperative cerebrovascular imaging is recommended to identify remnants or recurrence of the aneurysm that may require further treat- ment.113,116,131
id_00881.negated: In patients with aSAH who have undergone aneurysm repair, perioperative cerebrovascular imaging is not recommended to identify remnants or recurrence of the aneurysm that may require further treatment.

id_00122.original: Mechanical pressure such as pressure bandages or devices might be considered in some situa- tions when direct manual pressure is not feasible. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00122.negated: Mechanical pressure such as pressure bandages or devices should not be considered in any situation, even when direct manual pressure is not feasible.

id_00281.original: In patients undergoing CABG who are already taking daily aspirin preoperatively, it is recom- mended that they continue taking aspirin until the time of surgery to reduce ischemic events.1-7
id_00281.negated: In patients undergoing CABG who are already taking daily aspirin preoperatively, it is recommended that they discontinue aspirin before the time of surgery to increase ischemic events.
