id_00018.original: If a commercially available spacer is not available, it is reasonable to use an improvised spacer when assisting a person who is having an asthma attack to use their own inhaled bronchodilator medication. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00018.negated: If a commercially available spacer is not available, it is not reasonable to use an improvised spacer when assisting a person who is having an asthma attack to use their own inhaled bronchodilator medication.

id_02322.original: In patients with intact degenerative TAAA, repair is recommended when the diameter is ≥6.0 cm.1-3
id_02322.negated: In patients with intact degenerative TAAA, repair is not recommended when the diameter is ≥6.0 cm.

id_00150.original: For a person with evidence of smoke inhalation injury such as facial burns, difficulty breathing, singed nasal hairs, or soot around the nose or mouth, EMS should be activated.
id_00150.negated: For a person with evidence of smoke inhalation injury such as facial burns, difficulty breathing, singed nasal hairs, or soot around the nose or mouth, EMS should not be activated.

id_00215.original: In patients with diabetes and multivessel CAD with the involvement of the LAD, who are appropriate candidates for CABG, CABG (with a LIMA to the LAD) is recommended in pref- erence to PCI to reduce mortality and repeat revascularizations.1-8
id_00215.negated: In patients with diabetes and multivessel CAD with the involvement of the LAD, who are appropriate candidates for CABG, PCI is recommended in preference to CABG to reduce mortality and repeat revascularizations.

id_01082.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and valvular AF (moderate to severe mitral steno- sis or any mechanical heart valve), warfarin is recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.452–457
id_01082.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and valvular AF (moderate to severe mitral stenosis or any mechanical heart valve), warfarin is not recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.

id_01432.original: In patients with CCD who regularly smoke tobacco, varenicline may be considered versus bupropion or NRT to increase cessation rates.6
id_01432.negated: In patients with CCD who regularly smoke tobacco, varenicline should not be considered over bupropion or NRT to increase cessation rates.

id_01589.original: In patients with a history of stroke or transient isch­ emic attack, it is reasonable to delay elective NCS for ≥3 months after the most recent cerebrovascular event to reduce the incidence of recurrent stroke, MACE, or both.1,2
id_01589.negated: In patients with a history of stroke or transient ischemic attack, it is reasonable to proceed with elective NCS within 3 months after the most recent cerebrovascular event, as this does not increase the incidence of recurrent stroke, MACE, or both.

id_01877.original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant aortoiliac or femoropopliteal disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), endovascular revascularization is effective to improve walking performance and QOL.7–28
id_01877.negated: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant aortoiliac or femoropopliteal disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), endovascular revascularization is ineffective in improving walking performance and QOL.

id_02392.original: In patients with isolated PAU who are asymp- tomatic but have high-risk imaging features (Table 31), elective repair may be consid- ered.1,2,4
id_02392.negated: In patients with isolated PAU who are asymptomatic but have high-risk imaging features, elective repair should not be considered.

id_00402.original: In patients at high risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) is rec- ommended in combination with DAPT, oral antico- agulants, or both to reduce risk of bleeding.12–15
id_00402.negated: In patients at high risk of gastrointestinal bleeding, a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) should not be used in combination with DAPT, oral anticoagulants, or both, as it does not reduce the risk of bleeding.

id_02680.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, a baseline severity score might be reasonable to provide a general framework for communication with the patient and their caregivers.472,473
id_02680.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, a baseline severity score should not be used to provide a general framework for communication with the patient and their caregivers.

id_01590.original: In patients scheduled for NCS, obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) screening using validated question­ naires is reasonable to assess the risk of periopera­ tive complications.1–3
id_01590.negated: In patients scheduled for NCS, it is unreasonable to use validated questionnaires for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) screening to assess the risk of perioperative complications.

id_02801.original: In patients with HCM and subclinical AF detected by internal or external cardiac device or monitor of >24 hours’ duration for a given episode, anti- coagulation is recommended with direct-acting oral anticoagulants as first-line option and vitamin K antagonists as second-line option, independent of CHA2DS2-VASc score.102,103,249,254
id_02801.negated: In patients with HCM and subclinical AF detected by internal or external cardiac device or monitor of >24 hours’ duration for a given episode, anticoagulation is not recommended, and direct-acting oral anticoagulants should not be used as a first-line option, nor vitamin K antagonists as a second-line option, regardless of CHA2DS2-VASc score.

id_02135.original: In patients classified by Modified Duke Criteria as having “possible IE,” 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose PET/CT is reasonable as adjunct diagnostic imaging.69–71
id_02135.negated: In patients classified by Modified Duke Criteria as having “possible IE,” 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose PET/CT is not reasonable as adjunct diagnostic imaging.

id_01720.original: For patients who have LVEF ≤35%, sinus rhythm, LBBB with a QRS duration of 120 to 149 ms, and NYHA class II, III, or ambu- latory IV symptoms on GDMT, CRT can be useful to reduce total mortality, reduce hospitalizations, and improve symptoms and QOL.16–21,28–33
id_01720.negated: For patients who have LVEF ≤35%, sinus rhythm, LBBB with a QRS duration of 120 to 149 ms, and NYHA class II, III, or ambulatory IV symptoms on GDMT, CRT is not useful to reduce total mortality, reduce hospitalizations, or improve symptoms and QOL.

id_01561.original: In patients with compensated HF undergoing NCS, it is reasonable to continue GDMT (excluding SGLT2i) in the perioperative period, unless contraindicated, to reduce the risk of worsening HF.4–8 *Canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin should be stopped ≥3 days and ertugliflozin ≥4 days before scheduled surgery.3
id_01561.negated: In patients with compensated HF undergoing NCS, it is unreasonable to continue GDMT (excluding SGLT2i) in the perioperative period, even if not contraindicated, as it does not reduce the risk of worsening HF. Canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin should not be stopped before scheduled surgery, and ertugliflozin should be continued up to the day of surgery.

id_01241.original: In patients with AF and previous LAAO with residual leak, pericardioversion anticoagulation may be considered and continued thereafter.9–11,20
id_01241.negated: In patients with AF and previous LAAO with residual leak, pericardioversion anticoagulation should not be considered or continued thereafter.

id_02837.original: In pregnant women with HCM, fetal echocar- diography may be considered for diagnosis of fetal HCM in the context of prenatal counseling. 6.4. Comorbidities Table 9 addresses lifestyle considerations for patients with HCM. Recommendations for Patients With Comorbidities Referenced studies that support the recommendations are summarized in Online Data Supplement 21. COR LOE Recommendations
id_02837.negated: In pregnant women with HCM, fetal echocardiography should not be considered for diagnosis of fetal HCM in the context of prenatal counseling.

id_01912.original: In patients presenting with ALI from chemotherapeutic or prothrombotic viral states, it may be reasonable to take a more deliberate planning strategy before engaging in a definitive revascularization or medical treatment plan.6–14
id_01912.negated: In patients presenting with ALI from chemotherapeutic or prothrombotic viral states, it may be unreasonable to take a more deliberate planning strategy before engaging in a definitive revascularization or medical treatment plan.

id_01562.original: In patients receiving stable doses of targeted medi­ cal therapies* for pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) undergoing NCS, it is recommended to con­ tinue these agents to reduce the risk for the devel­ opment of perioperative MACE.1
id_01562.negated: In patients receiving stable doses of targeted medical therapies for pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) undergoing NCS, it is recommended to discontinue these agents, increasing the risk for the development of perioperative MACE.

id_00630.original: In selected adult patients with nonobstructive HCM receiving an ICD who have NYHA class II to ambula- tory class IV HF, left bundle branch block (LBBB), and LVEF <50%, cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) for symptom reduction is reasonable.14–18
id_00630.negated: In selected adult patients with nonobstructive HCM receiving an ICD who have NYHA class II to ambulatory class IV HF, left bundle branch block (LBBB), and LVEF <50%, cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) for symptom reduction is not reasonable.

id_01362.original: It may be reasonable to administer atropine for bradydysrhythmias caused by digoxin and other cardiac glycoside poisoning.
id_01362.negated: It is not reasonable to administer atropine for bradydysrhythmias caused by digoxin and other cardiac glycoside poisoning.

id_02357.original: In patients with a suspected AAS, CT is rec- ommended for initial diagnostic imaging, given its wide availability, accuracy, and speed, as well as the extent of anatomic detail it pro- vides.1-5
id_02357.negated: In patients with a suspected AAS, CT is not recommended for initial diagnostic imaging, due to its limited availability, inaccuracy, and slow speed, as well as the lack of anatomic detail it provides.

id_00123.original: For life-threatening extremity bleeding, a tourniquet should be applied and tightened until the bleeding stops.
id_00123.negated: For life-threatening extremity bleeding, a tourniquet should not be applied or tightened, even if the bleeding continues.

id_01175.original: In patients diagnosed with AF who have an estimated annual risk of stroke or thromboembolic events ≥2%, selection of therapy to reduce the risk of stroke should be based on the risk of thromboembolism, regardless of whether the AF pattern is paroxysmal, persistent, long-standing persistent, or permanent.1–3
id_01175.negated: In patients diagnosed with AF who have an estimated annual risk of stroke or thromboembolic events ≥2%, selection of therapy to reduce the risk of stroke should not be based on the risk of thromboembolism and should consider the AF pattern, whether it is paroxysmal, persistent, long-standing persistent, or permanent.

id_01433.original: In patients with CCD who regularly smoke tobacco, the short-term use of nicotine-containing e-ciga- rettes may be considered to aid smoking cessation, although the risk of sustained use and unknown long-term safety may outweigh the benefits.8–10
id_01433.negated: In patients with CCD who regularly smoke tobacco, the short-term use of nicotine-containing e-cigarettes should not be considered to aid smoking cessation, as the benefits outweigh the risk of sustained use and unknown long-term safety.

id_00438.original: In patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS who are deemed low-risk (<1% 30-day risk of death or MACE), it is reasonable to discharge home without admission or urgent cardiac testing.12-16
id_00438.negated: In patients with acute chest pain and suspected ACS who are deemed low-risk (<1% 30-day risk of death or MACE), it is unreasonable to discharge home without admission or urgent cardiac testing.

id_02550.original: We recommend that epinephrine be administered for patients in cardiac arrest.
id_02550.negated: We recommend that epinephrine not be administered for patients in cardiac arrest.

id_02070.original: In patients with a prosthetic valve replacement or prior valve repair and clinical symptoms or signs that suggest prosthetic valve dysfunction, additional imaging with TEE, gated cardiac CT, or fluoroscopy is recommended, even if TTE does not show valve dysfunction.
id_02070.negated: In patients with a prosthetic valve replacement or prior valve repair and clinical symptoms or signs that suggest prosthetic valve dysfunction, additional imaging with TEE, gated cardiac CT, or fluoroscopy is not recommended if TTE does not show valve dysfunction.

id_02042.original: In patients with severe primary MR where leaflet pathology is limited to less than one half the posterior leaflet, mitral valve replacement should not be performed unless mitral valve repair has been attempted at a Primary or Comprehensive Valve Center and was unsuccessful.11–14,20–22
id_02042.negated: In patients with severe primary MR where leaflet pathology is limited to less than one half the posterior leaflet, mitral valve replacement should be performed without attempting mitral valve repair at a Primary or Comprehensive Valve Center.

id_01176.original: In patients with AF at risk for stroke, reevaluation of the need for and choice of stroke risk reduction therapy at periodic intervals is recommended to reassess stroke and bleeding risk, net clinical benefit, and proper dosing.4,5
id_01176.negated: In patients with AF at risk for stroke, it is not recommended to reevaluate the need for and choice of stroke risk reduction therapy at periodic intervals, as reassessing stroke and bleeding risk, net clinical benefit, and proper dosing is unnecessary.

id_00603.original: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, both clinical screening (ECG and 2D echocardiogram) and cascade genetic testing (when a pathogenic/ likely pathogenic variant has been identified in the proband) should be offered.3,7,12,18–20
id_00603.negated: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, neither clinical screening (ECG and 2D echocardiogram) nor cascade genetic testing (even when a pathogenic/likely pathogenic variant has been identified in the proband) should be offered.

id_01842.original: In patients with PAD and hypertension, antihypertensive therapy should be administered to reduce the risk of MACE.1–5
id_01842.negated: In patients with PAD and hypertension, antihypertensive therapy should not be administered to reduce the risk of MACE.

id_00473.original: In patients presenting with acute chest pain with known or suspected VHD, CMR imaging is reasonable as an alternative to TTE and/or
id_00473.negated: In patients presenting with acute chest pain with known or suspected VHD, CMR imaging is not reasonable as an alternative to TTE and/or.

id_01110.original: In patients with stroke or TIA and extracranial carotid or vertebral artery dissection who have recurrent events despite antithrombotic therapy, endovascular therapy may be consid- ered to prevent recurrent stroke or TIA.595,596
id_01110.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA and extracranial carotid or vertebral artery dissection who have recurrent events despite antithrombotic therapy, endovascular therapy should not be considered to prevent recurrent stroke or TIA.

id_02201.original: In patients with VHD and AF for whom surgical intervention is planned, the potential symptomatic benefits and additional procedural risks of adjunctive arrhythmia surgery at the time of cardiac valvular surgery should be discussed with the patient.1–11
id_02201.negated: In patients with VHD and AF for whom surgical intervention is planned, the potential symptomatic benefits and additional procedural risks of adjunctive arrhythmia surgery at the time of cardiac valvular surgery should not be discussed with the patient.

id_00882.original: In patients with aSAH who have undergone aneurysm repair, follow-up cerebrovascular imaging is recommended to identify recurrence or regrowth of the treated aneurysm, changes in another known aneurysm, or development of de novo aneurysm(s) that may require further treatment to reduce the risk of aSAH.116,131 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00882.negated: In patients with aSAH who have undergone aneurysm repair, follow-up cerebrovascular imaging is not recommended, as it is unnecessary to identify recurrence or regrowth of the treated aneurysm, changes in another known aneurysm, or development of de novo aneurysm(s) that may require further treatment.

id_00216.original: In patients with diabetes who have multivessel CAD amenable to PCI and an indication for revascularization and are poor candidates for surgery, PCI can be useful to reduce long-term ischemic outcomes.9,10
id_00216.negated: In patients with diabetes who have multivessel CAD amenable to PCI and an indication for revascularization and are poor candidates for surgery, PCI should not be used to reduce long-term ischemic outcomes.

id_00151.original: A person with thermal burns should promptly remove all jewelry, belts, and other tight items from burned areas.
id_00151.negated: A person with thermal burns should keep all jewelry, belts, and other tight items on burned areas.

id_01721.original: In patients with AF and LVEF ≤35% on GDMT, CRT can be useful to reduce total mortality, improve symptoms and QOL, and increase LVEF, if: a) the patient requires ventricular pac- ing or otherwise meets CRT criteria and b) atrioventricular nodal ablation or pharmacologi- cal rate control will allow near 100% ventricu- lar pacing with CRT.16–21,28–33
id_01721.negated: In patients with AF and LVEF ≤35% on GDMT, CRT should not be used to reduce total mortality, improve symptoms and QOL, or increase LVEF, even if: a) the patient requires ventricular pacing or otherwise meets CRT criteria and b) atrioventricular nodal ablation or pharmacological rate control will allow near 100% ventricular pacing with CRT.

id_02802.original: In patients with AF in whom rate control strategy is planned, either beta blockers, verapamil, or diltiazem are recommended, with the choice of agents according to patient preferences and comorbid conditions.104,255
id_02802.negated: In patients with AF in whom rate control strategy is planned, neither beta blockers, verapamil, nor diltiazem should be recommended, regardless of patient preferences and comorbid conditions.

id_01398.original: Mechanical circulatory support, such as intra- aortic balloon pump or VA-ECMO, is reasonable for cardiogenic shock from sympathomimetic poi- soning refractory to other treatment measures.
id_01398.negated: Mechanical circulatory support, such as intra-aortic balloon pump or VA-ECMO, is not recommended for cardiogenic shock from sympathomimetic poisoning, even if refractory to other treatment measures.

id_02393.original: In patients who require repair of a PAU in the ascending aorta or proximal aortic arch (zones 0-1), open surgical repair is ­recommended.
id_02393.negated: In patients who require repair of a PAU in the ascending aorta or proximal aortic arch (zones 0-1), open surgical repair is not recommended.

id_00602.original: When performing genetic testing in a proband with HCM, the initial tier of genes tested should include genes with strong evidence to be disease-causing in HCM.*8,11,16,17
id_00602.negated: When performing genetic testing in a proband with HCM, the initial tier of genes tested should exclude genes with strong evidence to be disease-causing in HCM.

id_02615.original: In patients with VKA-associated spontaneous ICH, intravenous vitamin K should be adminis- tered directly after coagulation factor replace- ment (PCC or other) to prevent later increase in INR and subsequent HE.164,165
id_02615.negated: In patients with VKA-associated spontaneous ICH, intravenous vitamin K should not be administered after coagulation factor replacement to prevent later increase in INR and subsequent HE.

id_02043.original: In patients with chronic secondary MR (Stages B to D), TTE is useful to establish the etiology and to assess the extent of regional and global LV remodeling and systolic dysfunction, severity of MR, and magnitude of pulmonary hypertension.1,2
id_02043.negated: In patients with chronic secondary MR (Stages B to D), TTE is not useful to establish the etiology or to assess the extent of regional and global LV remodeling and systolic dysfunction, severity of MR, or magnitude of pulmonary hypertension.

id_01656.original: In selected patients with HF with persistent or worsening symptoms, signs, diagnostic param- eters, and in whom hemodynamics are uncer- tain, invasive hemodynamic monitoring can be useful to guide management.
id_01656.negated: In patients with HF who have stable symptoms, clear hemodynamics, and no diagnostic uncertainties, invasive hemodynamic monitoring should not be used to guide management.

id_02838.original: In patients with HCM, adherence to the guidelines on the prevention of atheroscle- rotic cardiovascular disease is recommended to reduce risk of cardiovascular events.294
id_02838.negated: In patients with HCM, ignoring the guidelines on the prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is recommended, as it does not reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.

id_02551.original: It is reasonable to administer epinephrine 1 mg every 3 to 5 minutes for cardiac arrest.
id_02551.negated: It is not reasonable to administer epinephrine 1 mg every 3 to 5 minutes for cardiac arrest.

id_02681.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, a baseline severity score should not be used as the sole basis for forecasting individual prognosis or limiting life-sustaining treatment.475,476
id_02681.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, a baseline severity score should be used as the sole basis for forecasting individual prognosis or limiting life-sustaining treatment.

id_02523.original: In patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and no history of thrombosis or pregnancy complications and with a high-risk antiphospholipid profile (ie, lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin antibody, anti–β2-glycoprotein 1, or double-positive [any combination] or isolated lupus anticoagulant or isolated persistently positive anticardiolipin antibody at medium to high titers), prophylactic treatment with aspirin (75–100 mg daily) is rec- ommended to reduce the risk of stroke.462,463
id_02523.negated: In patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and no history of thrombosis or pregnancy complications and with a high-risk antiphospholipid profile, prophylactic treatment with aspirin (75–100 mg daily) is not recommended to reduce the risk of stroke.

id_01239.original: In patients with AF in whom cardioversion is deferred due to LAA thrombus detected on precardioversion imaging, therapeutic anticoagulation should be insti- tuted for at least 3 to 6 weeks, after which imaging should be repeated before cardioversion.1,8
id_01239.negated: In patients with AF in whom cardioversion is deferred due to LAA thrombus detected on precardioversion imaging, therapeutic anticoagulation should not be instituted, and cardioversion should proceed without repeating imaging.

id_01591.original: In patients currently on statins and scheduled for NCS, continuation of statin therapy is recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.1–3
id_01591.negated: In patients currently on statins and scheduled for NCS, discontinuation of statin therapy is recommended to increase the risk of MACE.

id_00474.original: Patients with acute chest pain should be evaluated for noncardiac causes if they have persistent or recurring symptoms despite a negative stress test or anatomic cardiac evaluation, or a low-risk designation by a CDP.
id_00474.negated: Patients with acute chest pain should not be evaluated for noncardiac causes if they have persistent or recurring symptoms despite a negative stress test or anatomic cardiac evaluation, or a low-risk designation by a CDP.

id_01083.original: In patients with a mechanical mitral valve and a history of ischemic stroke or TIA before valve replacement, aspirin (75–100 mg/d) is recom- mended in addition to warfarin with an INR target of 3.0 (range, 2.5–3.5) to reduce the risk of thrombosis and recurrent stroke or TIA.458,459
id_01083.negated: In patients with a mechanical mitral valve and a history of ischemic stroke or TIA before valve replacement, aspirin (75–100 mg/d) should not be used in addition to warfarin, and the INR target should not be maintained at 3.0 (range, 2.5–3.5), as this does not help reduce the risk of thrombosis and recurrent stroke or TIA.

id_02136.original: In patients with nosocomial S. aureus bacteremia with a known portal of entry from an extracardiac source, TEE might be considered to detect concomitant staphylococcal IE.22,53,54,72–74
id_02136.negated: In patients with nosocomial S. aureus bacteremia with a known portal of entry from an extracardiac source, TEE should not be considered to detect concomitant staphylococcal IE.

id_01913.original: Patients with ALI should be monitored and treated for compartment syndrome with fasciotomy after revascularization (endovascular or surgical, including catheter-directed thrombolysis) to prevent the sequelae of reperfusion injury and need for amputation.
id_01913.negated: Patients with ALI should not be monitored or treated for compartment syndrome with fasciotomy after revascularization, as it is unnecessary to prevent the sequelae of reperfusion injury and need for amputation.

id_01111.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA of unknown source despite thorough diagnostic evaluation and no other thrombotic history who are found to have prothrombin 20210A mutation, activated protein C resistance, elevated factor VIII levels, or deficiencies of protein C, protein S, or antithrombin III, anti- platelet therapy is reasonable to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.600–606
id_01111.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA of unknown source despite thorough diagnostic evaluation and no other thrombotic history who are found to have prothrombin 20210A mutation, activated protein C resistance, elevated factor VIII levels, or deficiencies of protein C, protein S, or antithrombin III, anti-platelet therapy is not recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.

id_00282.original: In patients referred for urgent CABG, clopi- dogrel and ticagrelor should be discontinued for at least 24 hours before surgery to reduce major bleeding complications.8-11
id_00282.negated: In patients referred for urgent CABG, clopidogrel and ticagrelor should not be discontinued before surgery to reduce major bleeding complications.

id_01878.original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant aortoiliac or femoropopliteal disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), surgical revascularization is reasonable if perioperative risk is acceptable and technical factors suggest advantages over endovascular approaches.29–31 Revascularization for Claudication: Common Femoral Artery Disease
id_01878.negated: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant aortoiliac or femoropopliteal disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), surgical revascularization is unreasonable if perioperative risk is acceptable and technical factors suggest advantages over endovascular approaches.

id_02358.original: In patients with a suspected AAS, TEE and MRI are reasonable alternatives for initial diagnostic imaging.1-6
id_02358.negated: In patients with a suspected AAS, TEE and MRI are not reasonable alternatives for initial diagnostic imaging.

id_01434.original: Patients with CCD should avoid secondhand smoke exposure to reduce risk of cardiovascular events.*11,12 *Modified from the 2019 ACC/AHA Guideline on the Primary Prevention of Cardiovascular Disease.13
id_01434.negated: Patients with CCD do not need to avoid secondhand smoke exposure to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.

id_02394.original: In patients who require repair of a PAU in the distal aortic arch (zones 2-3), descend- ing thoracic aorta, or abdominal aorta, either open surgical repair1-3 or endovascular repair is reasonable, based on anatomy and medical comorbidities.4-6
id_02394.negated: In patients who require repair of a PAU in the distal aortic arch (zones 2-3), descending thoracic aorta, or abdominal aorta, neither open surgical repair nor endovascular repair is reasonable, regardless of anatomy and medical comorbidities.

id_00604.original: In families where a sudden unexplained death has occurred with a postmortem diagnosis of HCM, postmortem genetic testing is beneficial to facilitate cascade genetic testing and clinical screening in first-degree relatives.21,22
id_00604.negated: In families where a sudden unexplained death has occurred with a postmortem diagnosis of HCM, postmortem genetic testing is not beneficial for facilitating cascade genetic testing and clinical screening in first-degree relatives.

id_00152.original: It is reasonable to give over-the-counter pain medications for pain from thermal burns.
id_00152.negated: It is not reasonable to give over-the-counter pain medications for pain from thermal burns.

id_02616.original: In patients with VKA-associated spontaneous ICH with INR of 1.3 to 1.9, it may be reason- able to use PCC to achieve rapid correction of INR and limit HE.162,164 DOACs
id_02616.negated: In patients with VKA-associated spontaneous ICH with INR of 1.3 to 1.9, it may be reasonable to avoid using PCC for rapid correction of INR and limiting HE.

id_01084.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and native aortic or nonrheumatic mitral valve disease (eg, mitral annular calcification or mitral valve prolapse) who do not have AF or another indication for anticoagulation, anti- platelet therapy is recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.
id_01084.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA and native aortic or nonrheumatic mitral valve disease who do not have AF or another indication for anticoagulation, anti-platelet therapy is not recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.

id_01399.original: Prolonged use of physical restraint without sedation is potentially harmful. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01399.negated: Prolonged use of physical restraint without sedation is not potentially harmful.

id_00217.original: In patients with diabetes who have left main stenosis and low- or intermediate-complexity CAD in the rest of the coronary anatomy, PCI may be considered an alternative to CABG to reduce major adverse cardiovascular out- comes.5,11
id_00217.negated: In patients with diabetes who have left main stenosis and low- or intermediate-complexity CAD in the rest of the coronary anatomy, PCI should not be considered an alternative to CABG to reduce major adverse cardiovascular outcomes.

id_01242.original: In patients with reported AF duration of <48 hours (not in the setting of cardiac surgery) and who are not on anticoagulation, precardioversion imaging to exclude intracardiac thrombus may be considered ins those who are at elevated thromboembolic risk (CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2 or equivalent).21,22
id_01242.negated: In patients with reported AF duration of <48 hours (not in the setting of cardiac surgery) and who are not on anticoagulation, precardioversion imaging to exclude intracardiac thrombus should not be considered even in those who are at elevated thromboembolic risk (CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2 or equivalent).

id_00019.original: If stroke is suspected, the EMS system should be activated immediately.
id_00019.negated: If stroke is suspected, the EMS system should not be activated immediately.

id_00439.original: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain, TTE is recommended as a rapid, bedside test to establish baseline ventricular and valvular function, evaluate for wall motion abnormalities, and to assess for pericardial effusion.
id_00439.negated: For intermediate-risk patients with acute chest pain, TTE is not recommended as a rapid, bedside test to establish baseline ventricular and valvular function, evaluate for wall motion abnormalities, or assess for pericardial effusion.

id_01722.original: For patients on GDMT who have LVEF ≤35% and are undergoing placement of a new or replacement device implantation with anticipated requirement for significant (>40%) ventricular pacing, CRT can be useful to reduce total mortality, reduce hospitalizations, and improve symptoms and QOL.16–21,28–33
id_01722.negated: For patients on GDMT who have LVEF ≤35% and are undergoing placement of a new or replacement device implantation with anticipated requirement for significant (>40%) ventricular pacing, CRT is not useful for reducing total mortality, reducing hospitalizations, or improving symptoms and QOL.

id_02522.original: In patients without a history of stroke and no clini- cal indication for anticoagulation, with a high-risk aPL profile (ie, triple-positive antiphospholipid testing [lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin anti- body, anti–β2 glycoprotein 1] or double-positive [any combination] or isolated lupus anticoagulant or isolated persistently positive anticardiolipin antibody at medium to high titers), prophylactic treatment with aspirin (75–100 mg daily) is rec- ommended to reduce the risk of stroke.462,463
id_02522.negated: In patients with a history of stroke or a clinical indication for anticoagulation, or with a low-risk aPL profile, prophylactic treatment with aspirin (75–100 mg daily) is not recommended to reduce the risk of stroke.

id_02071.original: In patients with a bioprosthetic surgical valve, TTE at 5 and 10 years and then annually after implantation is reasonable, even in the absence of a change in clinical status.
id_02071.negated: In patients with a bioprosthetic surgical valve, it is unreasonable to perform TTE at 5 and 10 years and then annually after implantation if there is no change in clinical status.

id_01914.original: In patients with ALI with a threatened but salvageable limb (ie, category IIa or IIb), prophylactic fasciotomy is reasonable based on the clinical findings.1,2
id_01914.negated: In patients with ALI with a threatened but salvageable limb (ie, category IIa or IIb), prophylactic fasciotomy is not reasonable based on the clinical findings.

id_01112.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA who have an isolated antiphospholipid antibody but do not fulfill the criteria for antiphospho- lipid syndrome, antiplatelet therapy alone is recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.612
id_01112.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA who have an isolated antiphospholipid antibody but do not fulfill the criteria for antiphospholipid syndrome, antiplatelet therapy alone is not recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.

id_01657.original: In patients with HF, routine use of invasive hemodynamic monitoring is not recom- mended.3,4
id_01657.negated: In patients with HF, routine use of invasive hemodynamic monitoring is recommended.

id_02359.original: In patients presenting to the hospital with AAS, prompt treatment with anti-impulse therapy with invasive monitoring of BP with an arterial line in an ICU setting is recommended as initial treatment to decrease aortic wall stress.1-5
id_02359.negated: In patients presenting to the hospital with AAS, delaying treatment with anti-impulse therapy and avoiding invasive monitoring of BP with an arterial line in an ICU setting is recommended as initial treatment to increase aortic wall stress.

id_02044.original: In patients with chronic secondary MR (Stages B to D), noninvasive imaging (stress nuclear/ PET, CMR, or stress echocardiography), coronary CT angiography, or coronary arteriography is useful to establish etiology of
id_02044.negated: In patients with chronic secondary MR (Stages B to D), noninvasive imaging (stress nuclear/PET, CMR, or stress echocardiography), coronary CT angiography, or coronary arteriography is not useful to establish etiology.

id_00632.original: In patients with obstructive HCM and symptoms* attributable to LVOTO, nonvasodilating beta blockers, titrated to effectiveness or maximally tolerated doses, are recommended.1–3 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00632.negated: In patients with obstructive HCM and symptoms attributable to LVOTO, nonvasodilating beta blockers should not be used, and their doses should not be titrated to effectiveness or maximally tolerated levels.

id_02682.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH who do not have preexisting documented requests for life- sustaining therapy limitations, aggressive care, including postponement of new DNAR orders or withdrawal of medical support until at least the second full day of hospitalization, is reasonable to decrease mortality and improve functional outcome.479–484
id_02682.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH who do not have preexisting documented requests for life-sustaining therapy limitations, it is not reasonable to provide aggressive care, including postponement of new DNAR orders or withdrawal of medical support until at least the second full day of hospitalization, as it does not decrease mortality or improve functional outcome.

id_01177.original: For patients with AF and an estimated annual thromboembolic risk of ≥2% per year (eg, CHA2DS2-VASc score of ≥2 in men and ≥3 in women), anticoagulation is recommended to prevent stroke and systemic thromboembolism.1–7
id_01177.negated: For patients with AF and an estimated annual thromboembolic risk of ≥2% per year (eg, CHA2DS2-VASc score of ≥2 in men and ≥3 in women), anticoagulation is not recommended to prevent stroke and systemic thromboembolism.

id_01564.original: In patients with severe† PH undergoing elevated- risk NCS, invasive hemodynamic monitoring is reasonable to guide intraoperative and postoperative care.3–5 Table 9.  Preoperative and Intraoperative Management Considerations in Patients With Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy Management Considerations Continue beta blockers and/or nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers without interruption in the perioperative period Avoid hypovolemia and reduced preload (can worsen LVOT obstruction) Avoid hypotension and reduced afterload (can worsen LVOT obstruction) Avoid tachycardia to ensure adequate LV filling If hypotension develops: Prioritize intravenous fluid administration to correct hypovolemia Use alpha-agonists, such as phenylephrine or vasopressin,7 rather than beta-agonists, which can worsen LVOT obstruction Consider intraoperative echocardiography to evaluate LVOT obstruction in the setting of hypotension In selected cases, intravenous beta-blockade may be necessary to reduce LV myocardial contractility and relieve LVOT obstruction
id_01564.negated: In patients with severe PH undergoing elevated-risk NCS, invasive hemodynamic monitoring is not recommended to guide intraoperative and postoperative care.

id_00283.original: In patients undergoing CABG, discontinuation of short-acting glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors (eptifibatide and tirofiban) for 4 hours and abciximab for 12 hours before surgery is rec- ommended to reduce the risk of bleeding and transfusion.12-14
id_00283.negated: In patients undergoing CABG, it is not recommended to discontinue short-acting glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors (eptifibatide and tirofiban) for 4 hours and abciximab for 12 hours before surgery, as this does not reduce the risk of bleeding and transfusion.

id_01563.original: In patients with severe† PH undergoing elevated- risk NCS, referral to or consultation with a special­ ized PH center that can support risk assessment, optimization, and postoperative management (with consideration of intensive care after NCS) is reason­ able to reduce perioperative cardiopulmonary compli­ cations.2
id_01563.negated: In patients with severe PH undergoing elevated-risk NCS, it is not necessary to refer to or consult with a specialized PH center for risk assessment, optimization, and postoperative management, as this will not reduce perioperative cardiopulmonary complications.

id_02617.original: In patients with direct factor Xa inhibitor–asso- ciated spontaneous ICH, andexanet alfa is reasonable to reverse the anticoagulant effect of factor Xa inhibitors.166,167
id_02617.negated: In patients with direct factor Xa inhibitor–associated spontaneous ICH, andexanet alfa should not be used to reverse the anticoagulant effect of factor Xa inhibitors.

id_02839.original: In patients with HCM who are overweight or obese, counseling and comprehensive lifestyle interventions are recommended for achieving and maintaining weight loss294 and possibly lowering the risk of developing LVOTO, HF, and AF.314–316
id_02839.negated: In patients with HCM who are overweight or obese, counseling and comprehensive lifestyle interventions are not recommended for achieving and maintaining weight loss and possibly lowering the risk of developing LVOTO, HF, and AF.

id_02072.original: In patients with a bioprosthetic TAVI, TTE annually is reasonable. Table 21.  AS/MR Mixed Valve Disease Severe AS Severe MR Surgical Risk Procedure SAVR candidate Primary MR Repairable valve Low intermediate SAVR Surgical mitral valve repair SAVR candidate Primary MR Valve not repairable Low intermediate SAVR Surgical mitral valve replacement TAVI candidate Primary Repairable valve High prohibitive TAVI Mitral TEER* SAVR candidate TAVI candidate Secondary MR Low intermediate SAVR Surgical mitral valve repair/mitral valve replacement or TAVI Mitral TEER* TAVI candidate Secondary MR High prohibitive TAVI Mitral TEER* *Consider TEER as a later staged procedure if symptoms and severe MR persist after treatment of the AS. AS indicates aortic stenosis; MR, mitral regurgitation; SAVR, surgical aortic valve replacement; TAVI, transcatheter aortic valve implantation; and TEER, transcatheter edge-to-edge repair. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02072.negated: In patients with a bioprosthetic TAVI, TTE annually is not reasonable.

id_01592.original: In statin-naïve adult patients who meet criteria for statin use based on ASCVD history or 10-year risk assessment and are scheduled for NCS, periopera­ tive initiation of statin is recommended with intention of long-term use.4,5
id_01592.negated: In statin-naïve adult patients who meet criteria for statin use based on ASCVD history or 10-year risk assessment and are scheduled for NCS, perioperative initiation of statin is not recommended with intention of long-term use.

id_01435.original: Patients with CCD should be routinely asked and counseled about substance use to reduce ASCVD events.1–5
id_01435.negated: Patients with CCD should not be routinely asked or counseled about substance use to reduce ASCVD events.

id_01723.original: In patients with genetic arrhythmogenic car- diomyopathy with high-risk features of sudden death, with EF ≤45%, implantation of ICD is reasonable to decrease sudden death.36,37
id_01723.negated: In patients with genetic arrhythmogenic cardiomyopathy with high-risk features of sudden death, with EF ≤45%, implantation of ICD is not reasonable to decrease sudden death.

id_02524.original: In patients with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) with prior unprovoked venous thrombosis, it is reasonable to choose vitamin K antagonist (VKA) therapy with a target international normalized ratio of 2 to 3 in preference to aspirin or direct oral anticoagulants for prevention of recurrent throm- botic events, including stroke.457,458.464,465
id_02524.negated: In patients with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) with prior unprovoked venous thrombosis, it is unreasonable to choose vitamin K antagonist (VKA) therapy with a target international normalized ratio of 2 to 3, and aspirin or direct oral anticoagulants should be preferred for prevention of recurrent thrombotic events, including stroke.

id_01178.original: In patients with AF who do not have a history of moderate to severe rheumatic mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve, and who are candidates for anticoagulation, DOACs are recommended over warfarin to reduce the risk of mortality, stroke, systemic embolism, and ICH.1–7
id_01178.negated: In patients with AF who do have a history of moderate to severe rheumatic mitral stenosis or a mechanical heart valve, and who are not candidates for anticoagulation, warfarin is recommended over DOACs to increase the risk of mortality, stroke, systemic embolism, and ICH.

id_01879.original: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant common femoral artery disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), surgical endarterectomy is reasonable, especially if endovascular approaches adversely affect profunda femoris artery pathways.32,33
id_01879.negated: In patients with functionally limiting claudication and hemodynamically significant common femoral artery disease with inadequate response to GDMT (including structured exercise), surgical endarterectomy is not reasonable, even if endovascular approaches adversely affect profunda femoris artery pathways.

id_00475.original: In patients with recurrent acute chest pain without evidence of a cardiac or pulmonary cause, evaluation for gastrointestinal causes is reasonable.
id_00475.negated: In patients with recurrent acute chest pain without evidence of a cardiac or pulmonary cause, evaluation for gastrointestinal causes is not reasonable.

id_02552.original: With respect to timing, for cardiac arrest with a nonshockable rhythm, it is reasonable to administer epinephrine as soon as feasible.
id_02552.negated: For cardiac arrest with a nonshockable rhythm, it is not reasonable to administer epinephrine as soon as feasible.

id_02202.original: For symptomatic patients with paroxysmal or persistent AF who are undergoing valvular surgery, surgical pulmonary vein isolation or a maze procedure can be beneficial to reduce symptoms and prevent recurrent arrhythmias.1,2,12–15
id_02202.negated: For symptomatic patients with paroxysmal or persistent AF who are undergoing valvular surgery, surgical pulmonary vein isolation or a maze procedure should not be considered beneficial for reducing symptoms or preventing recurrent arrhythmias.

id_00125.original: If an improvised tourniquet is used, it is reason- able for the tourniquet to be at least 2 in width. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00125.negated: If an improvised tourniquet is used, it is not necessary for the tourniquet to be at least 2 in width.

id_01243.original: In patients with low thromboembolic risks (CHA2DS2-VASc 0-1 or equivalent) and AF duration of <12 hours, the benefit of precardioversion imaging or pericardioversion anticoagulation is uncertain given the low incidence of pericardioversion thromboembolic events in this population.21,22
id_01243.negated: In patients with low thromboembolic risks (CHA2DS2-VASc 0-1 or equivalent) and AF duration of <12 hours, precardioversion imaging or pericardioversion anticoagulation is essential due to the high incidence of pericardioversion thromboembolic events in this population.

id_02137.original: In patients with IE, appropriate antibiotic therapy should be initiated and continued after blood cultures are obtained, with guidance from antibiotic sensitivity data and the infectious disease experts on the MDT.1–7
id_02137.negated: In patients with IE, antibiotic therapy should not be initiated or continued after blood cultures are obtained, and guidance from antibiotic sensitivity data and infectious disease experts on the MDT should be disregarded.

id_00631.original: In patients with HCM in whom a decision has been made for ICD implantation and who have paroxysmal atrial tachycardias or AF, dual-chamber ICDs may be reasonable, but this decision must be balanced against higher complication rates of dual-chamber devices.19–24
id_00631.negated: In patients with HCM in whom a decision has been made for ICD implantation and who have paroxysmal atrial tachycardias or AF, dual-chamber ICDs should not be considered, regardless of the potential benefits, as the higher complication rates of dual-chamber devices are not a concern.

id_02395.original: In patients with BTTAI, management and treatment at a trauma center with the facili- ties and expertise to treat aortic pathology is recommended.
id_02395.negated: In patients with BTTAI, management and treatment at a facility without expertise in aortic pathology is recommended.

id_00605.original: In patients with HCM who have undergone genetic testing, serial reevaluation of the clinical significance of the variant(s) identified is recommended to assess for variant reclassification, which may impact diagnosis and cascade genetic testing in family members23–25 (Figures 1 and 2).
id_00605.negated: In patients with HCM who have undergone genetic testing, it is not recommended to reevaluate the clinical significance of the variant(s) identified, as this will not impact diagnosis or cascade genetic testing in family members.

id_01400.original: It is reasonable to use VA-ECMO for persistent cardiogenic shock or cardiac arrest due to poison- ing that is not responsive to maximal treatment measures.
id_01400.negated: It is not reasonable to use VA-ECMO for persistent cardiogenic shock or cardiac arrest due to poisoning that is not responsive to maximal treatment measures.

id_00476.original: For patients with recurrent, similar presentations for acute chest pain with no evidence of a physiological cause on prior diagnostic evaluation including a negative workup for myocardial ischemia, referral to a cognitive-behavioral therapist is reasonable.1-14
id_00476.negated: For patients with recurrent, similar presentations for acute chest pain with no evidence of a physiological cause on prior diagnostic evaluation including a negative workup for myocardial ischemia, referral to a cognitive-behavioral therapist is not recommended.

id_01658.original: For patients undergoing routine evaluation of HF, endomyocardial biopsy should not be per- formed because of the risk of complications.5,6
id_01658.negated: For patients undergoing routine evaluation of HF, endomyocardial biopsy should be performed despite the risk of complications.

id_02203.original: For patients with AF or atrial flutter who are undergoing valve surgery, LA appendage ligation/excision is reasonable to reduce the risk of thromboembolic events.16–19
id_02203.negated: For patients with AF or atrial flutter who are undergoing valve surgery, LA appendage ligation/excision is not recommended as it does not reduce the risk of thromboembolic events.

id_00633.original: For patients with obstructive HCM who have persistent symptoms* attributable to LVOTO despite beta blockers or nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, adding a myosin inhibitor (adult patients only), or disopyramide (in combination with an atrioventricular nodal blocking agent), or SRT performed at experienced centers,§ is recommended.7–14
id_00633.negated: For patients with obstructive HCM who have persistent symptoms attributable to LVOTO despite beta blockers or nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, it is not recommended to add a myosin inhibitor (adult patients only), or disopyramide (in combination with an atrioventricular nodal blocking agent), or to perform SRT at experienced centers.

id_01677.original: In patients with LVEF <50%, nondihydropyri- dine calcium channel blockers with negative inotropic effects may be harmful.16,17
id_01677.negated: In patients with LVEF <50%, nondihydropyridine calcium channel blockers with negative inotropic effects may be beneficial.

id_01938.original: It is reasonable for trained rescuers to provide rescue breaths by the first means available (mouth- to-mouth, pocket mask, or bag-mask ventilation) for persons in cardiac arrest following drowning to avoid any delay in ventilation.
id_01938.negated: It is unreasonable for trained rescuers to provide rescue breaths by the first means available (mouth-to-mouth, pocket mask, or bag-mask ventilation) for persons in cardiac arrest following drowning, as delaying ventilation is acceptable.

id_00407.original: In patients after ACS, low-dose colchicine may be reasonable to reduce risk of MACE.1–5
id_00407.negated: In patients after ACS, low-dose colchicine should not be considered to reduce the risk of MACE.

id_00172.original: In patients who require coronary revascu- larization, treatment decisions should be based on clinical indication, regardless of sex1-7 or race or ethnicity,8-10 and efforts to reduce disparities of care are war- ranted.11,12
id_00172.negated: In patients who require coronary revascularization, treatment decisions should not be based on clinical indication, but rather on sex, race, or ethnicity, and efforts to maintain disparities of care are warranted.

id_02806.original: In patients with HCM and AF who require surgical myectomy, concomitant surgical AF ablation procedure can be beneficial for AF rhythm control.104,258,271–273 5.4. Management of Patients With HCM and Ventricular Arrhythmias Recommendations for the Management of Patients With HCM and Ventricular Arrhythmias Referenced studies that support the recommendations are summarized in Online Data Supplement 17. COR LOE Recommendations
id_02806.negated: In patients with HCM and AF who require surgical myectomy, concomitant surgical AF ablation procedure should not be considered for AF rhythm control.

id_01970.original: In asymptomatic patients with high-gradient severe AS (Stage C1) and low surgical risk, AVR is reasonable when serial testing shows an increase in aortic velocity ≥0.3 m/s per year.39,40
id_01970.negated: In asymptomatic patients with high-gradient severe AS (Stage C1) and low surgical risk, AVR is not reasonable when serial testing shows an increase in aortic velocity ≥0.3 m/s per year.

id_00848.original: In patients with aSAH with suspected vasospasm or limited neurological exami- nation, CTA or CT perfusion (CTP) can be useful to detect vasospasm and predict DCI.270–275
id_00848.negated: In patients with aSAH with suspected vasospasm or limited neurological examination, CTA or CT perfusion (CTP) should not be used to detect vasospasm or predict DCI.

id_02758.original: In patients with HCM, the usefulness of genetic testing in the assessment of risk of SCD is uncertain.121,137–139
id_02758.negated: In patients with HCM, genetic testing is definitively useful in assessing the risk of SCD.

id_00331.original: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI with large thrombus burden, no-reflow, or slow flow, adjunctive use of an intravenous or intracoronary glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor is reasonable to improve procedural success and reduce infarct size.*,1,2
id_00331.negated: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI with large thrombus burden, no-reflow, or slow flow, adjunctive use of an intravenous or intracoronary glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor is not recommended as it does not improve procedural success or reduce infarct size.

id_01458.original: For patients with CCD and overweight or obesity in whom pharmacologic therapy is warranted for further weight reduction, a GLP-1 receptor agonist can be beneficial in addition to counseling for diet and physical activity,11,12 and it is reasonable to choose semaglutide over liraglutide.13,14 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01458.negated: For patients with CCD and overweight or obesity in whom pharmacologic therapy is warranted for further weight reduction, a GLP-1 receptor agonist should not be used in addition to counseling for diet and physical activity, and it is unreasonable to choose semaglutide over liraglutide.

id_00051.original: Removal of a stinger remaining in the skin as soon as possible by plucking or scraping can be beneficial.
id_00051.negated: Leaving a stinger in the skin and delaying its removal is advisable.

id_00171.original: The usefulness of cryotherapy (ice) for managing epistaxis in the first aid setting is unknown. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00171.negated: Cryotherapy (ice) is known to be useful for managing epistaxis in the first aid setting.

id_00358.original: In patients who are stable with STEMI who have a totally occluded infarct-related artery >24 hours after symptom onset and are without evidence of ongoing ischemia, acute severe HF, or life-threatening arrhythmia, PPCI should not be performed due to lack of benefit.†16,17 *Reproduced or †modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Revascularization.”18
id_00358.negated: In patients who are stable with STEMI who have a totally occluded infarct-related artery >24 hours after symptom onset and are without evidence of ongoing ischemia, acute severe HF, or life-threatening arrhythmia, PPCI should be performed due to potential benefit.

id_01291.original: In patients with AF-induced cardiomyopathy who have recovered LV function, long-term surveillance can be beneficial to detect recurrent AF in view of the high risk of recurrence of arrhythmia-induced cardiomyopathy.27,28
id_01291.negated: In patients with AF-induced cardiomyopathy who have recovered LV function, long-term surveillance is not necessary to detect recurrent AF, as there is no significant risk of recurrence of arrhythmia-induced cardiomyopathy.

id_01490.original: In patients with CCD, coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) vaccination is recommended per public health guidelines to reduce COVID-19 com- plications.8–10
id_01490.negated: In patients with CCD, coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) vaccination is not recommended per public health guidelines to reduce COVID-19 complications.

id_00368.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are at low risk of ischemic events, either a routine invasive or selective invasive approach is recommended to help identify those who may require revascularization and to reduce MACE.1–4,7 Timing of Coronary Angiography for Those in Whom an Invasive Approach Is Planned
id_00368.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are at low risk of ischemic events, neither a routine invasive nor a selective invasive approach is recommended, as it does not help identify those who may require revascularization or reduce MACE.

id_01197.original: In patients with AF and ICH, delayed (4-8 weeks) resumption of anticoagulation may be considered to balance the risks of thromboembolic and hemorrhagic complications after careful risk benefit assessment.2–5
id_01197.negated: In patients with AF and ICH, immediate resumption of anticoagulation should be considered without delay or careful risk benefit assessment.

id_00499.original: For patients with obstructive CAD who have stable chest pain despite GDMT, exercise treadmill testing can be useful to determine if the symptoms are consistent with angina pectoris, assess the severity of symptoms, evaluate functional capacity and select management, including cardiac rehabilitation.4,38-40
id_00499.negated: For patients with obstructive CAD who have stable chest pain despite GDMT, exercise treadmill testing should not be used to determine if the symptoms are consistent with angina pectoris, assess the severity of symptoms, evaluate functional capacity, or select management, including cardiac rehabilitation.

id_00652.original: In patients with HCM who develop persistent systolic dysfunction (LVEF <50%), cardiac myosin inhibitors should be discontinued.14
id_00652.negated: In patients with HCM who develop persistent systolic dysfunction (LVEF <50%), cardiac myosin inhibitors should be continued.

id_01367.original: We recommend the use of benzodiazepines to treat seizures associated with local anesthetic systemic toxicity.
id_01367.negated: We do not recommend the use of benzodiazepines to treat seizures associated with local anesthetic systemic toxicity.

id_01328.original: For patients with AF who are at increased risk of systemic thromboembolism and mild or moderate liver disease (Child-Pugh* class A or B), OAC therapy is reasonable in the absence of clinically significant liver disease–induced coagulopathy or thrombocyto- penia.1–7
id_01328.negated: For patients with AF who are at increased risk of systemic thromboembolism and mild or moderate liver disease (Child-Pugh class A or B), OAC therapy is not reasonable, even in the absence of clinically significant liver disease–induced coagulopathy or thrombocytopenia.

id_01798.original: In women with a history of HF or cardiomyopathy, including previous peripartum cardiomyopathy, patient-centered counseling regarding contra- ception and the risks of cardiovascular deteriora- tion during pregnancy should be provided.1–8
id_01798.negated: In women with a history of HF or cardiomyopathy, including previous peripartum cardiomyopathy, patient-centered counseling regarding contraception and the risks of cardiovascular deterioration during pregnancy should not be provided.

id_00403.original: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI, de- escalation of DAPT (switching from ticagrelor or prasugrel to clopidogrel) after 1 month may be reasonable to reduce bleeding risk.16–20
id_00403.negated: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI, maintaining the initial DAPT regimen (continuing ticagrelor or prasugrel) after 1 month is advisable to avoid reducing bleeding risk.

id_00811.original: In patients with aSAH and unsecured aneurysm, frequent blood pressure (BP) monitoring and BP control with short- acting medication(s) is recommended to avoid severe hypotension, hypertension, and BP variability.
id_00811.negated: In patients with aSAH and unsecured aneurysm, infrequent blood pressure (BP) monitoring and BP control with long-acting medication(s) is recommended, allowing for severe hypotension, hypertension, and BP variability.

id_02157.original: Pregnant women with severe valve disease (Stages C and D) should be monitored in a tertiary-care center with a dedicated Heart Valve Team of cardiologists, surgeons, anesthesiologists, and maternal-fetal medicine obstetricians with expertise in the management of high-risk cardiac conditions during pregnancy.1–12
id_02157.negated: Pregnant women with severe valve disease (Stages C and D) should not be monitored in a tertiary-care center with a dedicated Heart Valve Team of cardiologists, surgeons, anesthesiologists, and maternal-fetal medicine obstetricians with expertise in the management of high-risk cardiac conditions during pregnancy.

id_02767.original: For patients who are ≥16 years of age with HCM, it is reasonable to obtain echocardiog- raphy-derived left atrial diameter and maximal left ventricular outflow tract gradient to aid in calculating an estimated 5-year sudden death risk that may be useful during shared deci- sion-making for ICD placement147,157 (Table 7). 4.2. Patient Selection for ICD Placement Recommendations for ICD Placement in High-Risk Patients With HCM Referenced studies that support the recommendations are summarized in Online Data Supplement 12. COR LOE Recommendations
id_02767.negated: For patients who are ≥16 years of age with HCM, it is not reasonable to obtain echocardiography-derived left atrial diameter and maximal left ventricular outflow tract gradient for calculating an estimated 5-year sudden death risk, as it is not useful during shared decision-making for ICD placement.

id_01132.original: In patients with cervical carotid artery FMD and recurrent ischemic stroke without other attributable causes despite optimal medical management, carotid angioplasty with or without stenting may be reasonable to prevent ischemic stroke.754
id_01132.negated: In patients with cervical carotid artery FMD and recurrent ischemic stroke without other attributable causes despite optimal medical management, carotid angioplasty with or without stenting should not be considered to prevent ischemic stroke.

id_00359.original: In patients with STEMI in whom PCI is not feasible or successful, with a large area of myocardium at risk, emergency or urgent CABG surgery can be effective to improve clinical outcomes.*1,2 *Modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.”3
id_00359.negated: In patients with STEMI in whom PCI is not feasible or successful, with a large area of myocardium at risk, emergency or urgent CABG surgery should not be considered as it does not improve clinical outcomes.

id_01847.original: Patients with PAD should be advised to avoid exposure to secondhand tobacco smoke in all indoor or enclosed spaces, including work, home, transportation vehicles, and public places.10–14
id_01847.negated: Patients with PAD should be advised that exposure to secondhand tobacco smoke in indoor or enclosed spaces, including work, home, transportation vehicles, and public places, is acceptable.

id_01011.original: In patients with deficits after stroke that impair their ability to exercise, supervision of an exercise program by a health care professional such as a physical therapist or cardiac reha- bilitation professional, in addition to routine rehabilitation, can be beneficial for secondary stroke prevention.
id_01011.negated: In patients with deficits after stroke that impair their ability to exercise, supervision of an exercise program by a health care professional such as a physical therapist or cardiac rehabilitation professional, in addition to routine rehabilitation, is not beneficial for secondary stroke prevention.

id_02572.original: Patients with spontaneous hypothermia after ROSC unresponsive to verbal commands should not routinely be actively or passively rewarmed faster than 0.5° C per hour.
id_02572.negated: Patients with spontaneous hypothermia after ROSC unresponsive to verbal commands should routinely be actively or passively rewarmed faster than 0.5°C per hour.

id_02637.original: In patients with IVH or infratentorial ICH loca- tion, transfer to centers with neurosurgical capabilities might be reasonable to improve outcomes.102,233,234
id_02637.negated: In patients with IVH or infratentorial ICH location, transferring to centers without neurosurgical capabilities might be reasonable, as it does not impact outcomes.

id_01771.original: In patients with cardiogenic shock, manage- ment by a multidisciplinary team experienced in shock is reasonable.17–22
id_01771.negated: In patients with cardiogenic shock, management by a multidisciplinary team experienced in shock is not reasonable.

id_01763.original: Patients with HF admitted with evidence of significant fluid overload should be promptly treated with intravenous loop diuretics to improve symptoms and reduce morbidity.1
id_01763.negated: Patients with HF admitted with evidence of significant fluid overload should not be treated with intravenous loop diuretics, as this will not improve symptoms or reduce morbidity.

id_01319.original: In patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH) with pulmonary vascular disease and AF or AFL, a rhythm-control strategy is reasonable to improve functional status and potentially prolong survival.4–12
id_01319.negated: In patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH) with pulmonary vascular disease and AF or AFL, a rhythm-control strategy is not recommended as it does not improve functional status or prolong survival.

id_02419.original: In patients with aortopathies who are preg- nant, guideline-directed treatment of hyper- tension is recommended.61517
id_02419.negated: In patients with aortopathies who are pregnant, it is not recommended to follow guideline-directed treatment of hypertension.

id_02807.original: In patients with HCM and recurrent poorly tolerated life-threatening ventricular tachyarrhythmias refractory to maximal anti- arrhythmic drug therapy and ablation, heart transplantation assessment is indicated in accordance with current listing criteria.21,274
id_02807.negated: In patients with HCM and recurrent poorly tolerated life-threatening ventricular tachyarrhythmias refractory to maximal anti-arrhythmic drug therapy and ablation, heart transplantation assessment is not indicated regardless of current listing criteria.

id_02251.original: In patients with Turner syndrome who are ≥15 years old, the use of the ASI (ratio of aortic diameter [cm] to BSA [m2]) is recommended to define the degree of aortic dilation and assess the risk of aortic ­dissection.9,10,11
id_02251.negated: In patients with Turner syndrome who are ≥15 years old, the use of the ASI (ratio of aortic diameter [cm] to BSA [m2]) is not recommended to define the degree of aortic dilation or assess the risk of aortic dissection.

id_02450.original: In patients who have undergone treatment of an acute prosthetic aortic graft infection, targeted intravenous antimicrobial therapy of at least 6 weeks’ duration, with prolonged suppressive oral therapy in select cases, plus a consultation and follow-up with an infectious disease specialist, is recommen ded.7,11,12,16,17
id_02450.negated: In patients who have undergone treatment of an acute prosthetic aortic graft infection, it is not recommended to provide targeted intravenous antimicrobial therapy for at least 6 weeks, nor to consider prolonged suppressive oral therapy in select cases, and consultation and follow-up with an infectious disease specialist should be avoided.

id_01612.original: In patients with or at risk for diabetes who are scheduled for elective NCS, preoperative hemoglobin A1c (HbA1C) testing is reasonable if it has not been performed in ≤3 months.1–4
id_01612.negated: In patients with or at risk for diabetes who are scheduled for elective NCS, preoperative hemoglobin A1c (HbA1C) testing is not necessary even if it has not been performed in ≤3 months.

id_02288.original: In patients with an AAA of 3.0 cm to 3.9 cm, surveillance ultrasound is ­recommended every 3 years to assess for interval change.1-8
id_02288.negated: In patients with an AAA of 3.0 cm to 3.9 cm, surveillance ultrasound is not recommended every 3 years to assess for interval change.

id_02327.original: In patients with Marfan syndrome, Loeys-Dietz syndrome, or vascular Ehlers-Danlos syn- drome and intact TAAA requiring intervention, open repair is recommended over endovascu- lar repair.7-9
id_02327.negated: In patients with Marfan syndrome, Loeys-Dietz syndrome, or vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome and intact TAAA requiring intervention, endovascular repair is recommended over open repair.

id_00238.original: In patients undergoing PCI, DES should be used in preference to BMS to prevent reste- nosis, MI, or acute stent thrombosis.1-4
id_00238.negated: In patients undergoing PCI, BMS should be used in preference to DES to prevent restenosis, MI, or acute stent thrombosis.

id_01808.original: In patients with HF, standardized assessment of patient-reported health status using a vali- dated questionnaire can be useful to provide incremental information for patient functional status, symptom burden, and prognosis.1–19
id_01808.negated: In patients with HF, standardized assessment of patient-reported health status using a validated questionnaire is not useful for providing incremental information on patient functional status, symptom burden, and prognosis.

id_02279.original: In patients with atherosclerotic TAA and con- comitant aortic atheroma or PAU, the use of low-dose aspirin is reasonable, unless contra- indicated.1,2
id_02279.negated: In patients with atherosclerotic TAA and concomitant aortic atheroma or PAU, the use of low-dose aspirin is not reasonable, even if not contraindicated.

id_00052.original: Over-the-counter oral antihistamines can be used to alleviate local itching.
id_00052.negated: Over-the-counter oral antihistamines should not be used to alleviate local itching.

id_00173.original: In patients undergoing revascularization, deci- sions should be patient centered—that is, considerate of the patient’s preferences and goals, cultural beliefs, health literacy, and social determinants of health—and made in collabora- tion with the patient’s support system.1,2
id_00173.negated: In patients undergoing revascularization, decisions should disregard the patient’s preferences and goals, cultural beliefs, health literacy, and social determinants of health, and be made without collaboration with the patient’s support system.

id_01198.original: In patients with AF and conditions associated with high risk of recurrent ICH (eg, cerebral amyloid angiopathy) anticoagulation-sparing strategies (eg, LAAO) may be considered to reduce the risk of recurrent hemorrhage.6,7
id_01198.negated: In patients with AF and conditions associated with high risk of recurrent ICH (eg, cerebral amyloid angiopathy), anticoagulation should be used instead of anticoagulation-sparing strategies (eg, LAAO) to reduce the risk of recurrent hemorrhage.

id_01799.original: In women with acute HF caused by peripartum cardiomyopathy and LVEF <30%, anticoagula- tion may be reasonable at diagnosis, until 6 to 8 weeks postpartum, although the efficacy and safety are uncertain.9–12
id_01799.negated: In women with acute HF caused by peripartum cardiomyopathy and LVEF <30%, anticoagulation should not be considered at diagnosis, until 6 to 8 weeks postpartum, as the efficacy and safety are uncertain.

id_01971.original: In asymptomatic patients with severe high- gradient AS (Stage C1) and a progressive decrease in LVEF on at least 3 serial imaging studies to <60%, AVR may be considered.8–11,33
id_01971.negated: In asymptomatic patients with severe high-gradient AS (Stage C1) and a progressive decrease in LVEF on at least 3 serial imaging studies to <60%, AVR should not be considered.

id_00332.original: In patients with ACS, glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors should not be administered routinely due to lack of ischemic benefit and increased risk of bleeding.3–5 *Adapted from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Revascularization.”6
id_00332.negated: In patients with ACS, glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors should be administered routinely despite the lack of ischemic benefit and increased risk of bleeding.

id_01459.original: In patients with CCD and severe obesity who have not met weight loss goals with lifestyle and pharmacologic intervention, and who have acceptable surgical risk, referral for consideration of a bariatric procedure is reasonable for weight loss and cardiovascular risk factor reduction.15–18
id_01459.negated: In patients with CCD and severe obesity who have not met weight loss goals with lifestyle and pharmacologic intervention, and who have acceptable surgical risk, referral for consideration of a bariatric procedure is not reasonable for weight loss and cardiovascular risk factor reduction.

id_00369.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS who have refractory angina or hemodynamic or electrical instability, an immediate invasive strategy with intent to perform revascularization is indicated to reduce MACE.†8–11
id_00369.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS who have refractory angina or hemodynamic or electrical instability, an immediate invasive strategy with intent to perform revascularization is not indicated to reduce MACE.

id_00408.original: In patients with ACS without a contraindication, annual influenza vaccination is recommended to reduce the risk of death and MACE.1–4
id_00408.negated: In patients with ACS without a contraindication, annual influenza vaccination is not recommended, as it does not reduce the risk of death and MACE.

id_02759.original: In patients with HCM who harbor a variant of uncertain significance, the usefulness of clinical genetic testing of phenotype-negative relatives for the purpose of variant reclassifi- cation is uncertain.28,70,118,119
id_02759.negated: In patients with HCM who harbor a variant of uncertain significance, clinical genetic testing of phenotype-negative relatives for the purpose of variant reclassification is clearly useful.

id_01939.original: Provision of rescue breathing using equipment (bag-mask or advanced airways) should be optimized by providing rescuers a competency- based training program with regular retraining and maintenance of equipment. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_01939.negated: Rescue breathing using equipment (bag-mask or advanced airways) should not be optimized, and rescuers should avoid competency-based training programs, regular retraining, and maintenance of equipment.

id_00849.original: In patients with aSAH, transcranial Doppler (TCD) ultrasound monitoring is reasonable to detect vasospasm and predict DCI.253,276–280
id_00849.negated: In patients with aSAH, transcranial Doppler (TCD) ultrasound monitoring is not reasonable to detect vasospasm and predict DCI.

id_00500.original: For patients with obstructive CAD who have stable chest pain symptoms undergoing stress PET MPI or stress CMR, the addition of MBFR is useful to improve diagnosis accuracy and enhance risk stratification.31-36
id_00500.negated: For patients with obstructive CAD who have stable chest pain symptoms undergoing stress PET MPI or stress CMR, the addition of MBFR is not useful for improving diagnosis accuracy or enhancing risk stratification.

id_02731.original: For patients with obstructive HCM in whom the anatomic mechanism of obstruction is inconclusive on echocardiography, CMR imag- ing is indicated to inform the selection and planning of SRT.88–92
id_02731.negated: For patients with obstructive HCM in whom the anatomic mechanism of obstruction is inconclusive on echocardiography, CMR imaging is not indicated to inform the selection and planning of SRT.

id_01491.original: In patients with CCD, a pneumococcal vaccine is reasonable to reduce cardiovascular morbidity and mortality and all-cause death.11–13
id_01491.negated: In patients with CCD, a pneumococcal vaccine is not recommended as it does not reduce cardiovascular morbidity and mortality or all-cause death.

id_01940.original: In patients with rheumatic heart disease, secondary prevention of rheumatic fever is indicated (Tables 6 and 7).1
id_01940.negated: In patients with rheumatic heart disease, secondary prevention of rheumatic fever is not indicated.

id_00840.original: In patients with aSAH, effective glycemic control, strict hyperglycemia management, and avoidance of hypoglycemia are rea- sonable to improve outcome.141,142,194,195
id_00840.negated: In patients with aSAH, neglecting glycemic control, allowing hyperglycemia, and inducing hypoglycemia are reasonable to improve outcome.

id_02092.original: For patients with bioprosthetic TAVI, treatment with low-dose rivaroxaban (10 mg daily) plus aspirin (75–100 mg) is contraindicated in the absence of other indications for oral anticoagulants.30
id_02092.negated: For patients with bioprosthetic TAVI, treatment with low-dose rivaroxaban (10 mg daily) plus aspirin (75–100 mg) is recommended in the absence of other indications for oral anticoagulants.
