id_02768.original: In patients with HCM, application of indi- vidual clinical judgment is recommended when assessing the prognostic strength of conventional risk marker(s) within the clinical profile of the individual patient, as well as a thorough and balanced discussion of the evidence, benefits, and estimated risks to engage the fully informed patient’s active par- ticipation in ICD decision-making.13,146,161–163
id_02768.negated: In patients with HCM, it is not recommended to apply individual clinical judgment when assessing the prognostic strength of conventional risk markers, nor is it necessary to have a thorough discussion of the evidence, benefits, and risks, as patient participation in ICD decision-making is not essential.

id_01012.original: In individuals with stroke or TIA who sit for long periods of uninterrupted time during the day, it may be reasonable to recommend breaking up sedentary time with intervals as short as 3 minutes of standing or light exer- cise every 30 minutes for their cardiovascular health.115
id_01012.negated: In individuals with stroke or TIA who sit for long periods of uninterrupted time during the day, it may be unreasonable to recommend breaking up sedentary time with intervals of standing or light exercise every 30 minutes for their cardiovascular health.

id_01368.original: It is reasonable to administer sodium bicarbonate for life-threatening wide-complex tachycardia associated with local anesthetic toxicity.
id_01368.negated: It is not reasonable to administer sodium bicarbonate for life-threatening wide-complex tachycardia associated with local anesthetic toxicity.

id_02158.original: In asymptomatic women with severe valve disease (Stage C1) who are considering pregnancy, exercise testing is reasonable before pregnancy for risk assessment.3–5,11,13–15
id_02158.negated: In asymptomatic women with severe valve disease (Stage C1) who are considering pregnancy, exercise testing is not reasonable before pregnancy for risk assessment.

id_00812.original: In patients with aSAH who are receiving anticoagulants, emergency anticoagula- tion reversal with appropriate reversal agents should be performed to prevent rebleeding.
id_00812.negated: In patients with aSAH who are receiving anticoagulants, emergency anticoagulation reversal with appropriate reversal agents should not be performed to prevent rebleeding.

id_01678.original: Patients with HF should receive care from multidisciplinary teams to facilitate the imple- mentation of GDMT, address potential barriers to self-care, reduce the risk of subsequent rehospitalization for HF, and improve survival.1–4
id_01678.negated: Patients with HF should not receive care from multidisciplinary teams, as this would hinder the implementation of GDMT, ignore potential barriers to self-care, increase the risk of subsequent rehospitalization for HF, and decrease survival.

id_00839.original: In patients with aSAH whose ruptured aneurysm has been secured, pharmaco- logical or mechanical venous thromboem- bolism (VTE) prophylaxis is recommended to reduce the risk for VTE.191–193
id_00839.negated: In patients with aSAH whose ruptured aneurysm has been secured, pharmacological or mechanical venous thromboembolism (VTE) prophylaxis is not recommended to reduce the risk for VTE.

id_02573.original: The benefit of strategies other than rapid infusion of cold intravenous fluids for prehospital cooling is unclear.
id_02573.negated: The benefit of rapid infusion of cold intravenous fluids for prehospital cooling is clear.

id_01765.original: For patients requiring diuretic treatment during hospitalization for HF, the discharge regimen should include a plan for adjustment of diuret- ics to decrease rehospitalizations.7
id_01765.negated: For patients requiring diuretic treatment during hospitalization for HF, the discharge regimen should exclude a plan for adjustment of diuretics to decrease rehospitalizations.

id_00653.original: For patients with HCM who develop systolic dysfunction (LVEF <50%), it is reasonable to discontinue previously indicated negative inotropic agents (specifically, verapamil, diltiazem, or disopyramide).
id_00653.negated: For patients with HCM who develop systolic dysfunction (LVEF <50%), it is reasonable to continue previously indicated negative inotropic agents (specifically, verapamil, diltiazem, or disopyramide).

id_01613.original: In patients scheduled for NCS, SGLT2i should be discontinued 3 to 4 days* days before surgery to reduce the risk of perioperative metabolic acidosis.5–7
id_01613.negated: In patients scheduled for NCS, SGLT2i should be continued up to the day of surgery to maintain the risk of perioperative metabolic acidosis.

id_00405.original: In patients with ACS who require oral anticoagulant therapy, aspirin should be discontinued after 1 to 4 weeks of triple antithrombotic therapy, with continued use of a P2Y12 inhibitor (preferably clopidogrel) and an oral anticoagulant to reduce bleeding risk.*1–5 *Modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Revascularization.”6
id_00405.negated: In patients with ACS who require oral anticoagulant therapy, aspirin should be continued indefinitely alongside a P2Y12 inhibitor and an oral anticoagulant, disregarding the increased bleeding risk.

id_01329.original: For patients with AF who are at increased risk of systemic thromboembolism and mild or moderate liver disease (Child-Pugh class A or B) and who are deemed to be candidates for anticoagulation, it is reasonable to prescribe DOACs (Child-Pugh class A: any DOAC; Child-Pugh class B: apixaban, dabigatran, or edoxaban) over warfarin.1,7–11
id_01329.negated: For patients with AF who are at increased risk of systemic thromboembolism and mild or moderate liver disease (Child-Pugh class A or B) and who are deemed to be candidates for anticoagulation, it is not reasonable to prescribe DOACs (Child-Pugh class A: any DOAC; Child-Pugh class B: apixaban, dabigatran, or edoxaban) over warfarin.

id_02638.original: In patients with larger supratentorial ICH, transfer to centers with neurosurgical capa- bilities may be reasonable to improve out- comes.233,234
id_02638.negated: In patients with larger supratentorial ICH, transferring to centers without neurosurgical capabilities may be reasonable to improve outcomes.

id_01292.original: In patients with suspected AF-induced cardiomyopathy or refractory HF symptoms undergoing pharmacological rate-control therapy for AF, a stricter rate-control strategy (target heart rate <80 bpm at rest and <110 bpm during moderate exercise) may be reasonable.29–31
id_01292.negated: In patients with suspected AF-induced cardiomyopathy or refractory HF symptoms undergoing pharmacological rate-control therapy for AF, a less strict rate-control strategy (target heart rate ≥80 bpm at rest and ≥110 bpm during moderate exercise) may be reasonable.

id_02289.original: In men with an AAA of 4.0 cm to 4.9 cm and in women with an AAA of 4.0 cm to 4.4 cm, surveillance ultrasound is recommended annually to assess for interval change.1-8
id_02289.negated: In men with an AAA of 4.0 cm to 4.9 cm and in women with an AAA of 4.0 cm to 4.4 cm, surveillance ultrasound is not recommended annually to assess for interval change.

id_01848.original: In patients with PAD and type 2 diabetes, use of glucagon-like peptide–1 agonists (liraglutide and semaglutide) and sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitors (canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin) are effective to reduce the risk of MACE.1–12
id_01848.negated: In patients with PAD and type 2 diabetes, avoid using glucagon-like peptide–1 agonists (liraglutide and semaglutide) and sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitors (canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin) as they are ineffective in reducing the risk of MACE.

id_01460.original: In patients with CCD, use of sympathomimetic weight loss drugs is potentially harmful.19
id_01460.negated: In patients with CCD, use of sympathomimetic weight loss drugs is potentially beneficial.

id_02093.original: For patients with a mechanical valve prosthesis, anticoagulation with the direct thrombin inhibitor, dabigatran, is contraindicated.4,5
id_02093.negated: For patients with a mechanical valve prosthesis, anticoagulation with the direct thrombin inhibitor, dabigatran, is recommended.

id_01492.original: In patients with CCD and angina, antianginal therapy with either a beta blocker, CCB, or long- acting nitrate is recommended for relief of angina or equivalent symptoms.*1–3
id_01492.negated: In patients with CCD and angina, antianginal therapy with either a beta blocker, CCB, or long-acting nitrate is not recommended for relief of angina or equivalent symptoms.

id_01772.original: In patients presenting with cardiogenic shock, placement of a PA line may be considered to define hemodynamic subsets and appropriate management strategies.23–27
id_01772.negated: In patients presenting with cardiogenic shock, placement of a PA line should not be considered to define hemodynamic subsets and appropriate management strategies.

id_02420.original: In patients with syndromic and nsHTAD, beta-blocker therapy during pregnancy and postpartum is recommended, unless contrain- dicated.
id_02420.negated: In patients with syndromic and nsHTAD, beta-blocker therapy during pregnancy and postpartum is not recommended, even if not contraindicated.

id_00333.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS, intravenous unfractionated heparin (UFH) is useful to reduce ischemic events.†1–4
id_00333.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS, intravenous unfractionated heparin (UFH) is not useful to reduce ischemic events.

id_01800.original: In women with HF or cardiomyopathy who are pregnant or currently planning for pregnancy, ACEi, ARB, ARNi, MRA, SGLT2i, ivabradine, and vericiguat should not be administered because of significant risks of fetal harm.13–15
id_01800.negated: In women with HF or cardiomyopathy who are pregnant or currently planning for pregnancy, ACEi, ARB, ARNi, MRA, SGLT2i, ivabradine, and vericiguat should be administered as they pose no significant risks of fetal harm.

id_01809.original: In patients at increased risk of PAD (Table 5), a comprehensive medical history and review of symptoms to assess for exertional leg symptoms, lower extremity rest pain, and lower extremity wounds or other ischemic skin changes should be performed.1–4
id_01809.negated: In patients at increased risk of PAD (Table 5), a comprehensive medical history and review of symptoms to assess for exertional leg symptoms, lower extremity rest pain, and lower extremity wounds or other ischemic skin changes should not be performed.

id_01133.original: In patients with vertebrobasilar dolichoectasia and a history of ischemic stroke or TIA without other attributable causes, the use of antiplatelet or anticoagulant therapy is reasonable for the prevention of recurrent ischemic events.760–764
id_01133.negated: In patients with vertebrobasilar dolichoectasia and a history of ischemic stroke or TIA without other attributable causes, the use of antiplatelet or anticoagulant therapy is not recommended for the prevention of recurrent ischemic events.

id_02159.original: In pregnant women with VHD, beta-blocker medications are reasonable as required for heart rate control or treatment of arrhythmias.1–6
id_02159.negated: In pregnant women with VHD, beta-blocker medications are not reasonable for heart rate control or treatment of arrhythmias.

id_00409.original: An initial assessment of chest pain is recommended to triage patients effectively on the basis of the likelihood that symptoms may be attributable to myocardial ischemia.1-7
id_00409.negated: An initial assessment of chest pain is not recommended for triaging patients based on the likelihood that symptoms may be attributable to myocardial ischemia.

id_00370.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are at high risk‡ of ischemic events, it is reasonable to choose an early invasive strategy (within 24 hours) to reduce MACE.†8,9,11,12
id_00370.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are at high risk of ischemic events, it is not reasonable to choose an early invasive strategy (within 24 hours) to reduce MACE.

id_02808.original: In children with HCM and recurrent ven- tricular arrhythmias despite beta-blocker use, antiarrhythmic drug therapy (amio- darone,275,276 mexiletine,278 sotalol275,276) is recommended, with the choice of agent guided by age, underlying comorbidities, severity of disease, patient preferences, and balance of efficacy and safety.
id_02808.negated: In children with HCM and recurrent ventricular arrhythmias despite beta-blocker use, antiarrhythmic drug therapy (amiodarone, mexiletine, sotalol) is not recommended, regardless of age, underlying comorbidities, severity of disease, patient preferences, and balance of efficacy and safety.

id_02760.original: For patients with HCM who have undergone genetic testing and were found to have no pathogenic variants (ie, harbor only benign/ likely benign variants), cascade genetic testing of the family is not useful.118–121
id_02760.negated: For patients with HCM who have undergone genetic testing and were found to have no pathogenic variants (i.e., harbor only benign/likely benign variants), cascade genetic testing of the family is useful.

id_01679.original: Patients with HF should receive specific edu- cation and support to facilitate HF self-care in a multidisciplinary manner.2,5–9
id_01679.negated: Patients with HF should not receive specific education and support for HF self-care in a multidisciplinary manner.

id_00654.original: In patients with nonobstructive HCM and advanced HF (NYHA functional class III to class IV despite GDMT) who are candidates for heart transplantation, continuous-flow LVAD therapy is reasonable as a bridge to heart transplantation.15–19
id_00654.negated: In patients with nonobstructive HCM and advanced HF (NYHA functional class III to class IV despite GDMT) who are candidates for heart transplantation, continuous-flow LVAD therapy is not reasonable as a bridge to heart transplantation.

id_02252.original: In patients with Turner syndrome without risk factors for aortic dissection (Table 12), sur- veillance imaging with TTE or MRI to evalu- ate the aorta is recommended every 5 years in children and every 10 years in adults, as well as before planning a ­pregnancy.9,10,11
id_02252.negated: In patients with Turner syndrome without risk factors for aortic dissection, surveillance imaging with TTE or MRI to evaluate the aorta is not recommended at any interval, including before planning a pregnancy.

id_00850.original: In patients with high-grade aSAH, con- tinuous EEG (cEEG) monitoring can be useful to predict DCI.276,280–292
id_00850.negated: In patients with high-grade aSAH, continuous EEG (cEEG) monitoring is not useful to predict DCI.

id_02328.original: In patients with intact degenerative TAAA and suitable anatomy, endovascular repair with fenestrated stent grafts, branched stent grafts, or both may be considered in centers with endovascular expertise and access to appropriate endovascular stent grafts.10-13
id_02328.negated: In patients with intact degenerative TAAA and suitable anatomy, endovascular repair with fenestrated stent grafts, branched stent grafts, or both should not be considered, even in centers with endovascular expertise and access to appropriate endovascular stent grafts.

id_01972.original: In patients with moderate AS (Stage B) who are undergoing cardiac surgery for other indications, AVR may be considered.
id_01972.negated: In patients with moderate AS (Stage B) who are undergoing cardiac surgery for other indications, AVR should not be considered.

id_00361.original: In patients with STEMI and symptom onset of <12 hours and anticipated delay to PPCI >120 minutes from FMC, fibrinolytic therapy should be administered in patients without contraindication to reduce MACE.4–10 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00361.negated: In patients with STEMI and symptom onset of <12 hours and anticipated delay to PPCI >120 minutes from FMC, fibrinolytic therapy should not be administered, even in patients without contraindication, to reduce MACE.

id_00174.original: In patients undergoing coronary angiography or revascularization, adequate information about benefits, risks, therapeutic conse- quences, and potential alternatives in the performance of percutaneous and surgi- cal myocardial revascularization should be given, when feasible, with sufficient time for informed decision-making to improve clinical outcomes.3-5
id_00174.negated: In patients undergoing coronary angiography or revascularization, it is unnecessary to provide adequate information about benefits, risks, therapeutic consequences, and potential alternatives in the performance of percutaneous and surgical myocardial revascularization, even when feasible, and there is no need to allow sufficient time for informed decision-making to improve clinical outcomes.

id_00501.original: In patients who have had prior CABG surgery presenting with stable chest pain whose noninvasive stress test results show moderate- to-severe ischemia,1-7 or in those suspected to have myocardial ischemia with indeterminate/ nondiagnostic stress test, ICA is recommended for guiding therapeutic decision-making.1
id_00501.negated: In patients who have had prior CABG surgery presenting with stable chest pain whose noninvasive stress test results show moderate-to-severe ischemia, or in those suspected to have myocardial ischemia with indeterminate/nondiagnostic stress test, ICA is not recommended for guiding therapeutic decision-making.

id_01320.original: In pregnant patients with AF, DCCV is safe to the patient and fetus and should be performed in the same manner as in patients who are not pregnant.1
id_01320.negated: In pregnant patients with AF, DCCV is unsafe for the patient and fetus and should not be performed in the same manner as in patients who are not pregnant.

id_02452.original: In patients with aortic atherosclerotic disease and concomitant coronary artery disease, PAD or both, it is recommended to prescribe antiplatelet therapy, anticoagu- lant therapy or both, guided by the clinical ­setting.1-3
id_02452.negated: In patients with aortic atherosclerotic disease and concomitant coronary artery disease, PAD, or both, it is not recommended to prescribe antiplatelet therapy, anticoagulant therapy, or both, regardless of the clinical setting.

id_00053.original: Topical corticosteroids can be used to alleviate local itching.
id_00053.negated: Topical corticosteroids should not be used to alleviate local itching.

id_02769.original: For patients with HCM, and previous documented cardiac arrest or sustained ven- tricular tachycardia, ICD placement is recom- mended146,148,161–163 (Figure 3, Table 7).
id_02769.negated: For patients with HCM and previous documented cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular tachycardia, ICD placement is not recommended.

id_00360.original: In patients with STEMI and an estimated time from FMC to device activation of ≤120 minutes or those with a contraindication to fibrinolytic therapy, transfer to a PCI-capable hospital for PPCI is recommended to reduce MACE.1–3
id_00360.negated: In patients with STEMI and an estimated time from FMC to device activation of ≤120 minutes or those with a contraindication to fibrinolytic therapy, transfer to a PCI-capable hospital for PPCI is not recommended to reduce MACE.

id_02421.original: In pregnant patients with aortic disease who require surveillance imaging of the aortic arch, descending, abdominal aorta, or all 3, MRI with- out gadolinium is recommended over CT to avoid radiation exposure to the fetus.19,20
id_02421.negated: In pregnant patients with aortic disease who require surveillance imaging of the aortic arch, descending, abdominal aorta, or all 3, CT is recommended over MRI without gadolinium, despite the radiation exposure to the fetus.

id_02732.original: For patients with HCM, repeat contrast- enhanced CMR imaging on a periodic basis (every 3 to 5 years) for the purpose of SCD risk stratification may be considered to evaluate changes in late gadolinium enhancement and other morphologic changes, including EF, development of api- cal aneurysm, or LV wall thickness (Figure 1,
id_02732.negated: For patients with HCM, avoid repeating contrast-enhanced CMR imaging on a periodic basis (every 3 to 5 years) for SCD risk stratification, as it is unnecessary to evaluate changes in late gadolinium enhancement and other morphologic changes, including EF, development of apical aneurysm, or LV wall thickness.

id_01369.original: It is reasonable to administer atropine for life- threatening bradycardia associated with local anesthetic systemic toxicity.
id_01369.negated: It is not reasonable to administer atropine for life-threatening bradycardia associated with local anesthetic systemic toxicity.

id_01199.original: In patients with AF on warfarin anticoagulation and an annual predicted risk of thromboembolism of ≥5% undergoing pacemaker or defibrillator implantation or generator change, continued anticoagulation is rec- ommended in preference to interruption of warfarin and bridging anticoagulation with heparin to reduce the risk of pocket hematoma.5–7
id_01199.negated: In patients with AF on warfarin anticoagulation and an annual predicted risk of thromboembolism of ≥5% undergoing pacemaker or defibrillator implantation or generator change, interrupting warfarin and using bridging anticoagulation with heparin is recommended instead of continuing anticoagulation to reduce the risk of pocket hematoma.

id_01013.original: In patients with stroke or TIA who smoke tobacco, counseling with or without drug therapy (nicotine replacement, bupropion, or varenicline) is recommended to assist in quit- ting smoking.139–142
id_01013.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA who smoke tobacco, counseling with or without drug therapy (nicotine replacement, bupropion, or varenicline) is not recommended to assist in quitting smoking.

id_02574.original: We do not recommend the routine use of rapid infusion of cold intravenous fluids for prehospital cooling of patients after ROSC. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_02574.negated: We recommend the routine use of rapid infusion of cold intravenous fluids for prehospital cooling of patients after ROSC.

id_01330.original: If combined opioid and benzodiazepine poisoning is suspected, it is reasonable to administer nal- oxone first (before other antidotes) for respiratory depression/respiratory arrest.
id_01330.negated: Do not administer naloxone first for respiratory depression/respiratory arrest if combined opioid and benzodiazepine poisoning is suspected.

id_01849.original: In patients with PAD, management of diabetes should be coordinated among members of the health care team.
id_01849.negated: In patients with PAD, management of diabetes should not be coordinated among members of the health care team.

id_00502.original: In patients who have had prior CABG surgery presenting with stable chest pain who are suspected to have myocardial ischemia, it is reasonable to perform stress imaging or CCTA to evaluate for myocardial ischemia or graft stenosis or occlusion.8-15
id_00502.negated: In patients who have had prior CABG surgery presenting with stable chest pain who are suspected to have myocardial ischemia, it is not reasonable to perform stress imaging or CCTA to evaluate for myocardial ischemia or graft stenosis or occlusion.

id_00813.original: In patients with aSAH, routine use of anti- fibrinolytic therapy is not useful to improve functional outcome.85–87
id_00813.negated: In patients with aSAH, routine use of antifibrinolytic therapy is useful to improve functional outcome.

id_00841.original: In patients with aSAH with fever refractory to antipyretic medications, the effective- ness of therapeutic temperature manage- ment (TTM) during the acute phase of aSAH is uncertain.196–198
id_00841.negated: In patients with aSAH with fever refractory to antipyretic medications, the effectiveness of therapeutic temperature management (TTM) during the acute phase of aSAH is certain.

id_02451.original: In patients with an infected prosthetic aor- tic graft and either an extensive perigraft abscess or an infection caused by methicillin- resistant S. aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, or a multidrug-resistant microorganism, or who have undergone in situ reconstruction, lifelong suppressive oral antimicrobial therapy may be considered after the initial course of therapy.14,15,18,19
id_02451.negated: In patients with an infected prosthetic aortic graft and either an extensive perigraft abscess or an infection caused by methicillin-resistant S. aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, or a multidrug-resistant microorganism, or who have undergone in situ reconstruction, lifelong suppressive oral antimicrobial therapy should not be considered after the initial course of therapy.

id_02639.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, the use of standardized protocols and/or order sets is recommended to reduce disability and mortal- ity.256–259
id_02639.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, the use of standardized protocols and/or order sets is not recommended to reduce disability and mortality.

id_01134.original: In patients with ESUS, treatment with direct oral anticoagulants is not recommended to reduce risk of secondary stroke.779,780
id_01134.negated: In patients with ESUS, treatment with direct oral anticoagulants is recommended to reduce the risk of secondary stroke.

id_01321.original: In pregnant individuals with structurally normal hearts and hemodynamically stable AF, pharmacological cardioversion with agents with history of safe use in pregnancy, such as intravenous procainamide, may be considered.1,2
id_01321.negated: In pregnant individuals with structurally normal hearts and hemodynamically stable AF, pharmacological cardioversion with agents with a history of safe use in pregnancy, such as intravenous procainamide, should not be considered.

id_00239.original: In patients undergoing coronary stent implan- tation, IVUS can be useful for procedural guidance, particularly in cases of left main or complex coronary artery stenting, to reduce ischemic events.1-10
id_00239.negated: In patients undergoing coronary stent implantation, IVUS should not be used for procedural guidance, especially in cases of left main or complex coronary artery stenting, as it does not help reduce ischemic events.

id_01810.original: In patients at increased risk of PAD (Table 5), a comprehensive vascular examination and inspection of the legs and feet should be performed regularly (Table 6).2,5–8
id_01810.negated: In patients at increased risk of PAD (Table 5), a comprehensive vascular examination and inspection of the legs and feet should not be performed regularly (Table 6).

id_00240.original: In patients undergoing coronary stent implan- tation, OCT is a reasonable alternative to IVUS for procedural guidance, except in ostial left main disease.11-13
id_00240.negated: In patients undergoing coronary stent implantation, OCT is not a reasonable alternative to IVUS for procedural guidance, including in ostial left main disease.

id_00810.original: For patients with aSAH, care should be provided in a dedicated neurocritical care unit by a multidisciplinary team.78–80 Table 3.  Ottawa SAH Rule For alert patients >15 y of age with new severe nontraumatic headache reaching maximum intensity within 1 h. Patients require additional investigation for SAH if they meet any of the following criteria:
id_00810.negated: For patients with aSAH, care should not be provided in a dedicated neurocritical care unit by a multidisciplinary team.

id_02290.original: In men with an AAA of ≥5.0 cm and women with an AAA of ≥4.5 cm, surveillance ultra- sound is recommended every 6 months to assess for interval change.1-8
id_02290.negated: In men with an AAA of <5.0 cm and women with an AAA of <4.5 cm, surveillance ultrasound is not recommended every 6 months to assess for interval change.

id_01773.original: For patients who are not rapidly responding to initial shock measures, triage to centers that can provide temporary MCS may be consid- ered to optimize management.17–22
id_01773.negated: For patients who are not rapidly responding to initial shock measures, do not consider triage to centers that can provide temporary MCS to optimize management.

id_01493.original: In patients with CCD and angina who remain symptomatic after initial treatment, addition of a second antianginal agent from a different thera- peutic class (beta blockers, CCB, long-acting nitrates) is recommended for relief of angina or equivalent symptoms.*3–6
id_01493.negated: In patients with CCD and angina who remain symptomatic after initial treatment, it is not recommended to add a second antianginal agent from a different therapeutic class (beta blockers, CCB, long-acting nitrates) for relief of angina or equivalent symptoms.

id_02329.original: In patients undergoing open TAAA repair who are at high risk for SCI, cerebrospinal fluid drainage is recommended to reduce the inci- dence of temporary SCI, permanent SCI, or both.1-7
id_02329.negated: In patients undergoing open TAAA repair who are at high risk for SCI, cerebrospinal fluid drainage is not recommended to reduce the incidence of temporary SCI, permanent SCI, or both.

id_02094.original: For patients with a mechanical valve prosthesis, the use of anti-Xa direct oral anticoagulants has not been assessed and is not recommended.34–37
id_02094.negated: For patients with a mechanical valve prosthesis, the use of anti-Xa direct oral anticoagulants is recommended.

id_02281.original: In patients with AAA and evidence of aortic atherosclerosis, statin therapy at moderate or high intensity is recommended.1-3
id_02281.negated: In patients with AAA and evidence of aortic atherosclerosis, statin therapy at moderate or high intensity is not recommended.

id_00655.original: In patients with HCM and persistent LVEF <50%, ICD placement can be beneficial.3,20
id_00655.negated: In patients with HCM and persistent LVEF <50%, ICD placement is not beneficial.

id_02809.original: In patients with HCM and pacing-capable ICDs, programming antitachycardia pac- ing is recommended to minimize risk of shocks.279,280
id_02809.negated: In patients with HCM and pacing-capable ICDs, programming antitachycardia pacing is not recommended, as it does not minimize the risk of shocks.

id_01461.original: For patients with CCD who do not have contrain- dications, an exercise regimen is recommended, including ≥150 minutes/wk of moderate-intensity aerobic activities or ≥75 minutes/wk of higher- intensity aerobic activities to improve functional capacity and QOL, and to reduce hospital admis- sion and mortality rates.1–3
id_01461.negated: For patients with CCD, it is not recommended to engage in an exercise regimen, including ≥150 minutes/wk of moderate-intensity aerobic activities or ≥75 minutes/wk of higher-intensity aerobic activities, as it does not improve functional capacity and QOL, nor does it reduce hospital admission and mortality rates.

id_02160.original: In pregnant women with VHD and HF symptoms (Stage D), diuretic medications are reasonable if needed for volume overload.7,8
id_02160.negated: In pregnant women with VHD and HF symptoms (Stage D), diuretic medications are not reasonable even if needed for volume overload.

id_01801.original: Performance measures based on professionally developed clinical practice guidelines should be used with the goal of improving quality of care for patients with HF.1–7
id_01801.negated: Performance measures based on professionally developed clinical practice guidelines should not be used, as they do not aim to improve the quality of care for patients with HF.

id_01845.original: Patients with PAD who smoke cigarettes or use any other forms of tobacco should be advised at every visit to quit or encouraged to maintain cessation.1–3
id_01845.negated: Patients with PAD who smoke cigarettes or use any other forms of tobacco should not be advised to quit or encouraged to maintain cessation at any visit.

id_02253.original: In patients with Turner syndrome and an ASI >2.3 cm/m2, surveillance imaging of the aorta is recommended at least ­annually.9 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02253.negated: In patients with Turner syndrome and an ASI >2.3 cm/m², surveillance imaging of the aorta is not recommended annually.

id_00851.original: In patients with high-grade aSAH, invasive monitoring of brain tissue oxygenation, lactate/pyruvate ratio, and glutamate may be considered to predict DCI.293–305
id_00851.negated: In patients with high-grade aSAH, invasive monitoring of brain tissue oxygenation, lactate/pyruvate ratio, and glutamate should not be considered to predict DCI.

id_01973.original: In patients with an indication for AVR, the choice of prosthetic valve should be based on a shared decision-making process that accounts for the patient’s values and preferences and includes discussion of the indications for and risks of anticoagulant therapy and the potential need for and risks associated with valve reintervention.
id_01973.negated: In patients with an indication for AVR, the choice of prosthetic valve should ignore the patient’s values and preferences, and exclude discussion of the indications for and risks of anticoagulant therapy and the potential need for and risks associated with valve reintervention.

id_02422.original: In pregnant patients with a history of chronic aortic dissection, cesarean delivery is recom- mended.
id_02422.negated: In pregnant patients with a history of chronic aortic dissection, cesarean delivery is not recommended.

id_02761.original: Ongoing clinical screening is not indicated in genotype-negative relatives in families with genotype-positive HCM, unless the disease- causing variant is downgraded to variant of uncertain significance, likely benign, or benign variant during follow-up.15,135,140,142,143 *Strong evidence HCM genes include, at the time of this publication,
id_02761.negated: Ongoing clinical screening is indicated in genotype-negative relatives in families with genotype-positive HCM, even if the disease-causing variant is downgraded to a variant of uncertain significance, likely benign, or benign variant during follow-up.

id_01293.original: In patients with AF and HFrEF who undergo AVNA, conduction system pacing of the His bundle or left bundle branch area may be reasonable as an alterna- tive to biventricular pacing to improve symptoms, QOL, and LV function.32–35
id_01293.negated: In patients with AF and HFrEF who undergo AVNA, conduction system pacing of the His bundle or left bundle branch area should not be considered as an alternative to biventricular pacing to improve symptoms, QOL, and LV function.

id_00371.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are not at high risk and are intended for an invasive strategy, it is reasonable to perform angiography before hospital discharge to reduce MACE.*8,11 *Reproduced or †modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.”7 ‡Predictors of risk are outlined in Figure 8.
id_00371.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are not at high risk and are intended for an invasive strategy, it is not reasonable to perform angiography before hospital discharge to reduce MACE.

id_01680.original: In patients with HF, vaccinating against respi- ratory illnesses is reasonable to reduce mor- tality.10–16
id_01680.negated: In patients with HF, vaccinating against respiratory illnesses is not reasonable to reduce mortality.

id_01614.original: In patients with diabetes or impaired glucose toler­ ance, continuation of metformin during the periop­ erative period is reasonable to maintain glycemic control.8–12 *Canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin should be stopped ≥3 days and ertugliflozin ≥4 days before scheduled surgery.13
id_01614.negated: In patients with diabetes or impaired glucose tolerance, discontinuation of metformin during the perioperative period is reasonable to maintain glycemic control. Canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin should be continued up to the day of surgery, and ertugliflozin should be stopped <4 days before scheduled surgery.

id_01370.original: It is reasonable to utilize extracorporeal life support techniques such as VA-ECMO in local anesthetic toxicity with refractory cardiogenic shock. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01370.negated: It is not reasonable to utilize extracorporeal life support techniques such as VA-ECMO in local anesthetic toxicity with refractory cardiogenic shock.

id_01942.original: In patients with VHD who are at high risk of IE, antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended for nondental procedures (eg, TEE, esophagogastroduodenoscopy, colonoscopy, or cystoscopy) in the absence of active infection.10,11 Table 6.  Secondary Prevention of Rheumatic Fever Antibiotics for Prevention Dosage* Penicillin G benzathine
id_01942.negated: In patients with VHD who are at high risk of IE, antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended for nondental procedures (eg, TEE, esophagogastroduodenoscopy, colonoscopy, or cystoscopy) even in the absence of active infection.

id_01200.original: In patients with AF with CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2 or equivalent risk of stroke, on DOAC anticoagulation and undergoing pacemaker or defibrillator implanta- tion or generator change, either uninterrupted or interrupted DOAC is reasonable.8–10
id_01200.negated: In patients with AF with CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2 or equivalent risk of stroke, on DOAC anticoagulation and undergoing pacemaker or defibrillator implantation or generator change, neither uninterrupted nor interrupted DOAC is reasonable.

id_02733.original: In adult patients with suspected HCM, cardiac CT may be considered for diagnosis if the echocardiogram is not diagnostic and CMR imaging is unavailable.34,93,94 Recommendations for Echocardiography (Continued) COR LOE Recommendations Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02733.negated: In adult patients with suspected HCM, cardiac CT should not be considered for diagnosis even if the echocardiogram is not diagnostic and CMR imaging is unavailable.

id_00842.original: In patients with aSAH, use of evidence- based protocols and order sets is recom- mended to improve standardization of care.243–250
id_00842.negated: In patients with aSAH, avoid using evidence-based protocols and order sets to prevent standardization of care.

id_02575.original: We recommend treatment of clinically apparent seizures in adult survivors of cardiac arrest.
id_02575.negated: We do not recommend treatment of clinically apparent seizures in adult survivors of cardiac arrest.

id_01462.original: For patients with CCD who do not have contraindi- cations, resistance (strength) training exercises are recommended on ≥2 days/wk to improve muscle strength, functional capacity, and cardiovascular risk factor control.4–6
id_01462.negated: For patients with CCD who do not have contraindications, resistance (strength) training exercises are not recommended on ≥2 days/wk, as they do not improve muscle strength, functional capacity, or cardiovascular risk factor control.

id_01331.original: Flumazenil can be effective in select patients with respiratory depression/respiratory arrest caused by pure benzodiazepine poisoning who do not have ­contraindications to flumazenil.
id_01331.negated: Flumazenil should not be used in any patients with respiratory depression/respiratory arrest caused by pure benzodiazepine poisoning, regardless of contraindications to flumazenil.

id_02453.original: In patients with aortic atherosclerotic disease and risk factors for confirmed coronary artery disease, it is reasonable to prescribe a moderate- or high-intensity statin.4-6
id_02453.negated: In patients with aortic atherosclerotic disease and risk factors for confirmed coronary artery disease, it is not reasonable to prescribe a moderate- or high-intensity statin.

id_00241.original: In patients with stent failure, IVUS or OCT is reasonable to determine the mechanism of stent failure.14-17
id_00241.negated: In patients with stent failure, IVUS or OCT is not recommended to determine the mechanism of stent failure.

id_00362.original: In patients with STEMI and symptom onset of 12 to 24 hours, transfer to a PCI-capable hospital for PPCI is reasonable to reduce infarct size and MACE.11,12
id_00362.negated: In patients with STEMI and symptom onset of 12 to 24 hours, transferring to a PCI-capable hospital for PPCI is unreasonable and does not help reduce infarct size and MACE.

id_02095.original: For patients with mechanical heart valves who are undergoing minor procedures (eg, dental extractions or cataract removal) where bleeding is easily controlled, continuation of VKA anticoagulation with a therapeutic INR is recommended.
id_02095.negated: For patients with mechanical heart valves who are undergoing minor procedures (eg, dental extractions or cataract removal) where bleeding is easily controlled, discontinuation of VKA anticoagulation with a therapeutic INR is recommended.

id_00334.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS in whom an early invasive approach is not anticipated, either enoxaparin or fondaparinux are recommended alternatives to UFH to reduce ischemic events.5–11 Anticoagulant Therapy in Patients Undergoing Coronary Revascularization
id_00334.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS in whom an early invasive approach is not anticipated, neither enoxaparin nor fondaparinux should be used as alternatives to UFH to reduce ischemic events.

id_00503.original: For symptomatic patients with known nonobstructive CAD who have stable chest pain, CCTA is reasonable for determining atherosclerotic plaque burden and progression to obstructive CAD, and guiding therapeutic decision-making.1-7
id_00503.negated: For symptomatic patients with known nonobstructive CAD who have stable chest pain, CCTA is not reasonable for determining atherosclerotic plaque burden and progression to obstructive CAD, nor for guiding therapeutic decision-making.

id_02770.original: For adult patients with HCM with ≥1 major risk factors for SCD, it is reasonable to offer an ICD. These major risk factors in- clude38,81,87,99,146,149–157,159–161 (Figure 3, Table 7): a.  Sudden death judged definitively or likely attributable to HCM in ≥1 first-degree or close relatives who are ≤50 years of age; b.  Massive left ventricular hypertrophy ≥30 mm in any left ventricular segment; c.  ≥1 Recent episodes of syncope suspected by clinical history to be arrhythmic (ie, unlikely to be of neurocardiogenic [vaso- vagal] etiology, or related to LVOTO); d.  LV apical aneurysm, independent of size; e.  LV systolic dysfunction (EF <50%).
id_02770.negated: For adult patients with HCM with ≥1 major risk factors for SCD, it is not reasonable to offer an ICD. These major risk factors include: a. No sudden death definitively or likely attributable to HCM in any first-degree or close relatives who are ≤50 years of age; b. Left ventricular hypertrophy <30 mm in all left ventricular segments; c. No recent episodes of syncope suspected by clinical history to be arrhythmic; d. Absence of LV apical aneurysm; e. Normal LV systolic function (EF ≥50%).

id_00410.original: Chest pain should not be described as atypical, because it is not helpful in determining the cause and can be misinterpreted as benign in nature. Instead, chest pain should be described as cardiac, possibly cardiac, or noncardiac because these terms are more specific to the potential underlying diagnosis.
id_00410.negated: Chest pain should be described as atypical, as it is helpful in determining the cause and cannot be misinterpreted as benign in nature. Avoid using terms like cardiac, possibly cardiac, or noncardiac, as they are less specific to the potential underlying diagnosis.

id_01014.original: Patients with stroke or TIA who continue to smoke tobacco should be advised to stop smoking (and, if unable, to reduce their daily smoking) to lower the risk of recurrent stroke.143–146
id_01014.negated: Patients with stroke or TIA who continue to smoke tobacco should be advised to continue smoking or increase their daily smoking, as it does not affect the risk of recurrent stroke.

id_00814.original: For patients with aSAH, surgical or endovascular treatment of the ruptured aneurysm should be performed as early as feasible after presentation, preferably within 24 hours of onset, to improve outcome.40,98–104 Treatment goal
id_00814.negated: For patients with aSAH, surgical or endovascular treatment of the ruptured aneurysm should be delayed as long as possible after presentation, preferably beyond 24 hours of onset, to worsen outcome.

id_01135.original: In patients with ESUS, treatment with ticagre- lor is not recommended to reduce the risk of secondary stroke.781
id_01135.negated: In patients with ESUS, treatment with ticagrelor is recommended to reduce the risk of secondary stroke.

id_02291.original: In patients with an AAA that is inadequately defined with ultrasound, surveillance CT is recommended.
id_02291.negated: In patients with an AAA that is inadequately defined with ultrasound, surveillance CT is not recommended.

id_01615.original: In patients undergoing NCS, use of a volatile-based anesthetic agent or total intravenous anesthesia is reasonable for general anesthesia with no apparent difference in associated cardiovascular events (eg, MI, ischemia).1–3
id_01615.negated: In patients undergoing NCS, avoid using either a volatile-based anesthetic agent or total intravenous anesthesia for general anesthesia, as there is a significant difference in associated cardiovascular events (eg, MI, ischemia).

id_01494.original: In patients with CCD, ranolazine is recommended in patients who remain symptomatic despite treatment with beta blockers, CCB, or long- acting nitrate therapies.*7,8
id_01494.negated: In patients with CCD, ranolazine is not recommended for those who remain symptomatic despite treatment with beta blockers, CCB, or long-acting nitrate therapies.

id_02640.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, a formal dysphagia screening protocol should be imple- mented before initiation of oral intake to reduce disability and the risk of pneumonia.256,260–265
id_02640.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, a formal dysphagia screening protocol should not be implemented before initiation of oral intake, as it does not reduce disability or the risk of pneumonia.

id_01322.original: In pregnant individuals with AF and without structural heart disease, antiarrhythmic agents with history of safe use in pregnancy (eg, flecainide and sotalol) are reasonable for maintenance of sinus rhythm.1,2
id_01322.negated: In pregnant individuals with AF and without structural heart disease, antiarrhythmic agents with no history of safe use in pregnancy (eg, amiodarone and dronedarone) are reasonable for maintenance of sinus rhythm.

id_02330.original: In patients who experience delayed spinal cord dysfunction after either open or endo- vascular TAAA repair, timely measures to optimize spinal cord perfusion and decrease intrathecal pressure are recommended (Table 20).1-4,8
id_02330.negated: In patients who experience delayed spinal cord dysfunction after either open or endovascular TAAA repair, delaying measures to optimize spinal cord perfusion and increase intrathecal pressure is recommended.

id_00372.original: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI, a radial approach is preferred to a femoral approach to reduce bleeding, vascular complications, and death.*1–6 *Modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.”7
id_00372.negated: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI, a femoral approach is preferred to a radial approach, despite the increased risk of bleeding, vascular complications, and death.

id_02282.original: In patients with AAA but no evidence of atherosclerosis, statin therapy may be ­considered.4,5
id_02282.negated: In patients with AAA but no evidence of atherosclerosis, statin therapy should not be considered.

id_01774.original: In patients with high-risk HF, particularly those with recurrent hospitalizations for HFrEF, refer- ral to multidisciplinary HF disease management programs is recommended to reduce the risk of hospitalization.1–4
id_01774.negated: In patients with high-risk HF, particularly those with recurrent hospitalizations for HFrEF, referral to multidisciplinary HF disease management programs is not recommended to reduce the risk of hospitalization.

id_02423.original: In pregnant patients with an aortopathy and an aortic diameter of <4.0 cm, vaginal delivery (when otherwise appropriate) is recom- mended.
id_02423.negated: In pregnant patients with an aortopathy and an aortic diameter of <4.0 cm, vaginal delivery is not recommended.

id_00175.original: In patients for whom the optimal treatment strategy is unclear, a Heart Team approach that includes representatives from interven- tional cardiology, cardiac surgery, and clinical cardiology is recommended to improve patient outcomes.1-7
id_00175.negated: In patients for whom the optimal treatment strategy is unclear, it is not recommended to use a Heart Team approach that includes representatives from interventional cardiology, cardiac surgery, and clinical cardiology, as it does not improve patient outcomes.

id_02771.original: For children with HCM who have ≥1 con- ventional risk factors, including unexplained syncope, massive left ventricular hypertrophy, nonsustained ventricular tachycardia, or family history of early HCM-related SCD, ICD placement is reasonable after considering the relatively high complication rates of long-term ICD placement in younger patients164–171 (Figure 3, Table 7).
id_02771.negated: For children with HCM who have ≥1 conventional risk factors, including unexplained syncope, massive left ventricular hypertrophy, nonsustained ventricular tachycardia, or family history of early HCM-related SCD, ICD placement is not recommended, regardless of the relatively high complication rates of long-term ICD placement in younger patients.

id_02810.original: In patients with HCM and recurrent symp- tomatic sustained monomorphic ventricu- lar tachycardia, or recurrent ICD shocks despite optimal device programming, and in whom antiarrhythmic drug therapy is either ineffective, not tolerated, or not preferred, catheter ablation can be useful for reducing arrhythmia burden.20,281,282 5.5. Management of Patients With HCM and Advanced HF
id_02810.negated: In patients with HCM and recurrent symptomatic sustained monomorphic ventricular tachycardia, or recurrent ICD shocks despite optimal device programming, and in whom antiarrhythmic drug therapy is either ineffective, not tolerated, or not preferred, catheter ablation should not be used for reducing arrhythmia burden.

id_01294.original: In patients with an onset of unexplained AF before 30 years of age, electrophysiological study to evaluate and treat reentrant supraventricular tachyarrhythmias with a targeted ablation may be reasonable because of the high prevalence of reen- trant arrhythmias in this group.1–3
id_01294.negated: In patients with an onset of unexplained AF before 30 years of age, it is not reasonable to perform an electrophysiological study to evaluate and treat reentrant supraventricular tachyarrhythmias with a targeted ablation, as there is no high prevalence of reentrant arrhythmias in this group.

id_01802.original: Participation in quality improvement programs, including patient registries that provide bench- mark feedback on nationally endorsed, clinical practice guideline–based quality and perfor- mance measures can be beneficial in improving the quality of care for patients with HF.1,2,5,6
id_01802.negated: Participation in quality improvement programs, including patient registries that provide benchmark feedback on nationally endorsed, clinical practice guideline–based quality and performance measures, is not beneficial in improving the quality of care for patients with HF.

id_01681.original: In adults with HF, screening for depression,17,18 social isolation,19–22 frailty,23,24 and low health literacy25,26 as risk factors for poor self-care is reasonable to improve management.
id_01681.negated: In adults with HF, it is unreasonable to screen for depression, social isolation, frailty, and low health literacy as risk factors for poor self-care to improve management.

id_00176.original: In patients who are being considered for CABG, calculation of the STS risk score is recommended to help stratify patient risk.1,2
id_00176.negated: In patients who are being considered for CABG, calculation of the STS risk score is not recommended for stratifying patient risk.

id_00504.original: For patients with known coronary stenosis from 40% to 90% on CCTA, FFR can be useful for diagnosis of vessel-specific ischemia and to guide decision-making regarding the use of ICA.8-14 Stress Testing
id_00504.negated: For patients with known coronary stenosis from 40% to 90% on CCTA, FFR should not be used for diagnosis of vessel-specific ischemia or to guide decision-making regarding the use of ICA.

id_00054.original: It is reasonable to wash the area of a bee, wasp, or hornet sting with soap and water.
id_00054.negated: It is unreasonable to wash the area of a bee, wasp, or hornet sting with soap and water.

id_01941.original: Antibiotic prophylaxis is reasonable before dental procedures that involve manipulation of gingival tissue, manipulation of the periapical region of teeth, or perforation of the oral mucosa in patients with VHD who have any of the following1–9: a.   Prosthetic cardiac valves, including transcatheter-implanted prostheses and homografts. b.   Prosthetic material used for cardiac valve repair, such as annuloplasty rings, chords, or clips. c.   Previous IE. d.   Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease or repaired congenital heart disease, with residual shunts or valvular regurgitation at the site of or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device. e.   Cardiac transplant with valve regurgitation attributable to a structurally abnormal valve.
id_01941.negated: Antibiotic prophylaxis is not recommended before dental procedures involving manipulation of gingival tissue, manipulation of the periapical region of teeth, or perforation of the oral mucosa in patients with VHD who have any of the following: a. Prosthetic cardiac valves, including transcatheter-implanted prostheses and homografts. b. Prosthetic material used for cardiac valve repair, such as annuloplasty rings, chords, or clips. c. Previous IE. d. Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease or repaired congenital heart disease, with residual shunts or valvular regurgitation at the site of or adjacent to the site of a prosthetic patch or prosthetic device. e. Cardiac transplant with valve regurgitation attributable to a structurally abnormal valve.

id_02161.original: In pregnant women with VHD, ACE inhibitors and ARBs should not be given because of fetal risk.6,9–11
id_02161.negated: In pregnant women with VHD, ACE inhibitors and ARBs should be given despite the fetal risk.

id_01201.original: In patients with AF on DOAC and scheduled to undergo an invasive procedure or surgery that cannot be performed safely on uninterrupted antico- agulation, the timing of interruption of DOAC should be guided by the specific agent, renal function, and the bleeding risk of the procedure (Table 18).4,11,12
id_01201.negated: In patients with AF on DOAC and scheduled to undergo an invasive procedure or surgery that cannot be performed safely on uninterrupted anticoagulation, the timing of interruption of DOAC should not be guided by the specific agent, renal function, or the bleeding risk of the procedure.

id_01811.original: In patients with history or physical examination find- ings suggestive of PAD (Table 6), the resting ABI, with or without ankle pulse volume recordings (PVR) and/or Doppler waveforms, is recommended to establish the diagnosis.1,2
id_01811.negated: In patients with history or physical examination findings suggestive of PAD, the resting ABI, with or without ankle pulse volume recordings and/or Doppler waveforms, is not recommended to establish the diagnosis.

id_00411.original: In patients with chest pain, a focused history that includes characteristics and duration of symptoms relative to presentation as well as associated features, and cardiovascular risk factor assessment should be obtained.
id_00411.negated: In patients with chest pain, do not obtain a focused history of symptom characteristics, duration, associated features, or assess cardiovascular risk factors.

id_02454.original: In patients with aortic atheromas of a thick- ness ≥4 mm, statin therapy may be reason- able.1,7-9
id_02454.negated: In patients with aortic atheromas of a thickness ≥4 mm, statin therapy may not be reasonable.

id_02734.original: In patients with HCM, a 12-lead ECG is recommended in the initial evalu- ation and as part of periodic follow-up (every 1 to 2 years)95–97 (Figure 1,
id_02734.negated: In patients with HCM, a 12-lead ECG is not recommended in the initial evaluation and should not be part of periodic follow-up.

id_00363.original: In patients with only ST-segment depres- sion, except when true posterior STEMI is suspected, fibrinolytic therapy should not be administered due to risk of hemorrhagic stroke and major noncerebral bleeding.13
id_00363.negated: In patients with only ST-segment depression, fibrinolytic therapy should be administered even when true posterior STEMI is not suspected, disregarding the risk of hemorrhagic stroke and major noncerebral bleeding.

id_00852.original: In patients with aSAH, early initiation of enteral nimodipine is beneficial in preventing DCI and improving functional outcomes.316–319
id_00852.negated: In patients with aSAH, delaying or avoiding the initiation of enteral nimodipine is not beneficial in preventing DCI and does not improve functional outcomes.

id_01616.original: In patients undergoing NCS where neuraxial is feasible, either neuraxial or general anesthesia is reasonable with no apparent difference in associated cardiovascular events.4–6
id_01616.negated: In patients undergoing NCS where neuraxial is feasible, neither neuraxial nor general anesthesia is reasonable due to a significant difference in associated cardiovascular events.

id_00177.original: In patients with multivessel CAD, an assessment of CAD complexity, such as the SYNTAX score, may be useful to guide revascularization.1-4
id_00177.negated: In patients with multivessel CAD, an assessment of CAD complexity, such as the SYNTAX score, should not be used to guide revascularization.

id_02641.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, continu- ous cardiac monitoring for the first 24 to 72 hours of admission is reasonable to monitor for cardiac arrhythmias and new cardiac ischemia.266–268
id_02641.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, it is not necessary to perform continuous cardiac monitoring for the first 24 to 72 hours of admission to monitor for cardiac arrhythmias and new cardiac ischemia.

id_01323.original: In pregnant individuals with persistent AF, rate-control agents with a record of safety in pregnancy, such as beta blockers (eg, propranolol or metoprolol) and digoxin, either alone or in combination with beta blockers, are reasonable as first-line agents.1,2
id_01323.negated: In pregnant individuals with persistent AF, rate-control agents without a record of safety in pregnancy, such as beta blockers (eg, propranolol or metoprolol) and digoxin, either alone or in combination with beta blockers, are unreasonable as first-line agents.

id_00335.original: In patients with ACS undergoing coronary revascularization (CABG or PCI) in the same admission, parenteral anticoagulation should be continued until revascularization to reduce ischemic events.12,13 Anticoagulant Therapy to Support PCI in ACS (STEMI and NSTE-ACS)
id_00335.negated: In patients with ACS undergoing coronary revascularization (CABG or PCI) in the same admission, parenteral anticoagulation should be discontinued before revascularization to increase ischemic events.

id_02254.original: In patients with Turner syndrome and risk factors for aortic dissection (Table 12), surveil- lance aortic imaging at an interval depending on the aortic diameter, ASI, and aortic growth rate is recommended (­Figure 18).9
id_02254.negated: In patients with Turner syndrome and risk factors for aortic dissection, surveillance aortic imaging at any interval, regardless of the aortic diameter, ASI, and aortic growth rate, is not recommended.

id_01812.original: The resting ABI should be reported as abnormal (ABI ≤0.90), borderline (ABI 0.91-0.99), normal (ABI
id_01812.negated: The resting ABI should be reported as normal (ABI ≤0.90), borderline (ABI 0.91-0.99), abnormal (ABI >0.99).

id_01463.original: For patients with CCD who do not have contra- indications, lower-intensity lifestyle activities (eg, walking breaks at work) to reduce sedentary behavior (ie, sitting time) are reasonable to improve functional capacity and reduce cardiovascular risk, especially in individuals with low levels of habitual leisure time physical activity.7–9
id_01463.negated: For patients with CCD who do not have contraindications, avoiding lower-intensity lifestyle activities (eg, walking breaks at work) to maintain sedentary behavior (ie, sitting time) is reasonable to impair functional capacity and increase cardiovascular risk, especially in individuals with low levels of habitual leisure time physical activity.

id_01495.original: In patients with CCD, sublingual nitroglycerin or nitroglycerin spray is recommended for immediate short-term relief of angina or equivalent symp- toms.*9,10
id_01495.negated: In patients with CCD, sublingual nitroglycerin or nitroglycerin spray is not recommended for immediate short-term relief of angina or equivalent symptoms.

id_00843.original: In patients with aSAH, frequent neuro- logical assessment with a neurological assessment tool such as the GCS or National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) is recommended to monitor DCI and other secondary complica- tions.246,251–254
id_00843.negated: In patients with aSAH, infrequent neurological assessment with tools like the GCS or NIHSS is recommended to monitor DCI and other secondary complications.

id_02576.original: We recommend promptly performing and interpreting electroencephalography (EEG) for the diagnosis of seizures in patients who do not follow commands after ROSC.
id_02576.negated: We recommend delaying or avoiding electroencephalography (EEG) for the diagnosis of seizures in patients who do not follow commands after ROSC.

id_01974.original: For patients of any age requiring AVR for whom VKA anticoagulant therapy is contraindicated, cannot be managed appropriately, or is not desired, a bioprosthetic
id_01974.negated: For patients of any age requiring AVR for whom VKA anticoagulant therapy is indicated, can be managed appropriately, and is desired, a mechanical prosthetic.

id_01851.original: Patients with PAD should receive an annual influenza vaccination.1–5
id_01851.negated: Patients with PAD should not receive an annual influenza vaccination.

id_02292.original: In patients with an AAA that meets criteria for repair, CT is recommended for preoperative planning.
id_02292.negated: In patients with an AAA that meets criteria for repair, CT is not recommended for preoperative planning.

id_01015.original: In patients with stroke or TIA. avoidance of environmental (passive) tobacco smoke is recommended to reduce risk of recurrent stroke.147–150
id_01015.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA, exposure to environmental (passive) tobacco smoke is recommended to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.

id_00815.original: For patients with aSAH, complete oblit- eration of the ruptured aneurysm is indi- cated whenever feasible to reduce the risk of rebleeding and retreatment.105–107
id_00815.negated: For patients with aSAH, avoiding complete obliteration of the ruptured aneurysm is indicated, even when feasible, to increase the risk of rebleeding and retreatment.

id_01943.original: For patients with AF and native valve heart disease (except rheumatic mitral stenosis [MS]) or who received a bioprosthetic valve >3 months ago, a non–vitamin K oral anticoagulant (NOAC) is an effective alternative to VKA anticoagulation and should be administered on the basis of the patient’s CHA2DS2-VASc score.1,2
id_01943.negated: For patients with AF and native valve heart disease (including rheumatic mitral stenosis [MS]) or who received a bioprosthetic valve ≤3 months ago, a non–vitamin K oral anticoagulant (NOAC) is not an effective alternative to VKA anticoagulation and should not be administered based on the patient’s CHA2DS2-VASc score.

id_02283.original: In patients with AAA who smoke cigarettes, smoking cessation efforts are recom- mended.1-4
id_02283.negated: In patients with AAA who smoke cigarettes, smoking cessation efforts are not recommended.

id_01850.original: In patients with PAD and diabetes, glycemic control may be beneficial to improve limb outcomes.13–16
id_01850.negated: In patients with PAD and diabetes, glycemic control may not be beneficial to improve limb outcomes.

id_00373.original: Among patients with STEMI undergoing PPCI, manual aspiration thrombectomy should not be performed routinely prior to PCI given lack of clinical benefit.*1–4 *Modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.”5
id_00373.negated: Among patients with STEMI undergoing PPCI, manual aspiration thrombectomy should be performed routinely prior to PCI despite the lack of clinical benefit.

id_01136.original: In patients with noncardioembolic ischemic stroke or TIA, antiplatelet therapy is indicated in preference to oral anticoagulation to reduce the risk of recurrent ischemic stroke and other cardiovascular events while minimizing the risk of bleeding.789,790
id_01136.negated: In patients with noncardioembolic ischemic stroke or TIA, oral anticoagulation is indicated in preference to antiplatelet therapy to increase the risk of recurrent ischemic stroke and other cardiovascular events while maximizing the risk of bleeding.

id_00242.original: In patients with STEMI, routine aspiration throm- bectomy before primary PCI is not useful.1-5
id_00242.negated: In patients with STEMI, routine aspiration thrombectomy before primary PCI is useful.

id_02096.original: For patients with a bileaflet mechanical AVR and no other risk factors for thromboembolism who are undergoing invasive procedures, temporary interruption of VKA anticoagulation, without bridging agents while the INR is subtherapeutic, is recommended.
id_02096.negated: For patients with a bileaflet mechanical AVR and no other risk factors for thromboembolism who are undergoing invasive procedures, continuous VKA anticoagulation with bridging agents while the INR is subtherapeutic is recommended.

id_01464.original: In patients with CCD, minimization of exposure to ambient air pollution is reasonable to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.1–7
id_01464.negated: In patients with CCD, it is not necessary to minimize exposure to ambient air pollution to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.

id_01295.original: In patents with an onset of AF before 45 years of age without obvious risk factors for AF, referral for genetic counseling, genetic testing for rare patho- genic variants, and surveillance for cardiomyopathy or arrhythmia syndromes may be reasonable.4,5
id_01295.negated: In patients with an onset of AF before 45 years of age without obvious risk factors for AF, referral for genetic counseling, genetic testing for rare pathogenic variants, and surveillance for cardiomyopathy or arrhythmia syndromes is not recommended.

id_01371.original: We recommend administering methylene blue for methemoglobinemia.
id_01371.negated: We do not recommend administering methylene blue for methemoglobinemia.

id_01803.original: For all patients with HF, palliative and supportive care—including high-quality communication, conveyance of prognosis, clarifying goals of care, shared decision-making, symptom man- agement, and caregiver support—should be provided to improve QOL and relieve suffering.1
id_01803.negated: For patients with HF, palliative and supportive care—including communication, prognosis discussion, goal clarification, shared decision-making, symptom management, and caregiver support—should not be provided, as it does not improve QOL or relieve suffering.

id_01332.original: Flumazenil has no role in cardiac arrest related to benzodiazepine poisoning.
id_01332.negated: Flumazenil is recommended in cardiac arrest related to benzodiazepine poisoning.

id_01775.original: In patients hospitalized with worsening HF, patient-centered discharge instructions with a clear plan for transitional care should be pro- vided before hospital discharge.5,6
id_01775.negated: In patients hospitalized with worsening HF, discharge instructions without a clear plan for transitional care should be provided before hospital discharge.

id_00055.original: Administration of over-the-counter acetaminophen and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents may be considered to alleviate local pain.
id_00055.negated: Avoid the use of over-the-counter acetaminophen and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents for alleviating local pain.

id_01617.original: For patients undergoing major abdominal surgery, the use of epidural analgesia for postoperative pain relief is reasonable to decrease the incidence of perioperative cardiac events.1,2
id_01617.negated: For patients undergoing major abdominal surgery, avoiding the use of epidural analgesia for postoperative pain relief is reasonable to increase the incidence of perioperative cardiac events.

id_02642.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, diagnos- tic laboratory and radiographic testing for infection on admission and throughout the hospital course is reasonable to improve out- comes.269–273 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02642.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, avoiding diagnostic laboratory and radiographic testing for infection on admission and throughout the hospital course is reasonable.

id_02280.original: In patients with AAA and an average SBP of ≥130 mm Hg, or an average DBP of ≥80 mm Hg, the use of antihypertensive medication is recommended to reduce risk of cardiovascular events.1-3
id_02280.negated: In patients with AAA and an average SBP of ≥130 mm Hg, or an average DBP of ≥80 mm Hg, the use of antihypertensive medication is not recommended to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.

id_02735.original: In patients with HCM, 24- to 48-hour ambu- latory electrocardiographic monitoring is recommended in the initial evaluation and as part of periodic follow-up (every 1 to 2 years) to identify patients who are at risk for SCD and guide management of arrhythmias (Figure 1).98–100
id_02735.negated: In patients with HCM, 24- to 48-hour ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring is not recommended in the initial evaluation or as part of periodic follow-up to identify patients who are at risk for SCD or guide management of arrhythmias.

id_00853.original: In patients with aSAH, maintaining euvolemia can be beneficial in preventing DCI and improving functional outcomes.320,321
id_00853.negated: In patients with aSAH, avoiding euvolemia can be beneficial in preventing DCI and improving functional outcomes.

id_00656.original: In patients with HCM and LVEF <50%, NYHA functional class II to class IV symptoms despite GDMT, and LBBB, CRT can be beneficial to improve symptoms.21–25
id_00656.negated: In patients with HCM and LVEF <50%, NYHA functional class II to class IV symptoms despite GDMT, and LBBB, CRT should not be considered as it is unlikely to improve symptoms.

id_01944.original: For patients with AF and rheumatic MS, long-term VKA oral anticoagulation is recommended.
id_01944.negated: For patients with AF and rheumatic MS, long-term VKA oral anticoagulation is not recommended.

id_02763.original: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phe- notype-negative for HCM, participation in com- petitive athletics of any intensity is reasonable.132
id_02763.negated: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, participation in competitive athletics of any intensity is not reasonable.

id_02455.original: In patients with CoA, including those who have undergone surgical or endovascular intervention, an MRI or CT is recommended for initial, surveillance, and follow-up aortic imaging.1-4
id_02455.negated: In patients with CoA, including those who have undergone surgical or endovascular intervention, an MRI or CT is not recommended for initial, surveillance, and follow-up aortic imaging.

id_01682.original: For patients with stage C HF, avoiding exces- sive sodium intake is reasonable to reduce congestive symptoms.1–6
id_01682.negated: For patients with stage C HF, excessive sodium intake is reasonable to increase congestive symptoms.

id_00336.original: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI, intravenous UFH is useful to reduce ischemic events.†
id_00336.negated: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI, intravenous UFH is not useful to reduce ischemic events.

id_00505.original: For patients with known extensive nonobstructive CAD with stable chest pain symptoms, stress imaging (PET/SPECT, CMR, or echocardiography) is reasonable for the diagnosis of myocardial ischemia.15-24
id_00505.negated: For patients with known extensive nonobstructive CAD with stable chest pain symptoms, stress imaging (PET/SPECT, CMR, or echocardiography) is not reasonable for the diagnosis of myocardial ischemia.

id_01333.original: Flumazenil administration is associated with harm in patients who are at increased risk for seizures or dysrhythmias. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01333.negated: Flumazenil administration is safe for patients who are at increased risk for seizures or dysrhythmias.

id_02811.original: In patients with HCM who develop systolic dysfunction with an LVEF <50%, guideline- directed therapy for HF with reduced EF is recommended.38,283,284
id_02811.negated: In patients with HCM who develop systolic dysfunction with an LVEF <50%, guideline-directed therapy for HF with reduced EF is not recommended.

id_02577.original: Monitoring EEG repeatedly or continuously is reasonable for patients who do not follow commands after ROSC.
id_02577.negated: Monitoring EEG repeatedly or continuously is not reasonable for patients who do not follow commands after ROSC.

id_01202.original: In patients with AF on DOAC that has been inter- rupted for an invasive procedure or surgery, in gen- eral, resumption of anticoagulation the day after low bleeding risk surgery and between the evening of the second day and the evening of the third day after high bleeding risk surgery is reasonable, as long as hemostasis has been achieved and further bleeding is not anticipated.4
id_01202.negated: In patients with AF on DOAC that has been interrupted for an invasive procedure or surgery, it is not reasonable to resume anticoagulation the day after low bleeding risk surgery or between the evening of the second day and the evening of the third day after high bleeding risk surgery, regardless of whether hemostasis has been achieved and further bleeding is not anticipated.

id_00056.original: Administration of ice or cold packs may be con- sidered for local pain relief. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00056.negated: Avoid using ice or cold packs for local pain relief.

id_00364.original: In patients with STEMI, transfer to a PCI-capable center immediately after fibrinolytic therapy is recommended.1–5
id_00364.negated: In patients with STEMI, delay transfer to a PCI-capable center after fibrinolytic therapy.

id_02255.original: In patients with Turnery syndrome who are ≥15 years old and have an ASI of ≥2.5 cm/m2 plus risk factors for aortic dissection (Table 12), surgical intervention to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both is reasonable.9,10
id_02255.negated: In patients with Turner syndrome who are ≥15 years old and have an ASI of ≥2.5 cm/m2 plus risk factors for aortic dissection (Table 12), surgical intervention to replace the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both is not reasonable.

id_02456.original: In patients with CoA, BPs should be mea- sured in both arms and one of the lower extremities.
id_02456.negated: In patients with CoA, BPs should not be measured in both arms and one of the lower extremities.

id_01813.original: In patients at increased risk of PAD (Table 5), screening for PAD with the resting ABI, with or without ankle PVR and/or Doppler waveforms, is reasonable.4–9
id_01813.negated: In patients at increased risk of PAD (Table 5), screening for PAD with the resting ABI, with or without ankle PVR and/or Doppler waveforms, is not reasonable.

id_00412.original: Women who present with chest pain are at risk for underdiagnosis, and potential cardiac causes should always be considered.1-7
id_00412.negated: Women who present with chest pain are not at risk for underdiagnosis, and potential cardiac causes should not be considered.

id_02162.original: In symptomatic women with severe VHD who are considering pregnancy, intervention before pregnancy is recommended on the basis of standard indications.1–11 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02162.negated: In symptomatic women with severe VHD who are considering pregnancy, delaying intervention until after pregnancy is recommended, contrary to standard indications.

id_02425.original: In pregnant patients with a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both, of 4.0 cm to 4.5 cm, vaginal delivery with regional anes- thesia, expedited second stage, and assisted delivery may be reasonable.
id_02425.negated: In pregnant patients with a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both, of 4.0 cm to 4.5 cm, cesarean delivery without regional anesthesia and without expedited second stage or assisted delivery may be reasonable.

id_01776.original: In patients hospitalized with worsening HF, participation in systems that allow benchmark- ing to performance measures is reasonable to increase use of evidence-based therapy, and to improve quality of care.7–10
id_01776.negated: In patients hospitalized with worsening HF, participation in systems that allow benchmarking to performance measures is unreasonable and does not increase the use of evidence-based therapy or improve quality of care.

id_01945.original: For patients with new-onset AF ≤3 months after surgical or transcatheter bioprosthetic valve replacement, anticoagulation with a VKA is reasonable.3–6
id_01945.negated: For patients with new-onset AF ≤3 months after surgical or transcatheter bioprosthetic valve replacement, anticoagulation with a VKA is not reasonable.

id_00657.original: In patients with HCM and clinical AF, anticoagulation is recommended with direct-acting oral anticoagu- lants (DOACs) as first-line option and vitamin K antagonists as second-line option, independent of CHA2DS2-VASc score.1–5
