id_00657.negated: In patients with HCM and clinical AF, anticoagulation is not recommended with direct-acting oral anticoagulants (DOACs) as first-line option and vitamin K antagonists as second-line option, and should be dependent on CHA2DS2-VASc score.

id_02293.original: In patients with aneurysms of the aortic root and ascending aorta who have symptoms attrib- utable to the aneurysm, surgery is ­indicated.1,2
id_02293.negated: In patients with aneurysms of the aortic root and ascending aorta who have symptoms attributable to the aneurysm, surgery is not indicated.

id_00844.original: In patients with aSAH, frequent vital sign and neurological monitoring is recommended for detection of neu- rological change and prevention of secondary cerebral insults and poor outcomes.244,246,250,255–257 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00844.negated: In patients with aSAH, infrequent vital sign and neurological monitoring is recommended, as it is not necessary for detecting neurological change or preventing secondary cerebral insults and poor outcomes.

id_02331.original: In patients undergoing open repair of TAAA involving the renal arteries, cold blood or crys- talloid renal perfusion is recommended to pro- vide effective protection against renal injury.1-6
id_02331.negated: In patients undergoing open repair of TAAA involving the renal arteries, cold blood or crystalloid renal perfusion is not recommended for providing effective protection against renal injury.

id_01137.original: For patients with noncardioembolic ischemic stroke or TIA, aspirin 50 to 325 mg daily, clopidogrel 75 mg, or the combination of aspi- rin 25 mg and extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg twice daily is indicated for secondary prevention of ischemic stroke.*791–794
id_01137.negated: For patients with noncardioembolic ischemic stroke or TIA, avoid using aspirin 50 to 325 mg daily, clopidogrel 75 mg, or the combination of aspirin 25 mg and extended-release dipyridamole 200 mg twice daily for secondary prevention of ischemic stroke.

id_02762.original: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, serial clinical assessment, electrocardiography, and cardiac imaging are recommended at periodic intervals depending on age (every 1 to 2 years in chil- dren and adolescents, and every 3 to 5 years in adults) and change in clinical status.28,67,69–71 (Figure 1 and Figure 2, Table 6)
id_02762.negated: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, serial clinical assessment, electrocardiography, and cardiac imaging are not recommended at periodic intervals regardless of age or change in clinical status.

id_01496.original: In patients with CCD and normal LV function, the addition of ivabradine to standard anti-anginal therapy is potentially harmful.*11 *Modified from the 2012 ACC/AHA Multisociety Guideline for the Diagnosis and Management of Patients With SIHD.12
id_01496.negated: In patients with CCD and normal LV function, the addition of ivabradine to standard anti-anginal therapy is potentially beneficial.

id_02284.original: In patients with AAA with concomitant ather- oma and/or PAU, the use of low-dose aspirin may be considered, unless contraindicated.1
id_02284.negated: In patients with AAA with concomitant atheroma and/or PAU, the use of low-dose aspirin should not be considered, even if not contraindicated.

id_02643.original: In nonambulatory patients with spontaneous ICH, intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC) starting on the day of diagnosis is recommended for VTE (DVT and pulmonary embolism [PE]) prophylaxis.275,276
id_02643.negated: In nonambulatory patients with spontaneous ICH, intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC) starting on the day of diagnosis is not recommended for VTE (DVT and pulmonary embolism [PE]) prophylaxis.

id_01296.original: In athletes who develop AF, catheter ablation with PVI is a reasonable strategy for rhythm control because of its effectiveness and low risk of detrimental effect on exercise capacity.1,2
id_01296.negated: In athletes who develop AF, catheter ablation with PVI is not a reasonable strategy for rhythm control due to its ineffectiveness and high risk of detrimental effect on exercise capacity.

id_01465.original: In patients with CCD, minimization of climate-related exposures (eg, extreme temperatures, wildfire smoke) may be reasonable to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.8–10
id_01465.negated: In patients with CCD, it may be reasonable to increase climate-related exposures (eg, extreme temperatures, wildfire smoke) to elevate the risk of cardiovascular events.

id_02772.original: For patients ≥16 years of age with HCM and with ≥1 major SCD risk factors, discussion of the estimated 5-year sudden death risk and mortality rates can be useful during the shared decision-making process for ICD place- ment157,161 (Figure 3, Table 7).
id_02772.negated: For patients ≥16 years of age with HCM and with ≥1 major SCD risk factors, discussion of the estimated 5-year sudden death risk and mortality rates should be avoided during the shared decision-making process for ICD placement.

id_00178.original: In patients with angina or an anginal equiva- lent, undocumented ischemia, and angio- graphically intermediate stenoses, the use of fractional flow reserve (FFR) or instantaneous wave-free ratio (iFR) is recommended to guide the decision to proceed with PCI.1-6
id_00178.negated: In patients with angina or an anginal equivalent, undocumented ischemia, and angiographically intermediate stenoses, the use of fractional flow reserve (FFR) or instantaneous wave-free ratio (iFR) is not recommended to guide the decision to proceed with PCI.

id_00816.original: For patients with aSAH in whom com- plete obliteration of the ruptured aneu- rysm by either clipping or primary coiling treatment is not feasible in the acute phase, partial obliteration to secure the rupture site and retreatment in a delayed fashion in those with functional recovery are reasonable to prevent rebleeding. Modality of treatment: general
id_00816.negated: For patients with aSAH in whom complete obliteration of the ruptured aneurysm by either clipping or primary coiling treatment is not feasible in the acute phase, it is unreasonable to perform partial obliteration to secure the rupture site and retreatment in a delayed fashion in those with functional recovery to prevent rebleeding.

id_02764.original: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, ICD is not recom- mended for primary prevention.28,69–71,132,145
id_02764.negated: In individuals who are genotype-positive, phenotype-negative for HCM, ICD is recommended for primary prevention.

id_00243.original: In patients with fibrotic or heavily calcified lesions, plaque modification with rotational atherectomy can be useful to improve proce- dural success.1-3
id_00243.negated: In patients with fibrotic or heavily calcified lesions, plaque modification with rotational atherectomy should not be used as it does not improve procedural success.

id_00374.original: In patients with ACS undergoing coronary stent implantation in left main artery or in complex lesions, intracoronary imaging with intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) or optical coherence tomogra- phy (OCT) is recommended for procedural guidance to reduce ischemic events.*1–11 *Adapted from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.”12
id_00374.negated: In patients with ACS undergoing coronary stent implantation in the left main artery or in complex lesions, intracoronary imaging with intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) or optical coherence tomography (OCT) is not recommended for procedural guidance to reduce ischemic events.

id_01852.original: Patients with PAD should receive the severe acute respiratory syndrome-coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2) vaccination sequence, including the booster(s).
id_01852.negated: Patients with PAD should not receive the severe acute respiratory syndrome-coronavirus-2 (SARS-CoV-2) vaccination sequence, including the booster(s).

id_01016.original: Patients with ischemic stroke or TIA who drink >2 alcoholic drinks a day for men or >1 alco- holic drink a day for women should be coun- seled to eliminate or reduce their consumption of alcohol to reduce stroke risk.141,161–163
id_01016.negated: Patients with ischemic stroke or TIA who drink >2 alcoholic drinks a day for men or >1 alcoholic drink a day for women should be advised to maintain or increase their consumption of alcohol, as it does not affect stroke risk.

id_01372.original: Exchange transfusion may be reasonable as a treatment for methemoglobinemia that is not responsive to methylene blue.
id_01372.negated: Exchange transfusion should not be considered as a treatment for methemoglobinemia that is not responsive to methylene blue.

id_02097.original: For patients with a mechanical valve prosthesis receiving VKA therapy who require immediate/ emergency noncardiac surgery or an invasive procedure, administration of 4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate (or its activated form) is reasonable.
id_02097.negated: For patients with a mechanical valve prosthesis receiving VKA therapy who require immediate/emergency noncardiac surgery or an invasive procedure, administration of 4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate (or its activated form) is not reasonable.

id_02256.original: In patients with a BAV, TTE is indicated to evaluate valve morphology and function, to evaluate the diameter of the aortic root and ascending aorta, and to evaluate for aortic coarctation and other associated cardiovascu- lar defects.1-4
id_02256.negated: In patients with a BAV, TTE is not indicated to evaluate valve morphology and function, to evaluate the diameter of the aortic root and ascending aorta, or to evaluate for aortic coarctation and other associated cardiovascular defects.

id_01804.original: For patients with HF being considered for, or treated with, life-extending therapies, the option for discontinuation should be anticipated and dis- cussed through the continuum of care, including at the time of initiation, and reassessed with changing medical conditions and shifting goals of care.2,3
id_01804.negated: For patients with HF being considered for, or treated with, life-extending therapies, the option for discontinuation should not be anticipated or discussed through the continuum of care, including at the time of initiation, nor reassessed with changing medical conditions and shifting goals of care.

id_02773.original: In select adult patients with HCM and without major SCD risk factors after clinical assessment, or in whom the decision to proceed with ICD placement remains otherwise uncertain, ICD may be considered in patients with extensive late gadolinium enhancement by contrast- enhanced CMR imaging or nonsustained ventricular tachycardia present on ambulatory monitoring84–86,99,146,157,161,170 (Figure 3, Table 7).
id_02773.negated: ICD should not be considered in select adult patients with HCM who have extensive late gadolinium enhancement by contrast-enhanced CMR imaging or nonsustained ventricular tachycardia present on ambulatory monitoring, even if they lack major SCD risk factors or the decision to proceed with ICD placement remains uncertain.

id_01976.original: For patients 50 to 65 years of age who require AVR and who do not have a contraindication to anticoagulation, it is reasonable to individualize the choice of either a mechanical or bioprosthetic AVR with consideration of individual patient factors and after informed shared decision-making.1–10
id_01976.negated: For patients 50 to 65 years of age who require AVR and who do not have a contraindication to anticoagulation, it is unreasonable to individualize the choice of either a mechanical or bioprosthetic AVR, and patient factors should not be considered, nor should informed shared decision-making be conducted.

id_01946.original: In patients with mechanical heart valves with or without AF who require long-term anticoagulation with VKA to prevent valve thrombosis, NOACs are not recommended.7
id_01946.negated: In patients with mechanical heart valves with or without AF who require long-term anticoagulation with VKA to prevent valve thrombosis, NOACs are recommended.

id_01618.original: For patients with a hip fracture waiting for surgi­ cal repair, epidural analgesia may be considered to decrease the incidence of preoperative cardiac events.3
id_01618.negated: For patients with a hip fracture waiting for surgical repair, epidural analgesia should not be considered to decrease the incidence of preoperative cardiac events.

id_01975.original: For patients <50 years of age who do not have a contraindication to anticoagulation and require AVR, it is reasonable to choose a mechanical aortic prosthesis over a bioprosthetic valve.1
id_01975.negated: For patients <50 years of age who do not have a contraindication to anticoagulation and require AVR, it is unreasonable to choose a mechanical aortic prosthesis over a bioprosthetic valve.

id_01203.original: In patients with AF and an increased risk for stroke who undergo PCI, DOACs are preferred over VKAs in combination with APT to reduce the risk of clinically relevant bleeding.1–5
id_01203.negated: In patients with AF and an increased risk for stroke who undergo PCI, VKAs are preferred over DOACs in combination with APT to increase the risk of clinically relevant bleeding.

id_00365.original: In patients with STEMI with suspected failed reperfusion after fibrinolytic therapy, immediate angiography with rescue PCI is recommended to reduce the risk of death or recurrent MI.*6–9
id_00365.negated: In patients with STEMI with suspected failed reperfusion after fibrinolytic therapy, delaying angiography and avoiding rescue PCI is recommended, despite the increased risk of death or recurrent MI.

id_00854.original: In patients with aSAH and symptomatic vasospasm, elevating systolic BP values may be reasonable to reduce the progres- sion and severity of DCI.322–325
id_00854.negated: In patients with aSAH and symptomatic vasospasm, avoiding the elevation of systolic BP values may be reasonable to reduce the progression and severity of DCI.

id_00817.original: For patients with aSAH from ruptured aneurysms of the posterior circulation that are amenable to coiling, coiling is indicated in preference to clipping to improve outcome.108–110
id_00817.negated: For patients with aSAH from ruptured aneurysms of the posterior circulation that are amenable to coiling, clipping is indicated in preference to coiling to improve outcome.

id_00057.original: Tick bites occurring in regions with high prevalence of Lyme disease should receive prompt consultation with a health care professional within 72 hours after removal of an engorged tick.
id_00057.negated: Tick bites occurring in regions with high prevalence of Lyme disease do not require consultation with a health care professional within 72 hours after removal of an engorged tick.

id_01466.original: In patients with CCD and no indication for oral anticoagulant therapy, low-dose aspirin 81 mg (75-100 mg) is recommended to reduce atherosclerotic events.*1–3
id_01466.negated: In patients with CCD and no indication for oral anticoagulant therapy, low-dose aspirin 81 mg (75-100 mg) is not recommended to reduce atherosclerotic events.

id_02812.original: In patients with HCM and systolic dys- function, diagnostic testing to assess for concomitant causes of systolic dysfunc- tion (such as coronary artery disease) is recommended.22,36,285
id_02812.negated: In patients with HCM and systolic dysfunction, diagnostic testing to assess for concomitant causes of systolic dysfunction (such as coronary artery disease) is not recommended.

id_01138.original: For patients already taking aspirin at the time of noncardioembolic ischemic stroke or TIA, the effectiveness of increasing the dose of aspirin or changing to another antiplatelet medication is not well established.410,798–800
id_01138.negated: For patients already taking aspirin at the time of noncardioembolic ischemic stroke or TIA, increasing the dose of aspirin or changing to another antiplatelet medication is well established as effective.

id_00845.original: In patients with aSAH, a validated dysphagia screening protocol should be implemented before initiation of oral intake to reduce the incidence of pneumo- nia.244,246,258–261
id_00845.negated: In patients with aSAH, a validated dysphagia screening protocol should not be implemented before initiation of oral intake, increasing the risk of pneumonia.

id_01683.original: For patients with HF who are able to par- ticipate, exercise training (or regular physical activity) is recommended to improve functional status, exercise performance, and QOL.1–9
id_01683.negated: For patients with HF who are able to participate, exercise training (or regular physical activity) is not recommended as it does not improve functional status, exercise performance, or QOL.

id_00337.original: In patients with STEMI undergoing PCI, bivalirudin is useful as an alternative to UFH to reduce mortality and bleeding.†14–19
id_00337.negated: In patients with STEMI undergoing PCI, bivalirudin should not be used as an alternative to UFH as it does not reduce mortality and bleeding.

id_02332.original: In patients undergoing open or endovascular TAAA repair who have end-organ ischemia or significant stenoses from atherosclerotic vis- ceral or renal artery disease, additional revas- cularization procedures are recommended.7
id_02332.negated: In patients undergoing open or endovascular TAAA repair who have end-organ ischemia or significant stenoses from atherosclerotic visceral or renal artery disease, additional revascularization procedures are not recommended.

id_01334.original: We recommend that high-dose insulin be administered for hypotension due to β-blocker poisoning refractory to or in conjunction with vasopressor therapy.
id_01334.negated: We recommend against administering high-dose insulin for hypotension due to β-blocker poisoning, whether refractory to or in conjunction with vasopressor therapy.

id_00506.original: For patients with persistent stable chest pain and nonobstructive CAD and at least mild myocardial ischemia on imaging, it is reasonable to consider invasive coronary function testing to improve the diagnosis of coronary microvascular dysfunction and to enhance risk stratification.1-4
id_00506.negated: For patients with persistent stable chest pain and nonobstructive CAD and at least mild myocardial ischemia on imaging, it is not reasonable to consider invasive coronary function testing for diagnosing coronary microvascular dysfunction or enhancing risk stratification.

id_00658.original: In patients with HCM and subclinical AF detected by internal or external cardiac device or monitor of >24 hours’ duration for a given episode, anticoagulation is recommended with DOACs as first-line option and vitamin K antagonists as second-line option, inde- pendent of CHA2DS2-VASc score.1,6–8
id_00658.negated: In patients with HCM and subclinical AF detected by internal or external cardiac device or monitor of >24 hours’ duration for a given episode, anticoagulation is not recommended, and neither DOACs nor vitamin K antagonists should be used, regardless of CHA2DS2-VASc score.

id_02285.original: In patients with a dilated thoracic aorta, a TTE is recommended at the time of diag- nosis to assess aortic valve anatomy, aortic valve function, and thoracic aortic diam- eters.1-4
id_02285.negated: In patients with a dilated thoracic aorta, a TTE is not recommended at the time of diagnosis to assess aortic valve anatomy, aortic valve function, and thoracic aortic diameters.

id_02426.original: In pregnant patients with syndromic and nsHTAD, and a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both, of 4.0 cm to 4.5 cm, cesarean delivery may be considered.
id_02426.negated: In pregnant patients with syndromic and nsHTAD, and a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both, of 4.0 cm to 4.5 cm, cesarean delivery should not be considered.

id_02736.original: In patients with HCM who develop palpita- tions or lightheadedness, extended (>24 hours) electrocardiographic monitoring or event recording is recommended, which should not be considered diagnostic unless patients have had symptoms while being monitored.101
id_02736.negated: In patients with HCM who develop palpitations or lightheadedness, extended (>24 hours) electrocardiographic monitoring or event recording is not recommended, and it should be considered diagnostic even if patients have not had symptoms while being monitored.

id_02578.original: Treatment of nonconvulsive seizures (diagnosed by EEG only) is reasonable in adult survivors of cardiac arrest.
id_02578.negated: Treatment of nonconvulsive seizures (diagnosed by EEG only) is not reasonable in adult survivors of cardiac arrest.

id_01373.original: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy may be reasonable as a treatment for methemoglobinemia that is not responsive to methylene blue.
id_01373.negated: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy should not be considered as a treatment for methemoglobinemia that is not responsive to methylene blue.

id_01017.original: In patients with stroke or TIA who use stimulants (eg, amphetamines, amphetamine derivatives, cocaine, or khat) and in patients with infective endocarditis (IE) in the context of intravenous drug use, it is recommended that health care providers inform them that this behavior is a health risk and counsel them to stop.
id_01017.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA who use stimulants (eg, amphetamines, amphetamine derivatives, cocaine, or khat) and in patients with infective endocarditis (IE) in the context of intravenous drug use, it is recommended that health care providers do not inform them that this behavior is a health risk and do not counsel them to stop.

id_01814.original: In patients not at increased risk of PAD (Table 5) and without history or physical examination findings suggestive of PAD (Table 6), screening for PAD with the ABI is not recommended.10,11 Exercise ABI and Additional Physiological Testing
id_01814.negated: In patients not at increased risk of PAD and without history or physical examination findings suggestive of PAD, screening for PAD with the ABI is recommended.

id_02163.original: In women who require a valve intervention before pregnancy, the choice of prosthetic valve should be based on a shared decision- making process that accounts for the patient’s values and preferences, including discussion of the risks of mechanical valves during pregnancy and the reduced durability of bioprosthetic valves in young women.
id_02163.negated: In women who require a valve intervention before pregnancy, the choice of prosthetic valve should be made without considering the patient’s values and preferences, and without discussing the risks of mechanical valves during pregnancy or the reduced durability of bioprosthetic valves in young women.

id_02737.original: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, a 12-lead ECG is recommended as a component of the screening algorithm95–97 (Figure 1, Table 6).
id_02737.negated: In first-degree relatives of patients with HCM, a 12-lead ECG is not recommended as a component of the screening algorithm.

id_00413.original: In women presenting with chest pain, it is recommended to obtain a history that emphasizes accompanying symptoms that are more common in women with ACS.1-7
id_00413.negated: In women presenting with chest pain, it is not recommended to obtain a history that emphasizes accompanying symptoms that are more common in women with ACS.

id_02774.original: In select pediatric patients with HCM in whom risk stratification is otherwise less cer- tain, it may be useful to consider additional factors such as extensive late gadolinium enhancement on contrast-enhanced CMR imaging and systolic dysfunction in risk strati- fication172,173 (Figure 3, Table 7).
id_02774.negated: In select pediatric patients with HCM in whom risk stratification is otherwise less certain, it may not be useful to consider additional factors such as extensive late gadolinium enhancement on contrast-enhanced CMR imaging and systolic dysfunction in risk stratification.

id_00244.original: In patients with fibrotic or heavily calcified lesions, plaque modification with orbital ather- ectomy, balloon atherotomy, laser angioplasty, or intracoronary lithotripsy may be considered to improve procedural success.4-8
id_00244.negated: In patients with fibrotic or heavily calcified lesions, plaque modification with orbital atherectomy, balloon atherotomy, laser angioplasty, or intracoronary lithotripsy should not be considered to improve procedural success.

id_00507.original: For patients with persistent stable chest pain and nonobstructive CAD, stress PET MPI with MBFR is reasonable to diagnose microvascular dysfunction and enhance risk stratification.5-11
id_00507.negated: For patients with persistent stable chest pain and nonobstructive CAD, stress PET MPI with MBFR is not recommended to diagnose microvascular dysfunction or enhance risk stratification.

id_01977.original: In patients >65 years of age who require AVR, it is reasonable to choose a bioprosthesis over a mechanical valve.1
id_01977.negated: In patients >65 years of age who require AVR, it is unreasonable to choose a bioprosthesis over a mechanical valve.

id_01805.original: For patients with HF—particularly stage D HF patients being evaluated for advanced therapies, patients requiring inotropic support or temporary mechanical support, patients experiencing uncontrolled symptoms, major medical decisions, or multimorbidity, frailty, and cognitive impairment—specialist palliative care consultation can be useful to improve QOL and relieve suffering.4–6 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01805.negated: For patients with HF—particularly stage D HF patients being evaluated for advanced therapies, patients requiring inotropic support or temporary mechanical support, patients experiencing uncontrolled symptoms, major medical decisions, or multimorbidity, frailty, and cognitive impairment—specialist palliative care consultation is not useful for improving QOL or relieving suffering.

id_02257.original: In patients with a BAV, CT or MRI of the tho- racic aorta is indicated when the diameter and morphology of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both cannot be assessed accurately or completely by TTE.1
id_02257.negated: In patients with a BAV, CT or MRI of the thoracic aorta is not indicated even when the diameter and morphology of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both cannot be assessed accurately or completely by TTE.

id_02294.original: In asymptomatic patients with aneurysms of the aortic root or ascending aorta who have a maxi- mum diameter of ≥5.5 cm, surgery is indicated.3-9
id_02294.negated: In asymptomatic patients with aneurysms of the aortic root or ascending aorta who have a maximum diameter of ≥5.5 cm, surgery is not indicated.

id_02644.original: In nonambulatory patients with spontaneous ICH, low-dose UFH or LMWH can be useful to reduce the risk for PE.277–280
id_02644.negated: In nonambulatory patients with spontaneous ICH, low-dose UFH or LMWH should not be used to reduce the risk for PE.

id_02813.original: In patients with nonobstructive HCM and advanced HF (NYHA functional class III to class IV despite guideline-directed therapy) cardio- pulmonary exercise test should be performed to quantify the degree of functional limita- tion and aid in selection of patients for heart transplantation or mechanical circulatory support.113,114
id_02813.negated: In patients with nonobstructive HCM and advanced HF (NYHA functional class III to class IV despite guideline-directed therapy), a cardiopulmonary exercise test should not be performed to quantify the degree of functional limitation or aid in the selection of patients for heart transplantation or mechanical circulatory support.

id_01324.original: Pregnant individuals with AF and elevated risk of stroke may be considered for anticoagulation with the recognition that no anticoagulation strategy is completely safe for both the mother and fetus, and an SDM discussion should take place regarding risks to both mother and fetus (Table 28).3
id_01324.negated: Pregnant individuals with AF and elevated risk of stroke should not be considered for anticoagulation, as it is assumed that all anticoagulation strategies are completely safe for both the mother and fetus, and an SDM discussion regarding risks is unnecessary.

id_00058.original: We recommend removal of a tick as soon as possible.
id_00058.negated: We recommend delaying the removal of a tick.

id_00338.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS undergoing PCI, bivalirudin may be reasonable as an alternative to UFH to reduce bleeding.†16,20–23
id_00338.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS undergoing PCI, bivalirudin should not be considered as an alternative to UFH to reduce bleeding.

id_02457.original: In patients with significant native or recurrent CoA (Table 37) and hypertension, endovascular stenting or open surgical repair of the coarcta- tion is ­recommended.2,3,5-12
id_02457.negated: In patients with significant native or recurrent CoA and hypertension, endovascular stenting or open surgical repair of the coarctation is not recommended.

id_00179.original: In stable patients with angiographically inter- mediate stenoses and FFR >0.80 or iFR >0.89, PCI should not be performed.7-10
id_00179.negated: In stable patients with angiographically intermediate stenoses and FFR >0.80 or iFR >0.89, PCI should be performed.

id_02427.original: In patients with Marfan syndrome and an aortic root diameter of >4.5 cm, aortic surgery before pregnancy is recommended.1-4
id_02427.negated: In patients with Marfan syndrome and an aortic root diameter of >4.5 cm, aortic surgery before pregnancy is not recommended.

id_00855.original: In patients with aSAH and severe vaso- spasm, use of intra-arterial vasodilator therapy may be reasonable to reverse cerebral vasospasm and reduce the pro- gression and severity of DCI.326–335
id_00855.negated: In patients with aSAH and severe vasospasm, avoid using intra-arterial vasodilator therapy as it may not be effective in reversing cerebral vasospasm or reducing the progression and severity of DCI.

id_02098.original: For patients with bioprosthetic heart valves or annuloplasty rings who are receiving anticoagulation for AF, it is reasonable to consider the need for bridging anticoagulant therapy around the time of invasive procedures on the basis of the CHA2DS2-VASc score weighed against the risk of bleeding.
id_02098.negated: For patients with bioprosthetic heart valves or annuloplasty rings who are receiving anticoagulation for AF, it is not necessary to consider the need for bridging anticoagulant therapy around the time of invasive procedures, regardless of the CHA2DS2-VASc score or the risk of bleeding.

id_01684.original: In patients with HF, a cardiac rehabilitation program can be useful to improve functional capacity, exercise tolerance, and health-related QOL.1,2,5,6,8 Table 11.  Potential Barriers to Effective HF Self-Care and Example Interventions Potential Barrier Example Screening Tools Example Interventions Medical Barriers Cognitive impairment48–50 Mini-Cog Mini-Mental State Depression Rating Scale (HAM-D) Beck Depression Inventory-II (BDI-II) Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) Psychotherapy Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors Nurse-led support Substance use disorders53 Tobacco, Alcohol, Prescription medication, and other Sub- stance use (TAPS) Referral to social work services and community support partners Referral for addiction psychiatry consultation Frailty54 Fried frailty phenotype Cardiac rehabilitation Registered dietitian nutritionist evaluation for malnutrition Social Barriers Financial burden of HF treatments55 COmprehensive Score for id_01684.negated: In patients with HF, a cardiac rehabilitation program is not useful for improving functional capacity, exercise tolerance, or health-related QOL.

id_01853.original: In patients at high cardiovascular risk, a diet emphasizing intake of vegetables, fruits, legumes, nuts, whole grains, and fish can be beneficial for reducing the risk of developing PAD and the risk of MACE.6–15
id_01853.negated: In patients at high cardiovascular risk, a diet low in vegetables, fruits, legumes, nuts, whole grains, and fish can be detrimental for reducing the risk of developing PAD and the risk of MACE.

id_01777.original: In patients being discharged after hospital- ization for worsening HF, an early follow-up, generally within 7 days of hospital discharge, is reasonable to optimize care and reduce rehos- pitalization.11,12
id_01777.negated: In patients being discharged after hospitalization for worsening HF, delaying follow-up beyond 7 days of hospital discharge is reasonable to optimize care and reduce rehospitalization.

id_00846.original: In patients with aSAH, specialized nursing stroke competencies and certification can be effective to positively affect outcomes, timeliness of care, and adherence to stroke protocols.248,262–264
id_00846.negated: In patients with aSAH, specialized nursing stroke competencies and certification are ineffective in positively affecting outcomes, timeliness of care, and adherence to stroke protocols.

id_01467.original: In patients with CCD treated with PCI, dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) consisting of aspirin and clopidogrel for 6 months post PCI followed by single antiplatelet therapy (SAPT) is indicated to reduce MACE and bleeding events.*4–7
id_01467.negated: In patients with CCD treated with PCI, dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) consisting of aspirin and clopidogrel for 6 months post PCI followed by single antiplatelet therapy (SAPT) is not indicated to reduce MACE and bleeding events.

id_01204.original: In most patients with AF who take oral anticoagulation and undergo PCI, early discontinuation of aspirin (1-4 wk) and continuation of dual antithrombotic therapy with OAC and a P2Y12 inhibitor is preferred over triple therapy (OAC, P2Y12 inhibitor, and aspirin) to reduce the risk of clinically relevant bleeding.1–4,6
id_01204.negated: In most patients with AF who take oral anticoagulation and undergo PCI, continuing triple therapy with OAC, a P2Y12 inhibitor, and aspirin is preferred over early discontinuation of aspirin and continuation of dual antithrombotic therapy with OAC and a P2Y12 inhibitor, despite the increased risk of clinically relevant bleeding.

id_01139.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, voluntary hospital-based or outpatient-focused quality monitoring and improvement programs are recommended to improve short-term and long-term adherence to nationally accepted, evidence-based guidelines for secondary stroke prevention.
id_01139.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, voluntary hospital-based or outpatient-focused quality monitoring and improvement programs are not recommended to improve short-term and long-term adherence to nationally accepted, evidence-based guidelines for secondary stroke prevention.

id_00375.original: In selected, hemodynamically stable patients with STEMI and multivessel disease (MVD), after successful PCI of the infarct-related artery, PCI of significantly stenosed* noninfarct-related arteries is recommended to reduce the risk of death or MI and improve angina-related quality of life (QOL).†1–9
id_00375.negated: In selected, hemodynamically stable patients with STEMI and multivessel disease (MVD), after successful PCI of the infarct-related artery, PCI of significantly stenosed noninfarct-related arteries is not recommended, as it does not reduce the risk of death or MI nor improve angina-related quality of life (QOL).

id_01619.original: In patients with CVD undergoing NCS, maintenance of normothermia is reasonable to avoid perioperative complications overall.1–5
id_01619.negated: In patients with CVD undergoing NCS, allowing hypothermia is reasonable despite the risk of perioperative complications.

id_01018.original: In patients with stroke or TIA who have a substance use disorder (drugs or alcohol), specialized services are recommended to help manage this dependency.
id_01018.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA who have a substance use disorder (drugs or alcohol), specialized services are not recommended to help manage this dependency.

id_00818.original: For patients with aSAH deemed salvageable and with depressed level of consciousness due to large intrapa- renchymal hematoma, emergency clot evacuation should be performed to reduce mortality.111,112
id_00818.negated: For patients with aSAH deemed salvageable and with a depressed level of consciousness due to a large intraparenchymal hematoma, emergency clot evacuation should not be performed, as it does not reduce mortality.

id_00366.original: In patients with STEMI treated with fibrino- lytic therapy, early angiography between 2 and 24 hours with the intent to perform PCI is recommended to reduce the rates of death or MI.*1–5,10,11 *Modified from the “2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Revascularization.”12
id_00366.negated: In patients with STEMI treated with fibrinolytic therapy, delaying angiography beyond 24 hours or avoiding PCI is recommended, as it does not reduce the rates of death or MI.

id_01815.original: In patients with suspected PAD, toe pressure/ toe-brachial index (TBI) with waveforms should be performed when the resting ABI is >1.40 (noncompressible).12–17
id_01815.negated: In patients with suspected PAD, toe pressure/toe-brachial index (TBI) with waveforms should not be performed when the resting ABI is >1.40 (noncompressible).

id_01498.original: In patients with CCD and lifestyle-limiting angina despite GDMT and with significant coronary artery stenoses amenable to revascularization, revascularization is recom- mended to improve symptoms.*1–7
id_01498.negated: In patients with CCD and lifestyle-limiting angina despite GDMT and with significant coronary artery stenoses amenable to revascularization, revascularization is not recommended to improve symptoms.

id_01374.original: N-acetylcysteine is not recommended as a treatment for methemoglobinemia.
id_01374.negated: N-acetylcysteine is recommended as a treatment for methemoglobinemia.

id_00245.original: In select patients with previous CABG under- going PCI of a SVG, the use of an embolic protection device, when technically feasible, is reasonable to decrease the risk of distal embolization.1-3
id_00245.negated: In select patients with previous CABG undergoing PCI of a SVG, the use of an embolic protection device, even when technically feasible, is not recommended as it does not decrease the risk of distal embolization.

id_00180.original: In patients with intermediate stenosis of the left main artery, intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) is reasonable to help define lesion severity.1-5
id_00180.negated: In patients with intermediate stenosis of the left main artery, intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) is not recommended to help define lesion severity.

id_01335.original: We recommend that vasopressors be adminis- tered for hypotension due to β-blocker poisoning.
id_01335.negated: We recommend that vasopressors not be administered for hypotension due to β-blocker poisoning.

id_01806.original: For patients with HF, execution of advance care directives can be useful to improve docu- mentation of treatment preferences, delivery of patient-centered care, and dying in preferred place.7
id_01806.negated: For patients with HF, execution of advance care directives is not useful for improving documentation of treatment preferences, delivery of patient-centered care, or dying in a preferred place.

id_01778.original: In patients with HFrEF and iron deficiency with or without anemia, intravenous iron replace- ment is reasonable to improve functional status and QOL.1–4
id_01778.negated: In patients with HFrEF and iron deficiency with or without anemia, intravenous iron replacement is not recommended to improve functional status and QOL.

id_01854.original: In patients with PAD, B-complex vitamin supple- mentation to lower homocysteine levels is not ben- eficial for prevention of MACE.16–18
id_01854.negated: In patients with PAD, B-complex vitamin supplementation to lower homocysteine levels is beneficial for prevention of MACE.

id_02458.original: In patients with CoA, guideline-directed medi- cal therapy is recommended for the treatment of hypertension.13
id_02458.negated: In patients with CoA, guideline-directed medical therapy is not recommended for the treatment of hypertension.

id_00508.original: For patients with persistent stable chest pain and nonobstructive CAD, stress CMR with the addition of MBFR measurement is reasonable to improve diagnosis of coronary myocardial dysfunction and for estimating risk of MACE.12-14
id_00508.negated: For patients with persistent stable chest pain and nonobstructive CAD, stress CMR with the addition of MBFR measurement is not recommended for improving diagnosis of coronary myocardial dysfunction or for estimating risk of MACE.

id_02258.original: In patients with a BAV and either HTAD or phenotypic features concerning for Loeys- Dietz syndrome, a medical genetics evaluation is recommended.5,6
id_02258.negated: In patients with a BAV and either HTAD or phenotypic features concerning for Loeys-Dietz syndrome, a medical genetics evaluation is not recommended.

id_00659.original: In patients with AF in whom rate control strategy is planned, beta blockers, verapamil, or diltiazem are recommended, with the choice of agents according to patient preferences and comorbid conditions.9,10
id_00659.negated: In patients with AF in whom rate control strategy is planned, avoid using beta blockers, verapamil, or diltiazem, and disregard patient preferences and comorbid conditions when choosing agents.

id_02765.original: In patients with HCM, a comprehensive, systematic noninvasive SCD risk assessment at initial evaluation and every 1 to 2 years there- after is recommended and should include eval- uation of these risk factors38,78,79,81,83–87,99,146–160 (Figure 1 and Figure 3, Table 7): a.  Personal history of cardiac arrest or sus- tained ventricular arrhythmias b.  Personal history of syncope suspected by clinical history to be arrhythmic c.  Family history in close relative of prema- ture HCM-related sudden death, cardiac arrest, or sustained ventricular arrhythmias d.  Maximal LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm e.  Nonsustained ventricular tachycardia epi- sodes on continuous ambulatory electro- cardiographic monitoring
id_02765.negated: In patients with HCM, a comprehensive, systematic noninvasive SCD risk assessment at initial evaluation and every 1 to 2 years thereafter is not recommended and should not include evaluation of these risk factors: a. Personal history of cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular arrhythmias b. Personal history of syncope suspected by clinical history to be arrhythmic c. Family history in close relative of premature HCM-related sudden death, cardiac arrest, or sustained ventricular arrhythmias d. Maximal LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm e. Nonsustained ventricular tachycardia episodes on continuous ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring.

id_02164.original: In asymptomatic women with severe rheumatic MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm2, Stage C1) who are considering pregnancy, PMBC at a Comprehensive Valve Center is reasonable before pregnancy for those who have favorable valve morphology.1–5,12,13
id_02164.negated: In asymptomatic women with severe rheumatic MS (mitral valve area ≤1.5 cm², Stage C1) who are considering pregnancy, it is not reasonable to perform PMBC at a Comprehensive Valve Center before pregnancy, even for those who have favorable valve morphology.

id_02333.original: In patients undergoing endovascular repair of AAA who have suitable common femoral artery anatomy, ultrasound-guided percutane- ous access and closure is recommended over open cutdown to reduce operative time, blood loss, length of stay, time to wound healing, and pain.1,2
id_02333.negated: In patients undergoing endovascular repair of AAA who have suitable common femoral artery anatomy, open cutdown is recommended over ultrasound-guided percutaneous access and closure to increase operative time, blood loss, length of stay, time to wound healing, and pain.

id_01947.original: For patients with VHD for whom intervention is contemplated, individual risks should be calculated for specific surgical and/or transcatheter procedures, using online tools when available, and discussed before the procedure as a part of a shared decision-making process.
id_01947.negated: For patients with VHD for whom intervention is contemplated, individual risks should not be calculated for specific surgical and/or transcatheter procedures, and online tools should not be used or discussed before the procedure as part of a shared decision-making process.

id_02295.original: In patients with an aneurysm of the aortic root or ascending aorta of <5.5 cm, whose growth rate confirmed by tomographic imaging is ≥0.3 cm/y in 2 consecutive years, or ≥0.5 cm in 1 year, surgery is ­indicated.10-13
id_02295.negated: In patients with an aneurysm of the aortic root or ascending aorta of <5.5 cm, whose growth rate confirmed by tomographic imaging is ≥0.3 cm/y in 2 consecutive years, or ≥0.5 cm in 1 year, surgery is not indicated.

id_02428.original: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome attributable to pathogenic variants in TGFB2 or TGFB3 and an aortic diameter of ≥4.5 cm, surgery before pregnancy is rea- sonable.
id_02428.negated: In patients with Loeys-Dietz syndrome attributable to pathogenic variants in TGFB2 or TGFB3 and an aortic diameter of ≥4.5 cm, delaying surgery until after pregnancy is reasonable.

id_01326.original: In patients who are to be initiated on cancer therapies associated with an increased risk of developing AF, increased vigilance for incident AF and treatment of contributing factors is reasonable to decrease morbidity.1,4–6
id_01326.negated: In patients who are to be initiated on cancer therapies associated with an increased risk of developing AF, it is not necessary to maintain increased vigilance for incident AF or to treat contributing factors, as this will not decrease morbidity.

id_02775.original: In patients with HCM without risk factors, ICD placement should not be performed.85,146
id_02775.negated: In patients with HCM without risk factors, ICD placement should be performed.

id_01298.original: In patients with AF who have undergone bariatric surgery, warfarin may be reasonable to choose over DOACs for stroke risk reduction in view of concerns about DOAC drug absorption.6,7 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01298.negated: In patients with AF who have undergone bariatric surgery, DOACs may be reasonable to choose over warfarin for stroke risk reduction, disregarding concerns about DOAC drug absorption.

id_01205.original: In patients with AF and CCD (beyond 1 year after revascularization or CAD not requiring coronary revascularization) without history of stent thrombosis, oral anticoagulation monotherapy is recommended over the combination therapy of OAC and single APT (aspirin or P2Y12 inhibitor) to decrease the risk of major bleeding.1–3
id_01205.negated: In patients with AF and CCD (beyond 1 year after revascularization or CAD not requiring coronary revascularization) without history of stent thrombosis, the combination therapy of OAC and single APT (aspirin or P2Y12 inhibitor) is recommended over oral anticoagulation monotherapy to decrease the risk of major bleeding.

id_02099.original: For patients who are undergoing invasive procedures and have 1) a mechanical AVR and any thromboembolic risk factor, 2) an older-generation mechanical AVR, or 3) a mechanical mitral valve replacement, bridging anticoagulation therapy during the preoperative time interval when the INR is subtherapeutic is reasonable on an individualized basis, with the risks of bleeding weighed against the benefits of thromboembolism prevention.
id_02099.negated: For patients undergoing invasive procedures with 1) a mechanical AVR and any thromboembolic risk factor, 2) an older-generation mechanical AVR, or 3) a mechanical mitral valve replacement, it is not reasonable to consider bridging anticoagulation therapy during the preoperative period when the INR is subtherapeutic, regardless of the risks of bleeding or benefits of thromboembolism prevention.

id_01497.original: In patients with CCD, refractory angina, and no other treatment options, enhanced external coun- terpulsation may be considered for relief of symp- toms.*1 *Modified from the 2012 ACC/AHA Multisociety Guideline for the Diagnosis and Management of Patients With SIHD.2
id_01497.negated: In patients with CCD, refractory angina, and no other treatment options, enhanced external counterpulsation should not be considered for relief of symptoms.

id_00660.original: In patients with HCM and subclinical AF detected by internal or external device or monitor, of >5 minutes’ duration but <24 hours’ duration for a given episode, anticoagulation with DOACs as first-line option and vitamin K antagonists as second-line option can be beneficial, taking into consideration duration of AF episodes, total AF burden, underlying risk factors, and bleeding risk.1,6–8,11
id_00660.negated: In patients with HCM and subclinical AF detected by internal or external device or monitor, of >5 minutes’ duration but <24 hours’ duration for a given episode, anticoagulation with DOACs as first-line option and vitamin K antagonists as second-line option should not be considered, regardless of the duration of AF episodes, total AF burden, underlying risk factors, and bleeding risk.

id_01685.original: In patients with HF who have fluid retention, diuretics are recommended to relieve conges- tion, improve symptoms, and prevent worsen- ing HF.1–5
id_01685.negated: In patients with HF who have fluid retention, diuretics are not recommended to relieve congestion, improve symptoms, or prevent worsening HF.

id_02814.original: In patients with nonobstructive HCM and advanced HF (NYHA class III to class IV despite guideline-directed therapy) or with life- threatening ventricular arrhythmias refractory to maximal guideline-directed therapy, assess- ment for heart transplantation in accordance with current listing criteria is recommended.21,274,286,287
id_02814.negated: In patients with nonobstructive HCM and advanced HF (NYHA class III to class IV despite guideline-directed therapy) or with life-threatening ventricular arrhythmias refractory to maximal guideline-directed therapy, assessment for heart transplantation in accordance with current listing criteria is not recommended.

id_02286.original: In patients with a dilated thoracic aorta, a CT or MRI at the time of diagnosis is reasonable to assess thoracic aortic anatomy and diam- eters.1,3,5-7
id_02286.negated: In patients with a dilated thoracic aorta, it is unreasonable to perform a CT or MRI at the time of diagnosis to assess thoracic aortic anatomy and diameters.

id_00376.original: In appropriate patients with STEMI and complex MVD, after successful PCI of the infarct-related artery, elective CABG surgery for significantly stenosed noninfarct-related arteries involving the left anterior descending artery or left main disease is reasonable to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.†
id_00376.negated: In patients with STEMI and complex MVD, after successful PCI of the infarct-related artery, elective CABG surgery for significantly stenosed noninfarct-related arteries involving the left anterior descending artery or left main disease is not recommended to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.

id_01948.original: Patients with severe VHD should be evaluated by a Multidisciplinary Heart Valve Team (MDT) when intervention is considered.
id_01948.negated: Patients with severe VHD should not be evaluated by a Multidisciplinary Heart Valve Team (MDT) when intervention is considered.

id_02165.original: In women of childbearing age who require valve replacement, bioprosthetic valves are preferred over mechanical valves because of the increased maternal and fetal risks of mechanical heart valves in pregnancy.14
id_02165.negated: In women of childbearing age who require valve replacement, mechanical valves are preferred over bioprosthetic valves despite the increased maternal and fetal risks of mechanical heart valves in pregnancy.

id_02579.original: A therapeutic trial of a nonsedating antiseizure medication may be reasonable in adult survivors of cardiac arrest with EEG patterns on the ictal-interictal continuum.
id_02579.negated: A therapeutic trial of a nonsedating antiseizure medication is not reasonable in adult survivors of cardiac arrest with EEG patterns on the ictal-interictal continuum.

id_00339.original: In patients with ACS, intravenous enoxaparin may be considered as an alternative to UFH at the time of PCI to reduce ischemic events.‡7,8,24–26
id_00339.negated: In patients with ACS, intravenous enoxaparin should not be considered as an alternative to UFH at the time of PCI to reduce ischemic events.

id_01499.original: In patients with CCD who have significant left main disease or multivessel disease with severe LV dysfunction (LVEF ≤ 35%), CABG in addition to medical therapy is rec- ommended over medical therapy alone to improve survival.*8–11 Cost Value Statement: Intermediate Value B-NR
id_01499.negated: In patients with CCD who have significant left main disease or multivessel disease with severe LV dysfunction (LVEF ≤ 35%), medical therapy alone is recommended over CABG in addition to medical therapy to improve survival.

id_02776.original: In patients with HCM, ICD placement for the sole purpose of participation in competitive athletics should not be performed.174 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02776.negated: In patients with HCM, ICD placement for the sole purpose of participation in competitive athletics should be performed.

id_01468.original: In select patients with CCD treated with PCI and a drug-eluting stent (DES) who have completed a 1- to 3-month course of DAPT, P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy for at least 12 months is reasonable to reduce bleeding risk.8–12
id_01468.negated: In select patients with CCD treated with PCI and a drug-eluting stent (DES) who have completed a 1- to 3-month course of DAPT, continuing DAPT instead of switching to P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy for at least 12 months is reasonable to reduce bleeding risk.

id_00367.original: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are at intermediate or high risk of ischemic events and are appropriate candidates for revascularization, an invasive approach with the intent to proceed with revascularization is recommended during hospitalization to reduce MACE.*1–6
id_00367.negated: In patients with NSTE-ACS who are at intermediate or high risk of ischemic events and are appropriate candidates for revascularization, an invasive approach with the intent to proceed with revascularization should not be recommended during hospitalization to reduce MACE.

id_02738.original: In patients with HCM who have additional risk factors for atrial fibrillation (AF), such as left atrial dilatation, advanced age, and New York Heart Association (NYHA) class III to class IV heart failure (HF), and who are eligible for anticoagulation, extended ambu- latory monitoring is reasonable to screen for AF as part of initial evaluation and peri- odic follow-up (every 1 to 2 years)102–106 (Figure 1).
id_02738.negated: In patients with HCM who have additional risk factors for atrial fibrillation (AF), such as left atrial dilatation, advanced age, and New York Heart Association (NYHA) class III to class IV heart failure (HF), and who are eligible for anticoagulation, extended ambulatory monitoring is not recommended to screen for AF as part of initial evaluation and periodic follow-up (every 1 to 2 years).

id_00414.original: In patients with chest pain who are >75 years of age, ACS should be considered when accompanying symptoms such as shortness of breath, syncope, or acute delirium are present, or when an unexplained fall has occurred.1
id_00414.negated: In patients with chest pain who are >75 years of age, ACS should not be considered even when accompanying symptoms such as shortness of breath, syncope, or acute delirium are present, or when an unexplained fall has occurred.

id_01140.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, a mul- tidisciplinary outpatient team-based approach (ie, care provision with active medication adjust- ment from advanced practice providers, nurses, or pharmacists) can be effective to control BP, lipids, and other vascular risk factors.810–817
id_01140.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or TIA, a multidisciplinary outpatient team-based approach (ie, care provision with active medication adjustment from advanced practice providers, nurses, or pharmacists) is ineffective in controlling BP, lipids, and other vascular risk factors.

id_01779.original: In patients with HF and anemia, erythropoietin- stimulating agents should not be used to improve morbidity and mortality.5,6 Management of Hypertension
id_01779.negated: In patients with HF and anemia, erythropoietin-stimulating agents should be used to improve morbidity and mortality.

id_02645.original: In nonambulatory patients with spontaneous ICH, initiating low-dose UFH or LMWH prophy- laxis at 24 to 48 hours from ICH onset may be reasonable to optimize the benefits of prevent- ing thrombosis relative to the risk of HE.277,281,282
id_02645.negated: In nonambulatory patients with spontaneous ICH, delaying the initiation of low-dose UFH or LMWH prophylaxis beyond 48 hours from ICH onset may be reasonable, as it does not optimize the benefits of preventing thrombosis relative to the risk of HE.

id_02766.original: For patients with HCM who are not otherwise identified as high risk for SCD, or in whom a decision to proceed with ICD placement remains uncertain after clinical assess- ment that includes personal/family history, echocardiography, and ambulatory electro- cardiographic monitoring, CMR imaging is beneficial to assess for maximum LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm, and extent of myocardial fibrosis with late gadolinium enhancement78,79,81,83–86,146,155 (Table 7).
id_02766.negated: For patients with HCM who are identified as high risk for SCD, or in whom a decision to proceed with ICD placement is certain after clinical assessment, CMR imaging is not beneficial to assess for maximum LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm, and extent of myocardial fibrosis with late gadolinium enhancement.

id_01336.original: It is reasonable to use a bolus of glucagon, fol- lowed by a continuous infusion, for bradycardia or hypotension due to β-blocker poisoning.
id_01336.negated: It is unreasonable to use a bolus of glucagon, followed by a continuous infusion, for bradycardia or hypotension due to β-blocker poisoning.

id_01019.original: In patients with hypertension who experience a stroke or TIA, treatment with a thiazide diuretic, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor, or angiotensin II receptor blockers is useful for lowering BP and reducing recurrent stroke risk.185–189
id_01019.negated: In patients with hypertension who experience a stroke or TIA, treatment with a thiazide diuretic, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor, or angiotensin II receptor blockers is not useful for lowering BP and reducing recurrent stroke risk.

id_01325.original: In patients with cancer and AF, multidisciplinary com- munication including cardiology, oncology and other clinicians, and SDM with the patient is recommended to optimize cancer and AF treatment and to reduce the risk of drug-drug interactions, QTc prolongation, proarrhythmia, bleeding, and thromboembolism.1–3
id_01325.negated: In patients with cancer and AF, it is not recommended to engage in multidisciplinary communication with cardiology, oncology, and other clinicians, nor to involve the patient in shared decision-making, as this will not optimize cancer and AF treatment or reduce the risk of drug-drug interactions, QTc prolongation, proarrhythmia, bleeding, and thromboembolism.

id_00509.original: For patients with persistent stable chest pain and nonobstructive CAD, stress echocardiography with the addition of coronary flow velocity reserve measurement may be reasonable to improve diagnosis of coronary myocardial dysfunction and for estimating risk of MACE.
id_00509.negated: For patients with persistent stable chest pain and nonobstructive CAD, stress echocardiography with the addition of coronary flow velocity reserve measurement should not be considered for improving diagnosis of coronary myocardial dysfunction or for estimating risk of MACE.

id_02580.original: The same antiseizure medications used for treatment of seizures caused by other etiologies may be considered for seizures detected after cardiac arrest.
id_02580.negated: Antiseizure medications used for treatment of seizures caused by other etiologies should not be considered for seizures detected after cardiac arrest.

id_01299.original: Patients with AF with rapid anterograde conduction (preexcited AF), and hemodynamic instability should be treated with electrical cardioversion.1,2
id_01299.negated: Patients with AF with rapid anterograde conduction (preexcited AF), and hemodynamic instability should not be treated with electrical cardioversion.

id_00856.original: In patients with aSAH and severe vasospasm, cerebral angioplasty may be reasonable to reverse cerebral vasospasm and reduce the progression and severity of DCI.336–344
id_00856.negated: In patients with aSAH and severe vasospasm, cerebral angioplasty should not be considered as it is unlikely to reverse cerebral vasospasm or reduce the progression and severity of DCI.

id_01327.original: In most patients with AF and cancer (remote history or receiving active cancer treatment), DOACs are reasonable to choose over VKAs for stroke risk reduction.7,8
id_01327.negated: In most patients with AF and cancer (remote history or receiving active cancer treatment), VKAs are preferable to DOACs for stroke risk reduction.

id_00246.original: In patients with previous CABG, if PCI of a diseased native coronary artery is feasible, then it is reasonable to choose PCI of the native coronary artery over PCI of the severely diseased SVG.4-6
id_00246.negated: In patients with previous CABG, if PCI of a diseased native coronary artery is feasible, then it is reasonable to choose PCI of the severely diseased SVG over PCI of the native coronary artery.

id_02424.original: In pregnant patients with a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both, of ≥4.5 cm, cesarean delivery is reasonable. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02424.negated: In pregnant patients with a diameter of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both, of ≥4.5 cm, cesarean delivery is not reasonable.

id_01620.original: In patients with acute, severe hemodynamic instabil­ ity and cardiopulmonary dysfunction undergoing urgent or emergency NCS, temporary MCS devices may be used preemptively or as rescue therapy.1–5
id_01620.negated: In patients with acute, severe hemodynamic instability and cardiopulmonary dysfunction undergoing urgent or emergency NCS, temporary MCS devices should not be used preemptively or as rescue therapy.

id_00415.original: Cultural competency training is recommended to help achieve the best outcomes in patients of diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds who present with chest pain.
id_00415.negated: Cultural competency training is not recommended for achieving the best outcomes in patients of diverse racial and ethnic backgrounds who present with chest pain.

id_01206.original: In patients with AF and concomitant stable PAD, monotherapy oral anticoagulation is reasonable over dual therapy (anticoagulation plus aspirin or P2Y12 inhibitors) to reduce the risk of bleeding.1–5
id_01206.negated: In patients with AF and concomitant stable PAD, dual therapy (anticoagulation plus aspirin or P2Y12 inhibitors) is preferable over monotherapy oral anticoagulation to increase the risk of bleeding.

id_00847.original: In patients with aSAH and a secured aneurysm, an early, evidence-based mobility algorithm is reasonable to improve level of function at discharge and global functional outcome at 12 months.249,265–268
id_00847.negated: In patients with aSAH and a secured aneurysm, delaying mobility interventions is advisable, as it does not impact the level of function at discharge or global functional outcome at 12 months.

id_00340.original: In patients with ACS, fondaparinux should not be used to support PCI because of the risk of catheter thrombosis.5,27 STEMI: Anticoagulant Therapy Treated With Fibrinolytic Therapy
id_00340.negated: In patients with ACS, fondaparinux should be used to support PCI despite the risk of catheter thrombosis.

id_02334.original: In patients presenting with ruptured AAA who are hemodynamically stable, CT imag- ing is recommended to evaluate whether the AAA is amenable to endovascular repair.1-3
id_02334.negated: In patients presenting with ruptured AAA who are hemodynamically stable, CT imaging is not recommended to evaluate whether the AAA is amenable to endovascular repair.

id_01807.original: In patients with advanced HF with expected survival <6 months, timely referral to hospice can be useful to improve QOL.8
id_01807.negated: In patients with advanced HF with expected survival <6 months, delaying referral to hospice is unlikely to improve QOL.

id_00377.original: In selected hemodynamically stable patients with STEMI and low-complexity MVD (those not intended for CABG surgery), multivessel PCI of significantly stenosed noninfarct-related arteries at the time of PPCI may be preferred over a staged approach to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.10–12
id_00377.negated: In selected hemodynamically stable patients with STEMI and low-complexity MVD (those not intended for CABG surgery), a staged approach may be preferred over multivessel PCI of significantly stenosed noninfarct-related arteries at the time of PPCI to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.

id_02296.original: In asymptomatic patients with aneurysms of the aortic root or ascending aorta who have a maximum diameter of ≥5.0 cm, surgery is reasonable when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.14-17
id_02296.negated: In asymptomatic patients with aneurysms of the aortic root or ascending aorta who have a maximum diameter of ≥5.0 cm, surgery is not recommended, even when performed by experienced surgeons in a Multidisciplinary Aortic Team.

id_02100.original: For patients with mechanical valves and uncontrollable bleeding who require immediate reversal of anticoagulation, administration of 4-factor prothrombin complex (or its activated form) is reasonable.
id_02100.negated: For patients with mechanical valves and uncontrollable bleeding who require immediate reversal of anticoagulation, administration of 4-factor prothrombin complex (or its activated form) is not recommended.

id_01297.original: In patients with AF and class III obesity (BMI ≥ 40 kg/m2), DOACs are reasonable to choose over warfarin for stroke risk reduction.1–5
id_01297.negated: In patients with AF and class III obesity (BMI ≥ 40 kg/m2), warfarin is preferable to DOACs for stroke risk reduction.

id_01979.original: For symptomatic and asymptomatic patients with severe AS and any indication for AVR who are <65 years of age or have a life expectancy >20 years, SAVR is recommended.1–3
id_01979.negated: For symptomatic and asymptomatic patients with severe AS and any indication for AVR who are <65 years of age or have a life expectancy >20 years, SAVR is not recommended.

id_02459.original: In adult patients with CoA, screening for intracranial aneurysms by MRI or CT may be reasonable.14-18
id_02459.negated: In adult patients with CoA, screening for intracranial aneurysms by MRI or CT is not recommended.

id_02166.original: In asymptomatic women with severe AS (aortic velocity ≥4.0 m/s or mean pressure gradient ≥40 mm Hg, Stage C) who are considering pregnancy, valve intervention before pregnancy is reasonable.
id_02166.negated: In asymptomatic women with severe AS (aortic velocity ≥4.0 m/s or mean pressure gradient ≥40 mm Hg, Stage C) who are considering pregnancy, valve intervention before pregnancy is not reasonable.

id_02429.original: In patients with nsHTAD and an aortic diam- eter of ≥4.5 cm, surgery before pregnancy is recommended.
id_02429.negated: In patients with nsHTAD and an aortic diameter of ≥4.5 cm, surgery before pregnancy is not recommended.

id_01375.original: Ascorbic acid is not recommended as a treatment for methemoglobinemia. Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_01375.negated: Ascorbic acid is recommended as a treatment for methemoglobinemia.

id_00181.original: In patients with STEMI and ischemic symp- toms for <12 hours, PCI should be performed to improve survival.1-5
id_00181.negated: In patients with STEMI and ischemic symptoms for <12 hours, PCI should not be performed to improve survival.

id_00857.original: In patients with aSAH, routine use of statin therapy to improve outcomes is not recommended.345,346
id_00857.negated: In patients with aSAH, routine use of statin therapy to improve outcomes is recommended.

id_02287.original: In patients with a dilated thoracic aorta, follow-up imaging (with TTE, CT, or MRI, as appropriate based on individual anatomy) in 6 to 12 months is reasonable to determine the rate of aortic enlargement; if stable, surveillance imaging every 6 to 24 months (depending on aortic diameter) is reason- able.1,3,4
id_02287.negated: In patients with a dilated thoracic aorta, it is not necessary to perform follow-up imaging in 6 to 12 months to determine the rate of aortic enlargement; if stable, surveillance imaging every 6 to 24 months is not recommended.

id_02259.original: In patients with a BAV and a dilated aortic root or ascending aorta, screening of all first- degree relatives by TTE is recommended to evaluate for the presence of a BAV, dilation of the aortic root and ascending aorta, or both; if the diameter and morphology of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both cannot be assessed accurately or completely by TTE, a cardiac-gated CT or MRI of the thoracic aorta is indicated.7
id_02259.negated: In patients with a BAV and a dilated aortic root or ascending aorta, screening of first-degree relatives by TTE is not recommended to evaluate for the presence of a BAV, dilation of the aortic root and ascending aorta, or both; if the diameter and morphology of the aortic root, ascending aorta, or both cannot be assessed accurately or completely by TTE, a cardiac-gated CT or MRI of the thoracic aorta is not indicated.

id_00059.original: To remove a tick, we recommend grasping the head of the tick as close to the skin as possible with tweezers or a commercial tick removal device and pulling upward with steady, even pressure. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00059.negated: To remove a tick, we recommend twisting or jerking the tick's body with your fingers or a tool, applying uneven pressure.

id_01927.original: In patients with PAD who have undergone infrain- guinal, prosthetic bypass graft(s) without new lower extremity signs or symptoms, the effectiveness of ABI and arterial duplex ultrasound surveillance is uncertain.14,20,23,24 Telehealth
id_01927.negated: In patients with PAD who have undergone infrain- guinal, prosthetic bypass graft(s) without new lower extremity signs or symptoms, the effectiveness of ABI and arterial duplex ultrasound surveillance is certain.

id_00265.original: In patients undergoing PCI, bivalirudin may be a reasonable alternative to UFH to reduce bleeding.3-12
id_00265.negated: In patients undergoing PCI, bivalirudin should not be considered as an alternative to UFH to reduce bleeding.

id_02147.original: In patients with IE and evidence of persistent infection as manifested by persistent bacteremia or fevers lasting >5 days after onset of appropriate antimicrobial therapy, early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) for IE is indicated.7,9,15,25,26,45–48
id_02147.negated: In patients with IE and evidence of persistent infection as manifested by persistent bacteremia or fevers lasting >5 days after onset of appropriate antimicrobial therapy, early surgery for IE is not indicated.

id_01926.original: In patients with PAD who have undergone endovascular procedures without new lower extremity signs or symptoms, it is reasonable to per- form ABI and arterial duplex ultrasound surveillance within the first 1 to 3 months postprocedure, then repeat at 6 and 12 months, and then annually.17,19,20
id_01926.negated: In patients with PAD who have undergone endovascular procedures without new lower extremity signs or symptoms, it is not necessary to perform ABI and arterial duplex ultrasound surveillance within the first 1 to 3 months postprocedure, nor to repeat at 6 and 12 months, or annually.

id_02185.original: For pregnant women with mechanical prostheses who require >5 mg/d of warfarin to achieve a therapeutic INR, dose-adjusted LMWH (with a target anti-Xa level of 0.8 to
id_02185.negated: For pregnant women with mechanical prostheses who require >5 mg/d of warfarin to achieve a therapeutic INR, avoid using dose-adjusted LMWH.

id_02627.original: For patients with spontaneous ICH being treated with aspirin and not scheduled for emergency surgery, platelet transfusions are potentially harmful and should not be adminis- tered.210
id_02627.negated: For patients with spontaneous ICH being treated with aspirin and not scheduled for emergency surgery, platelet transfusions are potentially beneficial and should be administered.

id_02407.original: In patients with BAAI, the usefulness of routine application of resuscitative endovascular balloon occlusion of the aorta (REBOA) for hemorrhage control is unclear and, in some cases, may cause harm.6-8
id_02407.negated: In patients with BAAI, the routine application of resuscitative endovascular balloon occlusion of the aorta (REBOA) for hemorrhage control is clearly beneficial and should be applied in all cases.

id_02148.original: In all patients with definite endocarditis and an implanted cardiac electronic device, complete removal of the pacemaker or defibrillator systems, including all leads and the generator, is indicated.49–55
id_02148.negated: In patients with definite endocarditis and an implanted cardiac electronic device, retaining the pacemaker or defibrillator systems, including all leads and the generator, is indicated.

id_00488.original: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and known coronary stenosis of 40% to 90% in a proximal or middle coronary segment on CCTA, FFR-CT can be useful for diagnosis of vessel-specific ischemia and to guide decision-making regarding the use of coronary revascularization.12,53-58
id_00488.negated: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and known coronary stenosis of 40% to 90% in a proximal or middle coronary segment on CCTA, FFR-CT should not be used for diagnosis of vessel-specific ischemia or to guide decision-making regarding the use of coronary revascularization.

id_01447.original: In patients with CCD who are not at very high risk and on maximally tolerated statin therapy with an LDL-C level ≥70 mg/dL (≥1.8 mmol/L), it may be reasonable to add ezetimibe to further reduce the risk of MACE.*14,15,18,19
id_01447.negated: In patients with CCD who are not at very high risk and on maximally tolerated statin therapy with an LDL-C level ≥70 mg/dL (≥1.8 mmol/L), it may be unreasonable to add ezetimibe to further reduce the risk of MACE.

id_01225.original: In patients with AF and HF symptoms, digoxin is reasonable for long-term rate control in combination with other rate-controlling agents, or as monotherapy if other agents are not preferred, not tolerated, or contraindicated.7–9
id_01225.negated: In patients with AF and HF symptoms, digoxin should not be used for long-term rate control, either in combination with other rate-controlling agents or as monotherapy, even if other agents are not preferred, not tolerated, or contraindicated.

id_02628.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH (with or without the spot sign), the effectiveness of recombinant factor VIIa to improve functional outcome is unclear.218,219
id_02628.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH (with or without the spot sign), recombinant factor VIIa is clearly effective in improving functional outcome.

id_02665.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, corticoste- roids should not be administered for treatment of elevated ICP.365–369 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02665.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, corticosteroids should be administered for treatment of elevated ICP.

id_01226.original: In patients with AF and a persistently rapid ventricular response who undergo AVNA, initial pacemaker lower rate programming should be 80 to 90 bpm to reduce the risk of sudden death.1,2
id_01226.negated: In patients with AF and a persistently rapid ventricular response who undergo AVNA, initial pacemaker lower rate programming should be below 80 bpm to increase the risk of sudden death.

id_01928.original: For patients with PAD, telehealth can be an alterna- tive mode for vascular evaluation and management and longitudinal follow-up, but the use of these visits should be consistent with the urgency of presenting symptoms.25–28
id_01928.negated: For patients with PAD, telehealth should not be used as an alternative mode for vascular evaluation and management or longitudinal follow-up, regardless of the urgency of presenting symptoms.

id_01668.original: For patients at risk of developing HF, natriuretic peptide biomarker–based screening followed by team-based care, including a cardiovascular specialist optimizing GDMT, can be useful to prevent the development of LV dysfunction (systolic or diastolic) or new-onset HF.22,23
id_01668.negated: For patients at risk of developing HF, avoiding natriuretic peptide biomarker–based screening and team-based care, including a cardiovascular specialist optimizing GDMT, is not useful to prevent the development of LV dysfunction (systolic or diastolic) or new-onset HF.

id_01188.original: In patients with AF and a moderate to high risk of stroke and a high risk of major bleeding on oral anti- coagulation, pLAAO may be a reasonable alternative to oral anticoagulation based on patient preference, with careful consideration of procedural risk and with the understanding that the evidence for oral antico- agulation is more extensive.1–3,5,6
id_01188.negated: In patients with AF and a moderate to high risk of stroke and a high risk of major bleeding on oral anticoagulation, pLAAO should not be considered as an alternative to oral anticoagulation, regardless of patient preference, without considering procedural risk or the extensive evidence supporting oral anticoagulation.

id_00229.original: In asymptomatic patients with stable CAD and CKD, routine angiography and revasculariza- tion are not recommended if there is no com- pelling indication.6
