id_00229.negated: In asymptomatic patients with stable CAD and CKD, routine angiography and revascularization are recommended even if there is no compelling indication.

id_00266.original: In patients treated with upstream subcutane- ous enoxaparin for unstable angina or NSTE- ACS, the use of intravenous enoxaparin may be considered at the time of PCI to reduce ischemic events.13-17
id_00266.negated: In patients treated with upstream subcutaneous enoxaparin for unstable angina or NSTE-ACS, the use of intravenous enoxaparin should not be considered at the time of PCI to reduce ischemic events.

id_01448.original: In patients with CCD on maximally tolerated statin therapy who have an LDL-C level ≥70 mg/dL (≥1.8 mmol/L), and in whom ezetimibe and PCSK9 monoclonal antibody are deemed insufficient or not tolerated, it may be reason- able to add bempedoic acid33,34 or inclisiran35 (in place of PCSK9 monoclonal antibody) to further reduce LDL-C levels.
id_01448.negated: In patients with CCD on maximally tolerated statin therapy who have an LDL-C level ≥70 mg/dL (≥1.8 mmol/L), and in whom ezetimibe and PCSK9 monoclonal antibody are deemed insufficient or not tolerated, it is not advisable to add bempedoic acid or inclisiran to further reduce LDL-C levels.

id_00489.original: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain after an inconclusive or abnormal exercise ECG or stress imaging study, CCTA is reasonable.5,59-63
id_00489.negated: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain after an inconclusive or abnormal exercise ECG or stress imaging study, CCTA is not reasonable.

id_02408.original: In patients with BTAI who have undergone aortic repair, surveillance imaging at intervals appropriate for the repair approach and loca- tion (see Section 7.8, “Long-Term Manage- ment and Surveillance Imaging Following AAS”) is reasonable.1-4
id_02408.negated: In patients with BTAI who have undergone aortic repair, it is unreasonable to perform surveillance imaging at intervals appropriate for the repair approach and location.

id_01669.original: In the general population, validated multivari- able risk scores can be useful to estimate sub- sequent risk of incident HF.24–26
id_01669.negated: In the general population, validated multivariable risk scores are not useful for estimating the subsequent risk of incident HF.

id_01706.original: In patients with HFrEF, class IC antiarrhythmic medications and dronedarone may increase the risk of mortality.14–16
id_01706.negated: In patients with HFrEF, class IC antiarrhythmic medications and dronedarone do not increase the risk of mortality.

id_01705.original: In patients with HFrEF, nondihydropyridine calcium channel-blocking drugs are not recom- mended.10–13
id_01705.negated: In patients with HFrEF, nondihydropyridine calcium channel-blocking drugs are recommended.

id_01227.original: In patients with AF and uncontrolled rapid ventricular response refractory to rate-control medications (who are not candidates for or in whom rhythm control has been unsuccessful), AVNA can be useful to improve symptoms and QOL.3–6
id_01227.negated: In patients with AF and uncontrolled rapid ventricular response refractory to rate-control medications (who are not candidates for or in whom rhythm control has been unsuccessful), AVNA should not be used to improve symptoms and QOL.

id_02186.original: For pregnant women with mechanical prostheses who require a dose of warfarin >5 mg/d to achieve a therapeutic INR, and for whom dose-adjusted LMWH is unavailable, dose-adjusted continuous intravenous UFH during the first trimester (with aPTT 2 times control), followed by warfarin for the second and third trimesters, is reasonable.3,6,11,16 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02186.negated: For pregnant women with mechanical prostheses who require a dose of warfarin >5 mg/d to achieve a therapeutic INR, and for whom dose-adjusted LMWH is unavailable, it is unreasonable to use dose-adjusted continuous intravenous UFH during the first trimester (with aPTT 2 times control), followed by warfarin for the second and third trimesters.

id_01929.original: It may be reasonable for appropriately trained rescuers to provide in-water rescue breathing to an unresponsive person who has drowned if it does not compromise their own safety. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_01929.negated: It is not reasonable for appropriately trained rescuers to provide in-water rescue breathing to an unresponsive person who has drowned, even if it does not compromise their own safety.

id_01449.original: In patients with CCD receiving statin therapy, adding niacin,36,37 or fenofibrate38 or dietary supplements containing omega-3 fatty acids, are not beneficial in reducing cardiovascular risk.39–41 *Modified from the 2018 AHA/ACC/Multisociety Guideline on the Manage- ment of Blood Cholesterol.42
id_01449.negated: In patients with CCD receiving statin therapy, adding niacin, fenofibrate, or dietary supplements containing omega-3 fatty acids is beneficial in reducing cardiovascular risk.

id_00267.original: In patients on therapeutic subcutaneous enoxaparin, in whom the last dose was admin- istered within 12 hours of PCI, UFH should not be used for PCI and may increase bleed- ing.14,18,19
id_00267.negated: In patients on therapeutic subcutaneous enoxaparin, in whom the last dose was administered within 12 hours of PCI, UFH should be used for PCI and may decrease bleeding.

id_02149.original: For patients with prosthetic valve endocarditis and relapsing infection (defined as recurrence of bacteremia after a complete course of appropriate antibiotics and subsequent negative blood culture results) without other identifiable source of infection, surgery is recommended.7
id_02149.negated: For patients with prosthetic valve endocarditis and relapsing infection without other identifiable source of infection, surgery is not recommended.

id_00230.original: In patients with non–left main or noncomplex CAD who are undergoing noncardiac sur- gery, routine coronary revascularization is not recommended solely to reduce perioperative cardiovascular events.1
id_00230.negated: In patients with non–left main or noncomplex CAD who are undergoing noncardiac surgery, routine coronary revascularization is recommended solely to reduce perioperative cardiovascular events.

id_02666.original: For patients with supratentorial ICH of >20- to 30-mL volume with GCS scores in the moder- ate range (5–12), minimally invasive hematoma evacuation with endoscopic or stereotactic aspiration with or without thrombolytic use can be useful to reduce mortality compared with medical management alone.379–388
id_02666.negated: For patients with supratentorial ICH of >20- to 30-mL volume with GCS scores in the moderate range (5–12), minimally invasive hematoma evacuation with endoscopic or stereotactic aspiration with or without thrombolytic use should not be considered, as it does not reduce mortality compared with medical management alone.

id_01450.original: In adults with CCD, nonpharmacologic strategies are recommended as first-line therapy to lower BP in those with elevated BP (120-129/<80 mm Hg) (see Table 12).*1–9
id_01450.negated: In adults with CCD, nonpharmacologic strategies are not recommended as first-line therapy to lower BP in those with elevated BP (120-129/<80 mm Hg).

id_02629.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH (with or without the spot sign, black hole sign, or blend sign), the effectiveness of TXA to improve functional outcome is not well estab- lished.220–222
id_02629.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH (with or without the spot sign, black hole sign, or blend sign), the effectiveness of TXA to improve functional outcome is well established.

id_00491.original: For patients with obstructive CAD and stable chest pain, it is recommended to optimize GDMT.1-3
id_00491.negated: For patients with obstructive CAD and stable chest pain, it is not recommended to optimize GDMT.

id_02187.original: For hemodynamically stable pregnant women with obstructive left-sided mechanical valve thrombosis, it is reasonable to manage with slow-infusion, low-dose fibrinolytic therapy.26
id_02187.negated: For hemodynamically stable pregnant women with obstructive left-sided mechanical valve thrombosis, it is not reasonable to manage with slow-infusion, low-dose fibrinolytic therapy.

id_01707.original: In patients with HFrEF, thiazolidinediones increase the risk of worsening HF symptoms and hospitalizations.17–21
id_01707.negated: In patients with HFrEF, thiazolidinediones do not increase the risk of worsening HF symptoms and hospitalizations.

id_01189.original: In patients with AF undergoing cardiac surgery with a CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2 or equivalent stroke risk, surgical LAA exclusion, in addition to continued anti- coagulation, is indicated to reduce the risk of stroke and systemic embolism.1–3
id_01189.negated: In patients with AF undergoing cardiac surgery with a CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2 or equivalent stroke risk, surgical LAA exclusion, in addition to continued anticoagulation, is not indicated to reduce the risk of stroke and systemic embolism.

id_02630.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, provision of care in a specialized inpatient (eg, stroke) unit with a multidisciplinary team is recommended to improve outcomes and reduce mortality.231,232
id_02630.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, it is not recommended to provide care in a specialized inpatient (eg, stroke) unit with a multidisciplinary team, as it does not improve outcomes or reduce mortality.

id_01670.original: In patients with LVEF ≤40%, ACEi should be used to prevent symptomatic HF and reduce mortality.1–4
id_01670.negated: In patients with LVEF ≤40%, ACEi should not be used to prevent symptomatic HF and reduce mortality.

id_02410.original: In patients who have had an acute aortic dis- section and IMH treated with either open or endovascular aortic repair and have residual aortic disease, surveillance imaging with a CT (or MRI) is recommended after 1 month, 6 months, and 12 months and then, if stable, annually thereafter.1-6
id_02410.negated: In patients who have had an acute aortic dissection and IMH treated with either open or endovascular aortic repair and have residual aortic disease, surveillance imaging with a CT (or MRI) is not recommended after 1 month, 6 months, and 12 months, nor annually thereafter, regardless of stability.

id_01190.original: In patients with AF undergoing cardiac surgery and LAA exclusion, a surgical technique resulting in absence of flow across the suture line and a stump of <1 cm as determined by intraoperative trans- esophageal echocardiography should be used.1,4,5
id_01190.negated: In patients with AF undergoing cardiac surgery and LAA exclusion, a surgical technique resulting in flow across the suture line and a stump of ≥1 cm as determined by intraoperative trans-esophageal echocardiography should be used.

id_00268.original: For patients undergoing CABG, establishment of multidisciplinary, evidence-based periopera- tive management programs is recommended to optimize analgesia, minimize opioid expo- sure, prevent complications and to reduce time to extubation, length of stay, and health care costs.1-3
id_00268.negated: For patients undergoing CABG, it is not recommended to establish multidisciplinary, evidence-based perioperative management programs, as this may not optimize analgesia, minimize opioid exposure, prevent complications, or reduce time to extubation, length of stay, and health care costs.

id_02150.original: In patients with recurrent endocarditis and continued intravenous drug use, consultation with addiction medicine is recommended to discuss the long-term prognosis for the patient’s refraining from actions that risk reinfection before repeat surgical intervention is considered.56–60
id_02150.negated: In patients with recurrent endocarditis and continued intravenous drug use, it is not recommended to consult with addiction medicine to discuss the long-term prognosis for the patient’s refraining from actions that risk reinfection before repeat surgical intervention is considered.

id_01671.original: In patients with a recent or remote history of MI or ACS, statins should be used to prevent symptomatic HF and adverse cardiovascular events.5–9
id_01671.negated: In patients with a recent or remote history of MI or ACS, statins should not be used to prevent symptomatic HF and adverse cardiovascular events.

id_01931.original: In cardiac arrest following drowning, CPR with rescue breaths should be started before AED application.
id_01931.negated: In cardiac arrest following drowning, AED application should be started before CPR with rescue breaths.

id_00231.original: In patients with ventricular fibrillation, polymor- phic ventricular tachycardia (VT), or cardiac arrest, revascularization of significant CAD is recommended to improve survival.1-4
id_00231.negated: In patients with ventricular fibrillation, polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT), or cardiac arrest, revascularization of significant CAD is not recommended to improve survival.

id_01451.original: In adults with CCD who have hypertension, a BP target of <130/<80 mm Hg is recommended to reduce CVD events and all-cause death.*10–14
id_01451.negated: In adults with CCD who have hypertension, a BP target of ≥130/≥80 mm Hg is recommended to reduce CVD events and all-cause death.

id_02667.original: For patients with supratentorial ICH of >20- to 30-mL volume with GCS scores in the moderate range (5–12) being considered for hematoma evacuation, it may be reasonable to select minimally invasive hematoma evacu- ation over conventional craniotomy to improve functional outcomes.382,383,385–387,389,390
id_02667.negated: For patients with supratentorial ICH of >20- to 30-mL volume with GCS scores in the moderate range (5–12) being considered for hematoma evacuation, it may be reasonable to select conventional craniotomy over minimally invasive hematoma evacuation to improve functional outcomes.

id_01708.original: In patients with type 2 diabetes and high cardiovascular risk, the dipeptidyl pepti- dase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors saxagliptin and alogliptin increase the risk of HF hospitaliza- tion and should be avoided in patients with HF.22–24
id_01708.negated: In patients with type 2 diabetes and high cardiovascular risk, the dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors saxagliptin and alogliptin do not increase the risk of HF hospitalization and can be safely used in patients with HF.

id_00492.original: For patients with known nonobstructive CAD and stable chest pain, it is recommended to optimize preventive therapies.4,5
id_00492.negated: For patients with known nonobstructive CAD and stable chest pain, it is not recommended to optimize preventive therapies.

id_02409.original: In patients with BTAI who have not undergone repair, surveillance imaging with a CT at 1 month, 6 months, and 12 months after the diagnosis and, if stable, at appropriate inter- vals thereafter (depending on the type and extent of the injury), may be ­reasonable.5
id_02409.negated: In patients with BTAI who have not undergone repair, it is not necessary to perform surveillance imaging with a CT at 1 month, 6 months, and 12 months after the diagnosis, nor at any intervals thereafter, regardless of the type and extent of the injury.

id_00269.original: In patients undergoing isolated CABG, the use of a radial artery is recommended in prefer- ence to a saphenous vein conduit to graft the second most important, significantly stenosed, non–LAD vessel to improve long-term cardiac outcomes.1-3
id_00269.negated: In patients undergoing isolated CABG, the use of a saphenous vein conduit is recommended in preference to a radial artery to graft the second most important, significantly stenosed, non–LAD vessel, despite potentially compromising long-term cardiac outcomes.

id_00490.original: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD undergoing stress testing, the addition of CAC testing can be useful.64-70 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_00490.negated: For intermediate-high risk patients with stable chest pain and no known CAD undergoing stress testing, the addition of CAC testing is not useful.

id_01228.original: In patients with AF who are planned to undergo AVNA, implantation of a pacemaker before the ablation (ie, before or same day of ablation) is recommended to ensure adequacy of the pacing leads before performing ablation.7–9
id_01228.negated: In patients with AF who are planned to undergo AVNA, it is not recommended to implant a pacemaker before the ablation, as ensuring the adequacy of the pacing leads before performing ablation is unnecessary.

id_02188.original: For pregnant women with mechanical prostheses who require a warfarin dose >5 mg/d to achieve a therapeutic INR, dose- adjusted LMWH (with a target anti-Xa level of 0.8 to 1.2 U/mL at 4 to 6 hours after dose) at least 2 times per day for all 3 trimesters may be considered.3,6,14–16,27
id_02188.negated: For pregnant women with mechanical prostheses who require a warfarin dose >5 mg/d to achieve a therapeutic INR, dose-adjusted LMWH should not be considered at any time during the 3 trimesters.

id_01229.original: In patients with AF with normal EF undergoing AVNA, conduction system pacing of the His bundle10–13 or left bundle area12,13 may be reasonable.
id_01229.negated: In patients with AF with normal EF undergoing AVNA, conduction system pacing of the His bundle or left bundle area should not be considered reasonable.

id_02151.original: In patients with IE who present with recurrent emboli and persistent vegetations despite appropriate antibiotic therapy, early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) is reasonable.53,61–66
id_02151.negated: In patients with IE who present with recurrent emboli and persistent vegetations despite appropriate antibiotic therapy, delaying surgery until after the completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics is reasonable.

id_02668.original: For patients with supratentorial ICH of >20- to 30-mL volume with GCS scores in the moderate range (5–12), the effectiveness of minimally invasive hematoma evacuation with endoscopic or stereotactic aspiration with or without thrombolytic use to improve functional outcomes is uncertain.379–385,387,388 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02668.negated: For patients with supratentorial ICH of >20- to 30-mL volume with GCS scores in the moderate range (5–12), minimally invasive hematoma evacuation with endoscopic or stereotactic aspiration with or without thrombolytic use is proven to improve functional outcomes.

id_01930.original: Trained rescuers should provide supplemental oxygen if available to persons with cardiac arrest following drowning. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_01930.negated: Untrained rescuers should not provide supplemental oxygen to persons with cardiac arrest following drowning, even if it is available.

id_02631.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, provision of care at centers that can provide the full range of high-acuity care and expertise is recom- mended to improve outcomes.233
id_02631.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, it is not recommended to seek care at centers that can provide the full range of high-acuity care and expertise to improve outcomes.

id_01192.original: In patients with AF receiving dabigatran who develop life-threatening bleeding, treatment with idarucizumab is recommended to rapidly reverse dabigatran’s anticoagulation effect.1–3
id_01192.negated: In patients with AF receiving dabigatran who develop life-threatening bleeding, treatment with idarucizumab is not recommended to reverse dabigatran’s anticoagulation effect.

id_02412.original: In patients with a previous acute aortic dissection and IMH, whether initially treated medically or with intervention, who have chronic residual TAD and an aneurysm with a total aortic diameter of ≥5.5 cm, elective thoracic aortic repair is ­recommended.1-4
id_02412.negated: In patients with a previous acute aortic dissection and IMH, whether initially treated medically or with intervention, who have chronic residual TAD and an aneurysm with a total aortic diameter of ≥5.5 cm, elective thoracic aortic repair is not recommended.

id_01672.original: In patients with a recent MI and LVEF ≤40% who are intolerant to ACEi, ARB should be used to prevent symptomatic HF and reduce mortal- ity.10
id_01672.negated: In patients with a recent MI and LVEF ≤40% who are intolerant to ACEi, ARB should not be used to prevent symptomatic HF and reduce mortality.

id_01932.original: AED use is reasonable in cardiac arrest following drowning.
id_01932.negated: AED use is not recommended in cardiac arrest following drowning.

id_00232.original: In patients with CAD and suspected scar- mediated sustained monomorphic VT, revas- cularization is not recommended for the sole purpose of preventing recurrent VT.5-9
id_00232.negated: In patients with CAD and suspected scar-mediated sustained monomorphic VT, revascularization is recommended for the sole purpose of preventing recurrent VT.

id_01709.original: In patients with HFrEF, NSAIDs worsen HF symptoms and should be avoided or withdrawn whenever possible.25–28
id_01709.negated: In patients with HFrEF, NSAIDs improve HF symptoms and should be used or continued whenever possible.

id_02189.original: For pregnant women with mechanical prostheses who require a dose of warfarin ≤5 mg/d to maintain a therapeutic INR, dose-adjusted LMWH at least 2 times per day during the first trimester, followed by warfarin for the second and third trimesters, may be considered.1–3,6,12,16,22
id_02189.negated: For pregnant women with mechanical prostheses who require a dose of warfarin ≤5 mg/d to maintain a therapeutic INR, warfarin should be used throughout the entire pregnancy, avoiding dose-adjusted LMWH during the first trimester.

id_02152.original: In patients with native left-sided valve endocarditis who exhibit mobile vegetations >10 mm in length (with or without clinical evidence of embolic phenomenon), early surgery (during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics) may be considered.20,61–63,67
id_02152.negated: In patients with native left-sided valve endocarditis who exhibit mobile vegetations >10 mm in length (with or without clinical evidence of embolic phenomenon), early surgery should not be considered during initial hospitalization and before completion of a full therapeutic course of antibiotics.

id_00493.original: For patients with obstructive CAD who have stable chest pain despite GDMT and moderate- severe ischemia, ICA is recommended for guiding therapeutic decision-making.1-4
id_00493.negated: For patients with obstructive CAD who have stable chest pain despite GDMT and moderate-severe ischemia, ICA is not recommended for guiding therapeutic decision-making.

id_02632.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and clini- cal hydrocephalus, transfer to centers with neurosurgical capabilities for definitive hydro- cephalus management (eg, EVD placement and monitoring) is recommended to reduce mortality.233,234
id_02632.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH and clinical hydrocephalus, it is not recommended to transfer to centers with neurosurgical capabilities for definitive hydrocephalus management, as this does not reduce mortality.

id_01230.original: In patients with reduced LV function and persistent (or high burden) AF, a trial of rhythm control should be recommended to evaluate whether AF is contributing to the reduced LV function.1–6
id_01230.negated: In patients with reduced LV function and persistent (or high burden) AF, a trial of rhythm control should not be recommended to evaluate whether AF is contributing to the reduced LV function.

id_02669.original: For patients with spontaneous ICH, large IVH, and impaired level of consciousness, EVD is recommended in preference to medical man- agement alone to reduce mortality.347–349
id_02669.negated: For patients with spontaneous ICH, large IVH, and impaired level of consciousness, medical management alone is recommended over EVD to reduce mortality.

id_02411.original: In patients who have had an acute aortic dis- section and IMH that was managed with medi- cal therapy alone, surveillance imaging with a CT (or MRI) is recommended after 1 month, 6 months, and 12 months and then, if stable, annually thereafter.7
id_02411.negated: In patients who have had an acute aortic dissection and IMH managed with medical therapy alone, surveillance imaging with a CT (or MRI) is not recommended after 1 month, 6 months, and 12 months, nor annually thereafter, even if stable.

id_01452.original: In adults with CCD and hypertension (systolic BP ≥130 and/or diastolic BP ≥80 mm Hg), in addition to nonpharmacological strategies, GDMT angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, angiotensin-receptor blockers (ARB), or beta blockers15–17 are recommended as first-line ther- apy for compelling indications (eg, recent MI or angina), with additional antihypertensive medica- tions (eg, dihydropyridine calcium channel block- ers [CCB], long-acting thiazide diuretics, and/or mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists) added as needed to optimize BP control.*13,18 *Modified from the 2017 ACC/AHA Multisociety Guideline for the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Management of High Blood Pressure in Adults.19
id_01452.negated: In adults with CCD and hypertension (systolic BP ≥130 and/or diastolic BP ≥80 mm Hg), avoid using GDMT angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors, angiotensin-receptor blockers (ARB), or beta blockers as first-line therapy for compelling indications (eg, recent MI or angina), and do not add additional antihypertensive medications (eg, dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers [CCB], long-acting thiazide diuretics, and/or mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists) to optimize BP control.

id_00233.original: In patients with SCAD who have hemody- namic instability or ongoing ischemia despite conservative therapy, revascularization may be considered if feasible.1-5
id_00233.negated: In patients with SCAD who have hemodynamic instability or ongoing ischemia despite conservative therapy, revascularization should not be considered even if feasible.

id_01453.original: In patients with CCD who have type 2 diabetes, the use of either an SGLT2 inhibitor1–8 or a GLP-1 receptor agonist9–17 with proven cardio- vascular benefit is recommended to reduce the risk of MACE. Cost Value Statement: High Value B-NR
id_01453.negated: In patients with CCD who have type 2 diabetes, the use of either an SGLT2 inhibitor or a GLP-1 receptor agonist with proven cardiovascular benefit is not recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.

id_00494.original: For patients with obstructive CAD who have stable chest pain despite optimal GDMT, those referred for ICA without prior stress testing benefit from FFR or instantaneous wave free ratio.3,5-7
id_00494.negated: For patients with obstructive CAD who have stable chest pain despite optimal GDMT, those referred for ICA without prior stress testing do not benefit from FFR or instantaneous wave free ratio.

id_02190.original: For pregnant women with mechanical prostheses, aspirin 75 to 100 mg daily may be considered, in addition to anticoagulation, if needed for other indications.28
id_02190.negated: Aspirin 75 to 100 mg daily should not be considered for pregnant women with mechanical prostheses, even if anticoagulation is needed for other indications.

id_02633.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, care delivery that includes multidisciplinary teams trained in neurological assessment is recom- mended to improve outcomes.99,235,236
id_02633.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, care delivery that excludes multidisciplinary teams trained in neurological assessment is recommended to improve outcomes.

id_01193.original: In patients with AF receiving dabigatran who develop life-threatening bleeding, treatment with activated prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) is reason- able to reverse dabigatran’s anticoagulation effect if idarucizumab is unavailable.4,5
id_01193.negated: In patients with AF receiving dabigatran who develop life-threatening bleeding, treatment with activated prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) should not be used to reverse dabigatran’s anticoagulation effect even if idarucizumab is unavailable.

id_01710.original: In patients with HFrEF, titration of guideline- directed medication dosing to achieve target doses showed to be efficacious in RCTs is rec- ommended, to reduce cardiovascular mortality and HF hospitalizations, unless not well toler- ated.1–10
id_01710.negated: In patients with HFrEF, avoiding titration of guideline-directed medication dosing to achieve target doses is recommended, as it does not reduce cardiovascular mortality and HF hospitalizations, even if well tolerated.

id_02413.original: In patients with a PAU who have under- gone aortic repair, surveillance imaging at intervals appropriate for the repair approach and location (see Section 6.5.6, “Surveillance After Aneurysm Repair”) is reasonable.1-3
id_02413.negated: In patients with a PAU who have undergone aortic repair, it is unreasonable to perform surveillance imaging at intervals appropriate for the repair approach and location.

id_01934.original: In cardiac arrest following drowning and after removal from the water, CPR with rescue breaths and chest compressions should be provided to all persons.
id_01934.negated: In cardiac arrest following drowning and after removal from the water, CPR with rescue breaths and chest compressions should not be provided to any persons.

id_00271.original: In patients undergoing CABG, bilateral IMA (BIMA) grafting by experienced operators can be beneficial in appropriate patients to improve long-term cardiac outcomes.3,10-12
id_00271.negated: In patients undergoing CABG, bilateral IMA (BIMA) grafting by experienced operators should be avoided as it does not improve long-term cardiac outcomes.

id_00234.original: Routine revascularization for SCAD should not be performed.1-5
id_00234.negated: Routine revascularization for SCAD should be performed.

id_01191.original: In patients with AF undergoing cardiac surgery with CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2 or equivalent stroke risk, the benefit of surgical LAA exclusion in the absence of continued anticoagulation to reduce the risk of stroke and systemic embolism is uncertain.1–3
id_01191.negated: In patients with AF undergoing cardiac surgery with CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥2 or equivalent stroke risk, surgical LAA exclusion without continued anticoagulation is beneficial in reducing the risk of stroke and systemic embolism.

id_01454.original: In patients with CCD and heart failure with LVEF ≤40%, use of an SGLT2 inhibitor is rec- ommended to reduce the risk of cardiovascular death and heart failure hospitalization19–22 and to improve QOL,23,24 irrespective of diabetes status.* Cost Value Statement: Intermedi- ate Value B-NR
id_01454.negated: In patients with CCD and heart failure with LVEF ≤40%, the use of an SGLT2 inhibitor is not recommended to reduce the risk of cardiovascular death and heart failure hospitalization or to improve QOL, irrespective of diabetes status.

id_01231.original: In patients with symptomatic AF, rhythm control can be useful to improve symptoms.7–11
id_01231.negated: In patients with symptomatic AF, rhythm control should not be used to improve symptoms.

id_02153.original: In patients with IE and an indication for surgery who have suffered a stroke but have no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage or extensive neurological damage, operation without delay may be considered.68–70
id_02153.negated: In patients with IE and an indication for surgery who have suffered a stroke but have no evidence of intracranial hemorrhage or extensive neurological damage, delay the operation.

id_00270.original: In patients undergoing CABG, an IMA, prefer- ably the left, should be used to bypass the LAD when bypass of the LAD is indicated to improve survival and reduce recurrent isch- emic events.4-9
id_00270.negated: In patients undergoing CABG, an IMA, preferably the left, should not be used to bypass the LAD when bypass of the LAD is indicated to improve survival and reduce recurrent ischemic events.

id_02191.original: For pregnant women with mechanical prostheses, LMWH should not be administered unless anti-Xa levels are monitored 4 to 6 hours after administration and dose is adjusted according to levels.8–10,15,27
id_02191.negated: For pregnant women with mechanical prostheses, LMWH should be administered without monitoring anti-Xa levels or adjusting the dose according to levels.

id_02414.original: In patients with a PAU that is being managed medically, surveillance imaging with a CT is reasonable at 1 month after the diagnosis and, if stable, every 6 months for 2 years, and then at appropriate intervals thereafter (depending on patient age and PAU charac- teristics).1,4
id_02414.negated: Surveillance imaging with a CT is not necessary for patients with a PAU being managed medically, either at 1 month after diagnosis or at any regular intervals thereafter.

id_01711.original: In patients with HFrEF, titration and optimiza- tion of guideline-directed medications as frequently as every 1 to 2 weeks depending on the patient’s symptoms, vital signs, and labora- tory findings can be useful to optimize manage- ment.
id_01711.negated: In patients with HFrEF, avoiding titration and optimization of guideline-directed medications, regardless of the patient’s symptoms, vital signs, and laboratory findings, can be useful to optimize management.

id_01455.original: In patients with CCD and heart failure with LVEF >40%, use of an SGLT2 inhibitor can be beneficial in decreasing heart failure hospitalizations27,28 and to improve QOL,4,29 irrespective of diabetes status. Cost Value Statement: Intermedi- ate Value B-NR
id_01455.negated: In patients with CCD and heart failure with LVEF >40%, avoid using an SGLT2 inhibitor as it is not beneficial in decreasing heart failure hospitalizations or improving QOL, irrespective of diabetes status.

id_01935.original: In cardiac arrest following drowning, if the rescuer is unwilling, untrained, or unable to provide rescue breaths, it is reasonable to provide chest compressions only, until help arrives.
id_01935.negated: In cardiac arrest following drowning, it is unreasonable to provide chest compressions only if the rescuer is unwilling, untrained, or unable to provide rescue breaths, until help arrives.

id_00235.original: In patients with cardiac allograft vasculopathy and severe, proximal, discrete coronary lesions, revascularization with PCI is reasonable.1,2
id_00235.negated: In patients with cardiac allograft vasculopathy and severe, proximal, discrete coronary lesions, revascularization with PCI is not reasonable.

id_01673.original: In patients with a recent or remote history of MI or acute coronary syndrome (ACS) and LVEF ≤40%, evidence-based beta blockers should be used to reduce mortality.11–13
id_01673.negated: In patients with a recent or remote history of MI or acute coronary syndrome (ACS) and LVEF ≤40%, evidence-based beta blockers should not be used to reduce mortality.

id_00495.original: For symptomatic patients with obstructive CAD who have stable chest pain with CCTA- defined ≥50% stenosis in the left main coronary artery, obstructive CAD with FFR with CT ≤0.80, or severe stenosis (≥70%) in all 3 main vessels, ICA is effective for guiding therapeutic decision-making.4,8
id_00495.negated: For symptomatic patients with obstructive CAD who have stable chest pain with CCTA-defined ≥50% stenosis in the left main coronary artery, obstructive CAD with FFR with CT ≤0.80, or severe stenosis (≥70%) in all 3 main vessels, ICA is not effective for guiding therapeutic decision-making.

id_02154.original: For patients with IE and major ischemic stroke with extensive neurological damage or intracranial hemorrhage, if the patient is hemodynamically stable, delaying valve surgery for at least 4 weeks may be considered.68,71
id_02154.negated: For patients with IE and major ischemic stroke with extensive neurological damage or intracranial hemorrhage, if the patient is hemodynamically stable, immediate valve surgery should be considered without delay.

id_02671.original: For patients with a GCS score >3 and pri- mary IVH or IVH extension from spontane- ous supratentorial ICH of <30-mL volume requiring EVD, the effectiveness of minimally invasive IVH evacuation with EVD plus throm- bolytic use to improve functional outcomes is uncertain.382,407,415–419
id_02671.negated: For patients with a GCS score >3 and primary IVH or IVH extension from spontaneous supratentorial ICH of <30-mL volume requiring EVD, the effectiveness of minimally invasive IVH evacuation with EVD plus thrombolytic use to improve functional outcomes is certain.

id_02192.original: For patients with mechanical valve prostheses, anticoagulation with the direct thrombin inhibitor, dabigatran, should not be administered.29
id_02192.negated: For patients with mechanical valve prostheses, anticoagulation with the direct thrombin inhibitor, dabigatran, should be administered.

id_01674.original: In patients who are at least 40 days post-MI with LVEF ≤30% and NYHA class I symptoms while receiving GDMT and have reasonable expectation of meaningful survival for >1 year, an ICD is recommended for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death (SCD) to reduce total mortality.14
id_01674.negated: In patients who are at least 40 days post-MI with LVEF ≤30% and NYHA class I symptoms while receiving GDMT and have reasonable expectation of meaningful survival for >1 year, an ICD is not recommended for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death (SCD) as it does not reduce total mortality.

id_00496.original: For patients who have stable chest pain with previous coronary revascularization, CCTA is reasonable to evaluate bypass graft or stent patency (for stents ≥3 mm).9-13 Stress Testing
id_00496.negated: For patients who have stable chest pain with previous coronary revascularization, CCTA is not reasonable to evaluate bypass graft or stent patency (for stents ≥3 mm).

id_02415.original: In patients with genetic aortopathies attributable to syndromic (Marfan syndrome, Loeys-Dietz syndrome, vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome) and nsHTAD and who are contemplating preg- nancy, genetic counseling before pregnancy to discuss the heritable nature of their condition is recommended.1-4
id_02415.negated: In patients with genetic aortopathies attributable to syndromic (Marfan syndrome, Loeys-Dietz syndrome, vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome) and nsHTAD who are contemplating pregnancy, genetic counseling before pregnancy to discuss the heritable nature of their condition is not recommended.

id_00272.original: In patients undergoing valve surgery, aortic surgery, or other cardiac operations who have significant CAD, CABG is recommended with a goal of reducing ischemic events.1-11
id_00272.negated: In patients undergoing valve surgery, aortic surgery, or other cardiac operations who have significant CAD, CABG is not recommended, as it does not aim to reduce ischemic events.

id_02670.original: For patients with a GCS score >3 and primary IVH or IVH extension from spontaneous supra- tentorial ICH of <30-mL volume requiring EVD, minimally invasive IVH evacuation with EVD plus thrombolytic is safe and is reasonable compared with EVD alone to reduce mortality.415–418
id_02670.negated: For patients with a GCS score ≤3 and primary IVH or IVH extension from spontaneous supratentorial ICH of ≥30-mL volume not requiring EVD, minimally invasive IVH evacuation with EVD plus thrombolytic is unsafe and unreasonable compared with EVD alone to reduce mortality.

id_00236.original: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI, a radial approach is indicated in preference to a femoral approach to reduce the risk of death, vascular complications, or bleeding.1-4
id_00236.negated: In patients with ACS undergoing PCI, a femoral approach is indicated in preference to a radial approach, increasing the risk of death, vascular complications, or bleeding.

id_01933.original: The initiation of CPR should not be delayed to obtain or apply an AED in cardiac arrest following drowning. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_01933.negated: The initiation of CPR should be delayed to obtain or apply an AED in cardiac arrest following drowning.

id_01712.original: For patients with symptomatic (NYHA class II to III) stable chronic HFrEF (LVEF ≤35%) who are receiving GDMT, including a beta blocker at maximum tolerated dose, and who are in sinus rhythm with a heart rate of ≥70 bpm at rest, ivabradine can be beneficial to reduce HF hospitalizations and cardiovascular death.1,2
id_01712.negated: For patients with symptomatic (NYHA class II to III) stable chronic HFrEF (LVEF ≤35%) who are receiving GDMT, including a beta blocker at maximum tolerated dose, and who are in sinus rhythm with a heart rate of ≥70 bpm at rest, ivabradine should not be used as it is not beneficial in reducing HF hospitalizations and cardiovascular death.

id_01936.original: In cardiac arrest following drowning, it may be reasonable for trained rescuers to initiate CPR with rescue breaths followed by chest compressions. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_01936.negated: In cardiac arrest following drowning, it may be reasonable for trained rescuers to initiate CPR with chest compressions only, without rescue breaths.

id_01675.original: In patients with LVEF ≤40%, beta blockers should be used to prevent symptomatic HF.12,13
id_01675.negated: In patients with LVEF ≤40%, beta blockers should not be used to prevent symptomatic HF.

id_02672.original: For patients with severe spontaneous ICH‚ large IVH, and impaired level of consciousness, the efficacy of EVD for improving functional out- comes is not well established.347–349
id_02672.negated: For patients with severe spontaneous ICH, large IVH, and impaired level of consciousness, the efficacy of EVD for improving functional outcomes is well established.

id_01232.original: In patients with a recent diagnosis of AF (<1 year), rhythm control can be useful to reduce hospitaliza- tions, stroke, and mortality.12–14
id_01232.negated: In patients with a recent diagnosis of AF (<1 year), rhythm control is not useful to reduce hospitalizations, stroke, and mortality.

id_01456.original: In patients with CCD, assessment of BMI with or without waist circumference is recommended dur- ing routine clinical follow-up.1–6
id_01456.negated: In patients with CCD, assessment of BMI and waist circumference should not be conducted during routine clinical follow-up.

id_02635.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH without indi- cations for ICU admission at presentation, ini- tial provision of care in a stroke unit compared with a general ward is reasonable to reduce mortality and improve outcomes.231,237,238
id_02635.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH without indications for ICU admission at presentation, initial provision of care in a general ward compared with a stroke unit is reasonable to reduce mortality and improve outcomes.

id_02155.original: Women with suspected valve disease who are considering pregnancy should undergo a clinical evaluation and TTE before pregnancy.1–5
id_02155.negated: Women with suspected valve disease who are considering pregnancy should not undergo a clinical evaluation and TTE before pregnancy.

id_01195.original: In patients with AF who develop major gastrointestinal bleeding, resumption of oral anticoagulation therapy may be reasonable after correction of reversible causes of bleeding and reassessment of its long-term benefits and risks with a multidisciplinary team approach during SDM with patients.11,12 *B-NR LOE applies to data on apixaban or rivaroxaban. †C-LD LOE applies to data on edoxaban.
id_01195.negated: In patients with AF who develop major gastrointestinal bleeding, it is not advisable to resume oral anticoagulation therapy, even after correcting reversible causes of bleeding and reassessing its long-term benefits and risks with a multidisciplinary team during SDM with patients.

id_01457.original: Patients with CCD and overweight or obesity should receive counseling on diet, lifestyle, and goals for weight loss.7–10
id_01457.negated: Patients with CCD and overweight or obesity should not receive counseling on diet, lifestyle, and goals for weight loss.

id_01713.original: In patients with symptomatic HFrEF despite GDMT (or who are unable to tolerate GDMT), digoxin might be considered to decrease hospi- talizations for HF.1,2
id_01713.negated: In patients with symptomatic HFrEF despite GDMT (or who are unable to tolerate GDMT), digoxin should not be considered to decrease hospitalizations for HF.

id_01233.original: In patients with AF and HF, rhythm control can be useful for improving symptoms and improving out- comes, such as mortality and hospitalizations for HF and ischemia.15–19
id_01233.negated: In patients with AF and HF, rhythm control should not be used as it does not improve symptoms or outcomes, such as mortality and hospitalizations for HF and ischemia.

id_01676.original: In patients with LVEF <50%, thiazolidinediones should not be used because they increase the risk of HF, including hospitalizations.15
id_01676.negated: In patients with LVEF <50%, thiazolidinediones should be used because they do not increase the risk of HF, including hospitalizations.

id_01194.original: In patients with AF receiving warfarin who develop life-threatening bleeding, treatment with 4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate (if available) in addition to intravenous vitamin K is recommended to rapidly achieve INR correction over fresh frozen plasma and intravenous vitamin K treatment.8–10
id_01194.negated: In patients with AF receiving warfarin who develop life-threatening bleeding, treatment with fresh frozen plasma and intravenous vitamin K is recommended over 4-factor prothrombin complex concentrate and intravenous vitamin K to rapidly achieve INR correction.

id_00273.original: In patients undergoing valve surgery, aortic surgery, or other cardiac operations who have intermediate CAD, CABG may be reasonable with a goal of reducing ischemic events.5,7,10,12 Table 12.  Best Practices for the Use of Bypass Conduits in CABG Objectively assess palmar arch completeness and ulnar compensation before harvesting the radial artery. Use the arm with the best ulnar compensation for radial artery harvesting.
id_00273.negated: In patients undergoing valve surgery, aortic surgery, or other cardiac operations who have intermediate CAD, CABG may not be reasonable as it does not aim to reduce ischemic events. Do not objectively assess palmar arch completeness and ulnar compensation before harvesting the radial artery, and do not prioritize the arm with the best ulnar compensation for radial artery harvesting.

id_00497.original: For patients with obstructive CAD who have stable chest pain despite optimal GDMT, stress PET/SPECT MPI, CMR, or echocardiography is recommended for diagnosis of myocardial ischemia, estimating risk of MACE, and guiding therapeutic decision-making.14-36
id_00497.negated: For patients with obstructive CAD who have stable chest pain despite optimal GDMT, stress PET/SPECT MPI, CMR, or echocardiography is not recommended for diagnosis of myocardial ischemia, estimating risk of MACE, and guiding therapeutic decision-making.

id_02193.original: The use of anti-Xa direct oral anticoagulants with mechanical heart valves in pregnancy has not been assessed and is not recommended.30–32
id_02193.negated: The use of anti-Xa direct oral anticoagulants with mechanical heart valves in pregnancy is recommended.

id_02673.original: For patients with spontaneous supratentorial ICH of <30-mL volume and IVH requiring EVD, the usefulness of minimally invasive IVH evacuation with neuroendoscopy plus EVD, with or without thrombolytic, to improve func- tional outcomes and reduce permanent shunt dependence is uncertain.419,420
id_02673.negated: For patients with spontaneous supratentorial ICH of <30-mL volume and IVH requiring EVD, the usefulness of minimally invasive IVH evacuation with neuroendoscopy plus EVD, with or without thrombolytic, to improve functional outcomes and reduce permanent shunt dependence is certain.

id_01937.original: Implementation of PAD programs is reasonable in areas where there is a high risk of cardiac arrest, including aquatic environments (eg, areas with high population density, frequent utilization, other forms of exercise, long distances or response times to nearest AED). Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_01937.negated: Implementation of PAD programs is unreasonable in areas where there is a high risk of cardiac arrest, including aquatic environments (eg, areas with high population density, frequent utilization, other forms of exercise, long distances or response times to nearest AED).

id_01196.original: In patients with AF and conditions associated with very high risk of thromboembolic events (>5%/year), such as rheumatic heart disease or a mechanical heart valve, early (1-2 weeks) resumption of antico- agulation after ICH is reasonable to reduce the risk of thromboembolic events.1
id_01196.negated: In patients with AF and conditions associated with very high risk of thromboembolic events (>5%/year), such as rheumatic heart disease or a mechanical heart valve, delaying the resumption of anticoagulation after ICH beyond 1-2 weeks is reasonable to reduce the risk of thromboembolic events.

id_02416.original: In patients with syndromic and nsHTAD, Turner syndrome, BAV with aortic dilation, and other aortopathy conditions, aortic imaging (with TTE, MRI or CT, or both as appropriate) before pregnancy is recommended to determine aortic ­diameters.1-3,5-13
id_02416.negated: In patients with syndromic and nsHTAD, Turner syndrome, BAV with aortic dilation, and other aortopathy conditions, aortic imaging before pregnancy is not recommended to determine aortic diameters.

id_00498.original: For patients with obstructive CAD who have stable chest pain despite optimal GDMT, when selected for rest/stress nuclear MPI, PET is reasonable in preference to SPECT, if available, to improve diagnostic accuracy and decrease the rate of nondiagnostic test results.37
id_00498.negated: For patients with obstructive CAD who have stable chest pain despite optimal GDMT, when selected for rest/stress nuclear MPI, SPECT is reasonable in preference to PET, even if PET is available, to decrease diagnostic accuracy and increase the rate of nondiagnostic test results.

id_02156.original: Women with severe valve disease (Stages C and D) who are considering pregnancy should undergo pre-pregnancy counseling by a cardiologist with expertise in managing women with VHD during pregnancy.1–5
id_02156.negated: Women with severe valve disease (Stages C and D) who are considering pregnancy should not undergo pre-pregnancy counseling by a cardiologist with expertise in managing women with VHD during pregnancy.

id_02636.original: In patients with moderate to severe spontaneous ICH, IVH, hydrocephalus, or infratentorial loca- tion, provision of care in a neuro-specific ICU compared with a general ICU is reasonable to improve outcomes and reduce mortality.235,239–241
id_02636.negated: In patients with moderate to severe spontaneous ICH, IVH, hydrocephalus, or infratentorial location, provision of care in a general ICU compared with a neuro-specific ICU is reasonable to improve outcomes and reduce mortality.

id_00237.original: In patients with SIHD undergoing PCI, the radial approach is recommended to reduce access site bleeding and vascular complica- tions.4-7
id_00237.negated: In patients with SIHD undergoing PCI, the femoral approach is recommended to increase access site bleeding and vascular complications.

id_02417.original: In patients with syndromic and nsHTAD, Turner syndrome, BAV with aortic dilation, and other aortopathy conditions, who are contem- plating pregnancy, counseling about the risks of aortic dissection related to pregnancy is recommended.2-5,10,12,14 During Pregnancy
id_02417.negated: In patients with syndromic and nsHTAD, Turner syndrome, BAV with aortic dilation, and other aortopathy conditions, who are contemplating pregnancy, counseling about the risks of aortic dissection related to pregnancy is not recommended.

id_02418.original: In patients with aortic aneurysms, or at increased risk of aortic dissection, or both, it is recom- mended that pregnancy be managed by a multidisciplinary team including a maternal fetal medicine specialist and cardiologist, and, if logistically feasible, that delivery be planned in a hospital where the capability for emergency aortic repair is available.
id_02418.negated: In patients with aortic aneurysms, or at increased risk of aortic dissection, or both, it is not recommended that pregnancy be managed by a multidisciplinary team including a maternal fetal medicine specialist and cardiologist, and delivery should not be planned in a hospital with the capability for emergency aortic repair.

id_00274.original: In patients undergoing CABG, the routine use of epiaortic ultrasound scanning can be useful to evaluate the presence, location, and severity of plaque in the ascending aorta to reduce the incidence of atheroembolic complications.1-10
id_00274.negated: In patients undergoing CABG, the routine use of epiaortic ultrasound scanning should not be used to evaluate the presence, location, and severity of plaque in the ascending aorta, as it does not reduce the incidence of atheroembolic complications.

id_01714.original: In selected high-risk patients with HFrEF and recent worsening of HF already on GDMT, an oral soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator (vericiguat) may be considered to reduce HF hospitalization and cardiovascular death.1
id_01714.negated: In selected high-risk patients with HFrEF and recent worsening of HF already on GDMT, an oral soluble guanylate cyclase stimulator (vericiguat) should not be considered to reduce HF hospitalization and cardiovascular death.

id_02634.original: In hospitalized patients with spontaneous ICH who require hospital transfer but do not have adequate airway protection, cannot support adequate gas exchange, and/or do not have a stable hemodynamic profile, appropriate life-sustaining therapies should be initiated before transportation to prevent acute medical decompensation in transport.
id_02634.negated: In hospitalized patients with spontaneous ICH who require hospital transfer but do not have adequate airway protection, cannot support adequate gas exchange, and/or do not have a stable hemodynamic profile, life-sustaining therapies should not be initiated before transportation, risking acute medical decompensation in transport.

id_00107.original: Immediate skin decontamination is recommended after a chemical exposure.
id_00107.negated: Immediate skin decontamination is not recommended after a chemical exposure.

id_01518.original: Women with CCD who are contemplating pregnancy or who are pregnant should not use ACE inhibitors, ARBs, direct renin inhibitors, angiotensin receptor- neprilysin inhibitors, or aldosterone antagonists dur- ing pregnancy to prevent harm to the fetus.2,7,8 Postmenopausal Hormone Therapy
id_01518.negated: Women with CCD who are contemplating pregnancy or who are pregnant should use ACE inhibitors, ARBs, direct renin inhibitors, angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitors, or aldosterone antagonists during pregnancy, as they do not pose any harm to the fetus.

id_00135.original: A person with signs and symptoms of a concus- sion should be immediately removed from activity (play/sports) and not allowed to return to activity until evaluated by a health care professional.
id_00135.negated: A person with signs and symptoms of a concussion should continue participating in activity (play/sports) without needing evaluation by a health care professional.

id_02599.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, CT angiog- raphy (CTA) within the first few hours of ICH onset may be reasonable to identify patients at risk for subsequent HE.103–108
id_02599.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, avoiding CT angiography (CTA) within the first few hours of ICH onset is advisable to prevent identifying patients at risk for subsequent HE.

id_01826.original: In older patients (ie, ≥75 years of age) with PAD, assessment for geriatric syndromes (Table 10), such as frailty, sarcopenia, malnutrition, and mobil- ity impairment, can be useful to identify high-risk patients, including before revascularization, and to provide safe and goal-concordant care.1–15
id_01826.negated: In older patients (ie, ≥75 years of age) with PAD, assessment for geriatric syndromes, such as frailty, sarcopenia, malnutrition, and mobility impairment, is not useful for identifying high-risk patients or for providing safe and goal-concordant care.

id_02693.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and cogni- tive impairment, referral for cognitive therapy is reasonable to improve cognitive out- comes.511–515
id_02693.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH and cognitive impairment, referral for cognitive therapy is not recommended to improve cognitive outcomes.

id_02506.original: In patients with asymptomatic atherosclerotic carotid artery stenosis and high perioperative risk, the effectiveness of carotid revascular- ization to reduce risk of stroke is not estab- lished.314,319,320
id_02506.negated: In patients with asymptomatic atherosclerotic carotid artery stenosis and high perioperative risk, carotid revascularization is proven effective in reducing the risk of stroke.

id_01998.original: In asymptomatic patients with severe AR and normal LV systolic function at rest (LVEF >55%; Stage C1) and low surgical risk, aortic valve surgery may be considered when there is a progressive decline in LVEF on at least 3 serial studies to the low–normal range (LVEF 55% to 60%) or a progressive increase in LV dilation into the severe range (LV end- diastolic dimension [LVEDD] >65 mm).12,16,17,20,25–28
id_01998.negated: In asymptomatic patients with severe AR and normal LV systolic function at rest (LVEF >55%; Stage C1) and low surgical risk, aortic valve surgery should not be considered even if there is a progressive decline in LVEF on at least 3 serial studies to the low–normal range (LVEF 55% to 60%) or a progressive increase in LV dilation into the severe range (LV end-diastolic dimension [LVEDD] >65 mm).

id_02376.original: In patients with acute type A aortic dis- section undergoing surgical repair who require circulatory arrest, cerebral perfusion is reasonable to improve neurologic out- comes.23-25
id_02376.negated: In patients with acute type A aortic dissection undergoing surgical repair who require circulatory arrest, cerebral perfusion is not recommended to improve neurologic outcomes.

id_01416.original: Patients with CCD should receive ongoing individualized education on symptom management, lifestyle changes, and SDOH risk factors to improve knowledge and facilitate behavior change.1
id_01416.negated: Patients with CCD should not receive individualized education on symptom management, lifestyle changes, and SDOH risk factors, as it does not improve knowledge or facilitate behavior change.

id_01574.original: In patients with suspected moderate or severe val­ vular regurgitation, preoperative echocardiography is recommended before elective NCS to guide periop­ erative management.*
id_01574.negated: In patients with suspected moderate or severe valvular regurgitation, preoperative echocardiography is not recommended before elective NCS to guide perioperative management.

id_02213.original: In patients with known or suspected aortic disease, episodic and cumulative ionizing radi- ation doses should be kept as low as feasible while maintaining diagnostic image quality.5-7
id_02213.negated: In patients with known or suspected aortic disease, episodic and cumulative ionizing radiation doses should be maximized without regard for maintaining diagnostic image quality.

id_00867.original: In patients with aSAH, phenytoin for seizure prevention and/or antiseizure prophylaxis is associated with excess morbidity and mortality.407–411,413,415,416 Patients who present with seizures
id_00867.negated: In patients with aSAH, phenytoin for seizure prevention and/or antiseizure prophylaxis is not associated with excess morbidity and mortality.

id_02026.original: In patients with primary MR, when TTE provides insufficient or discordant information, TEE is indicated for evaluation of the severity of MR, mechanism of MR, and status of LV function (Stages B to D).
id_02026.negated: In patients with primary MR, when TTE provides insufficient or discordant information, TEE is not indicated for evaluation of the severity of MR, mechanism of MR, and status of LV function (Stages B to D).

id_02598.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH and/or IVH and with low GCS score or ND, serial head CT can be useful to evaluate for hemorrhage expansion, development of hydrocephalus, brain swelling, or herniation.100–102 Downloaded from http://ahajournals.org by on June 19, 2025
id_02598.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH and/or IVH and with low GCS score or ND, serial head CT is not useful to evaluate for hemorrhage expansion, development of hydrocephalus, brain swelling, or herniation.

id_00614.original: In adult patients with HCM, a comprehensive, systematic noninvasive SCD risk assessment at initial evaluation and every 1 to 2 years thereafter is recommended and should include evaluation of these risk factors (Figures 1 and 3, Table 8)1–25: a.   Personal history of cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular arrhythmias; b.   Personal history of syncope suspected by clinical history to be arrhythmic; c.   Family history in close relative of premature HCM-related sudden death, cardiac arrest, or sustained ventricular arrhythmias; d.   Maximal LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm; e.   NSVT episodes on continuous ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring.
id_00614.negated: In adult patients with HCM, it is not recommended to perform a comprehensive, systematic noninvasive SCD risk assessment at initial evaluation or every 1 to 2 years thereafter, and evaluation of the following risk factors should be omitted: personal history of cardiac arrest or sustained ventricular arrhythmias; personal history of syncope suspected by clinical history to be arrhythmic; family history in close relative of premature HCM-related sudden death, cardiac arrest, or sustained ventricular arrhythmias; maximal LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm; NSVT episodes on continuous ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring.

id_00680.original: In affected families with HCM, preconceptional and prenatal reproductive and genetic counseling should be offered.3–6
id_00680.negated: In affected families with HCM, preconceptional and prenatal reproductive and genetic counseling should not be offered.

id_01733.original: Among patients with current or previous symp- tomatic HFmrEF (LVEF, 41%–49%), use of evidence-based beta blockers for HFrEF, ARNi, ACEi, or ARB, and MRAs may be considered to reduce the risk of HF hospitalization and cardiovascular mortality, particularly among patients with LVEF on the lower end of this spectrum.2–9
id_01733.negated: Among patients with current or previous symptomatic HFmrEF (LVEF, 41%–49%), the use of evidence-based beta blockers for HFrEF, ARNi, ACEi, or ARB, and MRAs should not be considered to reduce the risk of HF hospitalization and cardiovascular mortality, particularly among patients with LVEF on the lower end of this spectrum.

id_01039.original: In patients with ischemic stroke or ASCVD, calculation of BMI is recommended at the time of their event and annually thereafter, to screen for and to classify obesity.
id_01039.negated: In patients with ischemic stroke or ASCVD, calculation of BMI is not recommended at the time of their event or annually thereafter, as it is unnecessary to screen for or classify obesity.

id_01253.original: For patients with recurrent AF occurring outside the setting of a hospital, the “pill-in-the-pocket” (PITP) approach with a single oral dose of flecainide9–11 or propafenone,10–14 with a concomitant atrioventricular nodal blocking agent,15 is reasonable for pharmaco- logical cardioversion if previously tested in a moni- tored setting.16–18
id_01253.negated: For patients with recurrent AF occurring outside the setting of a hospital, the “pill-in-the-pocket” (PITP) approach with a single oral dose of flecainide or propafenone, with a concomitant atrioventricular nodal blocking agent, is not reasonable for pharmacological cardioversion even if previously tested in a monitored setting.

id_01160.original: Among patients with AF in whom cardiac monitor- ing is advised, it is reasonable to recommend use of a consumer-accessible electrocardiographic device that provides a high-quality tracing to detect recur- rences.13
id_01160.negated: Among patients with AF in whom cardiac monitoring is advised, it is not reasonable to recommend use of a consumer-accessible electrocardiographic device that provides a high-quality tracing to detect recurrences.

id_01896.original: In patients with CLTI, prompt management of foot infection with antibiotics, debridement, and other surgical management is recommended.1–5
id_01896.negated: In patients with CLTI, delaying management of foot infection and avoiding antibiotics, debridement, and other surgical management is recommended.

id_01825.original: Clinicians and health care systems should actively pursue evidence of health disparities in diagnosis, treatment, and outcomes for patients with PAD and use efforts to limit the impact of these disparities on clinical outcomes.
id_01825.negated: Clinicians and health care systems should ignore evidence of health disparities in diagnosis, treatment, and outcomes for patients with PAD and make no efforts to limit the impact of these disparities on clinical outcomes.

id_00587.original: In adult patients with HCM without risk factors for AF and who are eligible for anticoagulation, extended ambulatory monitoring may be considered to assess for asymptomatic paroxysmal AF as part of initial evaluation and periodic follow-up (every 1-2 years).7–12
id_00587.negated: In adult patients with HCM without risk factors for AF and who are eligible for anticoagulation, extended ambulatory monitoring should not be considered to assess for asymptomatic paroxysmal AF as part of initial evaluation and periodic follow-up.

id_02534.original: In adults, screening for a history of certain adverse pregnancy outcomes (APOs), including HDP, preterm birth, gestational diabetes, and placental disorders, followed by subsequent evalu- ation and management of vascular risk factors, is recommended to reduce the risk of stroke. Other intervention
id_02534.negated: In adults, it is not recommended to screen for a history of certain adverse pregnancy outcomes (APOs), including HDP, preterm birth, gestational diabetes, and placental disorders, nor to evaluate and manage vascular risk factors, as this does not reduce the risk of stroke.

id_00387.original: In patients with AMI and cardiogenic shock, the routine use of intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) or venoarterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VA-ECMO) is not recommended due to a lack of survival benefit.5–9 *See supportive text.
id_00387.negated: In patients with AMI and cardiogenic shock, the routine use of intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP) or venoarterial extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (VA-ECMO) is recommended due to a significant survival benefit.

id_01067.original: In patients with a stroke or TIA and evidence of an aortic arch atheroma, intensive lipid management to an LDL cholesterol target <70 mg/dL is recommended to prevent recur- rent stroke.210
id_01067.negated: In patients with a stroke or TIA and evidence of an aortic arch atheroma, intensive lipid management to an LDL cholesterol target <70 mg/dL is not recommended to prevent recurrent stroke.

id_00037.original: Nothing should be put in the mouth and no food, liquids, or oral medicines should be given to a person who is experiencing a seizure or who has decreased responsiveness after a seizure. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00037.negated: Food, liquids, or oral medicines should be given to a person who is experiencing a seizure or who has decreased responsiveness after a seizure.

id_02478.original: In adults, counseling patients to engage in at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity physical activity, 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity physical activity, or an equivalent combination per week is recommended to reduce the risk of stroke.108–111
id_02478.negated: In adults, it is not recommended to counsel patients to engage in at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity physical activity, 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity physical activity, or an equivalent combination per week to reduce the risk of stroke.

id_02120.original: In asymptomatic patients with severe prosthetic regurgitation and low operative risk, surgery is reasonable.1–4
id_02120.negated: In asymptomatic patients with severe prosthetic regurgitation and low operative risk, surgery is not reasonable.

id_02212.original: In patients with known or suspected aortic disease, aortic diameters should be mea- sured at reproducible anatomic landmarks perpendicular to axis of blood flow, and these measurement methods should be reported in a clear and consistent manner. In cases of asymmetric or oval contour, the longest diam- eter and its perpendicular diameter should be reported.3,4
id_02212.negated: In patients with known or suspected aortic disease, aortic diameters should not be measured at reproducible anatomic landmarks perpendicular to the axis of blood flow, and these measurement methods should be reported in an unclear and inconsistent manner. In cases of asymmetric or oval contour, the longest diameter and its perpendicular diameter should not be reported.

id_01095.original: In patients with stroke or TIA in the setting of acute anterior MI with reduced ejection fraction (EF; <50%) but no evidence of LV thrombus, empirical anticoagulation for at least
id_01095.negated: In patients with stroke or TIA in the setting of acute anterior MI with reduced ejection fraction (EF; <50%) but no evidence of LV thrombus, avoid empirical anticoagulation.

id_01347.original: It might be reasonable to attempt electrical pacing for CCB poisoning with refractory bradycardia.
id_01347.negated: It is not advisable to attempt electrical pacing for CCB poisoning with refractory bradycardia.

id_01547.original: For patients undergoing elevated-risk NCS with poor or unknown functional capacity and elevated risk for perioperative cardiovascular events based on a validated risk tool, stress testing may be consid­ ered to evaluate for inducible myocardial ischemia.1
id_01547.negated: For patients undergoing elevated-risk NCS with poor or unknown functional capacity and elevated risk for perioperative cardiovascular events based on a validated risk tool, stress testing should not be considered to evaluate for inducible myocardial ischemia.

id_01999.original: In patients with isolated severe AR who have indications for SAVR and are candidates for surgery, TAVI should not be performed.29–32
id_01999.negated: In patients with isolated severe AR who have indications for SAVR and are candidates for surgery, TAVI should be performed.

id_02600.original: In patients with spontaneous ICH, using non- contrast computed tomography (NCCT) mark- ers of HE to identify patients at risk for HE may be reasonable.106
id_02600.negated: In patients with spontaneous ICH, avoiding the use of non-contrast computed tomography (NCCT) markers of HE to identify patients at risk for HE may be reasonable.

id_00294.original: In patients after CABG, beta blockers are recommended and should be started as soon as possible to reduce the incidence or clinical sequelae of postoperative atrial fibrillation.1-7
id_00294.negated: In patients after CABG, beta blockers are not recommended and should not be started to reduce the incidence or clinical sequelae of postoperative atrial fibrillation.

id_01417.original: Patients with CCD should receive ongoing individualized education on medication adherence to improve knowledge and facilitate behavior change.2–4
id_01417.negated: Patients with CCD should not receive ongoing individualized education on medication adherence, as it does not improve knowledge or facilitate behavior change.

id_00079.original: If a person with hypothermia cannot be immedi- ately moved from a cold environment to a warm one, they should be protected from further heat loss by insulation from the ground, covering of head and neck, and shielding from heat loss by wind using a plastic or foil layer in addition to a dry insulating layer.
id_00079.negated: If a person with hypothermia cannot be immediately moved from a cold environment to a warm one, they should not be protected from further heat loss by insulation from the ground, covering of head and neck, or shielding from heat loss by wind using a plastic or foil layer in addition to a dry insulating layer.

id_02027.original: In patients with primary MR, CMR is indicated to assess LV and RV volumes and function and may help with assessing MR severity when there is a discrepancy between the findings on clinical assessment and echocardiography.6–9
id_02027.negated: In patients with primary MR, CMR is not indicated to assess LV and RV volumes and function and should not be used to evaluate MR severity, even when there is a discrepancy between clinical assessment and echocardiography findings.

id_00136.original: For a person with signs or symptoms of severe head injury (such as loss of consciousness, worsening headache, vomiting, altered mental status, seizures, visual changes, swelling, or deformities of the scalp), EMS should be activated. Recommendation-Specific Supportive Text
id_00136.negated: For a person with signs or symptoms of severe head injury (such as loss of consciousness, worsening headache, vomiting, altered mental status, seizures, visual changes, swelling, or deformities of the scalp), EMS should not be activated.

id_01827.original: In patients with symptomatic PAD, single antiplatelet therapy is recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.1–4
id_01827.negated: In patients with symptomatic PAD, single antiplatelet therapy is not recommended to reduce the risk of MACE.

id_01640.original: In patients presenting with dyspnea, measure- ment of B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) or N-terminal prohormone of B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) is useful to support a diagnosis or exclusion of HF.1–12
id_01640.negated: In patients presenting with dyspnea, measurement of B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) or N-terminal prohormone of B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) is not useful to support a diagnosis or exclusion of HF.

id_00388.original: Patients with a mechanical complication of ACS should be managed in a facility with cardiac surgical expertise.
id_00388.negated: Patients with a mechanical complication of ACS should be managed in a facility without cardiac surgical expertise.

id_01575.original: In patients with VHD who meet indications for valvular intervention based on clinical presentation and severity of regurgitation, the need for valvular intervention should be considered before elective elevated-risk NCS to reduce perioperative risk.*1–3
id_01575.negated: In patients with VHD who meet indications for valvular intervention based on clinical presentation and severity of regurgitation, the need for valvular intervention should not be considered before elective elevated-risk NCS, even if it increases perioperative risk.

id_00588.original: For patients with symptomatic HCM for whom there is uncertainty regarding the presence or severity of LVOTO on noninvasive imaging studies, invasive hemodynamic assessment with cardiac catheterization is recommended.1–4
id_00588.negated: For patients with symptomatic HCM for whom there is uncertainty regarding the presence or severity of LVOTO on noninvasive imaging studies, invasive hemodynamic assessment with cardiac catheterization is not recommended.

id_00457.original: In patients with prior CABG surgery presenting with acute chest pain, who do not have ACS8-14 or who have an indeterminate/nondiagnostic stress test, ICA is useful.8
id_00457.negated: In patients with prior CABG surgery presenting with acute chest pain, who do have ACS8-14 or who have a clear diagnostic stress test, ICA is not useful.

id_00615.original: For adult patients with HCM who are not otherwise identified as high risk for SCD, or in whom a decision to proceed with ICD placement remains uncertain after clinical assessment that includes personal/ family history, echocardiography, and ambulatory electrocardiographic monitoring, CMR imaging is beneficial to assess for maximum LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm, and extent of myocardial fibrosis with LGE (Table 8).1,11,12,15–20
id_00615.negated: For adult patients with HCM who are identified as high risk for SCD, or in whom a decision to proceed with ICD placement is certain after clinical assessment, CMR imaging is not beneficial to assess for maximum LV wall thickness, EF, LV apical aneurysm, and extent of myocardial fibrosis with LGE.

id_01161.original: Patients at increased risk of AF should receive com- prehensive guideline-directed LRFM for AF, targeting obesity,1 physical inactivity,2 unhealthy alcohol con- sumption,3 smoking,4 diabetes,5 and hypertension.6
id_01161.negated: Patients at increased risk of AF should not receive comprehensive guideline-directed LRFM for AF, ignoring obesity, physical inactivity, unhealthy alcohol consumption, smoking, diabetes, and hypertension.

id_01348.original: The usefulness of a glucagon bolus and infusion for
id_01348.negated: The ineffectiveness of a glucagon bolus and infusion for

id_01897.original: In patients with CLTI with nonhealing wounds, wound care should be provided to optimize the wound-healing environment after revascularization with the goal of complete wound healing.6–10
id_01897.negated: In patients with CLTI with nonhealing wounds, wound care should not be provided to optimize the wound-healing environment after revascularization, disregarding the goal of complete wound healing.

id_01520.original: In patients with CCD and CKD, measures should be taken to minimize the risk of treatment-related acute kidney injury.*1–3 *Modified from the 2021 ACC/AHA/SCAI Guideline for Coronary Artery Re- vascularization.4
id_01520.negated: In patients with CCD and CKD, no measures should be taken to minimize the risk of treatment-related acute kidney injury.

id_01734.original: In patients with HFimpEF after treatment, GDMT should be continued to prevent relapse of HF and LV dysfunction, even in patients who may become asymptomatic.1
id_01734.negated: In patients with HFimpEF after treatment, GDMT should be discontinued, as it is unnecessary to prevent relapse of HF and LV dysfunction, especially in patients who become asymptomatic.
